Name: Execution Prevention
Description: System settings can prevent applications from running that haven't been downloaded from legitimate repositories which may help mitigate some of these issues. Not allowing unsigned applications from being run may also mitigate some risk.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Applications with known vulnerabilities or known shell escapes should not have the setuid or setgid bits set to reduce potential damage if an application is compromised. Additionally, the number of programs with setuid or setgid bits set should be minimized across a system. Ensuring that the sudo tty_tickets setting is enabled will prevent this leakage across tty sessions.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Remove users from the local administrator group on systems. By requiring a password, even if an adversary can get terminal access, they must know the password to run anything in the sudoers file. Setting the timestamp_timeout to 0 will require the user to input their password every time sudo is executed.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: The sudoers file should be strictly edited such that passwords are always required and that users can't spawn risky processes as users with higher privilege.

Name: User Account Control
Description: Although UAC bypass techniques exist, it is still prudent to use the highest enforcement level for UAC when possible and mitigate bypass opportunities that exist with techniques such as  DLL Search Order Hijacking .

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit the privileges of cloud accounts to assume, create, or impersonate additional roles, policies, and permissions to only those required. Where just-in-time access is enabled, consider requiring manual approval for temporary elevation of privileges.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Name: APT37
Description: APT37  has used malware that will issue the command  shutdown /r /t 1  to reboot a system after wiping its MBR.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has used a custom MBR wiper named BOOTWRECK, which will initiate a system reboot after wiping the victim's MBR.

Name: AvosLocker
Description: AvosLocker ’s Linux variant has terminated ESXi virtual machines.

Name: DCSrv
Description: DCSrv  has a function to sleep for two hours before rebooting the system.

Name: HermeticWiper
Description: HermeticWiper  can initiate a system shutdown.

Name: KillDisk
Description: KillDisk  attempts to reboot the machine by terminating specific processes.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has rebooted systems after destroying files and wiping the MBR on infected systems.

Name: LockerGoga
Description: LockerGoga  has been observed shutting down infected systems.

Name: LookBack
Description: LookBack  can shutdown and reboot the victim machine.

Name: Maze
Description: Maze  has issued a shutdown command on a victim machine that, upon reboot, will run the ransomware within a VM.

Name: NotPetya
Description: NotPetya  will reboot the system one hour after infection.

Name: Olympic Destroyer
Description: Olympic Destroyer  will shut down the compromised system after it is done modifying system configuration settings.

Name: Shamoon
Description: Shamoon  will reboot the infected system once the wiping functionality has been completed.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  can shutdown a compromised host through execution of  ExitWindowsEx  with the  EXW_SHUTDOWN  flag.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  has the ability to use Telnet for communication.

Name: Duqu
Description: Duqu  uses a custom command and control protocol that communicates over commonly used ports, and is frequently encapsulated by application layer protocols.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has used an IRC channel for C2 communications.

Name: Lucifer
Description: Lucifer  can use the Stratum protocol on port 10001 for communication between the cryptojacking bot and the mining server.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  malware has used IRC for C2.

Name: NETEAGLE
Description: Adversaries can also use  NETEAGLE  to establish an RDP connection with a controller over TCP/7519.

Name: QUIETEXIT
Description: QUIETEXIT  can use an inverse negotiated SSH connection as part of its C2.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  issued wget requests from infected systems to the C2.

Name: Siloscape
Description: Siloscape  connects to an IRC server for C2.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has used an IRC bot for C2 communications.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: 2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  used the  sp_addlinkedsrvlogin  command in MS-SQL to create a link between a created account and other servers in the network.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  has been known to add created accounts to local admin groups to maintain elevated access.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  has added user accounts to the User and Admin groups.

Name: Calisto
Description: Calisto  adds permissions and remote logins to all users.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has added newly created accounts to the administrators group to maintain elevated access.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has assigned newly created accounts the sysadmin role to maintain persistence.

Name: HAFNIUM
Description: HAFNIUM  has granted privileges to domain accounts.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has added accounts to specific groups with  net localgroup .

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  malware WhiskeyDelta-Two contains a function that attempts to rename the administrator’s account.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has added a user named DefaultAccount to the Administrators and Remote Desktop Users groups.

Name: Mimikatz
Description: The  Mimikatz  credential dumper has been extended to include Skeleton Key domain controller authentication bypass functionality. The  LSADUMP::ChangeNTLM  and  LSADUMP::SetNTLM  modules can also manipulate the password hash of an account without knowing the clear text value.

Name: ServHelper
Description: ServHelper  has added a user named "supportaccount" to the Remote Desktop Users and Administrators groups.

Name: SMOKEDHAM
Description: SMOKEDHAM  has added user accounts to local Admin groups.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Use multi-factor authentication for user and privileged accounts.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Configure access controls and firewalls to limit access to critical systems and domain controllers. Most cloud environments support separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances that enable further segmentation of cloud systems.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Protect domain controllers by ensuring proper security configuration for critical servers to limit access by potentially unnecessary protocols and services, such as SMB file sharing.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Do not allow domain administrator accounts to be used for day-to-day operations that may expose them to potential adversaries on unprivileged systems.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Ensure that low-privileged user accounts do not have permissions to modify accounts or account-related policies.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has removed a targeted organization's global admin accounts to lock the organization out of all access.

Name: LockerGoga
Description: LockerGoga  has been observed changing account passwords and logging off current users.

Name: MegaCortex
Description: MegaCortex  has changed user account passwords and logged users off the system.

Name: Meteor
Description: Meteor  has the ability to change the password of local users on compromised hosts and can log off users.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has enumerated all users and their roles from a victim's main treasury system.

Name: ShimRatReporter
Description: ShimRatReporter  listed all non-privileged and privileged accounts available on the machine.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  obtained a list of users and their roles from an Exchange server using  Get-ManagementRoleAssignment .

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  can identify administrator accounts on an infected machine.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  attempts to discover accounts from various locations such as a user's Evernote, AppleID, Telegram, Skype, and WeChat data.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Prevent administrator accounts from being enumerated when an application is elevating through UAC since it can lead to the disclosure of account names. The Registry key is located  HKLM\ SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\CredUI\EnumerateAdministrators . It can be disabled through GPO: Computer Configuration >  > Administrative Templates > Windows Components > Credential User Interface: E numerate administrator accounts on elevation.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  can gain system level privilege by passing  SeDebugPrivilege  to the  AdjustTokenPrivilege  API.

Name: BlackCat
Description: BlackCat  has the ability modify access tokens.

Name: Blue Mockingbird
Description: Blue Mockingbird  has used JuicyPotato to abuse the  SeImpersonate  token privilege to escalate from web application pool accounts to NT Authority\SYSTEM.

Name: C0017
Description: During  C0017 ,  APT41  used a ConfuserEx obfuscated BADPOTATO exploit to abuse named-pipe impersonation for local  NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM  privilege escalation.

Name: Cuba
Description: Cuba  has used  SeDebugPrivilege  and  AdjustTokenPrivileges  to elevate privileges.

Name: Duqu
Description: Duqu  examines running system processes for tokens that have specific system privileges. If it finds one, it will copy the token and store it for later use. Eventually it will start new processes with the stored token attached. It can also steal tokens to acquire administrative privileges.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can use  PowerSploit 's  Invoke-TokenManipulation  to manipulate access tokens.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has used has used Metasploit’s named-pipe impersonation technique to escalate privileges.

Name: Gelsemium
Description: Gelsemium  can use token manipulation to bypass UAC on Windows7 systems.

Name: HermeticWiper
Description: HermeticWiper  can use  AdjustTokenPrivileges  to grant itself privileges for debugging with  SeDebugPrivilege , creating backups with  SeBackupPrivilege , loading drivers with  SeLoadDriverPrivilege , and shutting down a local system with  SeShutdownPrivilege .

Name: Hydraq
Description: Hydraq  creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can adjust token privileges.

Name: KillDisk
Description: KillDisk  has attempted to get the access token of a process by calling  OpenProcessToken . If  KillDisk  gets the access token, then it attempt to modify the token privileges with  AdjustTokenPrivileges .

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can use  AdjustTokenPrivileges()  to elevate privileges.

Name: MegaCortex
Description: MegaCortex  can enable  SeDebugPrivilege  and adjust token privileges.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  can use Invoke-TokenManipulation for manipulating tokens.

Name: PowerSploit
Description: PowerSploit 's  Invoke-TokenManipulation  Exfiltration module can be used to manipulate tokens.

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  has attempted to adjust its token privileges to have the  SeDebugPrivilege .

Name: Sliver
Description: Sliver  has the ability to manipulate user tokens on targeted Windows systems.

Name: SslMM
Description: SslMM  contains a feature to manipulate process privileges and tokens.

Name: SUNSPOT
Description: SUNSPOT  modified its security token to grants itself debugging privileges by adding  SeDebugPrivilege .

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Limit permissions so that users and user groups cannot create tokens. This setting should be defined for the local system account only. GPO: Computer Configuration >  > Windows Settings > Security Settings > Local Policies > User Rights Assignment: Create a token object.    Also define who can create a process level token to only the local and network service through GPO: Computer Configuration >  > Windows Settings > Security Settings > Local Policies > User Rights Assignment: Replace a process level token.  Administrators should log in as a standard user but run their tools with administrator privileges using the built-in access token manipulation command  runas .

Name: User Account Management
Description: An adversary must already have administrator level access on the local system to make full use of this technique; be sure to restrict users and accounts to the least privileges they require.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls. Efforts should focus on minimizing the amount and sensitivity of data available to external parties.

Name: 2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  used a script to attempt RPC authentication against a number of hosts.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  can perform brute force attacks to obtain credentials.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has used brute force techniques to attempt account access when passwords are unknown or when password hashes are unavailable.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used Ncrack to reveal credentials.

Name: Caterpillar WebShell
Description: Caterpillar WebShell  has a module to perform brute force attacks on a system.

Name: Chaos
Description: Chaos  conducts brute force attacks against SSH services to gain initial access.

Name: CrackMapExec
Description: CrackMapExec  can brute force supplied user credentials across a network range.

Name: DarkVishnya
Description: DarkVishnya  used brute-force attack to obtain login data.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has attempted to brute force credentials to gain access.

Name: FIN5
Description: FIN5  has has used the tool GET2 Penetrator to look for remote login and hard-coded credentials.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has brute forced RDP credentials.

Name: HEXANE
Description: HEXANE  has used brute force attacks to compromise valid credentials.

Name: Kinsing
Description: Kinsing  has attempted to brute force hosts over SSH.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used brute force techniques to obtain credentials.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  performed brute force attacks against administrator accounts.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  has modules for brute forcing local administrator and AD user accounts.

Name: Pysa
Description: Pysa  has used brute force attempts against a central management console, as well as some Active Directory accounts.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can conduct brute force attacks to capture credentials.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  may attempt to connect to systems within a victim's network using  net use  commands and a predefined list or collection of passwords.

Name: Account Use Policies
Description: Set account lockout policies after a certain number of failed login attempts to prevent passwords from being guessed. Too strict a policy may create a denial of service condition and render environments un-usable, with all accounts used in the brute force being locked-out. Use conditional access policies to block logins from non-compliant devices or from outside defined organization IP ranges.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Use multi-factor authentication. Where possible, also enable multi-factor authentication on externally facing services.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Refer to NIST guidelines when creating password policies.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Proactively reset accounts that are known to be part of breached credentials either immediately, or after detecting bruteforce attempts.

Name: Axiom
Description: Axiom  has used spear phishing to initially compromise victims.

Name: GOLD SOUTHFIELD
Description: GOLD SOUTHFIELD  has conducted malicious spam (malspam) campaigns to gain access to victim's machines.

Name: Hikit
Description: Hikit  has been spread through spear phishing.

Name: Royal
Description: Royal  has been spread through the use of phishing campaigns including "call back phishing" where victims are lured into calling a number provided through email.

Name: Antivirus/Antimalware
Description: Anti-virus can automatically quarantine suspicious files.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion prevention systems and systems designed to scan and remove malicious email attachments or links can be used to block activity.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: Determine if certain websites or attachment types (ex: .scr, .exe, .pif, .cpl, etc.) that can be used for phishing are necessary for business operations and consider blocking access if activity cannot be monitored well or if it poses a significant risk.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: Use anti-spoofing and email authentication mechanisms to filter messages based on validity checks of the sender domain (using SPF) and integrity of messages (using DKIM). Enabling these mechanisms within an organization (through policies such as DMARC) may enable recipients (intra-org and cross domain) to perform similar message filtering and validation.

Name: User Training
Description: Users can be trained to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  has exfiltrated files using web services.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  can exfiltrate data over Google Drive.

Name: C0017
Description: During  C0017 ,  APT41  used Cloudflare services for data exfiltration.

Name: DropBook
Description: DropBook  has used legitimate web services to exfiltrate data.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has used the Telegram API  sendMessage  to relay data on compromised devices.

Name: ngrok
Description: ngrok  has been used by threat actors to configure servers for data exfiltration.

Name: Data Loss Prevention
Description: Data loss prevention can be detect and block sensitive data being uploaded to web services via web browsers.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: Web proxies can be used to enforce an external network communication policy that prevents use of unauthorized external services.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has used Dropbox, Amazon S3, and Google Drive to host malicious downloads.

Name: BADHATCH
Description: BADHATCH  can be utilized to abuse  sslip.io , a free IP to domain mapping service, as part of actor-controlled C2 channels.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  downloads have been hosted on Google Docs.

Name: BoomBox
Description: BoomBox  can download files from Dropbox using a hardcoded access token.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  can use legitimate websites for external C2 channels including Slack, Discord, and MS Teams.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  has been downloaded to victim's machines from OneDrive.

Name: C0017
Description: During  C0017 ,  APT41  used the Cloudflare services for C2 communications.

Name: C0027
Description: During  C0027 ,  Scattered Spider  downloaded tools from sites including file.io, GitHub, and paste.ee.

Name: Carbon
Description: Carbon  can use Pastebin to receive C2 commands.

Name: CharmPower
Description: CharmPower  can download additional modules from actor-controlled Amazon S3 buckets.

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla  can retrieve its primary payload from public sites such as Pastebin and Textbin.

Name: Doki
Description: Doki  has used the dogechain.info API to generate a C2 address.

Name: DropBook
Description: DropBook  can communicate with its operators by exploiting the Simplenote, DropBox, and the social media platform, Facebook, where it can create fake accounts to control the backdoor and receive instructions.

Name: Ember Bear
Description: Ember Bear  has used Discord's content delivery network (CDN) to deliver malware and malicious scripts to a compromised host.

Name: EXOTIC LILY
Description: EXOTIC LILY  has used file-sharing services including WeTransfer, TransferNow, and OneDrive to deliver payloads.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has used Pastebin and Google Storage to host content for their operations.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has used  sslip.io , a free IP to domain mapping service that also makes SSL certificate generation easier for traffic encryption, as part of their command and control.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has used Amazon Web Services to host C2.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  has used GitHub repositories for downloaders which will be obtained by the group's .NET executable on the compromised system.

Name: GuLoader
Description: GuLoader  has the ability to download malware from Google Drive.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has downloaded scripts from GitHub.

Name: Inception
Description: Inception  has incorporated at least five different cloud service providers into their C2 infrastructure including CloudMe.

Name: LazyScripter
Description: LazyScripter  has used GitHub to host its payloads to operate spam campaigns.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has used DropBox URLs to deliver variants of  PlugX .

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  has used web services including Paste.ee to host payloads.

Name: ngrok
Description: ngrok  has been used by threat actors to proxy C2 connections to ngrok service subdomains.

Name: Operation Spalax
Description: During  Operation Spalax , the threat actors used OneDrive and MediaFire to host payloads.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  has used Pastebin, Gitee, and GitLab for Command and Control.

Name: SharpStage
Description: SharpStage  has used a legitimate web service for evading detection.

Name: Sibot
Description: Sibot  has used a legitimate compromised website to download DLLs to the victim's machine.

Name: SMOKEDHAM
Description: SMOKEDHAM  has used Google Drive and Dropbox to host files downloaded by victims via malicious links.

Name: Snip3
Description: Snip3  can download additional payloads from web services including Pastebin and top4top.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has leveraged iplogger.org to send collected data back to C2.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has used legitimate web services including Pastebin, Dropbox, and GitHub for C2 communications.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  can download additional payloads hosted on a Discord channel.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: Web proxies can be used to enforce external network communication policy that prevents use of unauthorized external services.

Name: 2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  used valid accounts on the corporate network to escalate privileges, move laterally, and establish persistence within the corporate network.

Name: APT18
Description: APT18  actors leverage legitimate credentials to log into external remote services.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has used legitimate credentials to gain initial access, maintain access, and exfiltrate data from a victim network. The group has specifically used credentials stolen through a spearphishing email to login to the DCCC network. The group has also leveraged default manufacturer's passwords to gain initial access to corporate networks via IoT devices such as a VOIP phone, printer, and video decoder.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has used a compromised account to access an organization's VPN infrastructure.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has used valid accounts for initial access and privilege escalation.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used stolen credentials to compromise Outlook Web Access (OWA).

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  used compromised credentials to log on to other systems.

Name: Axiom
Description: Axiom  has used previously compromised administrative accounts to escalate privileges.

Name: Carbanak
Description: Carbanak  actors used legitimate credentials of banking employees to perform operations that sent them millions of dollars.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has used a valid account to maintain persistence via scheduled task.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has compromised user credentials and used valid accounts for operations.

Name: Dtrack
Description: Dtrack  used hard-coded credentials to gain access to a network share.

Name: Duqu
Description: Adversaries can instruct  Duqu  to spread laterally by copying itself to shares it has enumerated and for which it has obtained legitimate credentials (via keylogging or other means). The remote host is then infected by using the compromised credentials to schedule a task on remote machines that executes the malware.

Name: FIN10
Description: FIN10  has used stolen credentials to connect remotely to victim networks using VPNs protected with only a single factor.

Name: FIN4
Description: FIN4  has used legitimate credentials to hijack email communications.

Name: FIN5
Description: FIN5  has used legitimate VPN, RDP, Citrix, or VNC credentials to maintain access to a victim environment.

Name: FIN6
Description: To move laterally on a victim network,  FIN6  has used credentials stolen from various systems on which it gathered usernames and password hashes.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  has harvested valid administrative credentials for lateral movement.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has used valid accounts for persistence and lateral movement.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has used valid credentials with various services during lateral movement.

Name: GALLIUM
Description: GALLIUM  leveraged valid accounts to maintain access to a victim network.

Name: Industroyer
Description: Industroyer  can use supplied user credentials to execute processes and stop services.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  has used credential dumpers or stealers to obtain legitimate credentials, which they used to gain access to victim accounts.

Name: Kinsing
Description: Kinsing  has used valid SSH credentials to access remote hosts.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has used compromised credentials and/or session tokens to gain access into a victim's VPN, VDI, RDP, and IAMs.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has used administrator credentials to gain access to restricted network segments.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has obtained valid accounts to gain initial access.

Name: Linux Rabbit
Description: Linux Rabbit  acquires valid SSH accounts through brute force.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has used valid accounts including shared between Managed Service Providers and clients to move between the two environments.

Name: Night Dragon
Description: During  Night Dragon , threat actors used compromised VPN accounts to gain access to victim systems.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used compromised credentials to access other systems on a victim network.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used valid VPN credentials to gain initial access.

Name: PittyTiger
Description: PittyTiger  attempts to obtain legitimate credentials during operations.

Name: POLONIUM
Description: POLONIUM  has used valid compromised credentials to gain access to victim environments.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  have used previously acquired legitimate credentials prior to attacks.

Name: SeaDuke
Description: Some  SeaDuke  samples have a module to extract email from Microsoft Exchange servers using compromised credentials.

Name: Silence
Description: Silence  has used compromised credentials to log on to other systems and escalate privileges.

Name: Silent Librarian
Description: Silent Librarian  has used compromised credentials to obtain unauthorized access to online accounts.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used different compromised credentials for remote access and to move laterally.

Name: Suckfly
Description: Suckfly  used legitimate account credentials that they dumped to navigate the internal victim network as though they were the legitimate account owner.

Name: TEMP.Veles
Description: TEMP.Veles  has used compromised VPN accounts.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  actors obtain legitimate credentials using a variety of methods and use them to further lateral movement on victim networks.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used valid credentials for privileged accounts with the goal of accessing domain controllers.

Name: Account Use Policies
Description: Use conditional access policies to block logins from non-compliant devices or from outside defined organization IP ranges.

Name: Active Directory Configuration
Description: Disable legacy authentication, which does not support MFA, and require the use of modern authentication protocols instead.

Name: Application Developer Guidance
Description: Ensure that applications do not store sensitive data or credentials insecurely. (e.g. plaintext credentials in code, published credentials in repositories, or credentials in public cloud storage).

Name: Password Policies
Description: Applications and appliances that utilize default username and password should be changed immediately after the installation, and before deployment to a production environment.   When possible, applications that use SSH keys should be updated periodically and properly secured. Policies should minimize (if not eliminate) reuse of passwords between different user accounts, especially employees using the same credentials for personal accounts that may not be defended by enterprise security resources.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Audit domain and local accounts as well as their permission levels routinely to look for situations that could allow an adversary to gain wide access by obtaining credentials of a privileged account.       These audits should also include if default accounts have been enabled, or if new local accounts are created that have not be authorized. Follow best practices for design and administration of an enterprise network to limit privileged account use across administrative tiers.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Regularly audit user accounts for activity and deactivate or remove any that are no longer needed.

Name: User Training
Description: Applications may send push notifications to verify a login as a form of multi-factor authentication (MFA). Train users to only accept valid push notifications and to report suspicious push notifications.

Name: Andariel
Description: Andariel  has used watering hole attacks, often with zero-day exploits, to gain initial access to victims within a specific IP range.

Name: APT19
Description: APT19  performed a watering hole attack on forbes.com in 2014 to compromise targets.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has compromised targets via strategic web compromise utilizing custom exploit kits.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has infected victims by tricking them into visiting compromised watering hole websites.

Name: APT37
Description: APT37  has used strategic web compromises, particularly of South Korean websites, to distribute malware. The group has also used torrent file-sharing sites to more indiscriminately disseminate malware to victims. As part of their compromises, the group has used a Javascript based profiler called RICECURRY to profile a victim's web browser and deliver malicious code accordingly.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has conducted watering holes schemes to gain initial access to victims.

Name: Axiom
Description: Axiom  has used watering hole attacks to gain access.

Name: Bad Rabbit
Description: Bad Rabbit  spread through watering holes on popular sites by injecting JavaScript into the HTML body or a  .js  file.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  compromised three Japanese websites using a Flash exploit to perform watering hole attacks.

Name: Bundlore
Description: Bundlore  has been spread through malicious advertisements on websites.

Name: C0010
Description: During  C0010 , UNC3890 actors likely established a watering hole that was hosted on a login page of a legitimate Israeli shipping company that was active until at least November 2021.

Name: Dark Caracal
Description: Dark Caracal  leveraged a watering hole to serve up malicious code.

Name: Darkhotel
Description: Darkhotel  used embedded iframes on hotel login portals to redirect selected victims to download malware.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has compromised targets via strategic web compromise (SWC) utilizing a custom exploit kit.

Name: Earth Lusca
Description: Earth Lusca  has performed watering hole attacks.

Name: Elderwood
Description: Elderwood  has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims by injecting malicious code into specific public Web pages visited by targets within a particular sector.

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  has used compromised websites and Google Ads to bait victims into downloading its installer.

Name: KARAE
Description: KARAE  was distributed through torrent file-sharing websites to South Korean victims, using a YouTube video downloader application as a lure.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  delivered  RATANKBA  and other malicious code to victims via a compromised legitimate website.

Name: Leafminer
Description: Leafminer  has infected victims using watering holes.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has infected victims using watering holes.

Name: LoudMiner
Description: LoudMiner  is typically bundled with pirated copies of Virtual Studio Technology (VST) for Windows and macOS.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  has distributed  Machete  through a fake blog website.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has conducted watering-hole attacks through media and magazine websites.

Name: Operation Dust Storm
Description: During  Operation Dust Storm , the threat actors used a watering hole attack on a popular software reseller to exploit the then-zero-day Internet Explorer vulnerability CVE-2014-0322.

Name: Patchwork
Description: Patchwork  has used watering holes to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.

Name: PLATINUM
Description: PLATINUM  has sometimes used drive-by attacks against vulnerable browser plugins.

Name: POORAIM
Description: POORAIM  has been delivered through compromised sites acting as watering holes.

Name: PROMETHIUM
Description: PROMETHIUM  has used watering hole attacks to deliver malicious versions of legitimate installers.

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  has infected victim machines through compromised websites and exploit kits.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  has distributed its malware via the RIG and SUNDOWN exploit kits, as well as online advertising network  Yandex.Direct .

Name: Snip3
Description: Snip3  has been delivered to targets via downloads from malicious domains.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  has extensively used strategic web compromises to target victims.

Name: Transparent Tribe
Description: Transparent Tribe  has used websites with malicious hyperlinks and iframes to infect targeted victims with  Crimson ,  njRAT , and other malicious tools.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has infected victims using watering holes.

Name: Windigo
Description: Windigo  has distributed Windows malware via drive-by downloads.

Name: Windshift
Description: Windshift  has used compromised websites to register custom URL schemes on a remote system.

Name: Application Isolation and Sandboxing
Description: Browser sandboxes can be used to mitigate some of the impact of exploitation, but sandbox escapes may still exist.   Other types of virtualization and application microsegmentation may also mitigate the impact of client-side exploitation. The risks of additional exploits and weaknesses in implementation may still exist for these types of systems.

Name: Exploit Protection
Description: Security applications that look for behavior used during exploitation such as Windows Defender Exploit Guard (WDEG) and the Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET) can be used to mitigate some exploitation behavior.    Control flow integrity checking is another way to potentially identify and stop a software exploit from occurring.    Many of these protections depend on the architecture and target application binary for compatibility.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: For malicious code served up through ads, adblockers can help prevent that code from executing in the first place. Script blocking extensions can help prevent the execution of JavaScript that may commonly be used during the exploitation process.

Name: Update Software
Description: Ensure all browsers and plugins kept updated can help prevent the exploit phase of this technique. Use modern browsers with security features turned on.

Name: 2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  used  BlackEnergy ’s network sniffer module to discover user credentials being sent over the network between the local LAN and the power grid’s industrial control systems.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  deployed the open source tool Responder to conduct NetBIOS Name Service poisoning, which captured usernames and hashed passwords that allowed access to legitimate credentials.     APT28  close-access teams have used Wi-Fi pineapples to intercept Wi-Fi signals and user credentials.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has used SniffPass to collect credentials by sniffing network traffic.

Name: DarkVishnya
Description: DarkVishnya  used network sniffing to obtain login data.

Name: Emotet
Description: Emotet  has been observed to hook network APIs to monitor network traffic.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can be used to conduct packet captures on target hosts.

Name: FoggyWeb
Description: FoggyWeb  can configure custom listeners to passively monitor all incoming HTTP GET and POST requests sent to the AD FS server from the intranet/internet and intercept HTTP requests that match the custom URI patterns defined by the actor.

Name: Impacket
Description: Impacket  can be used to sniff network traffic via an interface or raw socket.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used the Nirsoft SniffPass network sniffer to obtain passwords sent over non-secure protocols.

Name: MESSAGETAP
Description: MESSAGETAP  uses the libpcap library to listen to all traffic and parses network protocols starting with Ethernet and IP layers. It continues parsing protocol layers including SCTP, SCCP, and TCAP and finally extracts SMS message data and routing metadata.

Name: NBTscan
Description: NBTscan  can dump and print whole packet content.

Name: Penquin
Description: Penquin  can sniff network traffic to look for packets matching specific conditions.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  contains a module for taking packet captures on compromised hosts.

Name: Regin
Description: Regin  appears to have functionality to sniff for credentials passed over HTTP, SMTP, and SMB.

Name: Responder
Description: Responder  captures hashes and credentials that are sent to the system after the name services have been poisoned.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has used intercepter-NG to sniff passwords in network traffic.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: Ensure that all wired and/or wireless traffic is encrypted appropriately. Use best practices for authentication protocols, such as Kerberos, and ensure web traffic that may contain credentials is protected by SSL/TLS.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Use multi-factor authentication wherever possible.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Deny direct access of broadcasts and multicast sniffing, and prevent attacks such as  LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay

Name: User Account Management
Description: In cloud environments, ensure that users are not granted permissions to create or modify traffic mirrors unless this is explicitly required.

Name: Dok
Description: Dok  proxies web traffic to potentially monitor and alter victim HTTP(S) traffic.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used modified versions of PHProxy to examine web traffic between the victim and the accessed website.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable legacy network protocols that may be used   to intercept network traffic if applicable, especially those that are not needed within an environment.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: Ensure that all wired and/or wireless traffic is encrypted appropriately. Use best practices for authentication protocols, such as Kerberos, and ensure web traffic that may contain credentials is protected by SSL/TLS.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Use network appliances and host-based security software to block network traffic that is not necessary within the environment, such as legacy protocols that may be leveraged for AiTM conditions.

Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Description: Limit access to network infrastructure and resources that can be used to reshape traffic or otherwise produce AiTM conditions.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that can identify traffic patterns indicative of AiTM activity can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Network segmentation can be used to isolate infrastructure components that do not require broad network access. This may mitigate, or at least alleviate, the scope of AiTM activity.

Name: User Training
Description: Train users to be suspicious about certificate errors. Adversaries may use their own certificates in an attempt to intercept HTTPS traffic. Certificate errors may arise when the application’s certificate does not match the one expected by the host.

Name: EXOTIC LILY
Description: EXOTIC LILY  has used contact forms on victim websites to generate phishing e-mails.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has searched for information on the target company's website.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has conducted research against potential victim websites as part of its operational planning.

Name: Silent Librarian
Description: Silent Librarian  has searched victim's websites to identify the interests and academic areas of targeted individuals and to scrape source code, branding, and organizational contact information for phishing pages.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls. Efforts should focus on minimizing the amount and sensitivity of data available to external parties.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has collected victim organization information including but not limited to organization hierarchy, functions, press releases, and others.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has studied publicly available information about a targeted organization to tailor spearphishing efforts against specific departments and/or individuals.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: For  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  gathered victim organization information to identify specific targets.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls. Efforts should focus on minimizing the amount and sensitivity of data available to external parties.

Name: Application Developer Guidance
Description: Application developers should consider taking measures to validate authentication requests by enabling one-time passwords, providing timestamps or sequence numbers for messages sent, using digital signatures, and/or using random session keys.

Name: Application Isolation and Sandboxing
Description: Make it difficult for adversaries to advance their operation through exploitation of undiscovered or unpatched vulnerabilities by using sandboxing. Other types of virtualization and application microsegmentation may also mitigate the impact of some types of exploitation. Risks of additional exploits and weaknesses in these systems may still exist.

Name: Exploit Protection
Description: Security applications that look for behavior used during exploitation such as Windows Defender Exploit Guard (WDEG) and the Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET) can be used to mitigate some exploitation behavior.   Control flow integrity checking is another way to potentially identify and stop a software exploit from occurring.   Many of these protections depend on the architecture and target application binary for compatibility and may not work for software targeted for defense evasion.

Name: Threat Intelligence Program
Description: Develop a robust cyber threat intelligence capability to determine what types and levels of threat may use software exploits and 0-days against a particular organization.

Name: Update Software
Description: Update software regularly by employing patch management for internal enterprise endpoints and servers.

Name: Aria-body
Description: Aria-body  has the ability to identify the titles of running windows on a compromised host.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  can obtain application window titles and then determines which windows to perform Screen Capture on.

Name: Cadelspy
Description: Cadelspy  has the ability to identify open windows on the compromised host.

Name: Catchamas
Description: Catchamas  obtains application windows titles and then determines which windows to perform  Screen Capture  on.

Name: DarkWatchman
Description: DarkWatchman  reports window names along with keylogger information to provide application context.

Name: Duqu
Description: The discovery modules used with  Duqu  can collect information on open windows.

Name: Flagpro
Description: Flagpro  can check the name of the window displayed on the system.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: FunnyDream  has the ability to discover application windows via execution of  EnumWindows .

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  can identify installed security tools based on window names.

Name: HEXANE
Description: HEXANE  has used a PowerShell-based keylogging tool to capture the window title.

Name: HotCroissant
Description: HotCroissant  has the ability to list the names of all open windows on the infected host.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can enumerate windows and child windows on a compromised host.

Name: Kazuar
Description: Kazuar  gathers information about opened windows.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  malware IndiaIndia obtains and sends to its C2 server the title of the window for each running process. The KilaAlfa keylogger also reports the title of the window in the foreground.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  saves the window names.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  can enumerate all windows on the victim’s machine.

Name: NetTraveler
Description: NetTraveler  reports window names along with keylogger information to provide application context.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can discover and close windows on controlled systems.

Name: NightClub
Description: NightClub  can use  GetForegroundWindow  to enumerate the active window.

Name: njRAT
Description: njRAT  gathers information about opened windows during the initial infection.

Name: PLEAD
Description: PLEAD  has the ability to list open windows on the compromised host.

Name: PoisonIvy
Description: PoisonIvy  captures window titles.

Name: PowerDuke
Description: PowerDuke  has a command to get text of the current foreground window.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  has the ability to enumerate windows on a compromised host.

Name: Remexi
Description: Remexi  has a command to capture active windows on the machine and retrieve window titles.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  can use  the  GetForegroundWindow  and  GetWindowText  APIs to discover where the user is typing.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can enumerate the active Window during keylogging through execution of  GetActiveWindowTitle .

Name: SOUNDBITE
Description: SOUNDBITE  is capable of enumerating application windows.

Name: Trojan.Karagany
Description: Trojan.Karagany  can monitor the titles of open windows to identify specific keywords.

Name: WINERACK
Description: WINERACK  can enumerate active windows.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  has a file uploader plugin that automatically exfiltrates the collected data and log files to the C2 server.

Name: CosmicDuke
Description: CosmicDuke  exfiltrates collected files automatically over FTP to remote servers.

Name: Crutch
Description: Crutch  has automatically exfiltrated stolen files to Dropbox.

Name: Doki
Description: Doki  has used a script that gathers information from a hardcoded list of IP addresses and uploads to an Ngrok URL.

Name: Ebury
Description: Ebury  can automatically exfiltrate gathered SSH credentials.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  has the ability to automatically send collected data back to the threat actors' C2.

Name: Frankenstein
Description: During  Frankenstein , the threat actors collected information via  Empire , which was automatically sent back to the adversary's C2.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  has used modules that automatically upload gathered documents to the C2 server.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  has performed  frequent and scheduled data exfiltration from compromised networks.

Name: LightNeuron
Description: LightNeuron  can be configured to automatically exfiltrate files under a specified directory.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete ’s collected files are exfiltrated automatically to remote servers.

Name: OutSteel
Description: OutSteel  can automatically upload collected files to its C2 server.

Name: Peppy
Description: Peppy  has the ability to automatically exfiltrate files and keylogs.

Name: Rover
Description: Rover  automatically searches for files on local drives based on a predefined list of file extensions and sends them to the command and control server every 60 minutes.  Rover  also automatically sends keylogger files and screenshots to the C2 server on a regular timeframe.

Name: ShimRatReporter
Description: ShimRatReporter  sent collected system and network information compiled into a report to an adversary-controlled C2.

Name: Sidewinder
Description: Sidewinder  has configured tools to automatically send collected files to attacker controlled servers.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  can automatically exfiltrate collected documents to the C2 server.

Name: TajMahal
Description: TajMahal  has the ability to manage an automated queue of egress files and commands sent to its C2.

Name: TINYTYPHON
Description: When a document is found matching one of the extensions in the configuration,  TINYTYPHON  uploads it to the C2 server.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has used a copy function to automatically exfiltrate sensitive data from air-gapped systems using USB storage.

Name: USBStealer
Description: USBStealer  automatically exfiltrates collected files via removable media when an infected device connects to an air-gapped victim machine after initially being connected to an internet-enabled victim machine.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  has automatically collected data from USB drives, keystrokes, and screen images before exfiltration.

Name: APT1
Description: APT1  used a batch script to perform a series of discovery techniques and saves it to a text file.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  used a publicly available tool to gather and compress multiple documents on the DCCC and DNC networks.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  has automatically collected data about the compromised system.

Name: BADNEWS
Description: BADNEWS  monitors USB devices and copies files with certain extensions to a predefined directory.

Name: Bankshot
Description: Bankshot  recursively generates a list of files within a directory and sends them back to the control server.

Name: ccf32
Description: ccf32  can be used to automatically collect files from a compromised host.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has used custom DLLs for continuous retrieval of data from memory.

Name: Comnie
Description: Comnie  executes a batch script to store discovery information in %TEMP%\info.dat and then uploads the temporarily file to the remote C2 server.

Name: Confucius
Description: Confucius  has used a file stealer to steal documents and images with the following extensions: txt, pdf, png, jpg, doc, xls, xlm, odp, ods, odt, rtf, ppt, xlsx, xlsm, docx, pptx, and jpeg.

Name: Crutch
Description: Crutch  can automatically monitor removable drives in a loop and copy interesting files.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can automatically gather the username, domain name, machine name, and other information from a compromised system.

Name: FIN5
Description: FIN5  scans processes on all victim systems in the environment and uses automated scripts to pull back the results.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has used a script to iterate through a list of compromised PoS systems, copy and remove data to a log file, and to bind to events from the submit payment button.

Name: Frankenstein
Description: During  Frankenstein , the threat actors used  Empire  to automatically gather the username, domain name, machine name, and other system information.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: FunnyDream  can monitor files for changes and automatically collect them.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  has deployed scripts on compromised systems that automatically scan for interesting documents.

Name: GoldFinder
Description: GoldFinder  logged and stored information related to the route or hops a packet took from a compromised machine to a hardcoded C2 server, including the target C2 URL, HTTP response/status code, HTTP response headers and values, and data received from the C2 node.

Name: Helminth
Description: A  Helminth  VBScript receives a batch script to execute a set of commands in a command prompt.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can sort and collect specific documents as well as generate a list of all files on a newly inserted drive and store them in an encrypted file.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  has performed frequent and scheduled data collection from victim networks.

Name: LightNeuron
Description: LightNeuron  can be configured to automatically collect files under a specified directory.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has used the Csvde tool to collect Active Directory files and data.

Name: MESSAGETAP
Description: MESSAGETAP  checks two files, keyword_parm.txt and parm.txt, for instructions on how to target and save data parsed and extracted from SMS message data from the network traffic. If an SMS message contained either a phone number, IMSI number, or keyword that matched the predefined list, it is saved to a CSV file for later theft by the threat actor.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has automatically collected mouse clicks, continuous screenshots on the machine, and set timers to collect the contents of the clipboard and website browsing.

Name: Micropsia
Description: Micropsia  executes an RAR tool to recursively archive files based on a predefined list of file extensions ( .xls,  .xlsx,  .csv,  .odt,  .doc,  .docx,  .ppt,  .pptx,  .pdf,  .mdb,  .accdb,  .accde, *.txt).

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  used custom batch scripts to collect files automatically from a targeted system.

Name: Mythic
Description: Mythic  supports scripting of file downloads from agents.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can automatically archive collected data.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used automated collection.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used a script to collect information about the infected system.

Name: OutSteel
Description: OutSteel  can automatically scan for and collect files with specific extensions.

Name: Pacu
Description: Pacu  can automatically collect data, such as CloudFormation templates, EC2 user data, AWS Inspector reports, and IAM credential reports.

Name: Patchwork
Description: Patchwork  developed a file stealer to search C:\ and collect files with certain extensions.  Patchwork  also executed a script to enumerate all drives, store them as a list, and upload generated files to the C2 server.

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  used file system monitoring to track modification and enable automatic exfiltration.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  contains a module for recursively parsing through files and directories to gather valid credit card numbers.

Name: Proxysvc
Description: Proxysvc  automatically collects data about the victim and sends it to the control server.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can conduct an initial scan for Microsoft Word documents on the local system, removable media, and connected network drives, before tagging and collecting them. It can continue tagging documents to collect with follow up scans.

Name: ROADTools
Description: ROADTools  automatically gathers data from Azure AD environments using the Azure Graph API.

Name: RotaJakiro
Description: Depending on the Linux distribution,  RotaJakiro  executes a set of commands to collect device information and sends the collected information to the C2 server.

Name: Rover
Description: Rover  automatically collects files from the local system and removable drives based on a predefined list of file extensions on a regular timeframe.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  monitors browsing activity and automatically captures screenshots if a victim browses to a URL matching one of a list of strings.

Name: ShimRatReporter
Description: ShimRatReporter  gathered information automatically, without instruction from a C2, related to the user and host machine that is compiled into a report and sent to the operators.

Name: Sidewinder
Description: Sidewinder  has used tools to automatically collect system and network configuration information.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  has a file searcher component that can automatically collect and archive files based on a predefined list of file extensions.

Name: T9000
Description: T9000  searches removable storage devices for files with a pre-defined list of file extensions (e.g. * .doc,  .ppt,  .xls,  .docx,  .pptx, *.xlsx). Any matching files are encrypted and written to a local user directory.

Name: TajMahal
Description: TajMahal  has the ability to index and compress files into a send queue for exfiltration.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  ran a command to compile an archive of file types of interest from the victim user's directories.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has collected information automatically using the adversary's  USBferry  attack.

Name: USBStealer
Description: For all non-removable drives on a victim,  USBStealer  executes automated collection of certain files for later exfiltration.

Name: Valak
Description: Valak  can download a module to search for and build a report of harvested credential data.

Name: VERMIN
Description: VERMIN  saves each collected file with the automatically generated format {0:dd-MM-yyyy}.txt .

Name: WindTail
Description: WindTail  can identify and add files that possess specific file extensions to an array for archiving.

Name: Zebrocy
Description: Zebrocy  scans the system and automatically collects files with the following extensions: .doc, .docx, ,.xls, .xlsx, .pdf, .pptx, .rar, .zip, .jpg, .jpeg, .bmp, .tiff, .kum, .tlg, .sbx, .cr, .hse, .hsf, and .lhz.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: Encryption and off-system storage of sensitive information may be one way to mitigate collection of files, but may not stop an adversary from acquiring the information if an intrusion persists over a long period of time and the adversary is able to discover and access the data through other means. Strong passwords should be used on certain encrypted documents that use them to prevent offline cracking through  Brute Force  techniques.

Name: Remote Data Storage
Description: Encryption and off-system storage of sensitive information may be one way to mitigate collection of files, but may not stop an adversary from acquiring the information if an intrusion persists over a long period of time and the adversary is able to discover and access the data through other means.

Name: ADVSTORESHELL
Description: ADVSTORESHELL  encrypts with the 3DES algorithm and a hardcoded key prior to exfiltration.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  can encrypt data with 3DES before sending it over to a C2 server.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  has compressed collected data before exfiltration.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  used a publicly available tool to gather and compress multiple documents on the DCCC and DNC networks.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32 's backdoor has used LZMA compression and RC4 encryption before exfiltration.

Name: Aria-body
Description: Aria-body  has used ZIP to compress data gathered on a compromised host.

Name: Axiom
Description: Axiom  has compressed and encrypted data prior to exfiltration.

Name: Backdoor.Oldrea
Description: Backdoor.Oldrea  writes collected data to a temporary file in an encrypted form before exfiltration to a C2 server.

Name: BloodHound
Description: BloodHound  can compress data collected by its SharpHound ingestor into a ZIP file to be written to disk.

Name: BLUELIGHT
Description: BLUELIGHT  can zip files before exfiltration.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  can compress data stolen from the Registry and volume shadow copies prior to exfiltration.

Name: Cadelspy
Description: Cadelspy  has the ability to compress stolen data into a .cab file.

Name: Chrommme
Description: Chrommme  can encrypt and store on disk collected data before exfiltration.

Name: Daserf
Description: Daserf  hides collected data in password-protected .rar archives.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has compressed data into .zip files prior to exfiltration.

Name: Dtrack
Description: Dtrack  packs collected data into a password protected archive.

Name: Emotet
Description: Emotet  has been observed encrypting the data it collects before sending it to the C2 server.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can ZIP directories on the target system.

Name: Epic
Description: Epic  encrypts collected data using a public key framework before sending it over the C2 channel.   Some variants encrypt the collected data with AES and encode it with base64 before transmitting it to the C2 server.

Name: Exaramel for Windows
Description: Exaramel for Windows  automatically encrypts files before sending them to the C2 server.

Name: FELIXROOT
Description: FELIXROOT  encrypts collected data with AES and Base64 and then sends it to the C2 server.

Name: FIN6
Description: Following data collection,  FIN6  has compressed log files into a ZIP archive prior to staging and exfiltration.

Name: Gold Dragon
Description: Gold Dragon  encrypts data using Base64 before being sent to the command and control server.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: The  Ke3chang  group has been known to compress data before exfiltration.

Name: Kessel
Description: Kessel  can RC4-encrypt credentials before sending to the C2.

Name: KONNI
Description: KONNI  has encrypted data and files prior to exfiltration.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has compressed exfiltrated data with RAR and used RomeoDelta malware to archive specified directories in .zip format, encrypt the .zip file, and upload it to C2.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has archived victim's data prior to exfiltration.

Name: LightNeuron
Description: LightNeuron  contains a function to encrypt and store emails that it collects.

Name: Lizar
Description: Lizar  has encrypted data before sending it to the server.

Name: LuminousMoth
Description: LuminousMoth  has manually archived stolen files from victim machines before exfiltration.

Name: Lurid
Description: Lurid  can compress data before sending it.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  stores zipped files with profile data from installed web browsers.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has encrypted files and information before exfiltration.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  has the ability to compress archived screenshots.

Name: Patchwork
Description: Patchwork  encrypted the collected files' path with AES and then encoded them with base64.

Name: Pillowmint
Description: Pillowmint  has encrypted stolen credit card information with AES and further encoded it with Base64.

Name: PowerLess
Description: PowerLess  can encrypt browser database files prior to exfiltration.

Name: Prikormka
Description: After collecting documents from removable media,  Prikormka  compresses the collected files, and encrypts it with Blowfish.

Name: Proton
Description: Proton  zips up files before exfiltrating them.

Name: Remexi
Description: Remexi  encrypts and adds all gathered browser data into files for upload to C2.

Name: RunningRAT
Description: RunningRAT  contains code to compress files.

Name: ShimRatReporter
Description: ShimRatReporter  used LZ compression to compress initial reconnaissance reports before sending to the C2.

Name: TAINTEDSCRIBE
Description: TAINTEDSCRIBE  has used  FileReadZipSend  to compress a file and send to C2.

Name: VERMIN
Description: VERMIN  encrypts the collected files using 3-DES.

Name: WellMail
Description: WellMail  can archive files on the compromised host.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  will compress entire  ~/Desktop  folders excluding all  .git  folders, but only if the total data size is under 200MB.

Name: Zebrocy
Description: Zebrocy   has used a method similar to RC4 as well as AES for encryption and hexadecimal for encoding data before exfiltration.

Name: Audit
Description: System scans can be performed to identify unauthorized archival utilities.

Name: BoxCaon
Description: BoxCaon  established persistence by setting the  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\load  registry key to point to its executable.

Name: Dtrack
Description: Dtrack ’s RAT makes a persistent target file with auto execution on the host start.

Name: Mis-Type
Description: Mis-Type  has created registry keys for persistence, including  HKCU\Software\bkfouerioyou ,  HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Active Setup\Installed Components\{6afa8072-b2b1-31a8-b5c1-{Unique Identifier} , and  HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Active Setup\Installed Components\{3BF41072-B2B1-31A8-B5C1-{Unique Identifier} .

Name: Misdat
Description: Misdat  has created registry keys for persistence, including  HKCU\Software\dnimtsoleht\StubPath ,  HKCU\Software\snimtsOleht\StubPath ,  HKCU\Software\Backtsaleht\StubPath ,  HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Active Setup\Installed. Components\{3bf41072-b2b1-21c8-b5c1-bd56d32fbda7} , and  HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Active Setup\Installed Components\{3ef41072-a2f1-21c8-c5c1-70c2c3bc7905} .

Name: xCaon
Description: xCaon  has added persistence via the Registry key  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\load  which causes the malware to run each time any user logs in.

Name: APT19
Description: APT19  downloaded and launched code within a SCT file.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has used COM scriptlets to download Cobalt Strike beacons.

Name: APT37
Description: APT37  has used Ruby scripts to execute payloads.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has utilized AutoIt and custom scripts to perform internal reconnaissance.

Name: Bandook
Description: Bandook  can support commands to execute Java-based payloads.

Name: Bonadan
Description: Bonadan  can create bind and reverse shells on the infected system.

Name: CHOPSTICK
Description: CHOPSTICK  is capable of performing remote command execution.

Name: DarkComet
Description: DarkComet  can execute various types of scripts on the victim’s machine.

Name: Donut
Description: Donut  can generate shellcode outputs that execute via Ruby.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has used the command line for execution.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  uses a command-line interface to interact with systems.

Name: FIN5
Description: FIN5  scans processes on all victim systems in the environment and uses automated scripts to pull back the results.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has used scripting to iterate through a list of compromised PoS systems, copy data to a log file, and remove the original data files.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  used SQL scripts to help perform tasks on the victim's machine.

Name: FIVEHANDS
Description: FIVEHANDS  can receive a command line argument to limit file encryption to specified directories.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has used a Perl reverse shell to communicate with C2.

Name: Get2
Description: Get2  has the ability to run executables with command-line arguments.

Name: gh0st RAT
Description: gh0st RAT  is able to open a remote shell to execute commands.

Name: Imminent Monitor
Description: Imminent Monitor  has a CommandPromptPacket and ScriptPacket module(s) for creating a remote shell and executing scripts.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Malware used by  Ke3chang  can run commands on the command-line interface.

Name: Kessel
Description: Kessel  can create a reverse shell between the infected host and a specified system.

Name: Matryoshka
Description: Matryoshka  is capable of providing Meterpreter shell access.

Name: Melcoz
Description: Melcoz  has been distributed through an AutoIt loader script.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used various types of scripting for execution.

Name: Operation Spalax
Description: For  Operation Spalax , the threat actors used Nullsoft Scriptable Install System (NSIS) scripts to install malware.

Name: P.A.S. Webshell
Description: P.A.S. Webshell  has the ability to create reverse shells with Perl scripts.

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  has executed a Lua script through a Lua interpreter for Windows.

Name: SpeakUp
Description: SpeakUp  uses Perl scripts.

Name: Stealth Falcon
Description: Stealth Falcon  malware uses WMI to script data collection and command execution on the victim.

Name: Whitefly
Description: Whitefly  has used a simple remote shell tool that will call back to the C2 server and wait for commands.

Name: Windigo
Description: Windigo  has used a Perl script for information gathering.

Name: WINERACK
Description: WINERACK  can create a reverse shell that utilizes statically-linked Wine cmd.exe code to emulate Windows command prompt commands.

Name: Zeus Panda
Description: Zeus Panda  can launch remote scripts on the victim’s machine.

Name: Antivirus/Antimalware
Description: Anti-virus can be used to automatically quarantine suspicious files.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: On Windows 10, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to prevent  Visual Basic  and  JavaScript  scripts from executing potentially malicious downloaded content   .

Name: Code Signing
Description: Where possible, only permit execution of signed scripts.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable or remove any unnecessary or unused shells or interpreters.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use application control where appropriate. For example, PowerShell Constrained Language mode can be used to restrict access to sensitive or otherwise dangerous language elements such as those used to execute arbitrary Windows APIs or files (e.g.,  Add-Type ).

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: When PowerShell is necessary, consider restricting PowerShell execution policy to administrators. Be aware that there are methods of bypassing the PowerShell execution policy, depending on environment configuration.  PowerShell JEA (Just Enough Administration) may also be used to sandbox administration and limit what commands admins/users can execute through remote PowerShell sessions.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: Script blocking extensions can help prevent the execution of scripts and HTA files that may commonly be used during the exploitation process. For malicious code served up through ads, adblockers can help prevent that code from executing in the first place.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has hijacked legitimate application-specific startup scripts to enable malware to execute on system startup.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  has installed an "init.d" startup script to maintain persistence.

Name: RotaJakiro
Description: Depending on the Linux distribution and when executing with root permissions,  RotaJakiro  may install persistence using a  .conf  file in the  /etc/init/  folder.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Restrict write access to logon scripts to specific administrators.

Name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Description: Ensure proper permissions are set for Registry hives to prevent users from modifying keys for logon scripts that may lead to persistence.

Name: Bundlore
Description: Bundlore  can install malicious browser extensions that are used to hijack user searches.

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  can use malicious browser extensions to steal cookies and other user information.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used Google Chrome browser extensions to infect victims and to steal passwords and cookies.

Name: OSX/Shlayer
Description: OSX/Shlayer  can install malicious Safari browser extensions to serve ads.

Name: Audit
Description: Ensure extensions that are installed are the intended ones as many malicious extensions will masquerade as legitimate ones.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Set a browser extension allow or deny list as appropriate for your security policy.

Name: Limit Software Installation
Description: Only install browser extensions from trusted sources that can be verified. Browser extensions for some browsers can be controlled through Group Policy. Change settings to prevent the browser from installing extensions without sufficient permissions.

Name: Update Software
Description: Ensure operating systems and browsers are using the most current version.

Name: User Training
Description: Close out all browser sessions when finished using them to prevent any potentially malicious extensions from continuing to run.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has collected browser bookmark information to learn more about compromised hosts, obtain personal information about users, and acquire details about internal network resources.

Name: Calisto
Description: Calisto  collects information on bookmarks from Google Chrome.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has used  type \ \c$\Users\ \Favorites\Links\Bookmarks bar\Imported From IE*citrix*  for bookmark discovery.

Name: DarkWatchman
Description: DarkWatchman  can retrieve browser history.

Name: Dtrack
Description: Dtrack  can retrieve browser history.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  has the ability to gather browser data such as bookmarks and visited sites.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has used Google Chrome bookmarks to identify internal resources and assets.

Name: Lizar
Description: Lizar  can retrieve browser history and database files.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  retrieves the user profile data (e.g., browsers) from Chrome and Firefox browsers.

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can collect the contents of the  %USERPROFILE%\AppData\Local\Google\Chrome\User Data\LocalState  file.

Name: MobileOrder
Description: MobileOrder  has a command to upload to its C2 server victim browser bookmarks.

Name: PowerLess
Description: PowerLess  has a browser info stealer module that can read Chrome and Edge browser database files.

Name: SUGARDUMP
Description: SUGARDUMP  has collected browser bookmark and history information.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  has the ability to use form-grabbing to extract data from web data forms.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp  has captured credentials when a user performs login through a SSL session.

Name: Chaes
Description: Chaes  has used the Puppeteer module to hook and monitor the Chrome web browser to collect user information from infected hosts.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can perform browser pivoting and inject into a user's browser to inherit cookies, authenticated HTTP sessions, and client SSL certificates.

Name: Dridex
Description: Dridex  can perform browser attacks via web injects to steal information such as credentials, certificates, and cookies.

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  can monitor browser activity for online banking actions and display full-screen overlay images to block user access to the intended site or present additional data fields.

Name: IcedID
Description: IcedID  has used web injection attacks to redirect victims to spoofed sites designed to harvest banking and other credentials.   IcedID  can use a self signed TLS certificate in connection with the spoofed site and simultaneously maintains a live connection with the legitimate site to display the correct URL and certificates in the browser.

Name: Melcoz
Description: Melcoz  can monitor the victim's browser for online banking sessions and display an overlay window to manipulate the session in the background.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can use advanced web injects to steal web banking credentials.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  uses web injects and browser redirection to trick the user into providing their login credentials on a fake or modified web page.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has injected HTML codes into banking sites to steal sensitive online banking information (ex: usernames and passwords).

Name: User Account Management
Description: Since browser pivoting requires a high integrity process to launch from, restricting user permissions and addressing Privilege Escalation and  Bypass User Account Control  opportunities can limit the exposure to this technique.

Name: User Training
Description: Close all browser sessions regularly and when they are no longer needed.

Name: APT37
