Description: APT37  has used an audio capturing utility known as SOUNDWAVE that captures microphone input.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor 's has a plugin that is capable of recording audio using available input sound devices.

Name: Bandook
Description: Bandook  has modules that are capable of capturing audio.

Name: Cadelspy
Description: Cadelspy  has the ability to record audio from the compromised host.

Name: Cobian RAT
Description: Cobian RAT  has a feature to perform voice recording on the victim’s machine.

Name: Crimson
Description: Crimson  can perform audio surveillance using microphones.

Name: DarkComet
Description: DarkComet  can listen in to victims' conversations through the system’s microphone.

Name: Derusbi
Description: Derusbi  is capable of performing audio captures.

Name: DOGCALL
Description: DOGCALL  can capture microphone data from the victim's machine.

Name: EvilGrab
Description: EvilGrab  has the capability to capture audio from a victim machine.

Name: Flame
Description: Flame  can record audio using any existing hardware recording devices.

Name: Imminent Monitor
Description: Imminent Monitor  has a remote microphone monitoring capability.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can record sound using input audio devices.

Name: Janicab
Description: Janicab  captured audio and sent it out to a C2 server.

Name: jRAT
Description: jRAT  can capture microphone recordings.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  captures audio from the computer’s microphone.

Name: MacMa
Description: MacMa  has the ability to record audio.

Name: MacSpy
Description: MacSpy  can record the sounds from microphones on a computer.

Name: Micropsia
Description: Micropsia  can perform microphone recording.

Name: NanoCore
Description: NanoCore  can capture audio feeds from the system.

Name: NightClub
Description: NightClub  can load a module to leverage the LAME encoder and  mciSendStringW  to control and capture audio.

Name: PowerSploit
Description: PowerSploit 's  Get-MicrophoneAudio  Exfiltration module can record system microphone audio.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  can record sound with the microphone.

Name: Remcos
Description: Remcos  can capture data from the system’s microphone.

Name: Revenge RAT
Description: Revenge RAT  has a plugin for microphone interception.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  has an audio capture and eavesdropping module.

Name: T9000
Description: T9000  uses the Skype API to record audio and video calls. It writes encrypted data to  %APPDATA%\Intel\Skype .

Name: TajMahal
Description: TajMahal  has the ability to capture VoiceIP application audio on an infected host.

Name: VERMIN
Description: VERMIN  can perform audio capture.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  regularly deploys both publicly available (ex:  Mimikatz ) and custom password retrieval tools on victims.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  used GetPassword_x64 to harvest credentials.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used different versions of Mimikatz to obtain credentials.

Name: Axiom
Description: Axiom  has been known to dump credentials.

Name: Carbanak
Description: Carbanak  obtains Windows logon password details.

Name: HOMEFRY
Description: HOMEFRY  can perform credential dumping.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has used publicly available tools to dump password hashes, including  HOMEFRY .

Name: OnionDuke
Description: OnionDuke  steals credentials from its victims.

Name: PinchDuke
Description: PinchDuke  steals credentials from compromised hosts.  PinchDuke 's credential stealing functionality is believed to be based on the source code of the Pinch credential stealing malware (also known as LdPinch). Credentials targeted by  PinchDuke  include ones associated many sources such as WinInet Credential Cache, and Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP).

Name: Poseidon Group
Description: Poseidon Group  conducts credential dumping on victims, with a focus on obtaining credentials belonging to domain and database servers.

Name: Revenge RAT
Description: Revenge RAT  has a plugin for credential harvesting.

Name: Sowbug
Description: Sowbug  has used credential dumping tools.

Name: Suckfly
Description: Suckfly  used a signed credential-dumping tool to obtain victim account credentials.

Name: Tonto Team
Description: Tonto Team  has used a variety of credential dumping tools.

Name: Trojan.Karagany
Description: Trojan.Karagany  can dump passwords and save them into  \ProgramData\Mail\MailAg\pwds.txt .

Name: Active Directory Configuration
Description: Manage the access control list for "Replicating Directory Changes" and other permissions associated with domain controller replication.       Consider adding users to the "Protected Users" Active Directory security group. This can help limit the caching of users' plaintext credentials.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: On Windows 10, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to secure LSASS and prevent credential stealing.

Name: Credential Access Protection
Description: With Windows 10, Microsoft implemented new protections called Credential Guard to protect the LSA secrets that can be used to obtain credentials through forms of credential dumping. It is not configured by default and has hardware and firmware system requirements.    It also does not protect against all forms of credential dumping.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: Ensure Domain Controller backups are properly secured.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Consider disabling or restricting NTLM.   Consider disabling WDigest authentication.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Ensure that local administrator accounts have complex, unique passwords across all systems on the network.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Windows:Do not put user or admin domain accounts in the local administrator groups across systems unless they are tightly controlled, as this is often equivalent to having a local administrator account with the same password on all systems. Follow best practices for design and administration of an enterprise network to limit privileged account use across administrative tiers.  Linux:Scraping the passwords from memory requires root privileges. Follow best practices in restricting access to privileged accounts to avoid hostile programs from accessing such sensitive regions of memory.

Name: Privileged Process Integrity
Description: On Windows 8.1 and Windows Server 2012 R2, enable Protected Process Light for LSA.

Name: User Training
Description: Limit credential overlap across accounts and systems by training users and administrators not to use the same password for multiple accounts.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used the BITS protocol to exfiltrate stolen data from a compromised host.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  used  BITSAdmin  to download and install payloads.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  has been downloaded via Windows BITS functionality.

Name: BITSAdmin
Description: BITSAdmin  can be used to create  BITS Jobs  to launch a malicious process.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can download a hosted "beacon" payload using  BITSAdmin .

Name: Egregor
Description: Egregor  has used BITSadmin to download and execute malicious DLLs.

Name: JPIN
Description: A  JPIN  variant downloads the backdoor payload via the BITS service.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has used  BITSAdmin  to download additional tools.

Name: MarkiRAT
Description: MarkiRAT  can use BITS Utility to connect with the C2 server.

Name: Patchwork
Description: Patchwork  has used BITS jobs to download malicious payloads.

Name: ProLock
Description: ProLock  can use BITS jobs to download its malicious payload.

Name: UBoatRAT
Description: UBoatRAT  takes advantage of the /SetNotifyCmdLine option in  BITSAdmin  to ensure it stays running on a system to maintain persistence.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used batch scripts that utilizes WMIC to execute a  BITSAdmin  transfer of a ransomware payload to each compromised machine.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Modify network and/or host firewall rules, as well as other network controls, to only allow legitimate BITS traffic.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Consider reducing the default BITS job lifetime in Group Policy or by editing the  JobInactivityTimeout  and  MaxDownloadTime  Registry values in   HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\BITS .

Name: User Account Management
Description: Consider limiting access to the BITS interface to specific users or groups.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: Configure SNMPv3 to use the highest level of security (authPriv) available.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Apply extended ACLs to block unauthorized protocols outside the trusted network.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Configure intrusion prevention devices to detect SNMP queries and commands from unauthorized sources.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Segregate SNMP traffic on a separate management network.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: Allowlist MIB objects and implement SNMP views.

Name: Update Software
Description: Keep system images and software updated and migrate to SNMPv3.

Name: AADInternals
Description: AADInternals  can execute commands on Azure virtual machines using the VM agent.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has used Azure Run Command and Azure Admin-on-Behalf-of (AOBO) to execute code on virtual machines.

Name: Pacu
Description: Pacu  can run commands on EC2 instances using AWS Systems Manager Run Command.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Limit the number of cloud accounts with permissions to remotely execute commands on virtual machines, and ensure that these are not used for day-to-day operations. In Azure, limit the number of accounts with the roles Azure Virtual Machine Contributer and above, and consider using temporary Just-in-Time (JIT) roles to avoid permanently assigning privileged access to virtual machines.   In Azure AD, limit the number of Global and Intune administrators to only those required. In AWS, limit users with permission to execute the  ssm:SendCommand  action, and use tags to restrict the number of machines those users can execute commands on.

Name: Audit
Description: Audit images deployed within the environment to ensure they do not contain any malicious components.

Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Description: Limit communications with the container service to local Unix sockets or remote access via SSH. Require secure port access to communicate with the APIs over TLS by disabling unauthenticated access to the Docker API on port 2375. Instead, communicate with the Docker API over TLS on port 2376.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Deny direct remote access to internal systems through the use of network proxies, gateways, and firewalls.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Ensure containers are not running as root by default. In Kubernetes environments, consider defining Pod Security Standards that prevent pods from running privileged containers.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  can steal data from the victim’s clipboard.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  used a Trojan called KEYLIME to collect data from the clipboard.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used tools capable of stealing contents of the clipboard.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  collects information from the clipboard by using the OpenClipboard() and GetClipboardData() libraries.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  has a plugin that collects data stored in the Windows clipboard by using the OpenClipboard and GetClipboardData APIs.

Name: Cadelspy
Description: Cadelspy  has the ability to steal data from the clipboard.

Name: Catchamas
Description: Catchamas  steals data stored in the clipboard.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  has the ability to capture and store clipboard data.

Name: CosmicDuke
Description: CosmicDuke  copies and exfiltrates the clipboard contents every 30 seconds.

Name: DarkComet
Description: DarkComet  can steal data from the clipboard.

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla  can download a clipboard information stealer module.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can harvest clipboard data on both Windows and macOS systems.

Name: Explosive
Description: Explosive  has a function to use the OpenClipboard wrapper.

Name: FlawedAmmyy
Description: FlawedAmmyy  can collect clipboard data.

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  can capture clipboard data from a compromised host.

Name: Helminth
Description: The executable version of  Helminth  has a module to log clipboard contents.

Name: JHUHUGIT
Description: A  JHUHUGIT  variant accesses a screenshot saved in the clipboard and converts it to a JPG image.

Name: jRAT
Description: jRAT  can capture clipboard data.

Name: Koadic
Description: Koadic  can retrieve the current content of the user clipboard.

Name: KONNI
Description: KONNI  had a feature to steal data from the clipboard.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  hijacks the clipboard data by creating an overlapped window that listens to keyboard events.

Name: MacSpy
Description: MacSpy  can steal clipboard contents.

Name: MarkiRAT
Description: MarkiRAT  can capture clipboard content.

Name: Melcoz
Description: Melcoz  can monitor content saved to the clipboard.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has a function to hijack data from the clipboard by monitoring the contents of the clipboard and replacing the cryptocurrency wallet with the attacker's.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors collected clipboard data in plaintext.

Name: Remcos
Description: Remcos  steals and modifies data from the clipboard.

Name: Remexi
Description: Remexi  collects text from the clipboard.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  can extract clipboard data from a compromised host.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  collects data from the clipboard.

Name: RunningRAT
Description: RunningRAT  contains code to open and copy data from the clipboard.

Name: TajMahal
Description: TajMahal  has the ability to steal data from the clipboard of an infected host.

Name: TinyZBot
Description: TinyZBot  contains functionality to collect information from the clipboard.

Name: VERMIN
Description: VERMIN  collects data stored in the clipboard.

Name: Zeus Panda
Description: Zeus Panda  can hook GetClipboardData function to watch for clipboard pastes to collect.

Name: Pacu
Description: Pacu  can enumerate AWS infrastructure, such as EC2 instances.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit permissions to discover cloud infrastructure in accordance with least privilege. Organizations should limit the number of users within the organization with an IAM role that has administrative privileges, strive to reduce all permanent privileged role assignments, and conduct periodic entitlement reviews on IAM users, roles and policies.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  has the ability to use RPC for lateral movement.

Name: Kivars
Description: Kivars  has the ability to remotely trigger keyboard input and mouse clicks.

Name: MacMa
Description: MacMa  can manage remote screen sessions.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  can propagate via peer-to-peer communication and updates using RPC.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used the WebDAV protocol to execute  Ryuk  payloads hosted on network file shares.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: If remote services, such as the ability to make direct connections to cloud virtual machines, are not required, disable these connection types where feasible.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Use multi-factor authentication on remote service logons where possible.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit the accounts that may use remote services. Limit the permissions for accounts that are at higher risk of compromise; for example, configure SSH so users can only run specific programs.

Name: Pacu
Description: Pacu  can enumerate AWS storage services, such as S3 buckets and Elastic Block Store volumes.

Name: Peirates
Description: Peirates  can list AWS S3 buckets.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Restrict granting of permissions related to listing objects in cloud storage to necessary accounts.

Name: AADInternals
Description: AADInternals  can enumerate information about a variety of cloud services, such as Office 365 and Sharepoint instances or OpenID Configurations.

Name: Pacu
Description: Pacu  can enumerate AWS services, such as CloudTrail and CloudWatch.

Name: ROADTools
Description: ROADTools  can enumerate Azure AD applications and service principals.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Enforce the principle of least-privilege by limiting dashboard visibility to only the resources required. This may limit the discovery value of the dashboard in the event of a compromised account.

Name: 3PARA RAT
Description: 3PARA RAT  has a command to retrieve metadata for files on disk as well as a command to list the current working directory.

Name: 4H RAT
Description: 4H RAT  has the capability to obtain file and directory listings.

Name: Action RAT
Description: Action RAT  has the ability to collect drive and file information on an infected machine.

Name: admin@338
Description: admin@338  actors used the following commands after exploiting a machine with  LOWBALL  malware to obtain information about files and directories:  dir c:\ >> %temp%\download   dir "c:\Documents and Settings" >> %temp%\download   dir "c:\Program Files\" >> %temp%\download   dir d:\ >> %temp%\download

Name: ADVSTORESHELL
Description: ADVSTORESHELL  can list files and directories.

Name: Amadey
Description: Amadey  has searched for folders associated with antivirus software.

Name: Aoqin Dragon
Description: Aoqin Dragon  has run scripts to identify file formats including Microsoft Word.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  has the ability to search for .txt, .ppt, .hwp, .pdf, and .doc files in specified directories.

Name: APT18
Description: APT18  can list files information for specific directories.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has used  Forfiles  to locate PDF, Excel, and Word documents during collection. The group also searched a compromised DCCC computer for specific terms.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  has a tool that looks for files and directories on the local file system.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32 's backdoor possesses the capability to list files and directories on a machine.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  have enumerated files and directories, or searched in specific locations within a compromised host.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used tools with the ability to search for files on a compromised host.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  has executed  file /bin/pwd  on exploited victims, perhaps to return architecture related information.

Name: Aria-body
Description: Aria-body  has the ability to gather metadata from a file and to search for file and directory names.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  has a plugin that enumerates files with specific extensions on all hard disk drives and stores file information in encrypted log files.

Name: AuditCred
Description: AuditCred  can search through folders and files on the system.

Name: AutoIt backdoor
Description: AutoIt backdoor  is capable of identifying documents on the victim with the following extensions: .doc; .pdf, .csv, .ppt, .docx, .pst, .xls, .xlsx, .pptx, and .jpeg.

Name: Avaddon
Description: Avaddon  has searched for specific files prior to encryption.

Name: Avenger
Description: Avenger  has the ability to browse files in directories such as Program Files and the Desktop.

Name: AvosLocker
Description: AvosLocker  has searched for files and directories on a compromised network.

Name: Azorult
Description: Azorult  can recursively search for files in folders and collects files from the desktop with certain extensions.

Name: Babuk
Description: Babuk  has the ability to enumerate files on a targeted system.

Name: BabyShark
Description: BabyShark  has used  dir  to search for "programfiles" and "appdata".

Name: BackConfig
Description: BackConfig  has the ability to identify folders and files related to previous infections.

Name: Backdoor.Oldrea
Description: Backdoor.Oldrea  collects information about available drives, default browser, desktop file list, My Documents, Internet history, program files, and root of available drives. It also searches for ICS-related software files.

Name: BACKSPACE
Description: BACKSPACE  allows adversaries to search for files.

Name: BADFLICK
Description: BADFLICK  has searched for files on the infected host.

Name: BADNEWS
Description: BADNEWS  identifies files with certain extensions from USB devices, then copies them to a predefined directory.

Name: BadPatch
Description: BadPatch  searches for files with specific file extensions.

Name: Bandook
Description: Bandook  has a command to list files on a system.

Name: Bankshot
Description: Bankshot  searches for files on the victim's machine.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can enumerate the victim's desktop.

Name: BBSRAT
Description: BBSRAT  can list file and directory information.

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal  can retrieve a file listing from the system.

Name: Black Basta
Description: Black Basta  can enumerate specific files for encryption.

Name: BlackCat
Description: BlackCat  can enumerate files for encryption.

Name: BLACKCOFFEE
Description: BLACKCOFFEE  has the capability to enumerate files.

Name: BlackEnergy
Description: BlackEnergy  gathers a list of installed apps from the uninstall program Registry. It also gathers registered mail, browser, and instant messaging clients from the Registry.  BlackEnergy  has searched for given file types.

Name: BlackMould
Description: BlackMould  has the ability to find files on the targeted system.

Name: BLINDINGCAN
Description: BLINDINGCAN  can search, read, write, move, and execute files.

Name: BLUELIGHT
Description: BLUELIGHT  can enumerate files and collect associated metadata.

Name: BoomBox
Description: BoomBox  can search for specific files and directories on a machine.

Name: BoxCaon
Description: BoxCaon  has searched for files on the system, such as documents located in the desktop folder.

Name: Brave Prince
Description: Brave Prince  gathers file and directory information from the victim’s machine.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  has collected a list of files from the victim and uploaded it to its C2 server, and then created a new list of specific files to steal.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors conducted a file listing discovery against multiple hosts to ensure locker encryption was successful.

Name: CaddyWiper
Description: CaddyWiper  can enumerate all files and directories on a compromised host.

Name: Cannon
Description: Cannon  can obtain victim drive information as well as a list of folders in C:\Program Files.

Name: Cardinal RAT
Description: Cardinal RAT  checks its current working directory upon execution and also contains watchdog functionality that ensures its executable is located in the correct path (else it will rewrite the payload).

Name: Caterpillar WebShell
Description: Caterpillar WebShell  can search for files in directories.

Name: ccf32
Description: ccf32  can parse collected files to identify specific file extensions.

Name: CharmPower
Description: CharmPower  can enumerate drives and list the contents of the C: drive on a victim's computer.

Name: ChChes
Description: ChChes  collects the victim's %TEMP% directory path and version of Internet Explorer.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has utilized multiple commands to identify data of interest in file and directory listings.

Name: China Chopper
Description: China Chopper 's server component can list directory contents.

Name: CHOPSTICK
Description: An older version of  CHOPSTICK  has a module that monitors all mounted volumes for files with the extensions .doc, .docx, .pgp, .gpg, .m2f, or .m2o.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  can browse directories on a compromised host.

Name: Clop
Description: Clop  has searched folders and subfolders for files to encrypt.

Name: cmd
Description: cmd  can be used to find files and directories with native functionality such as  dir  commands.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can explore files on a compromised system.

Name: Confucius
Description: Confucius  has used a file stealer that checks the Document, Downloads, Desktop, and Picture folders for documents and images with specific extensions.

Name: Conti
Description: Conti  can discover files on a local system.

Name: CookieMiner
Description: CookieMiner  has looked for files in the user's home directory with "wallet" in their name using  find .

Name: CORALDECK
Description: CORALDECK  searches for specified files.

Name: CosmicDuke
Description: CosmicDuke  searches attached and mounted drives for file extensions and keywords that match a predefined list.

Name: CrackMapExec
Description: CrackMapExec  can discover specified filetypes and log files on a targeted system.

Name: CreepyDrive
Description: CreepyDrive  can specify the local file path to upload files from.

Name: Crimson
Description: Crimson  contains commands to list files and directories, as well as search for files matching certain extensions from a defined list.

Name: CrossRAT
Description: CrossRAT  can list all files on a system.

Name: Cryptoistic
Description: Cryptoistic  can scan a directory to identify files for deletion.

Name: Cuba
Description: Cuba  can enumerate files by using a variety of functions.

Name: Cyclops Blink
Description: Cyclops Blink  can use the Linux API  statvfs  to enumerate the current working directory.

Name: Dacls
Description: Dacls  can scan directories on a compromised host.

Name: Dark Caracal
Description: Dark Caracal  collected file listings of all default Windows directories.

Name: Darkhotel
Description: Darkhotel  has used malware that searched for files with specific patterns.

Name: DarkWatchman
Description: DarkWatchman  has the ability to enumerate file and folder names.

Name: DDKONG
Description: DDKONG  lists files on the victim’s machine.

Name: DEATHRANSOM
Description: DEATHRANSOM  can use loop operations to enumerate directories on a compromised host.

Name: Denis
Description: Denis  has several commands to search directories for files.

Name: Derusbi
Description: Derusbi  is capable of obtaining directory, file, and drive listings.

Name: Diavol
Description: Diavol  has a command to traverse the files and directories in a given path.

Name: Doki
Description: Doki  has resolved the path of a process PID to use as a script argument.

Name: down_new
Description: down_new  has the ability to list the directories on a compromised host.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has used a batch script to gather folder and file names from victim hosts.

Name: DropBook
Description: DropBook  can collect the names of all files and folders in the Program Files directories.

Name: Dtrack
Description: Dtrack  can list files on available disk volumes.

Name: DustySky
Description: DustySky  scans the victim for files that contain certain keywords and document types including PDF, DOC, DOCX, XLS, and XLSX, from a list that is obtained from the C2 as a text file. It can also identify logical drives for the infected machine.

Name: Ebury
Description: Ebury  can list directory entries.

Name: Elise
Description: A variant of  Elise  executes  dir C:\progra~1  when initially run.

Name: ELMER
Description: ELMER  is capable of performing directory listings.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  includes various modules for finding files of interest on hosts and network shares.

Name: Epic
Description: Epic  recursively searches for all .doc files on the system and collects a directory listing of the Desktop, %TEMP%, and %WINDOWS%\Temp directories.

Name: FALLCHILL
Description: FALLCHILL  can search files on a victim.

Name: FatDuke
Description: FatDuke  can enumerate directories on target machines.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has used the Windows  dir  command to enumerate files and directories in a victim's network.

Name: FinFisher
Description: FinFisher  enumerates directories and scans for certain files.

Name: FIVEHANDS
Description: FIVEHANDS  has the ability to enumerate files on a compromised host in order to encrypt files with specific extensions.

Name: FLASHFLOOD
Description: FLASHFLOOD  searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on the local system and removable media.

Name: FoggyWeb
Description: FoggyWeb 's loader can check for the  FoggyWeb  backdoor .pri file on a compromised AD FS server.

Name: Forfiles
Description: Forfiles  can be used to locate certain types of files/directories in a system.(ex: locate all files with a specific extension, name, and/or age)

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has used WizTree to obtain network files and directory listings.

Name: FruitFly
Description: FruitFly  looks for specific files and file types.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: FunnyDream  can identify files with .doc, .docx, .ppt, .pptx, .xls, .xlsx, and .pdf extensions and specific timestamps for collection.

Name: FYAnti
Description: FYAnti  can search the  C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\  directory for files of a specified size.

Name: Fysbis
Description: Fysbis  has the ability to search for files.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  macros can scan for Microsoft Word and Excel files to inject with additional malicious macros.  Gamaredon Group  has also used its backdoors to automatically list interesting files (such as Office documents) found on a system.

Name: Gelsemium
Description: Gelsemium  can retrieve data from specific Windows directories, as well as open random files as part of  Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion .

Name: GeminiDuke
Description: GeminiDuke  collects information from the victim, including installed drivers, programs previously executed by users, programs and services configured to automatically run at startup, files and folders present in any user's home folder, files and folders present in any user's My Documents, programs installed to the Program Files folder, and recently accessed files, folders, and programs.

Name: Gold Dragon
Description: Gold Dragon  lists the directories for Desktop, program files, and the user’s recently accessed files.

Name: GoldenSpy
Description: GoldenSpy  has included a program "ExeProtector", which monitors for the existence of  GoldenSpy  on the infected system and redownloads if necessary.

Name: GravityRAT
Description: GravityRAT  collects the volumes mapped on the system, and also steals files with the following extensions: .docx, .doc, .pptx, .ppt, .xlsx, .xls, .rtf, and .pdf.

Name: GrimAgent
Description: GrimAgent  has the ability to enumerate files and directories on a compromised host.

Name: HAFNIUM
Description: HAFNIUM  has searched file contents on a compromised host.

Name: HermeticWiper
Description: HermeticWiper  can enumerate common folders such as My Documents, Desktop, and AppData.

Name: Heyoka Backdoor
Description: Heyoka Backdoor  has the ability to search the compromised host for files.

Name: HOPLIGHT
Description: HOPLIGHT  has been observed enumerating system drives and partitions.

Name: HotCroissant
Description: HotCroissant  has the ability to retrieve a list of files in a given directory as well as drives and drive types.

Name: HTTPBrowser
Description: HTTPBrowser  is capable of listing files, folders, and drives on a victim.

Name: Hydraq
Description: Hydraq  creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can check for the existence of files, including its own components, as well as retrieve a list of logical drives.

Name: IceApple
Description: The  IceApple  Directory Lister module can list information about files and directories including creation time, last write time, name, and size.

Name: Imminent Monitor
Description: Imminent Monitor  has a dynamic debugging feature to check whether it is located in the %TEMP% directory, otherwise it copies itself there.

Name: Inception
Description: Inception  used a file listing plugin to collect information about file and directories both on local and remote drives.

Name: Industroyer
Description: Industroyer ’s data wiper component enumerates specific files on all the Windows drives.

Name: InnaputRAT
Description: InnaputRAT  enumerates directories and obtains file attributes on a system.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can list information about files in a directory and recently opened or used documents.  InvisiMole  can also search for specific files by supplied file mask.

Name: Ixeshe
Description: Ixeshe  can list file and directory information.

Name: JPIN
Description: JPIN  can enumerate drives and their types. It can also change file permissions using cacls.exe.

Name: jRAT
Description: jRAT  can browse file systems.

Name: Kasidet
Description: Kasidet  has the ability to search for a given filename on a victim.

Name: Kazuar
Description: Kazuar  finds a specified directory, lists the files and metadata about those files.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  uses command-line interaction to search files and directories.

Name: KeyBoy
Description: KeyBoy  has a command to launch a file browser or explorer on the system.

Name: KEYMARBLE
Description: KEYMARBLE  has a command to search for files on the victim’s machine.

Name: KGH_SPY
Description: KGH_SPY  can enumerate files and directories on a compromised host.

Name: KillDisk
Description: KillDisk  has used the  FindNextFile  command as part of its file deletion process.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has the ability to enumerate all files and directories on an infected system.

Name: Kinsing
Description: Kinsing  has used the find command to search for specific files.

Name: Kivars
Description: Kivars  has the ability to list drives on the infected host.

Name: Koadic
Description: Koadic  can obtain a list of directories.

Name: KONNI
Description: A version of  KONNI  searches for filenames created with a previous version of the malware, suggesting different versions targeted the same victims and the versions may work together.

Name: Kwampirs
Description: Kwampirs  collects a list of files and directories in C:\ with the command  dir /s /a c:\ >> "C:\windows\TEMP.tmp" .

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  malware can use a common function to identify target files by their extension, and some also enumerate files and directories, including a Destover-like variant that lists files and gathers information for all drives.

Name: Leafminer
Description: Leafminer  used a tool called MailSniper to search for files on the desktop and another utility called Sobolsoft to extract attachments from EML files.

Name: Linfo
Description: Linfo  creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can list contents of drives and search for files.

Name: Lokibot
Description: Lokibot  can search for specific files on an infected host.

Name: LookBack
Description: LookBack  can retrieve file listings from the victim machine.

Name: LuminousMoth
Description: LuminousMoth  has used malware that scans for files in the Documents, Desktop, and Download folders and in other drives.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  produces file listings in order to search for files to be exfiltrated.

Name: MacMa
Description: MacMa  can search for a specific file on the compromised computer and can enumerate files in Desktop, Downloads, and Documents folders.

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can search for files and directories.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  malware can list a victim's logical drives and the type, as well the total/free space of the fixed devices. Other malware can list a directory's contents.

Name: MarkiRAT
Description: MarkiRAT  can look for files carrying specific extensions such as: .rtf, .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .ppt, .pptx, .pps, .ppsx, .txt, .gpg, .pkr, .kdbx, .key, and .jpb.

Name: MegaCortex
Description: MegaCortex  can parse the available drives and directories to determine which files to encrypt.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has searched compromised systems for folders of interest including those related to HR, audit and expense, and meeting memos.

Name: MESSAGETAP
Description: MESSAGETAP  checks for the existence of two configuration files (keyword_parm.txt and parm.txt) and attempts to read the files every 30 seconds.

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  can recursively enumerate files in an operator-provided directory.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has searched the Program Files directories for specific folders and has searched for strings related to its mutexes.

Name: Micropsia
Description: Micropsia  can perform a recursive directory listing for all volume drives available on the victim's machine and can also fetch specific files by their paths.

Name: MiniDuke
Description: MiniDuke  can enumerate local drives.

Name: Misdat
Description: Misdat  is capable of running commands to obtain a list of files and directories, as well as enumerating logical drives.

Name: MobileOrder
Description: MobileOrder  has a command to upload to its C2 server information about files on the victim mobile device, including SD card size, installed app list, SMS content, contacts, and calling history.

Name: MoonWind
Description: MoonWind  has a command to return a directory listing for a specified directory.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has used malware that checked if the ProgramData folder had folders or files with the keywords "Kasper," "Panda," or "ESET."

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has searched the entire target system for DOC, DOCX, PPT, PPTX, XLS, XLSX, and PDF files.

Name: NDiskMonitor
Description: NDiskMonitor  can obtain a list of all files and directories as well as logical drives.

Name: Nebulae
Description: Nebulae  can list files and directories on a compromised host.

Name: NETEAGLE
Description: NETEAGLE  allows adversaries to enumerate and modify the infected host's file system. It supports searching for directories, creating directories, listing directory contents, reading and writing to files, retrieving file attributes, and retrieving volume information.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  has the ability to search for files on the compromised host.

Name: Night Dragon
Description: During  Night Dragon , threat actors used  zwShell  to establish full remote control of the connected machine and browse the victim file system.

Name: NightClub
Description: NightClub  can use a file monitor to identify .lnk, .doc, .docx, .xls, .xslx, and .pdf files.

Name: njRAT
Description: njRAT  can browse file systems using a file manager module.

Name: NotPetya
Description: NotPetya  searches for files ending with dozens of different file extensions prior to encryption.

Name: ObliqueRAT
Description: ObliqueRAT  has the ability to recursively enumerate files on an infected endpoint.

Name: OceanSalt
Description: OceanSalt  can extract drive information from the endpoint and search files on the system.

Name: Octopus
Description: Octopus  can collect information on the Windows directory and searches for compressed RAR files on the host.

Name: Okrum
Description: Okrum  has used DriveLetterView to enumerate drive information.

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , the threat actors used  dir c:\\  to search for files.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  conducted word searches within documents on a compromised host in search of security and financial matters.

Name: Operation Honeybee
Description: During  Operation Honeybee , the threat actors used a malicious DLL to search for files with specific keywords.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors gathered a recursive directory listing to find files and directories of interest.

Name: Orz
Description: Orz  can gather victim drive information.

Name: OSX/Shlayer
Description: OSX/Shlayer  has used the command  appDir="$(dirname $(dirname "$currentDir"))"  and  $(dirname "$(pwd -P)")  to construct installation paths.

Name: OutSteel
Description: OutSteel  can search for specific file extensions, including zipped files.

Name: OwaAuth
Description: OwaAuth  has a command to list its directory and logical drives.

Name: P.A.S. Webshell
Description: P.A.S. Webshell  has the ability to list files and file characteristics including extension, size, ownership, and permissions.

Name: Pasam
Description: Pasam  creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve lists of files.

Name: Patchwork
Description: A  Patchwork  payload has searched all fixed drives on the victim for files matching a specified list of extensions.

Name: Penquin
Description: Penquin  can use the command code  do_vslist  to send file names, size, and status to C2.

Name: Peppy
Description: Peppy  can identify specific files for exfiltration.

Name: PinchDuke
Description: PinchDuke  searches for files created within a certain timeframe and whose file extension matches a predefined list.

Name: PingPull
Description: PingPull  can enumerate storage volumes and folder contents of a compromised host.

Name: Pisloader
Description: Pisloader  has commands to list drives on the victim machine and to list file information for a given directory.

Name: PLEAD
Description: PLEAD  has the ability to list drives and files on the compromised host.

Name: PlugX
Description: PlugX  has a module to enumerate drives and find files recursively.

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  has the ability to list files upon receiving the  ls  command from C2.

Name: POORAIM
Description: POORAIM  can conduct file browsing.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  can enumerate files on the local file system and includes a module for enumerating recently accessed files.

Name: PowerDuke
Description: PowerDuke  has commands to get the current directory name as well as the size of a file. It also has commands to obtain information about logical drives, drive type, and free space.

Name: POWRUNER
Description: POWRUNER  may enumerate user directories on a victim.

Name: Prestige
Description: Prestige  can traverse the file system to discover files to encrypt by identifying specific extensions defined in a hardcoded list.

Name: Prikormka
Description: A module in  Prikormka  collects information about the paths, size, and creation time of files with specific file extensions, but not the actual content of the file.

Name: Proxysvc
Description: Proxysvc  lists files in directories.

Name: Psylo
Description: Psylo  has commands to enumerate all storage devices and to find all files that start with a particular string.

Name: Pteranodon
Description: Pteranodon  identifies files matching certain file extension and copies them to subdirectories it created.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  can walk through directories and recursively search for strings in files.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can identify whether it has been run previously on a host by checking for a specified folder.

Name: QuietSieve
Description: QuietSieve  can search files on the target host by extension, including doc, docx, xls, rtf, odt, txt, jpg, pdf, rar, zip, and 7z.

Name: RainyDay
Description: RainyDay  can use a file exfiltration tool to collect recently changed files with specific extensions.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can collect directory and file lists.

Name: RARSTONE
Description: RARSTONE  obtains installer properties from Uninstall Registry Key entries to obtain information about installed applications and how to uninstall certain applications.

Name: Rclone
Description: Rclone  can list files and directories with the  ls ,  lsd , and  lsl  commands.

Name: RedLeaves
Description: RedLeaves  can enumerate and search for files and directories.

Name: Remcos
Description: Remcos  can search for files on the infected machine.

Name: Remexi
Description: Remexi  searches for files on the system.

Name: RemoteUtilities
Description: RemoteUtilities  can enumerate files and directories on a target machine.

Name: Remsec
Description: Remsec  is capable of listing contents of folders on the victim.  Remsec  also searches for custom network encryption software on victims.

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  has the ability to identify specific files and directories that are not to be encrypted.

Name: Rising Sun
Description: Rising Sun  can enumerate information about files from the infected system, including file size, attributes, creation time, last access time, and write time.  Rising Sun  can enumerate the compilation timestamp of Windows executable files.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  has the ability to gather a list of files and directories on the infected system.

Name: Rover
Description: Rover  automatically searches for files on local drives based on a predefined list of file extensions.

Name: Royal
Description: Royal  can identify specific files and directories to exclude from the encryption process.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  can check for specific files and directories associated with virtualization and malware analysis.

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  has enumerated files and folders on all mounted drives.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  can search a compromised host for specific files.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has enumerated files on a compromised host.

Name: SDBbot
Description: SDBbot  has the ability to get directory listings or drive information on a compromised host.

Name: Seasalt
Description: Seasalt  has the capability to identify the drive type on a victim.

Name: SharpDisco
Description: SharpDisco  can identify recently opened files by using an LNK format parser to extract the original file path from LNK files found in either  %USERPROFILE%\Recent  (Windows XP) or  %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Recent  (newer Windows versions) .

Name: ShimRat
Description: ShimRat  can list directories.

Name: SHOTPUT
Description: SHOTPUT  has a command to obtain a directory listing.

Name: SideTwist
Description: SideTwist  has the ability to search for specific files.

Name: Sidewinder
Description: Sidewinder  has used malware to collect information on files and directories.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  has several modules, such as  ls.py ,  pwd.py , and  recentFiles.py , to enumerate directories and files.

Name: Siloscape
Description: Siloscape  searches for the Kubernetes config file and other related files using a regular expression.

Name: Skidmap
Description: Skidmap  has checked for the existence of specific files including  /usr/sbin/setenforce  and   /etc/selinux/config . It also has the ability to monitor the cryptocurrency miner file and process.

Name: Sliver
Description: Sliver  can enumerate files on a target system.

Name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
Description: SLOTHFULMEDIA  can enumerate files and directories.

Name: Smoke Loader
Description: Smoke Loader  recursively searches through directories for files.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  obtained information about the configured Exchange virtual directory using  Get-WebServicesVirtualDirectory .

Name: SombRAT
Description: SombRAT  can execute  enum  to enumerate files in storage on a compromised system.

Name: SoreFang
Description: SoreFang  has the ability to list directories.

Name: SOUNDBITE
Description: SOUNDBITE  is capable of enumerating and manipulating files and directories.

Name: Sowbug
Description: Sowbug  identified and extracted all Word documents on a server by using a command containing * .doc and *.docx. The actors also searched for documents based on a specific date range and attempted to identify all installed software on a victim.

Name: SPACESHIP
Description: SPACESHIP  identifies files and directories for collection by searching for specific file extensions or file modification time.

Name: StreamEx
Description: StreamEx  has the ability to enumerate drive types.

Name: StrifeWater
Description: StrifeWater  can enumerate files on a compromised host.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  can parse the hard drive on a compromised host to identify specific file extensions.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  uses a driver to scan for specific filesystem driver objects.

Name: SUGARDUMP
Description: SUGARDUMP  can search for and collect data from specific Chrome, Opera, Microsoft Edge, and Firefox files, including any folders that have the string  Profile  in its name.

Name: SUNBURST
Description: SUNBURST  had commands to enumerate files and directories.

Name: SUNSPOT
Description: SUNSPOT  enumerated the Orion software Visual Studio solution directory path.

Name: SynAck
Description: SynAck  checks its directory location in an attempt to avoid launching in a sandbox.

Name: SysUpdate
Description: SysUpdate  can search files on a compromised host.

Name: Taidoor
Description: Taidoor  can search for specific files.

Name: TAINTEDSCRIBE
Description: TAINTEDSCRIBE  can use  DirectoryList  to enumerate files in a specified directory.

Name: TajMahal
Description: TajMahal  has the ability to index files from drives, user profiles, and removable drives.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has used a script that checks  /proc/*/environ  for environment variables related to AWS.

Name: ThreatNeedle
Description: ThreatNeedle  can obtain file and directory information.

Name: TINYTYPHON
Description: TINYTYPHON  searches through the drive containing the OS, then all drive letters C through to Z, for documents matching certain extensions.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  searches the system for all of the following file extensions: .avi, .mov, .mkv, .mpeg, .mpeg4, .mp4, .mp3, .wav, .ogg, .jpeg, .jpg, .png, .bmp, .gif, .tiff, .ico, .xlsx, and .zip. It can also obtain browsing history, cookies, and plug-in information.

Name: Trojan.Karagany
Description: Trojan.Karagany  can enumerate files and directories on a compromised host.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has monitored files' modified time.

Name: TSCookie
Description: TSCookie  has the ability to discover drive information on the infected host.

Name: Turian
Description: Turian  can search for specific files and list directories.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  surveys a system upon check-in to discover files in specific locations on the hard disk %TEMP% directory, the current user's desktop, the Program Files directory, and Recent.     Turla  RPC backdoors have also searched for files matching the  lPH*.dll  pattern.

Name: TYPEFRAME
Description: TYPEFRAME  can search directories for files on the victim’s machine.

Name: UPPERCUT
Description: UPPERCUT  has the capability to gather the victim's current directory.

Name: Uroburos

Name: USBferry

Name: USBStealer

Name: Volgmer
Description: Volgmer  can list directories on a victim.

Name: WannaCry
Description: WannaCry  searches for variety of user files by file extension before encrypting them using RSA and AES, including Office, PDF, image, audio, video, source code, archive/compression format, and key and certificate files.

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  can enumerate directories on a compromise host.

Name: WastedLocker
Description: WastedLocker  can enumerate files and directories just prior to encryption.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  can locate files based on hardcoded file extensions.

Name: Windigo
Description: Windigo  has used a script to check for the presence of files created by OpenSSH backdoors.

Name: WindTail
Description: WindTail  has the ability to enumerate the users home directory and the path to its own application bundle.

Name: WINERACK
Description: WINERACK  can enumerate files and directories.

Name: WinMM
Description: WinMM  sets a WH_CBT Windows hook to search for and capture files on the victim.

Name: Winnti for Windows
Description: Winnti for Windows  can check for the presence of specific files prior to moving to the next phase of execution.

Name: Winnti Group
Description: Winnti Group  has used a program named ff.exe to search for specific documents on compromised hosts.

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  can list all files and their associated attributes, including filename, type, owner, creation time, last access time, last write time, size, and permissions.

Name: XAgentOSX
Description: XAgentOSX  contains the readFiles function to return a detailed listing (sometimes recursive) of a specified directory.    XAgentOSX  contains the showBackupIosFolder function to check for IOS device backups by running  ls -la ~/Library/Application\ Support/MobileSync/Backup/ .

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  has used  mdfind  to enumerate a list of apps known to grant screen sharing permissions.

Name: yty
Description: yty  gathers information on victim’s drives and has a plugin for document listing.

Name: Zebrocy
Description: Zebrocy  searches for files that are 60mb and less and contain the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .ppt, .pptx, .exe, .zip, and .rar.  Zebrocy  also runs the  echo %APPDATA%  command to list the contents of the directory.      Zebrocy  can obtain the current execution path as well as perform drive enumeration.

Name: Zeus Panda
Description: Zeus Panda  searches for specific directories on the victim’s machine.

Name: ZLib
Description: ZLib  has the ability to enumerate files and drives.

Name: Zox
Description: Zox  can enumerate files on a compromised host.

Name: zwShell
Description: zwShell  can browse the file system.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  has a command to open a file manager and explorer on the system.

Name: ADVSTORESHELL
Description: ADVSTORESHELL  is capable of starting a process using CreateProcess.

Name: Amadey
Description: Amadey  has used a variety of Windows API calls, including  GetComputerNameA ,  GetUserNameA , and  CreateProcessA .

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  has the ability to use multiple dynamically resolved API calls.

Name: APT37
Description: APT37  leverages the Windows API calls: VirtualAlloc(), WriteProcessMemory(), and CreateRemoteThread() for process injection.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has used the Windows API to execute code within a victim's system.

Name: Aria-body
Description: Aria-body  has the ability to launch files using  ShellExecute .

Name: AsyncRAT
Description: AsyncRAT  has the ability to use OS APIs including  CheckRemoteDebuggerPresent .

Name: Attor

Name: Avaddon

Name: AvosLocker

Name: Babuk

Name: BackConfig

Name: Bad Rabbit

Name: Bandook

Name: Bankshot

Name: Bazar

Name: BBK

Name: BendyBear

Name: BitPaymer

Name: Black Basta

Name: BloodHound

Name: LitePower
Description: LitePower  can use various API calls.

Description: Uroburos  can use native Windows APIs including  GetHostByName .

Name: Ursnif

Name: Volgmer
Description: Volgmer  executes payloads using the Windows API call CreateProcessW().

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  can use a variety of API calls on a compromised host.

Name: WastedLocker
Description: WastedLocker 's custom crypter, CryptOne, leveraged the VirtualAlloc() API function to help execute the payload.

Name: Waterbear
Description: Waterbear  can leverage API functions for execution.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  has used the  ExitWindowsEx  to flush file buffers to disk and stop running processes and other API calls.

Name: WindTail
Description: WindTail  can invoke Apple APIs  contentsOfDirectoryAtPath ,  pathExtension , and (string)  compare .

Name: Winnti for Windows
Description: Winnti for Windows  can use Native API to create a new process and to start services.

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  can use multiple native APIs, including  WriteProcessMemory ,  CreateProcess , and  CreateRemoteThread  for process injection.

Name: XAgentOSX
Description: XAgentOSX  contains the execFile function to execute a specified file on the system using the NSTask:launch method.

Name: xCaon

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  can leverage native API including  RegisterServiceCtrlHandler   to register a service.RegisterServiceCtrlHandler

Name: ZxxZ
