Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: On Windows 10, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to prevent Office VBA macros from calling Win32 APIs.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Identify and block potentially malicious software executed that may be executed through this technique by using application control    tools, like Windows Defender Application Control  , AppLocker,       or Software Restriction Policies    where appropriate.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Name: Agent.btz
Description: Agent.btz  drops itself onto removable media devices and creates an autorun.inf file with an instruction to run that file. When the device is inserted into another system, it opens autorun.inf and loads the malware.

Name: ANDROMEDA
Description: ANDROMEDA  has been spread via infected USB keys.

Name: Aoqin Dragon
Description: Aoqin Dragon  has used a dropper that employs a worm infection strategy using a removable device to breach a secure network environment.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  uses a tool to infect connected USB devices and transmit itself to air-gapped computers when the infected USB device is inserted.

Name: CHOPSTICK
Description: Part of  APT28 's operation involved using  CHOPSTICK  modules to copy itself to air-gapped machines and using files written to USB sticks to transfer data and command traffic.

Name: Conficker
Description: Conficker  variants used the Windows AUTORUN feature to spread through USB propagation.

Name: Crimson
Description: Crimson  can spread across systems by infecting removable media.

Name: Darkhotel
Description: Darkhotel 's selective infector modifies executables stored on removable media as a method of spreading across computers.

Name: DustySky
Description: DustySky  searches for removable media and duplicates itself onto it.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  actors have mailed USB drives to potential victims containing malware that downloads and installs various backdoors, including in some cases for ransomware operations.

Name: Flame
Description: Flame  contains modules to infect USB sticks and spread laterally to other Windows systems the stick is plugged into using Autorun functionality.

Name: H1N1
Description: H1N1  has functionality to copy itself to removable media.

Name: LuminousMoth
Description: LuminousMoth  has used malicious DLLs to spread malware to connected removable USB drives on infected machines.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has used a customized  PlugX  variant which could spread through USB connections.

Name: njRAT
Description: njRAT  can be configured to spread via removable drives.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  has the ability to use removable drives to spread through compromised networks.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can spread itself by infecting other portable executable files on removable drives.

Name: SHIPSHAPE
Description: APT30  may have used the  SHIPSHAPE  malware to move onto air-gapped networks.  SHIPSHAPE  targets removable drives to spread to other systems by modifying the drive to use Autorun to execute or by hiding legitimate document files and copying an executable to the folder with the same name as the legitimate document.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  can propagate via removable media using an autorun.inf file or the CVE-2010-2568 LNK vulnerability.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has attempted to transfer  USBferry  from an infected USB device by copying an Autorun function to the target machine.

Name: Unknown Logger
Description: Unknown Logger  is capable of spreading to USB devices.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has copied itself to and infected removable drives for propagation.

Name: USBferry
Description: USBferry  can copy its installer to attached USB storage devices.

Name: USBStealer
Description: USBStealer  drops itself onto removable media and relies on Autorun to execute the malicious file when a user opens the removable media on another system.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: On Windows 10, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to block unsigned/untrusted executable files (such as .exe, .dll, or .scr) from running from USB removable drives.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable Autorun if it is unnecessary.    Disallow or restrict removable media at an organizational policy level if it is not required for business operations.

Name: Limit Hardware Installation
Description: Limit the use of USB devices and removable media within a network.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  uses a tool that captures information from air-gapped computers via an infected USB and transfers it to network-connected computer when the USB is inserted.

Name: CHOPSTICK
Description: Part of  APT28 's operation involved using  CHOPSTICK  modules to copy itself to air-gapped machines, using files written to USB sticks to transfer data and command traffic.

Name: USBStealer
Description: USBStealer  drops commands for a second victim onto a removable media drive inserted into the first victim, and commands are executed when the drive is inserted into the second victim.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable Autoruns if it is unnecessary.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Disallow or restrict removable media at an organizational policy level if they are not required for business operations.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  was executed through the kubelet API run command and by executing commands on running containers.

Name: Kinsing
Description: Kinsing  was executed with an Ubuntu container entry point that runs shell scripts.

Name: Peirates
Description: Peirates  can use  kubectl  or the Kubernetes API to run commands.

Name: Siloscape
Description: Siloscape  can send kubectl commands to victim clusters through an IRC channel and can run kubectl locally to spread once within a victim cluster.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  executed  Hildegard  through the kubelet API run command and by executing commands on running containers.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Remove unnecessary tools and software from containers.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use read-only containers, read-only file systems, and minimal images when possible to prevent the execution of commands.   Where possible, also consider using application control and software restriction tools (such as those provided by SELinux) to restrict access to files, processes, and system calls in containers.

Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Description: Limit communications with the container service to managed and secured channels, such as local Unix sockets or remote access via SSH. Require secure port access to communicate with the APIs over TLS by disabling unauthenticated access to the Docker API and Kubernetes API Server.    In Kubernetes clusters deployed in cloud environments, use native cloud platform features to restrict the IP ranges that are permitted to access to API server.   Where possible, consider enabling just-in-time (JIT) access to the Kubernetes API to place additional restrictions on access.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Ensure containers are not running as root by default. In Kubernetes environments, consider defining Pod Security Standards that prevent pods from running privileged containers and using the  NodeRestriction  admission controller to deny the kublet access to nodes and pods outside of the node it belongs to.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Enforce authentication and role-based access control on the container service to restrict users to the least privileges required.   When using Kubernetes, avoid giving users wildcard permissions or adding users to the  system:masters  group, and use  RoleBindings  rather than  ClusterRoleBindings  to limit user privileges to specific namespaces.

Name: 2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  used a trojanized version of Windows Notepad to add a layer of persistence for  Industroyer .

Name: Bonadan
Description: Bonadan  has maliciously altered the OpenSSH binary on targeted systems to create a backdoor.

Name: Ebury
Description: Ebury  has been embedded into modified OpenSSH binaries to gain persistent access to SSH credential information.

Name: Industroyer
Description: Industroyer  has used a Trojanized version of the Windows Notepad application for an additional backdoor persistence mechanism.

Name: Kessel
Description: Kessel  has maliciously altered the OpenSSH binary on targeted systems to create a backdoor.

Name: Kobalos
Description: Kobalos  replaced the SSH client with a trojanized SSH client to steal credentials on compromised systems.

Name: ThiefQuest
Description: ThiefQuest  searches through the  /Users/  folder looking for executable files. For each executable,  ThiefQuest  prepends a copy of itself to the beginning of the file. When the file is executed, the  ThiefQuest  code is executed first.  ThiefQuest  creates a hidden file, copies the original target executable to the file, then executes the new hidden file to maintain the appearance of normal behavior.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  uses a malicious browser application to replace the legitimate browser in order to continuously capture credentials, monitor web traffic, and download additional modules.

Name: Code Signing
Description: Ensure all application component binaries are signed by the correct application developers.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has used spearphishing to compromise credentials.

Name: Scattered Spider
Description: Scattered Spider  has used a combination of credential phishing and social engineering to capture one-time-password (OTP) codes.

Name: ZIRCONIUM
Description: ZIRCONIUM  targeted presidential campaign staffers with credential phishing e-mails.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: Use anti-spoofing and email authentication mechanisms to filter messages based on validity checks of the sender domain (using SPF) and integrity of messages (using DKIM). Enabling these mechanisms within an organization (through policies such as DMARC) may enable recipients (intra-org and cross domain) to perform similar message filtering and validation.

Name: User Training
Description: Users can be trained to identify social engineering techniques and spearphishing attempts.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has used masscan to search for kubelets and the kubelet API for additional running containers.

Name: Peirates
Description: Peirates  can enumerate Kubernetes pods in a given namespace.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has checked for running containers with  docker ps  and for specific container names with  docker inspect .    TeamTNT  has also searched for Kubernetes pods running in a local network.

Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Description: Limit communications with the container service to managed and secured channels, such as local Unix sockets or remote access via SSH. Require secure port access to communicate with the APIs over TLS by disabling unauthenticated access to the Docker API and Kubernetes API Server.    In Kubernetes clusters deployed in cloud environments, use native cloud platform features to restrict the IP ranges that are permitted to access to API server.   Where possible, consider enabling just-in-time (JIT) access to the Kubernetes API to place additional restrictions on access.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Deny direct remote access to internal systems through the use of network proxies, gateways, and firewalls.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Enforce the principle of least privilege by limiting dashboard visibility to only the required users. When using Kubernetes, avoid giving users wildcard permissions or adding users to the  system:masters  group, and use  RoleBindings  rather than  ClusterRoleBindings  to limit user privileges to specific namespaces.

Name: APT17
Description: APT17  has created and cultivated profile pages in Microsoft TechNet. To make profile pages appear more legitimate,  APT17  has created biographical sections and posted in forum threads.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has created KeyBase accounts to communicate with ransomware victims.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Name: Disco
Description: Disco  has achieved initial access and execution through content injection into DNS,  HTTP, and SMB replies to targeted hosts that redirect them to download malicious files.

Name: MoustachedBouncer
Description: MoustachedBouncer  has injected content into DNS, HTTP, and SMB replies to redirect specifically-targeted victims to a fake Windows Update page to download malware.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: Where possible, ensure that online traffic is appropriately encrypted through services such as trusted VPNs.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: Consider blocking download/transfer and execution of potentially uncommon file types known to be used in adversary campaigns.

Name: Exaramel for Linux
Description: Exaramel for Linux  has a hardcoded location that it uses to achieve persistence if the startup system is Upstart or System V and it is running as root.

Name: Audit
Description: Use auditing tools capable of detecting privilege and service abuse opportunities on systems within an enterprise and correct them.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: On Windows 10, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to prevent an application from writing a signed vulnerable driver to the system.   On Windows 10 and 11, enable Microsoft Vulnerable Driver Blocklist to assist in hardening against third party-developed drivers.

Name: Code Signing
Description: Enforce registration and execution of only legitimately signed service drivers where possible.

Name: Limit Software Installation
Description: Restrict software installation to trusted repositories only and be cautious of orphaned software packages.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Ensure that Driver Signature Enforcement is enabled to restrict unsigned drivers from being installed.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Restrict read/write access to system-level process files to only select privileged users who have a legitimate need to manage system services.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit privileges of user accounts and groups so that only authorized administrators can interact with system-level process changes and service configurations.

Name: 2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  added a login to a SQL Server with  sp_addlinkedsrvlogin .

Name: Indrik Spider
Description: Indrik Spider  used  wmic.exe  to add a new user to the system.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Use multi-factor authentication for user and privileged accounts.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Configure access controls and firewalls to limit access to domain controllers and systems used to create and manage accounts.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Protect domain controllers by ensuring proper security configuration for critical servers.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Limit the number of accounts with permissions to create other accounts. Do not allow domain administrator accounts to be used for day-to-day operations that may expose them to potential adversaries on unprivileged systems.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  has the ability to steal credentials from FTP clients and wireless profiles.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has used a variety of publicly available tools like  LaZagne  to gather credentials.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used the Smartftp Password Decryptor tool to decrypt FTP passwords.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  uses an external software known as NetPass to recover passwords.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp 's passw.plug plugin can gather account information from multiple instant messaging, email, and social media services, as well as FTP, VNC, and VPN clients.

Name: CosmicDuke
Description: CosmicDuke  collects user credentials, including passwords, for various programs including popular instant messaging applications and email clients as well as WLAN keys.

Name: Evilnum
Description: Evilnum  can collect email credentials from victims.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has used the Stealer One credential stealer to target e-mail and file transfer utilities including FTP.

Name: HEXANE
Description: HEXANE  has run  cmdkey  on victim machines to identify stored credentials.

Name: KGH_SPY
Description: KGH_SPY  can collect credentials from WINSCP.

Name: LaZagne
Description: LaZagne  can obtain credentials from databases, mail, and WiFi across multiple platforms.

Name: Leafminer
Description: Leafminer  used several tools for retrieving login and password information, including LaZagne.

Name: Lokibot
Description: Lokibot  has stolen credentials from multiple applications and data sources including Windows OS credentials, email clients, FTP, and SFTP clients.

Name: Matryoshka
Description: Matryoshka  is capable of stealing Outlook passwords.

Name: Mimikatz
Description: Mimikatz  performs credential dumping to obtain account and password information useful in gaining access to additional systems and enterprise network resources. It contains functionality to acquire information about credentials in many ways, including from the credential vault and DPAPI.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has performed credential dumping with  LaZagne  and other tools, including by dumping passwords saved in victim email.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can retrieve passwords from messaging and mail client applications.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used credential dumping tools such as  LaZagne  to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.

Name: OLDBAIT
Description: OLDBAIT  collects credentials from several email clients.

Name: PinchDuke
Description: PinchDuke  steals credentials from compromised hosts.  PinchDuke 's credential stealing functionality is believed to be based on the source code of the Pinch credential stealing malware (also known as LdPinch). Credentials targeted by  PinchDuke  include ones associated with many sources such as The Bat!, Yahoo!, Mail.ru, Passport.Net, Google Talk, and Microsoft Outlook.

Name: PLEAD
Description: PLEAD  has the ability to steal saved passwords from Microsoft Outlook.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  can decrypt passwords stored in the RDCMan configuration file.

Name: Prikormka
Description: A module in  Prikormka  collects passwords stored in applications installed on the victim.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  can use Lazagne for harvesting credentials.

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: QuasarRAT  can obtain passwords from common FTP clients.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used account credentials they obtained to attempt access to Group Managed Service Account (gMSA) passwords.

Name: Stealth Falcon
Description: Stealth Falcon  malware gathers passwords from multiple sources, including Windows Credential Vault and Outlook.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has attempted to obtain credentials from OpenSSH, realvnc, and PuTTY.

Name: Password Policies
Description: The password for the user's login keychain can be changed from the user's login password. This increases the complexity for an adversary because they need to know an additional password. Organizations may consider weighing the risk of storing credentials in password stores and web browsers. If system, software, or web browser credential disclosure is a significant concern, technical controls, policy, and user training may be used to prevent storage of credentials in improper locations.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Limit the number of accounts and services with permission to query information from password stores to only those required. Ensure that accounts and services with permissions to query password stores only have access to the secrets they require.

Name: 2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  pushed additional malicious tools onto an infected system to steal user credentials, move laterally, and destroy data.

Name: ABK
Description: ABK  has the ability to download files from C2.

Name: Action RAT
Description: Action RAT  has the ability to download additional payloads onto an infected machine.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  can download additional files for execution on the victim’s machine.

Name: Agent.btz
Description: Agent.btz  attempts to download an encrypted binary from a specified domain.

Name: Ajax Security Team
Description: Ajax Security Team  has used Wrapper/Gholee, custom-developed malware, which downloaded additional malware to the infected system.

Name: Amadey
Description: Amadey  can download and execute files to further infect a host machine with additional malware.

Name: Anchor
Description: Anchor  can download additional payloads.

Name: Andariel
Description: Andariel  has downloaded additional tools and malware onto compromised hosts.

Name: ANDROMEDA
Description: ANDROMEDA  can download additional payloads from C2.

Name: APT-C-36
Description: APT-C-36  has downloaded binary data from a specified domain after the malicious document is opened.

Name: APT18
Description: APT18  can upload a file to the victim’s machine.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has downloaded additional files, including by using a first-stage downloader to contact the C2 server to obtain the second-stage implant.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has downloaded additional tools and malware onto compromised networks.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  has a tool that can copy files to remote machines.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has added JavaScript to victim websites to download additional frameworks that profile and compromise website visitors.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has downloaded additional files and programs from its C2 server.

Name: APT37
Description: APT37  has downloaded second stage malware from compromised websites.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  used a backdoor, NESTEGG, that has the capability to download and upload files to and from a victim’s machine.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has downloaded tools to compromised hosts.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  used  certutil  to download additional files.

Name: Aquatic Panda
Description: Aquatic Panda  has downloaded additional malware onto compromised hosts.

Name: Aria-body
Description: Aria-body  has the ability to download additional payloads from C2.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  uses  certutil  and  BITSAdmin  to download additional malware.

Name: AsyncRAT
Description: AsyncRAT  has the ability to download files over SFTP.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  can download additional plugins, updates and other files.

Name: AuditCred
Description: AuditCred  can download files and additional malware.

Name: Avenger
Description: Avenger  has the ability to download files from C2 to a compromised host.

Name: Azorult
Description: Azorult  can download and execute additional files.  Azorult  has also downloaded a ransomware payload called Hermes.

Name: BabyShark
Description: BabyShark  has downloaded additional files from the C2.

Name: BackConfig
Description: BackConfig  can download and execute additional payloads on a compromised host.

Name: Backdoor.Oldrea
Description: Backdoor.Oldrea  can download additional modules from C2.

Name: BackdoorDiplomacy
Description: BackdoorDiplomacy  has downloaded additional files and tools onto a compromised host.

Name: BADFLICK
Description: BADFLICK  has download files from its C2 server.

Name: BADHATCH
Description: BADHATCH  has the ability to load a second stage malicious DLL file onto a compromised machine.

Name: BADNEWS
Description: BADNEWS  is capable of downloading additional files through C2 channels, including a new version of itself.

Name: BadPatch
Description: BadPatch  can download and execute or update malware.

Name: Bandook
Description: Bandook  can download files to the system.

Name: Bankshot
Description: Bankshot  uploads files and secondary payloads to the victim's machine.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can download and deploy additional payloads, including ransomware and post-exploitation frameworks such as  Cobalt Strike .

Name: BBK
Description: BBK  has the ability to download files from C2 to the infected host.

Name: BendyBear
Description: BendyBear  is designed to download an implant from a C2 server.

Name: BISCUIT
Description: BISCUIT  has a command to download a file from the C2 server.

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal  has the capability to download files to execute on the victim’s machine.

Name: BITSAdmin
Description: BITSAdmin  can be used to create  BITS Jobs  to upload and/or download files.

Name: BITTER
Description: BITTER  has downloaded additional malware and tools onto a compromised host.

Name: BlackMould
Description: BlackMould  has the ability to download files to the victim's machine.

Name: BLINDINGCAN
Description: BLINDINGCAN  has downloaded files to a victim machine.

Name: BLUELIGHT
Description: BLUELIGHT  can download additional files onto the host.

Name: Bonadan
Description: Bonadan  can download additional modules from the C2 server.

Name: BONDUPDATER
Description: BONDUPDATER  can download or upload files from its C2 server.

Name: BoomBox
Description: BoomBox  has the ability to download next stage malware components to a compromised system.

Name: BoxCaon
Description: BoxCaon  can download files.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  has used various tools to download files, including DGet (a similar tool to wget).

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  can download files to compromised hosts.

Name: build_downer
Description: build_downer  has the ability to download files from C2 to the infected host.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  can download and execute additional payloads including through the use of a  Dex  command.

Name: Bundlore
Description: Bundlore  can download and execute new versions of itself.

Name: C0010
Description: During  C0010 , UNC3890 actors downloaded tools and malware onto a compromised host.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors downloaded additional tools and files onto a compromised network.

Name: C0017
Description: During  C0017 ,  APT41  downloaded malicious payloads onto compromised systems.

Name: C0018
Description: During  C0018 , the threat actors downloaded additional tools, such as  Mimikatz  and  Sliver , as well as  Cobalt Strike  and  AvosLocker  ransomware onto the victim network.

Name: C0021
Description: During  C0021 , the threat actors downloaded additional tools and files onto victim machines.

Name: C0026
Description: During  C0026 , the threat actors downloaded malicious payloads onto select compromised hosts.

Name: C0027
Description: During  C0027 ,  Scattered Spider  downloaded tools using victim organization systems.

Name: Calisto
Description: Calisto  has the capability to upload and download files to the victim's machine.

Name: CallMe
Description: CallMe  has the capability to download a file to the victim from the C2 server.

Name: Cannon
Description: Cannon  can download a payload for execution.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp  can download and execute new plugins from the C2 server.

Name: Cardinal RAT
Description: Cardinal RAT  can download and execute additional payloads.

Name: CARROTBALL
Description: CARROTBALL  has the ability to download and install a remote payload.

Name: CARROTBAT

Description: Caterpillar WebShell  has a module to download and upload files to the system.

Name: certutil

Name: Chaes
Description: Chaes  can download additional files onto an infected machine.

Description: ChChes  is capable of downloading files, including additional modules.

Name: CHOPSTICK

Name: Chrommme
Description: Chrommme  can download its code from C2.

Name: CloudDuke
Description: CloudDuke  downloads and executes additional malware from either a Web address or a Microsoft OneDrive account.

Name: cmd
Description: cmd  can be used to copy files to/from a remotely connected external system.

Name: Cobalt Group
Description: Cobalt Group  has used public sites such as github.com and sendspace.com to upload files and then download them to victim computers.    The group's JavaScript backdoor is also capable of downloading files.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can deliver additional payloads to victim machines.

Name: CoinTicker
Description: CoinTicker  executes a Python script to download its second stage.

Name: Conficker
Description: Conficker  downloads an HTTP server to the infected machine.

Name: Confucius
Description: Confucius  has downloaded additional files and payloads onto a compromised host following initial access.

Name: CookieMiner

Name: CORESHELL
Description: CORESHELL  downloads another dropper from its C2 server.

Name: CostaBricks

Name: CostaRicto
Description: During  CostaRicto , the threat actors downloaded malware and tools onto a compromised host.

Name: CreepyDrive
Description: CreepyDrive  can download files to the compromised host.

Name: Crimson

Name: Cryptoistic
Description: Cryptoistic  has the ability to send and receive files.

Name: CSPY Downloader

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware or unusual data transfer over known protocols like FTP can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific obfuscation technique used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool C2 signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way as to avoid detection by common defensive tools.

Name: HermeticWiper
Description: HermeticWiper  can recursively wipe folders and files in  Windows ,  Program Files ,  Program Files(x86) ,  PerfLogs ,  Boot, System ,  Volume Information , and  AppData  folders using  FSCTL_MOVE_FILE .  HermeticWiper  can also overwrite symbolic links and big files in  My Documents  and on the Desktop with random bytes.

Name: Industroyer
Description: Industroyer ’s data wiper module clears registry keys and overwrites both ICS configuration and Windows files.

Name: Kazuar
Description: Kazuar  can overwrite files with random data before deleting them.

Name: KillDisk
Description: KillDisk  deletes system files to make the OS unbootable.  KillDisk  also targets and deletes files with 35 different file extensions.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has deleted the target's systems and resources both on-premises and in the cloud.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has used a custom secure delete function to overwrite file contents with data from heap memory.

Name: Meteor
Description: Meteor  can fill a victim's files and directories with zero-bytes in replacement of real content before deleting them.

Name: Olympic Destroyer
Description: Olympic Destroyer  overwrites files locally and on remote shares.

Name: PowerDuke
Description: PowerDuke  has a command to write random data across a file and delete it.

Name: Proxysvc
Description: Proxysvc  can overwrite files indicated by the attacker before deleting them.

Name: RawDisk
Description: RawDisk  was used in  Shamoon  to write to protected system locations such as the MBR and disk partitions in an effort to destroy data.

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  has the capability to destroy files and folders.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has used the  BlackEnergy  KillDisk component to overwrite files on Windows-based Human-Machine Interfaces.

Name: SDelete
Description: SDelete  deletes data in a way that makes it unrecoverable.

Name: Shamoon
Description: Shamoon  attempts to overwrite operating system files and disk structures with image files.     In a later variant, randomly generated data was used for data overwrites.

Name: StoneDrill
Description: StoneDrill  has a disk wiper module that targets files other than those in the Windows directory.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  can corrupt files by overwriting the first 1 MB with  0xcc  and appending random extensions.

Name: Xbash
Description: Xbash  has destroyed Linux-based databases as part of its ransomware capabilities.

Name: Data Backup
Description: Consider implementing IT disaster recovery plans that contain procedures for taking regular data backups that can be used to restore organizational data.   Ensure backups are stored off system and is protected from common methods adversaries may use to gain access and destroy the backups to prevent recovery.

Name: BADNEWS
Description: After encrypting C2 data,  BADNEWS  converts it into a hexadecimal representation and then encodes it into base64.

Name: H1N1
Description: H1N1  obfuscates C2 traffic with an altered version of base64.

Name: Linux Rabbit
Description: Linux Rabbit  sends the payload from the C2 server as an encoded URL parameter.

Name: Mythic
Description: Mythic  provides various transform functions to encode and/or randomize C2 data.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has used encoded data in HTTP URLs for C2.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific obfuscation technique used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool C2 signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way as to avoid detection by common defensive tools.

Name: AADInternals
Description: AADInternals can collect files from a user’s OneDrive.

Name: C0027
Description: During  C0027 ,  Scattered Spider  accessed victim OneDrive environments to search for VPN and MFA enrollment information, help desk instructions, and new hire guides.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has obtained files from the victim's cloud storage instances.

Name: Pacu
Description: Pacu  can enumerate and download files stored in AWS storage services, such as S3 buckets.

Name: Peirates
Description: Peirates  can dump the contents of AWS S3 buckets. It can also retrieve service account tokens from kOps buckets in Google Cloud Storage or S3.

Name: Audit
Description: Frequently check permissions on cloud storage to ensure proper permissions are set to deny open or unprivileged access to resources.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: Encrypt data stored at rest in cloud storage.    Managed encryption keys can be rotated by most providers. At a minimum, ensure an incident response plan to storage breach includes rotating the keys and test for impact on client applications.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Cloud service providers support IP-based restrictions when accessing cloud resources. Consider using IP allowlisting along with user account management to ensure that data access is restricted not only to valid users but only from expected IP ranges to mitigate the use of stolen credentials to access data.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Consider using multi-factor authentication to restrict access to resources and cloud storage APIs.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Use access control lists on storage systems and objects.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Configure user permissions groups and roles for access to cloud storage.   Implement strict Identity and Access Management (IAM) controls to prevent access to storage solutions except for the applications, users, and services that require access.   Ensure that temporary access tokens are issued rather than permanent credentials, especially when access is being granted to entities outside of the internal security boundary.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has used Hermes ransomware to encrypt files with AES256.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  used a ransomware called Encryptor RaaS to encrypt files on the targeted systems and provide a ransom note to the user.

Name: Avaddon
Description: Avaddon  encrypts the victim system using a combination of AES256 and RSA encryption schemes.

Name: AvosLocker
Description: AvosLocker  has encrypted files and network resources using AES-256 and added an  .avos ,  .avos2 , or  .AvosLinux  extension to filenames.

Name: Babuk
Description: Babuk  can use ChaCha8 and ECDH to encrypt data.

Name: Bad Rabbit
Description: Bad Rabbit  has encrypted files and disks using AES-128-CBC and RSA-2048.

Name: BitPaymer
Description: BitPaymer  can import a hard-coded RSA 1024-bit public key, generate a 128-bit RC4 key for each file, and encrypt the file in place, appending  .locked  to the filename.

Name: Black Basta
Description: Black Basta  can encrypt files with the ChaCha20 cypher and using a multithreaded process to increase speed.

Name: BlackCat
Description: BlackCat  has the ability to encrypt Windows devices, Linux devices, and VMWare instances.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors used  Conti  ransomware to encrypt a compromised network.

Name: C0018
Description: During  C0018 , the threat actors used  AvosLocker  ransomware to encrypt files on the compromised network.

Name: Clop
Description: Clop  can encrypt files using AES, RSA, and RC4 and will add the ".clop" extension to encrypted files.

Name: Conti
Description: Conti  can use  CreateIoCompletionPort() ,  PostQueuedCompletionStatus() , and  GetQueuedCompletionPort()  to rapidly encrypt files, excluding those with the extensions of .exe, .dll, and .lnk. It has used a different AES-256 encryption key per file with a bundled RAS-4096 public encryption key that is unique for each victim.  Conti  can use "Windows Restart Manager" to ensure files are unlocked and open for encryption.

Name: Cuba
Description: Cuba  has the ability to encrypt system data and add the ".cuba" extension to encrypted files.

Name: DCSrv
Description: DCSrv  has encrypted drives using the core encryption mechanism from DiskCryptor.

Name: DEATHRANSOM
Description: DEATHRANSOM  can use public and private key pair encryption to encrypt files for ransom payment.

Name: Diavol
Description: Diavol  has encrypted files using an RSA key though the  CryptEncrypt  API and has appended filenames with ".lock64".

Name: Egregor
Description: Egregor  can encrypt all non-system files using a hybrid AES-RSA algorithm prior to displaying a ransom note.

Name: EKANS
Description: EKANS  uses standard encryption library functions to encrypt files.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  has encrypted virtual disk volumes on ESXi servers using a version of Darkside ransomware.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has deployed ransomware such as  Ragnar Locker , White Rabbit, and attempted to execute Noberus on compromised networks.

Name: FIVEHANDS
Description: FIVEHANDS  can use an embedded NTRU public key to encrypt data for ransom.

Name: HELLOKITTY
Description: HELLOKITTY  can use an embedded RSA-2048 public key to encrypt victim data for ransom.

Name: Indrik Spider
Description: Indrik Spider  has encrypted domain-controlled systems using  BitPaymer .

Name: JCry
Description: JCry  has encrypted files and demanded Bitcoin to decrypt those files.

Name: KillDisk
Description: KillDisk  has a ransomware component that encrypts files with an AES key that is also RSA-1028 encrypted.

Name: LockerGoga
Description: LockerGoga  has encrypted files, including core Windows OS files, using RSA-OAEP MGF1 and then demanded Bitcoin be paid for the decryption key.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has used BitLocker and DiskCryptor to encrypt targeted workstations.

Name: Maze
Description: Maze  has disrupted systems by encrypting files on targeted machines, claiming to decrypt files if a ransom payment is made.  Maze  has used the ChaCha algorithm, based on Salsa20, and an RSA algorithm to encrypt files.

Name: MegaCortex
Description: MegaCortex  has used the open-source library, Mbed Crypto, and generated AES keys to carry out the file encryption process.

Name: Netwalker
Description: Netwalker  can encrypt files on infected machines to extort victims.

Name: NotPetya
Description: NotPetya  encrypts user files and disk structures like the MBR with 2048-bit RSA.

Name: Pay2Key
Description: Pay2Key  can encrypt data on victim's machines using RSA and AES algorithms in order to extort a ransom payment for decryption.

Name: Prestige
Description: Prestige  has leveraged the CryptoPP C++ library to encrypt files on target systems using AES and appended filenames with  .enc .

Name: ProLock
Description: ProLock  can encrypt files on a compromised host with RC6, and encrypts the key with RSA-1024.

Name: Pysa
Description: Pysa  has used RSA and AES-CBC encryption algorithm to encrypt a list of targeted file extensions.

Name: Ragnar Locker
Description: Ragnar Locker  encrypts files on the local machine and mapped drives prior to displaying a note demanding a ransom.

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  can encrypt files on victim systems and demands a ransom to decrypt the files.

Name: RobbinHood
Description: RobbinHood  will search for an RSA encryption key and then perform its encryption process on the system files.

Name: Royal
Description: Royal  uses a multi-threaded encryption process that can partially encrypt targeted files with the OpenSSL library and the AES256 algorithm.

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  has used a combination of symmetric (AES) and asymmetric (RSA) encryption to encrypt files. Files have been encrypted with their own AES key and given a file extension of .RYK. Encrypted directories have had a ransom note of RyukReadMe.txt written to the directory.

Name: SamSam
Description: SamSam  encrypts victim files using RSA-2048 encryption and demands a ransom be paid in Bitcoin to decrypt those files.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has used  Prestige  ransomware to encrypt data at targeted organizations in transportation and related logistics industries in Ukraine and Poland.

Name: Seth-Locker
Description: Seth-Locker  can encrypt files on a targeted system, appending them with the suffix .seth.

Name: Shamoon
Description: Shamoon  has an operational mode for encrypting data instead of overwriting it.

Name: SynAck
Description: SynAck  encrypts the victims machine followed by asking the victim to pay a ransom.

Name: TA505
Description: TA505  has used a wide variety of ransomware, such as  Clop , Locky, Jaff, Bart, Philadelphia, and GlobeImposter, to encrypt victim files and demand a ransom payment.

Name: ThiefQuest
Description: ThiefQuest  encrypts a set of file extensions on a host, deletes the original files, and provides a ransom note with no contact information.

Name: WannaCry
Description: WannaCry  encrypts user files and demands that a ransom be paid in Bitcoin to decrypt those files.

Name: WastedLocker
Description: WastedLocker  can encrypt data and leave a ransom note.

Name: Xbash
Description: Xbash  has maliciously encrypted victim's database systems and demanded a cryptocurrency ransom be paid.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  performs AES-CBC encryption on files under  ~/Documents ,  ~/Downloads , and ~/Desktop  with a fixed key and renames files to give them a  .enc  extension. Only files with sizes less than 500MB are encrypted.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: On Windows 10, enable cloud-delivered protection and Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to block the execution of files that resemble ransomware.

Name: Data Backup
Description: Consider implementing IT disaster recovery plans that contain procedures for regularly taking and testing data backups that can be used to restore organizational data.   Ensure backups are stored off system and is protected from common methods adversaries may use to gain access and destroy the backups to prevent recovery. Consider enabling versioning in cloud environments to maintain backup copies of storage objects.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has collected files from various information repositories.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has collected schemas and user accounts from systems running SQL Server.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has accessed victim security and IT environments and Microsoft Teams to mine valuable information.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has searched a victim's network for organization collaboration channels like MS Teams or Slack to discover further high-privilege account credentials.

Name: P.A.S. Webshell
Description: P.A.S. Webshell  has the ability to list and extract data from SQL databases.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  accessed victims' internal knowledge repositories (wikis) to view sensitive corporate information on products, services, and internal business operations.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has used a custom .NET tool to collect documents from an organization's internal central database.

Name: Audit
Description: Consider periodic review of accounts and privileges for critical and sensitive repositories.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Enforce the principle of least-privilege. Consider implementing access control mechanisms that include both authentication and authorization.

Name: User Training
Description: Develop and publish policies that define acceptable information to be stored in repositories.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has collected files from network shared drives.

Name: BADNEWS
Description: When it first starts,  BADNEWS  crawls the victim's mapped drives and collects documents with the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .pdf, .ppt, .pptx, and .txt.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  has exfiltrated files stolen from file shares.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors collected files from network shared drives prior to network encryption.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has collected data of interest from network shares.

Name: CosmicDuke
Description: CosmicDuke  steals user files from network shared drives with file extensions and keywords that match a predefined list.

Name: Egregor
Description: Egregor  can collect any files found in the enumerated drivers before sending it to its C2 channel.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has searched network shares to access sensitive documents.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  malware has collected Microsoft Office documents from mapped network drives.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has collected data from remote systems by mounting network shares with  net use  and using Robocopy to transfer data.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can collect data from network drives and stage it for exfiltration.

Name: Sowbug
Description: Sowbug  extracted Word documents from a file server on a victim network.

Name: Action RAT
Description: Action RAT  can collect local data from an infected machine.

Name: Amadey
Description: Amadey  can collect information from a compromised host.

Name: Andariel
Description: Andariel  has collected large numbers of files from compromised network systems for later extraction.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  can collect data on a compromised host.

Name: APT1
Description: APT1  has collected files from a local victim.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has retrieved internal documents from machines inside victim environments, including by using  Forfiles  to stage documents before exfiltration.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has stolen data from compromised hosts.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  will identify Microsoft Office documents on the victim's computer.

Name: APT37
Description: APT37  has collected data from victims' local systems.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has collected data from a compromised host.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used various tools to steal files from the compromised host.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  has uploaded files and data from a compromised host.

Name: AuTo Stealer
Description: AuTo Stealer  can collect data such as PowerPoint files, Word documents, Excel files, PDF files, text files, database files, and image files from an infected machine.

Name: Axiom
Description: Axiom  has collected data from a compromised network.

Name: BADFLICK
Description: BADFLICK  has uploaded files from victims' machines.

Name: BADNEWS
Description: When it first starts,  BADNEWS  crawls the victim's local drives and collects documents with the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .pdf, .ppt, .pptx, and .txt.

Name: BadPatch
Description: BadPatch  collects files from the local system that have the following extensions, then prepares them for exfiltration: .xls, .xlsx, .pdf, .mdb, .rar, .zip, .doc, .docx.

Name: Bandook
Description: Bandook  can collect local files from the system .

Name: Bankshot
Description: Bankshot  collects files from the local system.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can retrieve information from the infected machine.

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal  has collected information from a compromised host.

Name: BlackMould
Description: BlackMould  can copy files on a compromised host.

Name: BLINDINGCAN
Description: BLINDINGCAN  has uploaded files from victim machines.

Name: BoxCaon
Description: BoxCaon  can upload files from a compromised host.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  has exfiltrated files stolen from local systems.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  has the ability to upload files from a compromised system.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  can capture and compress stolen credentials from the Registry and volume shadow copies.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors obtained files and data from the compromised network.

Name: C0017
Description: During  C0017 ,  APT41  collected information related to compromised machines as well as Personal Identifiable Information (PII) from victim networks.

Name: C0026
Description: During  C0026 , the threat actors collected documents from compromised hosts.

Name: Calisto
Description: Calisto  can collect data from user directories.

Name: Caterpillar WebShell
Description: Caterpillar WebShell  has a module to collect information from the local database.

Name: ccf32
Description: ccf32  can collect files from a compromised host.

Name: CharmPower
Description: CharmPower  can collect data and files from a compromised host.

Name: China Chopper
Description: China Chopper 's server component can upload local files.

Name: Chrommme
Description: Chrommme  can collect data from a local system.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  can collect information from a compromised host.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can collect data from a local system.

Name: CookieMiner
Description: CookieMiner  has retrieved iPhone text messages from iTunes phone backup files.

Name: CosmicDuke
Description: CosmicDuke  steals user files from local hard drives with file extensions that match a predefined list.

Name: CostaRicto
Description: During  CostaRicto , the threat actors collected data and files from compromised networks.

Name: CreepyDrive
Description: CreepyDrive  can upload files to C2 from victim machines.

Name: Crimson
Description: Crimson  can collect information from a compromised host.

Name: Crutch
Description: Crutch  can exfiltrate files from compromised systems.

Name: Cryptoistic
Description: Cryptoistic  can retrieve files from the local file system.

Name: CURIUM
Description: CURIUM  has exfiltrated data from a compromised machine.

Name: Cyclops Blink
Description: Cyclops Blink  can upload files from a compromised host.

Name: DanBot
Description: DanBot  can upload files from compromised hosts.

Name: Dark Caracal
Description: Dark Caracal  collected complete contents of the 'Pictures' folder from compromised Windows systems.

Name: DarkWatchman
Description: DarkWatchman  can collect files from a compromised host.

Name: DnsSystem
Description: DnsSystem  can upload files from infected machines after receiving a command with  uploaddd  in the string.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has collected data from local victim systems.

Name: DRATzarus
Description: DRATzarus  can collect information from a compromised host.

Name: Drovorub
Description: Drovorub  can transfer files from the victim machine.

Name: Dtrack
Description: Dtrack  can collect a variety of information from victim machines.

Name: EnvyScout
Description: EnvyScout  can collect sensitive NTLM material from a compromised host.

Name: esentutl
Description: esentutl  can be used to collect data from local file systems.

Name: FatDuke
Description: FatDuke  can copy files and directories from a compromised host.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has gathered stolen credentials, sensitive data such as point-of-sale (POS), and ATM data from a compromised network before exfiltration.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has collected and exfiltrated payment card data from compromised systems.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  has collected files and other sensitive information from a compromised network.

Name: Flagpro
Description: Flagpro  can collect data from a compromised host, including Windows authentication information.

Name: FLASHFLOOD
Description: FLASHFLOOD  searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on the local system.  FLASHFLOOD  will scan the My Recent Documents, Desktop, Temporary Internet Files, and TEMP directories.  FLASHFLOOD  also collects information stored in the Windows Address Book.

Name: FlawedAmmyy
Description: FlawedAmmyy  has collected information and files from a compromised machine.

Name: FoggyWeb
Description: FoggyWeb  can retrieve configuration data from a compromised AD FS server.

Name: Forfiles
Description: Forfiles  can be used to act on (ex: copy, move, etc.) files/directories in a system during (ex: copy files into a staging area before).

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has searched local system resources to access sensitive documents.

Name: FrameworkPOS
Description: FrameworkPOS  can collect elements related to credit card data from process memory.

Name: Frankenstein
Description: During  Frankenstein , the threat actors used  Empire  to gather various local system information.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: FunnyDream  can upload files from victims' machines.

Name: GALLIUM
Description: GALLIUM  collected data from the victim's local system, including password hashes from the SAM hive in the Registry.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  has collected files from infected systems and uploaded them to a C2 server.

Name: Gelsemium
Description: Gelsemium  can collect data from a compromised host.

Name: Goopy
Description: Goopy  has the ability to exfiltrate documents from infected systems.

Name: GravityRAT
Description: GravityRAT  steals files with the following extensions: .docx, .doc, .pptx, .ppt, .xlsx, .xls, .rtf, and .pdf.

Name: Green Lambert
Description: Green Lambert  can collect data from a compromised host.

Name: GrimAgent
Description: GrimAgent  can collect data and files from a compromised host.

Name: HAFNIUM
Description: HAFNIUM  has collected data and files from a compromised machine.

Name: Hikit
Description: Hikit  can upload files from compromised machines.

Name: Hydraq
Description: Hydraq  creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can read data from files.

Name: IceApple
Description: IceApple  can collect files, passwords, and other data from a compromised host.

Name: Inception
Description: Inception  used a file hunting plugin to collect .txt, .pdf, .xls or .doc files from the infected host.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can collect data from the system, and can monitor changes in specified directories.

Name: Ixeshe
Description: Ixeshe  can collect data from a local system.

Name: Kazuar
Description: Kazuar  uploads files from a specified directory to the C2 server.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  gathered information and files from local directories for exfiltration.

Name: Kevin
Description: Kevin  can upload logs and other data from a compromised host.

Name: KGH_SPY
Description: KGH_SPY  can send a file containing victim system information to C2.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has collected Office, PDF, and HWP documents from its victims.

Name: Koadic
Description: Koadic  can download files off the target system to send back to the server.

Name: KONNI
Description: KONNI  has stored collected information and discovered processes in a tmp file.

Name: KOPILUWAK
Description: KOPILUWAK  can gather information from compromised hosts.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  uploaded sensitive files, information, and credentials from a targeted organization for extortion or public release.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has collected data and files from compromised networks.

Name: LightNeuron
Description: LightNeuron  can collect files from a local system.

Name: Linfo
Description: Linfo  creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can obtain data from local systems.

Name: LuminousMoth
Description: LuminousMoth  has collected files and data from compromised machines.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  searches the File system for files of interest.

Name: MacMa
Description: MacMa  can collect then exfiltrate files from the compromised system.

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can collect files and information from a compromised host.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has used a web shell to exfiltrate a ZIP file containing a dump of LSASS memory on a compromised machine.

Name: MarkiRAT
Description: MarkiRAT  can upload data from the victim's machine to the C2 server.

Name: MCMD
Description: MCMD  has the ability to upload files from an infected device.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has collected various files from the compromised computers.

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  can collect files and system information from a compromised host.

Name: Milan
Description: Milan  can upload files from a compromised host.

Name: Mis-Type
Description: Mis-Type  has collected files and data from a compromised host.

Name: Misdat
Description: Misdat  has collected files and data from a compromised host.

Name: MobileOrder
Description: MobileOrder  exfiltrates data collected from the victim mobile device.

Name: Mongall
Description: Mongall  has the ability to upload files from victim's machines.

Name: Nebulae
Description: Nebulae  has the capability to upload collected files to C2.

Name: Neoichor
Description: Neoichor  can upload files from a victim's machine.

Name: NightClub
Description: NightClub  can use a file monitor to steal specific files from targeted systems.

Name: njRAT
Description: njRAT  can collect data from a local system.

Name: Octopus

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , the threat actors collected data, files, and other information from compromised networks.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  used malicious Trojans and DLL files to exfiltrate data from an infected host.

Name: Operation Honeybee
Description: During  Operation Honeybee , the threat actors collected data from compromised hosts.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors exfiltrated files and directories of interest from the targeted system.

Name: PowerSploit
Description: PowerSploit  contains a collection of Exfiltration modules that can access data from local files, volumes, and processes.

Description: Proxysvc  searches the local system and gathers data.

Name: PUNCHTRACK
Description: PUNCHTRACK  scrapes memory for properly formatted payment card data.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can use a variety of commands, including esentutl.exe to steal sensitive data from Internet Explorer and Microsoft Edge, to acquire information that is subsequently exfiltrated.

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: QuasarRAT  can retrieve files from compromised client machines.

Name: QuietSieve
Description: QuietSieve  can collect files from a compromised host.

Name: RainyDay
Description: RainyDay  can use a file exfiltration tool to collect recently changed files on a compromised host.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can collect Microsoft Word documents from the target's file system, as well as  .txt ,  .doc , and  .xls  files from the Internet Explorer cache.

Name: RawPOS
Description: RawPOS  dumps memory from specific processes on a victim system, parses the dumped files, and scrapes them for credit card data.

Name: RCSession
Description: RCSession  can collect data from a compromised host.

Name: Rising Sun
Description: Rising Sun  has collected data and files from a compromised host.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  can collect host data and specific file types.

Name: Rover
Description: Rover  searches for files on local drives based on a predefined list of file extensions.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  can collect files and information from a compromised host.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has exfiltrated internal documents, files, and other data from compromised hosts.

Name: Sardonic
Description: Sardonic  has the ability to collect data from a compromised machine to deliver to the attacker.

Name: SDBbot
Description: SDBbot  has the ability to access the file system on a compromised host.

Name: Shark
Description: Shark  can upload files to its C2.

Name: SharpDisco
Description: SharpDisco  has dropped a recent-files stealer plugin to  C:\Users\Public\WinSrcNT\It11.exe .

Name: ShimRat
Description: ShimRat  has the capability to upload collected files to a C2.

Name: SideTwist
Description: SideTwist  has the ability to upload files from a compromised host.

Name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
Description: SLOTHFULMEDIA  has uploaded files and information from victim machines.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  extracted files from compromised networks.

Name: SombRAT
Description: SombRAT  has collected data and files from a compromised host.

Name: SpicyOmelette
Description: SpicyOmelette  has collected data and other information from a compromised host.

Name: STARWHALE
Description: STARWHALE  can collect data from an infected local host.

Name: Stealth Falcon
Description: Stealth Falcon  malware gathers data from the local victim system.

Name: StrifeWater
Description: StrifeWater  can collect data from a compromised host.

Name: SUNBURST
Description: SUNBURST  collected information from a compromised host.

Name: SVCReady
Description: SVCReady  can collect data from an infected host.

Name: SysUpdate
Description: SysUpdate  can collect information and files from a compromised host.

Name: Taidoor
Description: Taidoor  can upload data and files from a victim's machine.

Name: TajMahal
Description: TajMahal  has the ability to steal documents from the local system including the print spooler queue.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  ran a command to compile an archive of file types of interest from the victim user's directories.

Name: ThreatNeedle
Description: ThreatNeedle  can collect data and files from a compromised host.

Name: TinyTurla
Description: TinyTurla  can upload files from a compromised host.

Name: Tomiris
Description: Tomiris  has the ability to collect recent files matching a hardcoded list of extensions prior to exfiltration.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  collects local files and information from the victim’s local machine.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  RPC backdoors can upload files from victim machines.

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  can use its  Get  command to exfiltrate specified files from the compromised system.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has collected files from victim machines, including certificates and cookies.

Name: USBferry
Description: USBferry  can collect information from an air-gapped host machine.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has stolen the Active Directory database from targeted environments and used  Wevtutil  to extract event log information.

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  can collect data from a compromised host.

Name: WellMail
Description: WellMail  can exfiltrate files from the victim machine.

Name: WellMess
Description: WellMess  can send files from the victim machine to C2.

Name: Wevtutil
Description: Wevtutil  can be used to export events from a specific log.

Name: Windigo
Description: Windigo  has used a script to gather credentials in files left on disk by OpenSSH backdoors.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has collected data from a compromised host prior to exfiltration.

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  can collect information from a compromised host.

Name: xCaon
Description: xCaon  has uploaded files from victims' machines.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  collects contacts and application data from files in Desktop, Documents, Downloads, Dropbox, and WeChat folders.

Name: yty
Description: yty  collects files with the following extensions: .ppt, .pptx, .pdf, .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .docm, .rtf, .inp, .xlsm, .csv, .odt, .pps, .vcf and sends them back to the C2 server.

Name: Zox
Description: Zox  has the ability to upload files from a targeted system.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  can transfer files from a compromised host.

Name: ZxxZ
Description: ZxxZ  can collect data from a compromised host.

Name: Data Loss Prevention
Description: Data loss prevention can restrict access to sensitive data and detect sensitive data that is unencrypted.

Name: Kevin
Description: Kevin  can create directories to store logs and other collected data.

Name: Kobalos
Description: Kobalos  can write captured SSH connection credentials to a file under the  /var/run  directory with a  .pid  extension for exfiltration.

Name: QUIETCANARY
Description: QUIETCANARY  has the ability to stage data prior to exfiltration.

Name: Shark
Description: Shark  has stored information in folders named  U1  and  U2  prior to exfiltration.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has staged collected data in password-protected archives.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has collected and staged credentials and network enumeration information, using  the networkdll and psfin  TrickBot  modules.

Name: FlawedAmmyy
Description: FlawedAmmyy  may obfuscate portions of the initial C2 handshake.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: FunnyDream  can send compressed and obfuscated packets to C2.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors encrypted IP addresses used for "Agent" proxy hops with RC4.

Name: RDAT
Description: RDAT  has used encoded data within subdomains as AES ciphertext to communicate from the host to the C2.

Name: SideTwist
Description: SideTwist  can embed C2 responses in the source code of a fake Flickr webpage.

Name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
Description: SLOTHFULMEDIA  has hashed a string containing system information prior to exfiltration via POST requests.

Name: TrailBlazer
Description: TrailBlazer  can masquerade its C2 traffic as legitimate Google Notifications HTTP requests.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate some obfuscation activity at the network level.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has injected fraudulent transactions into compromised networks that mimic legitimate behavior to siphon off incremental amounts of money.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: Consider encrypting important information to reduce an adversary’s ability to perform tailored data modifications.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Identify critical business and system processes that may be targeted by adversaries and work to isolate and secure those systems against unauthorized access and tampering.

Name: Remote Data Storage
Description: Consider implementing IT disaster recovery plans that contain procedures for taking regular data backups that can be used to restore organizational data.   Ensure backups are stored off system and is protected from common methods adversaries may use to gain access and manipulate backups.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Ensure least privilege principles are applied to important information resources to reduce exposure to data manipulation risk.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  can find and collect data from removable media devices.

Name: APT28
Description: An  APT28  backdoor may collect the entire contents of an inserted USB device.

Name: Aria-body
Description: Aria-body  has the ability to collect data from USB devices.

Name: BADNEWS
Description: BADNEWS  copies files with certain extensions from USB devices toa predefined directory.

Name: CosmicDuke
Description: CosmicDuke  steals user files from removable media with file extensions and keywords that match a predefined list.

Name: Crimson
Description: Crimson  contains a module to collect data from removable drives.

Name: Crutch
Description: Crutch  can monitor removable drives and exfiltrate files matching a given extension list.

Name: Explosive
Description: Explosive  can scan all .exe files located in the USB drive.

Name: FLASHFLOOD
Description: FLASHFLOOD  searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on removable media and copies them to a staging area. The default file types copied would include data copied to the drive by  SPACESHIP .

Name: FunnyDream
Description: The  FunnyDream  FilePakMonitor component has the ability to collect files from removable devices.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: A  Gamaredon Group  file stealer has the capability to steal data from newly connected logical volumes on a system, including USB drives.

Name: GravityRAT
Description: GravityRAT  steals files based on an extension list if a USB drive is connected to the system.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can collect jpeg files from connected MTP devices.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  can find, encrypt, and upload files from fixed and removable drives.

Name: ObliqueRAT
Description: ObliqueRAT  has the ability to extract data from removable devices connected to the endpoint.

Name: Prikormka
Description: Prikormka  contains a module that collects documents with certain extensions from removable media or fixed drives connected via USB.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can collect data from removable media and stage it for exfiltration.

Name: Remsec
Description: Remsec  has a package that collects documents from any inserted USB sticks.

Name: Rover
Description: Rover  searches for files on attached removable drives based on a predefined list of file extensions every five seconds.

Name: TajMahal
Description: TajMahal  has the ability to steal written CD images and files of interest from previously connected removable drives when they become available again.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  RPC backdoors can collect files from USB thumb drives.

Name: USBStealer
Description: Once a removable media device is inserted back into the first victim,  USBStealer  collects data from it that was exfiltrated from a second victim.

Name: Data Loss Prevention
Description: Data loss prevention can restrict access to sensitive data and detect sensitive data that is unencrypted.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  has divided files if the size is 0x1000000 bytes or more.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has split archived exfiltration files into chunks smaller than 1MB.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors limited  Rclone 's bandwidth setting during exfiltration.

Name: C0026
Description: During  C0026 , the threat actors split encrypted archives containing stolen files and information into 3MB parts prior to exfiltration.

Name: Carbanak
Description: Carbanak  exfiltrates data in compressed chunks if a message is larger than 4096 bytes .

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  will break large data sets into smaller chunks for exfiltration.

Name: Helminth
Description: Helminth  splits data into chunks up to 23 bytes and sends the data in DNS queries to its C2 server.

Name: Kessel
Description: Kessel  can split the data to be exilftrated into chunks that will fit in subdomains of DNS queries.

Name: Kevin
Description: Kevin  can exfiltrate data to the C2 server in 27-character chunks.

Name: LuminousMoth
Description: LuminousMoth  has split archived files into multiple parts to bypass a 5MB limit.

Name: Mythic
Description: Mythic  supports custom chunk sizes used to upload/download files.

Name: ObliqueRAT
Description: ObliqueRAT  can break large files of interest into smaller chunks to prepare them for exfiltration.

Name: OopsIE
Description: OopsIE  exfiltrates command output and collected files to its C2 server in 1500-byte blocks.

Name: POSHSPY
Description: POSHSPY  uploads data in 2048-byte chunks.

Name: Rclone
Description: The  Rclone  "chunker" overlay supports splitting large files in smaller chunks during upload to circumvent size limits.

Name: RDAT
Description: RDAT  can upload a file via HTTP POST response to the C2 split into 102,400-byte portions.  RDAT  can also download data from the C2 which is split into 81,920-byte portions.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  actors have split RAR files for exfiltration into parts.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary command and control infrastructure and malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: Data Backup
Description: Consider implementing IT disaster recovery plans that contain procedures for taking regular data backups that can be used to restore organizational data.   Ensure backups are stored off system and is protected from common methods adversaries may use to gain access and destroy the backups to prevent recovery.

Name: Doki
Description: Doki  was run through a deployed container.

Name: Kinsing
Description: Kinsing  was run through a deployed Ubuntu container.

Name: Peirates
Description: Peirates  can deploy a pod that mounts its node’s root file system, then execute a command to create a reverse shell on the node.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has deployed different types of containers into victim environments to facilitate execution.     TeamTNT  has also transferred cryptocurrency mining software to Kubernetes clusters discovered within local IP address ranges.

Name: Audit
Description: Scan images before deployment, and block those that are not in compliance with security policies. In Kubernetes environments, the admission controller can be used to validate images after a container deployment request is authenticated but before the container is deployed.

Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Description: Limit communications with the container service to managed and secured channels, such as local Unix sockets or remote access via SSH. Require secure port access to communicate with the APIs over TLS by disabling unauthenticated access to the Docker API, Kubernetes API Server, and container orchestration web applications.    In Kubernetes clusters deployed in cloud environments, use native cloud platform features to restrict the IP ranges that are permitted to access to API server.   Where possible, consider enabling just-in-time (JIT) access to the Kubernetes API to place additional restrictions on access.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Deny direct remote access to internal systems through the use of network proxies, gateways, and firewalls.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Enforce the principle of least privilege by limiting container dashboard access to only the necessary users. When using Kubernetes, avoid giving users wildcard permissions or adding users to the  system:masters  group, and use  RoleBindings  rather than  ClusterRoleBindings  to limit user privileges to specific namespaces.

Name: AsyncRAT
Description: AsyncRAT  can use the  CheckRemoteDebuggerPresent  function to detect the presence of a debugger.

Name: Black Basta
Description: The  Black Basta  dropper can check system flags, CPU registers, CPU instructions, process timing, system libraries, and APIs to determine if a debugger is present.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  can search for tools used in static analysis.

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla  can detect debuggers by using functions such as  DebuggerIsAttached  and  DebuggerIsLogging .  DarkTortilla  can also detect profilers by verifying the  COR_ENABLE_PROFILING  environment variable is present and active.

Name: DRATzarus
Description: DRATzarus  can use  IsDebuggerPresent  to detect whether a debugger is present on a victim.

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can search for debugging tools on a compromised host.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  used tools that used the  IsDebuggerPresent  call to detect debuggers.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  can check for debugging tools.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  has used  is_debugger_present  as part of its environmental checks.

Name: ThiefQuest
Description: ThiefQuest  uses a function named  is_debugging  to perform anti-debugging logic. The function invokes  sysctl  checking the returned value of  P_TRACED .  ThiefQuest  also calls  ptrace  with the  PTRACE_DENY_ATTACH  flag to prevent debugging.

Name: 2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  used heavily obfuscated code with  Industroyer  in its Windows Notepad backdoor.

Name: Action RAT
Description: Action RAT 's commands, strings, and domains can be Base64 encoded within the payload.

Name: ADVSTORESHELL
