Description: Most of the strings in  ADVSTORESHELL  are encrypted with an XOR-based algorithm; some strings are also encrypted with 3DES and reversed. API function names are also reversed, presumably to avoid detection in memory.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  has had its code obfuscated in an apparent attempt to make analysis difficult.    Agent Tesla  has used the Rijndael symmetric encryption algorithm to encrypt strings.

Name: Amadey
Description: Amadey  has obfuscated strings such as antivirus vendor names, domains, files, and others.

Name: Anchor
Description: Anchor  has obfuscated code with stack strings and string encryption.

Name: AppleJeus
Description: AppleJeus  has XOR-encrypted collected system information prior to sending to a C2.  AppleJeus  has also used the open source ADVObfuscation library for its components.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  has the ability to Base64 encode its payload and custom encrypt API calls.

Name: APT-C-36
Description: APT-C-36  has used ConfuserEx to obfuscate its variant of  Imminent Monitor , compressed payload and RAT packages, and password protected encrypted email attachments to avoid detection.

Name: APT18
Description: APT18  obfuscates strings in the payload.

Name: APT19
Description: APT19  used Base64 to obfuscate payloads.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  encrypted a .dll payload using RTL and a custom encryption algorithm.  APT28  has also obfuscated payloads with base64, XOR, and RC4.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  obfuscates files or information to help evade defensive measures.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has performed code obfuscation, including encoding payloads using Base64 and using a framework called "Dont-Kill-My-Cat (DKMC).  APT32  also encrypts the library used for network exfiltration with AES-256 in CBC mode in their macOS backdoor.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has used base64 to encode payloads.

Name: APT37
Description: APT37  obfuscates strings and payloads.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used malware to drop encrypted CAB files.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  used VMProtected binaries in multiple intrusions.

Name: Aria-body
Description: Aria-body  has used an encrypted configuration file for its loader.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  has used an XOR-based algorithm to encrypt payloads twice with different keys.

Name: Attor
Description: Strings in  Attor 's components are encrypted with a XOR cipher, using a hardcoded key and the configuration data, log files and plugins are encrypted using a hybrid encryption scheme of Blowfish-OFB combined with RSA.

Name: AuditCred
Description: AuditCred  encrypts the configuration.

Name: Avaddon
Description: Avaddon  has used encrypted strings.

Name: Avenger
Description: Avenger  has the ability to XOR encrypt files to be sent to C2.

Name: AvosLocker
Description: AvosLocker  has used XOR-encoded strings.

Name: BackdoorDiplomacy
Description: BackdoorDiplomacy  has obfuscated tools and malware it uses with VMProtect.

Name: BADHATCH
Description: BADHATCH  can be compressed with the ApLib algorithm.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  has used XOR, RSA2, and RC4 encrypted files.

Name: BendyBear
Description: BendyBear  has encrypted payloads using RC4 and XOR.

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal 's DLL file and non-malicious decoy file are encrypted with RC4 and some function name strings are obfuscated.

Name: BitPaymer
Description: BitPaymer  has used RC4-encrypted strings and string hashes to avoid identifiable strings within the binary.

Name: BITTER
Description: BITTER  has used a RAR SFX dropper to deliver malware.

Name: BlackOasis
Description: BlackOasis 's first stage shellcode contains a NOP sled with alternative instructions that was likely designed to bypass antivirus tools.

Name: BLINDINGCAN
Description: BLINDINGCAN  has obfuscated code using Base64 encoding.

Name: Blue Mockingbird
Description: Blue Mockingbird  has obfuscated the wallet address in the payload binary.

Name: BLUELIGHT
Description: BLUELIGHT  has a XOR-encoded payload.

Name: BoomBox
Description: BoomBox  can encrypt data using AES prior to exfiltration.

Name: BOOSTWRITE
Description: BOOSTWRITE  has encoded its payloads using a ChaCha stream cipher with a 256-bit key and 64-bit Initialization vector (IV) to evade detection.

Name: BoxCaon
Description: BoxCaon  used the "StackStrings" obfuscation technique to hide malicious functionalities.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  has used encrypted payload files and maintains an encrypted configuration structure in memory.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  has been delivered as password-protected zipped ISO files and used control-flow-flattening to obfuscate the flow of functions.

Name: Bundlore
Description: Bundlore  has obfuscated data with base64, AES, RC4, and bz2.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors used Base64-encoded strings.

Name: C0017
Description: During  C0017 ,  APT41  broke malicious binaries, including  DEADEYE  and  KEYPLUG , into multiple sections on disk to evade detection.

Name: Carbanak
Description: Carbanak  encrypts strings to make analysis more difficult.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp  has used XOR-based encryption to mask C2 server locations within the trojan.

Name: Carbon
Description: Carbon  encrypts configuration files and tasks for the malware to complete using CAST-128 algorithm.

Name: Cardinal RAT
Description: Cardinal RAT  encodes many of its artifacts and is encrypted (AES-128) when downloaded.

Name: CARROTBALL
Description: CARROTBALL  has used a custom base64 alphabet to decode files.

Name: CARROTBAT
Description: CARROTBAT  has the ability to download a base64 encoded payload.

Name: Chinoxy
Description: Chinoxy  has encrypted its configuration file.

Name: Chrommme
Description: Chrommme  can encrypt sections of its code to evade detection.

Name: Clambling
Description: The  Clambling  executable has been obfuscated when dropped on a compromised host.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can hash functions to obfuscate calls to the Windows API and use a public/private key pair to encrypt Beacon session metadata.

Name: CoinTicker
Description: CoinTicker  initially downloads a hidden encoded file.

Name: Comnie
Description: Comnie  uses RC4 and Base64 to obfuscate strings.

Name: ComRAT
Description: ComRAT  has encrypted its virtual file system using AES-256 in XTS mode.

Name: Conficker
Description: Conficker  has obfuscated its code to prevent its removal from host machines.

Name: Conti
Description: Conti  can use compiler-based obfuscation for its code, encrypt DLLs, and hide Windows API calls.

Name: CORESHELL
Description: CORESHELL  obfuscates strings using a custom stream cipher.

Name: CozyCar
Description: The payload of  CozyCar  is encrypted with simple XOR with a rotating key. The  CozyCar  configuration file has been encrypted with RC4 keys.

Name: Cuba
Description: Cuba  has used multiple layers of obfuscation to avoid analysis, including its Base64 encoded payload.

Name: Dacls
Description: Dacls  can encrypt its configuration file with AES CBC.

Name: DanBot
Description: DanBot  can Base64 encode its payload.

Name: Dark Caracal
Description: Dark Caracal  has obfuscated strings in  Bandook  by base64 encoding, and then encrypting them.

Name: Darkhotel
Description: Darkhotel  has obfuscated code using RC4, XOR, and RSA.

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla  has been obfuscated with the DeepSea .NET and ConfuserEx code obfuscators.

Name: DarkWatchman
Description: DarkWatchman  has been delivered as compressed RAR payloads in ZIP files to victims.

Name: Daserf
Description: Daserf  uses encrypted Windows APIs and also encrypts data using the alternative base64+RC4 or the Caesar cipher.

Name: DCSrv
Description: DCSrv 's configuration is encrypted.

Name: DEADEYE
Description: DEADEYE  has encrypted its payload.

Name: Denis
Description: Denis  obfuscates its code and encrypts the API names.

Name: Diavol
Description: Diavol  has Base64 encoded the RSA public key used for encrypting files.

Name: DOGCALL
Description: DOGCALL  is encrypted using single-byte XOR.

Name: Donut
Description: Donut  can generate encrypted, compressed/encoded, or otherwise obfuscated code modules.

Name: DRATzarus
Description: DRATzarus  can be partly encrypted with XOR.

Name: Dridex
Description: Dridex 's strings are obfuscated using RC4.

Name: Drovorub
Description: Drovorub  has used XOR encrypted payloads in WebSocket client to server messages.

Name: DustySky
Description: The  DustySky  dropper uses a function to obfuscate the name of functions and other parts of the malware.

Name: Earth Lusca
Description: Earth Lusca  used Base64 to encode strings.

Name: Ebury
Description: Ebury  has obfuscated its strings with a simple XOR encryption with a static key.

Name: ECCENTRICBANDWAGON
Description: ECCENTRICBANDWAGON  has encrypted strings with RC4.

Name: Ecipekac
Description: Ecipekac  can use XOR, AES, and DES to encrypt loader shellcode.

Name: EKANS
Description: EKANS  uses encoded strings in its process kill list.

Name: Elderwood
Description: Elderwood  has encrypted documents and malicious executables.

Name: Elise
Description: Elise  encrypts several of its files, including configuration files.

Name: Ember Bear
Description: Ember Bear  has obfuscated malware to help avoid detection.

Name: Emissary
Description: Variants of  Emissary  encrypt payloads using various XOR ciphers, as well as a custom algorithm that uses the "srand" and "rand" functions.

Name: EnvyScout
Description: EnvyScout  can Base64 encode payloads.

Name: Epic
Description: Epic  heavily obfuscates its code to make analysis more difficult.

Name: Exaramel for Linux
Description: Exaramel for Linux  uses RC4 for encrypting the configuration.

Name: FatDuke
Description: FatDuke  can use base64 encoding, string stacking, and opaque predicates for obfuscation.

Name: FELIXROOT
Description: FELIXROOT  encrypts strings in the backdoor using a custom XOR algorithm.

Name: Final1stspy
Description: Final1stspy  obfuscates strings with base64 encoding.

Name: FinFisher
Description: FinFisher  is heavily obfuscated in many ways, including through the use of spaghetti code in its functions in an effort to confuse disassembly programs. It also uses a custom XOR algorithm to obfuscate code.

Name: FIVEHANDS
Description: The  FIVEHANDS  payload is encrypted with AES-128.

Name: Flagpro
Description: Flagpro  has been delivered within ZIP or RAR password-protected archived files.

Name: FlawedGrace
Description: FlawedGrace  encrypts its C2 configuration files with AES in CBC mode.

Name: FoggyWeb
Description: FoggyWeb  has been XOR-encoded.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has base64 encoded payloads to avoid detection.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: FunnyDream  can Base64 encode its C2 address stored in a template binary with the  xyz0123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvw_-  or xyz0123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvw_=  character sets.

Name: Fysbis
Description: Fysbis  has been encrypted using XOR and RC4.

Name: GALLIUM
Description: GALLIUM  used a modified version of  HTRAN  in which they obfuscated strings such as debug messages in an apparent attempt to evade detection.

Name: Gallmaker
Description: Gallmaker  obfuscated shellcode used during execution.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  has delivered self-extracting 7z archive files within malicious document attachments.

Name: Gazer
Description: Gazer  logs its actions into files that are encrypted with 3DES. It also uses RSA to encrypt resources.

Name: Gelsemium
Description: Gelsemium  has the ability to compress its components.

Name: GoldenSpy
Description: GoldenSpy 's uninstaller has base64-encoded its variables.

Name: GoldMax
Description: GoldMax  has written AES-encrypted and Base64-encoded configuration files to disk.

Name: Goopy
Description: Goopy 's decrypter have been inflated with junk code in between legitimate API functions, and also included infinite loops to avoid analysis.

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: The  Grandoreiro  payload has been delivered encrypted with a custom XOR-based algorithm and also as a base64-encoded ZIP file.

Name: GravityRAT
Description: GravityRAT  supports file encryption (AES with the key "lolomycin2017").

Name: Green Lambert
Description: Green Lambert  has encrypted strings.

Name: GreyEnergy
Description: GreyEnergy  encrypts its configuration files with AES-256 and also encrypts its strings.

Name: GrimAgent
Description: GrimAgent  has used Rotate on Right (RoR) and Rotate on Left (RoL) functionality to encrypt strings.

Name: Group5
Description: Group5  disguised its malicious binaries with several layers of obfuscation, including encrypting the files.

Name: H1N1
Description: H1N1  uses multiple techniques to obfuscate strings, including XOR.

Name: Hancitor
Description: Hancitor  has used Base64 to encode malicious links.  Hancitor  has also delivered compressed payloads in ZIP files to victims.

Name: HAWKBALL
Description: HAWKBALL  has encrypted the payload with an XOR-based algorithm.

Name: Helminth
Description: The  Helminth  config file is encrypted with RC4.

Name: HermeticWiper
Description: HermeticWiper  can compress 32-bit and 64-bit driver files with the Lempel-Ziv algorithm.

Name: HermeticWizard
Description: HermeticWizard  has the ability to encrypt PE files with a reverse XOR loop.

Name: Heyoka Backdoor
Description: Heyoka Backdoor  can encrypt its payload.

Name: Hi-Zor
Description: Hi-Zor  uses various XOR techniques to obfuscate its components.

Name: HiddenWasp
Description: HiddenWasp  encrypts its configuration and payload.

Name: Higaisa
Description: Higaisa  used Base64 encoded compressed payloads.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has encrypted an ELF file.

Name: HOMEFRY
Description: Some strings in  HOMEFRY  are obfuscated with XOR x56.

Name: HotCroissant
Description: HotCroissant  has encrypted strings with single-byte XOR and base64 encoded RC4.

Name: HTTPBrowser
Description: HTTPBrowser 's code may be obfuscated through structured exception handling and return-oriented programming.

Name: Hydraq
Description: Hydraq  uses basic obfuscation in the form of spaghetti code.

Name: HyperBro
Description: HyperBro  can be delivered encrypted to a compromised host.

Name: IcedID
Description: IcedID  has utilzed encrypted binaries and base64 encoded strings.

Name: Imminent Monitor
Description: Imminent Monitor  has encrypted the spearphish attachments to avoid detection from email gateways; the debugger also encrypts information before sending to the C2.

Name: Inception
Description: Inception  has encrypted malware payloads dropped on victim machines with AES and RC4 encryption.

Name: Industroyer
Description: Industroyer  uses heavily obfuscated code in its Windows Notepad backdoor.

Name: InnaputRAT
Description: InnaputRAT  uses an 8-byte XOR key to obfuscate API names and other strings contained in the payload.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  avoids analysis by encrypting all strings, internal files, configuration data and by using a custom executable format.

Name: IronNetInjector
Description: IronNetInjector  can obfuscate variable names, encrypt strings, as well as base64 encode and Rijndael encrypt payloads.

Name: ISMInjector
Description: ISMInjector  is obfuscated with the off-the-shelf SmartAssembly .NET obfuscator created by red-gate.com.

Name: JHUHUGIT
Description: Many strings in  JHUHUGIT  are obfuscated with a XOR algorithm.

Name: JPIN
Description: A  JPIN  uses a encrypted and compressed payload that is disguised as a bitmap within the resource section of the installer.

Name: jRAT
Description: jRAT ’s Java payload is encrypted with AES.   Additionally, backdoor files are encrypted using DES as a stream cipher. Later variants of  jRAT  also incorporated AV evasion methods such as Java bytecode obfuscation via the commercial Allatori obfuscation tool.

Name: Kazuar
Description: Kazuar  is obfuscated using the open source ConfuserEx protector.  Kazuar  also obfuscates the name of created files/folders/mutexes and encrypts debug messages written to log files using the Rijndael cipher.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  has used Base64-encoded shellcode strings.

Name: Kerrdown
Description: Kerrdown  can encrypt, encode, and compress multiple layers of shellcode.

Name: Kessel
Description: Kessel 's configuration is hardcoded and RC4 encrypted within the binary.

Name: Kevin
Description: Kevin  has Base64-encoded its configuration file.

Name: KeyBoy
Description: In one version of  KeyBoy , string obfuscation routines were used to hide many of the critical values referenced in the malware.

Name: KEYPLUG
Description: KEYPLUG  can use a hardcoded one-byte XOR encoded configuration file.

Name: KGH_SPY
Description: KGH_SPY  has used encrypted strings in its installer.

Name: KillDisk
Description: KillDisk  uses VMProtect to make reverse engineering the malware more difficult.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has obfuscated binary strings including the use of XOR encryption and Base64 encoding.     Kimsuky  has also modified the first byte of DLL implants targeting victims to prevent recognition of the executable file format.

Name: Kobalos
Description: Kobalos  encrypts all strings using RC4 and bundles all functionality into a single function call.

Name: KONNI
Description: KONNI  is heavily obfuscated and includes encrypted configuration files.

Name: Kwampirs
Description: Kwampirs  downloads additional files that are base64-encoded and encrypted with another cipher.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has used multiple types of encryption and encoding for their payloads, including AES, Caracachs, RC4, XOR, Base64, and other tricks such as creating aliases in code for  Native API  function names.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has obfuscated code using base64 and gzip compression.

Name: LightNeuron
Description: LightNeuron  encrypts its configuration files with AES-256.

Name: Lokibot
Description: Lokibot  has obfuscated strings with base64 encoding.

Name: LoudMiner
Description: LoudMiner  has encrypted DMG files.

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  has been obfuscated and contains encrypted functions.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  malware has used base64-encoded files and has also encrypted embedded strings with AES.

Name: Matryoshka
Description: Matryoshka  obfuscates API function names using a substitute cipher combined with Base64 encoding.

Name: Maze
Description: Maze  has decrypted strings and other important information during the encryption process.  Maze  also calls certain functions dynamically to hinder analysis.

Name: MCMD
Description: MCMD  can Base64 encode output strings prior to sending to C2.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has encoded strings in its malware with base64 as well as with a simple, single-byte XOR obfuscation using key 0x40.

Name: Metador
Description: Metador  has encrypted their payloads.

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain 's module file has been encrypted via XOR.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has encrypted payloads and strings.

Name: Micropsia
Description: Micropsia  obfuscates the configuration with a custom Base64 and XOR.

Name: Milan
Description: Milan  can encode files containing information about the targeted system.

Name: MiniDuke
Description: MiniDuke  can use control flow flattening to obscure code.

Name: Mofang
Description: Mofang  has compressed the  ShimRat  executable within malicious email attachments.  Mofang  has also encrypted payloads before they are downloaded to victims.

Name: Molerats
Description: Molerats  has delivered compressed executables within ZIP files to victims.

Name: More_eggs
Description: More_eggs 's payload has been encrypted with a key that has the hostname and processor family information appended to the end.

Name: Moses Staff
Description: Moses Staff  has used obfuscated web shells in their operations.

Name: Mosquito
Description: Mosquito ’s installer is obfuscated with a custom crypter to obfuscate the installer.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has delivered initial payloads hidden using archives and encoding measures.

Name: NanHaiShu
Description: NanHaiShu  encodes files in Base64.

Name: NanoCore
Description: NanoCore ’s plugins were obfuscated with Eazfuscater.NET 3.3.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  has used a custom obfuscation algorithm to hide strings including Registry keys, APIs, and DLL names.

Name: Night Dragon
Description: During  Night Dragon , threat actors used a DLL that included an XOR-encoded section.

Name: NightClub
Description: NightClub  can obfuscate strings using the congruential generator  (LCG): staten+1 = (690069 × staten + 1) mod 232 .

Name: njRAT
Description: njRAT  has included a base64 encoded executable.

Name: NOKKI
Description: NOKKI  uses Base64 encoding for strings.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has encrypted and encoded data in its malware, including by using base64.

Name: OLDBAIT
Description: OLDBAIT  obfuscates internal strings and unpacks them at startup.

Name: OopsIE
Description: OopsIE  uses the Confuser protector to obfuscate an embedded .Net Framework assembly used for C2.  OopsIE  also encodes collected data in hexadecimal format before writing to files on disk and obfuscates strings.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  encrypted malware such as   DRATzarus  with XOR and DLL files with base64.

Name: Operation Dust Storm
Description: During  Operation Dust Storm , the threat actors encoded some payloads with a single-byte XOR, both skipping the key itself and zeroing in an attempt to avoid exposing the key; other payloads were Base64-encoded.

Name: Operation Honeybee
Description: During  Operation Honeybee , the threat actors used Base64 to encode files with a custom key.

Name: Operation Spalax
Description: For  Operation Spalax , the threat actors used XOR-encrypted payloads.

Name: Orz
Description: Some  Orz  strings are base64 encoded, such as the embedded DLL known as MockDll.

Name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D  encrypts its strings in RSA256 and encodes them in a custom base64 scheme and XOR.

Name: Out1
Description: Out1  has the ability to encode data.

Name: P.A.S. Webshell
Description: P.A.S. Webshell  can use encryption and base64 encoding to hide strings and to enforce access control once deployed.

Name: Pandora
Description: Pandora  has the ability to compress stings with QuickLZ.

Name: PcShare
Description: PcShare  has been encrypted with XOR using different 32-long Base16 strings and compressed with LZW algorithm.

Name: Penquin
Description: Penquin  has encrypted strings in the binary for obfuscation.

Name: Pillowmint
Description: Pillowmint  has been compressed and stored within a registry key.  Pillowmint  has also obfuscated the AES key used for encryption.

Name: PipeMon
Description: PipeMon  modules are stored encrypted on disk.

Name: Pisloader
Description: Pisloader  obfuscates files by splitting strings into smaller sub-strings and including "garbage" strings that are never used. The malware also uses return-oriented programming (ROP) technique and single-byte XOR to obfuscate data.

Name: PlugX
Description: PlugX  can use API hashing and modify the names of strings to evade detection.

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  has used a custom encryption scheme for communication between scripts.

Name: PoisonIvy
Description: PoisonIvy  hides any strings related to its own indicators of compromise.

Name: PolyglotDuke
Description: PolyglotDuke  can custom encrypt strings.

Name: Pony
Description: Pony  attachments have been delivered via compressed archive files.  Pony  also obfuscates the memory flow by adding junk instructions when executing to make analysis more difficult.

Name: POSHSPY
Description: POSHSPY  appends a file signature header (randomly selected from six file types) to encrypted data prior to upload or download.

Name: PowerStallion
Description: PowerStallion  uses a XOR cipher to encrypt command output written to its OneDrive C2 server.

Name: Prikormka
Description: Some resources in  Prikormka  are encrypted with a simple XOR operation or encoded with Base64.

Name: PS1
Description: PS1  is distributed as a set of encrypted files and scripts.

Name: PUNCHBUGGY
Description: PUNCHBUGGY  has hashed most its code's functions and encrypted payloads with base64 and XOR.

Name: PUNCHTRACK
Description: PUNCHTRACK  is loaded and executed by a highly obfuscated launcher.

Name: Putter Panda
Description: Droppers used by  Putter Panda  use RC4 or a 16-byte XOR key consisting of the bytes 0xA0 – 0xAF to obfuscate payloads.

Name: PyDCrypt
Description: PyDCrypt  has been compiled and encrypted with PyInstaller, specifically using the --key flag during the build phase.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  has hidden code within Excel spreadsheets by turning the font color to white and splitting it across multiple cells.

Name: Raindrop
Description: Raindrop  encrypted its payload using a simple XOR algorithm with a single-byte key.

Name: RainyDay
Description: RainyDay  has downloaded as a XOR-encrypted payload.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  has base64-encoded its portable executable and hidden itself under a JPG header.  Ramsay  can also embed information within document footers.

Name: RCSession
Description: RCSession  can compress and obfuscate its strings to evade detection on a compromised host.

Name: Reaver
Description: Reaver  encrypts some of its files with XOR.

Name: RedLeaves
Description: A  RedLeaves  configuration file is encrypted with a simple XOR key, 0x53.

Name: RegDuke
Description: RegDuke  can use control-flow flattening or the commercially available .NET Reactor for obfuscation.

Name: Remcos
Description: Remcos  uses RC4 and base64 to obfuscate data, including Registry entries and file paths.

Name: Remexi
Description: Remexi  obfuscates its configuration data with XOR.

Name: Remsec
Description: Some data in  Remsec  is encrypted using RC5 in CBC mode, AES-CBC with a hardcoded key, RC4, or Salsa20. Some data is also base64-encoded.

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  has used encrypted strings and configuration files.

Name: Rifdoor
Description: Rifdoor  has encrypted strings with a single byte XOR algorithm.

Name: Rising Sun
Description: Configuration data used by  Rising Sun  has been encrypted using an RC4 stream algorithm.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  has modified UPX headers after packing files to break unpackers.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  can encrypt data prior to exfiltration by using an RSA public key.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  strings, network data, configuration, and modules are encrypted with a modified RC4 algorithm.  RTM  has also been delivered to targets as various archive files including ZIP, 7-ZIP, and RAR.

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  can use anti-disassembly and code transformation obfuscation techniques.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  has been obfuscated to help avoid detection.

Name: Sakula
Description: Sakula  uses single-byte XOR obfuscation to obfuscate many of its files.

Name: SamSam
Description: SamSam  has been seen using AES or DES to encrypt payloads and payload components.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has used Base64 encoding within malware variants.

Name: Sardonic
Description: Sardonic  can use certain ConfuserEx features for obfuscation and can be encoded in a base64 string.

Name: SDBbot
Description: SDBbot  has the ability to XOR the strings for its installer component with a hardcoded 128 byte key.

Name: Seasalt
Description: Seasalt  obfuscates configuration data.

Name: ShadowPad
Description: ShadowPad  has encrypted its payload, a virtual file system, and various files.

Name: Shamoon
Description: Shamoon  contains base64-encoded strings.

Name: Shark
Description: Shark  can use encrypted and encoded files for C2 configuration.

Name: ShimRat
Description: ShimRat  has been delivered as a package that includes compressed DLL and shellcode payloads within a .dat file.

Name: ShimRatReporter
Description: ShimRatReporter  encrypted gathered information with a combination of shifting and XOR using a static key.

Name: SHOTPUT
Description: SHOTPUT  is obscured using XOR encoding and appended to a valid GIF file.

Name: Sidewinder
Description: Sidewinder  has used base64 encoding and ECDH-P256 encryption for payloads.

Name: Siloscape
Description: Siloscape  itself is obfuscated and uses obfuscated API calls.

Name: Skidmap
Description: Skidmap  has encrypted it's main payload using 3DES.

Name: Sliver
Description: Sliver  can encrypt strings at compile time.

Name: Small Sieve
Description: Small Sieve  has the ability to use a custom hex byte swapping encoding scheme combined with an obfuscated Base64 function to protect program strings and Telegram credentials.

Name: Smoke Loader
Description: Smoke Loader  uses a simple one-byte XOR method to obfuscate values in the malware.

Name: Snip3
Description: Snip3  has the ability to obfuscate strings using XOR encryption.

Name: SodaMaster
Description: SodaMaster  can use "stackstrings" for obfuscation.

Name: SombRAT
Description: SombRAT  can encrypt strings with XOR-based routines and use a custom AES storage format for plugins, configuration, C2 domains, and harvested data.

Name: SoreFang
Description: SoreFang  has the ability to encode and RC6 encrypt data sent to C2.

Name: SpeakUp
Description: SpeakUp  encodes its second-stage payload with Base64.

Name: Squirrelwaffle
Description: Squirrelwaffle  has been obfuscated with a XOR-based algorithm.

Name: STARWHALE
Description: STARWHALE  has been obfuscated with hex-encoded strings.

Name: StoneDrill
Description: StoneDrill  has obfuscated its module with an alphabet-based table or XOR encryption.

Name: StreamEx
Description: StreamEx  obfuscates some commands by using statically programmed fragments of strings when starting a DLL. It also uses a one-byte xor against 0x91 to encode configuration data.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  has used encrypted strings in its dropper component.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  uses encrypted configuration blocks and writes encrypted files to disk.

Name: SUNBURST
Description: SUNBURST  strings were compressed and encoded in Base64.    SUNBURST  also obfuscated collected system information using a FNV-1a + XOR algorithm.

Name: SUNSPOT
Description: SUNSPOT  encrypted log entries it collected with the stream cipher RC4 using a hard-coded key. It also uses AES128-CBC encrypted blobs for  SUNBURST  source code and data extracted from the SolarWinds Orion <MsBuild.exe process.

Name: SUPERNOVA
Description: SUPERNOVA  contained Base64-encoded strings.

Name: SVCReady
Description: SVCReady  can encrypt victim data with an RC4 cipher.

Name: SynAck
Description: SynAck  payloads are obfuscated prior to compilation to inhibit analysis and/or reverse engineering.

Name: SysUpdate
Description: SysUpdate  can encrypt and encode its configuration file.

Name: TA2541
Description: TA2541  has used compressed and char-encoded scripts in operations.

Name: TA505
Description: TA505  has password-protected malicious Word documents.

Name: Taidoor
Description: Taidoor  can use encrypted string blocks for obfuscation.

Name: TajMahal
Description: TajMahal  has used an encrypted Virtual File System to store plugins.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has encrypted its binaries via AES and encoded files using Base64.

Name: TEARDROP
Description: TEARDROP  created and read from a file with a fake JPG header, and its payload was encrypted with a simple rotating XOR cipher.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: A  Threat Group-3390  tool can encrypt payloads using XOR.  Threat Group-3390  malware is also obfuscated using Metasploit’s shikata_ga_nai encoder as well as compressed with LZNT1 compression.

Name: ThreatNeedle
Description: ThreatNeedle  has been compressed and obfuscated using RC4, AES, or XOR.

Name: TINYTYPHON
Description: TINYTYPHON  has used XOR with 0x90 to obfuscate its configuration file.

Name: Torisma
Description: Torisma  has been Base64 encoded and AES encrypted.

Name: Transparent Tribe
Description: Transparent Tribe  has dropped encoded executables on compromised hosts.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  uses non-descriptive names to hide functionality and uses an AES CBC (256 bits) encryption algorithm for its loader and configuration files.

Name: Trojan.Karagany
Description: Trojan.Karagany  can base64 encode and AES-128-CBC encrypt data prior to transmission.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has encrypted configuration files.

Name: Turian
Description: Turian  can use VMProtect for obfuscation.

Name: TYPEFRAME
Description: APIs and strings in some  TYPEFRAME  variants are RC4 encrypted. Another variant is encoded with XOR.

Name: UBoatRAT
Description: UBoatRAT  encrypts instructions in the payload using a simple XOR cipher.

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  can use AES and CAST-128 encryption to obfuscate resources.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has used an XOR-based algorithm to encrypt Tor clients dropped to disk.    Ursnif  droppers have also been delivered as password-protected zip files that execute base64 encoded  PowerShell  commands.

Name: USBStealer
Description: Most strings in  USBStealer  are encrypted using 3DES and XOR and reversed.

Name: Valak
Description: Valak  has the ability to base64 encode and XOR encrypt strings.

Name: VERMIN
Description: VERMIN  is obfuscated using the obfuscation tool called ConfuserEx.

Name: Volgmer
Description: A  Volgmer  variant is encoded using a simple XOR cipher.

Name: WastedLocker
Description: The  WastedLocker  payload includes encrypted strings stored within the .bss section of the binary file.

Name: Waterbear
Description: Waterbear  has used RC4 encrypted shellcode and encrypted functions.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  can Base64 encode strings, store downloaded files in reverse byte order,  and use the Eazfuscator tool to obfuscate its third stage.

Name: Whitefly
Description: Whitefly  has encrypted the payload used for C2.

Name: Windshift
Description: Windshift  has used string encoding with floating point calculations.

Name: WindTail
Description: WindTail  can be delivered as a compressed, encrypted, and encoded payload.

Name: Winnti for Linux
Description: Winnti for Linux  can encode its configuration file with single-byte XOR encoding.

Name: Winnti for Windows
Description: Winnti for Windows  has the ability to encrypt and compress its payload.

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  has used Base64 encoded strings and scripts.

Name: XTunnel
Description: A version of  XTunnel  introduced in July 2015 obfuscated the binary using opaque predicates and other techniques in a likely attempt to obfuscate it and bypass security products.

Name: YAHOYAH
Description: YAHOYAH  encrypts its configuration file using a simple algorithm.

Name: ZeroT
Description: ZeroT  has encrypted its payload with RC4.

Name: Zeus Panda
Description: Zeus Panda  encrypts strings with XOR.  Zeus Panda  also encrypts all configuration and settings in AES and RC4.

Name: Zox
Description: Zox  has been encoded with Base64.

Name: ZxxZ
Description: ZxxZ  has been encoded to avoid detection from static analysis tools.

Name: Antivirus/Antimalware
Description: Anti-virus can be used to automatically detect and quarantine suspicious files. Consider utilizing the Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI) on Windows 10+ to analyze commands after being processed/interpreted.

Name: Audit
Description: Consider periodic review of common fileless storage locations (such as the Registry or WMI repository) to potentially identify abnormal and malicious data.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: On Windows 10+, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to prevent execution of potentially obfuscated payloads.

Name: User Training
Description: Ensure that a finite amount of ingress points to a software deployment system exist with restricted access for those required to allow and enable newly deployed software.

Name: ABK
Description: ABK  has the ability to decrypt AES encrypted payloads.

Name: Action RAT
Description: Action RAT  can use Base64 to decode actor-controlled C2 server communications.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  has the ability to decrypt strings encrypted with the Rijndael symmetric encryption algorithm.

Name: Amadey
Description: Amadey  has decoded antivirus name strings.

Name: AppleJeus
Description: AppleJeus  has decoded files received from a C2.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  can decode its payload prior to execution.

Name: APT19
Description: An  APT19  HTTP malware variant decrypts strings using single-byte XOR keys.

Name: APT28
Description: An  APT28  macro uses the command  certutil -decode  to decode contents of a .txt file storing the base64 encoded payload.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used malware to decrypt encrypted CAB files.

Name: Aria-body
Description: Aria-body  has the ability to decrypt the loader configuration and payload DLL.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  uses a fromCharCode() deobfuscation method to avoid explicitly writing execution commands and to hide its code.

Name: AuditCred
Description: AuditCred  uses XOR and RC4 to perform decryption on the code functions.

Name: Avaddon
Description: Avaddon  has decrypted encrypted strings.

Name: Avenger
Description: Avenger  has the ability to decrypt files downloaded from C2.

Name: AvosLocker
Description: AvosLocker  has deobfuscated XOR-encoded strings.

Name: Azorult
Description: Azorult  uses an XOR key to decrypt content and uses Base64 to decode the C2 address.

Name: Babuk
Description: Babuk  has the ability to unpack itself into memory using XOR.

Name: BabyShark
Description: BabyShark  has the ability to decode downloaded files prior to execution.

Name: BackConfig
Description: BackConfig  has used a custom routine to decrypt strings.

Name: BADFLICK
Description: BADFLICK  can decode shellcode using a custom rotating XOR cipher.

Name: Bandook
Description: Bandook  has decoded its PowerShell script.

Name: Bankshot
Description: Bankshot  decodes embedded XOR strings.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can decrypt downloaded payloads.  Bazar  also resolves strings and other artifacts at runtime.

Name: BBK
Description: BBK  has the ability to decrypt AES encrypted payloads.

Name: BBSRAT
Description: BBSRAT  uses  Expand  to decompress a CAB file into executable content.

Name: BendyBear
Description: BendyBear  has decrypted function blocks using a XOR key during runtime to evade detection.

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal  has decoded strings in the malware using XOR and RC4.

Name: BLINDINGCAN
Description: BLINDINGCAN  has used AES and XOR to decrypt its DLLs.

Name: BoomBox
Description: BoomBox  can decrypt AES-encrypted files downloaded from C2.

Name: BOOSTWRITE
Description: BOOSTWRITE  has used a a 32-byte long multi-XOR key to decode data inside its payload.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  downloads encoded payloads and decodes them on the victim.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  has the ability to deobfuscate its payload prior to execution.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  can deobfuscate C2 server responses and unpack its code on targeted hosts.

Name: Bundlore
Description: Bundlore  has used  openssl  to decrypt AES encrypted payload data.  Bundlore  has also used base64 and RC4 with a hardcoded key to deobfuscate data.

Name: C0017
Description: During  C0017 ,  APT41  used the DUSTPAN loader to decrypt embedded payloads.

Name: C0021
Description: During  C0021 , the threat actors deobfuscated encoded PowerShell commands including use of the specific string  'FromBase'+0x40+'String' , in place of  FromBase64String  which is normally used to decode base64.

Name: Carbon
Description: Carbon  decrypts task and configuration files for execution.

Name: Cardinal RAT
Description: Cardinal RAT  decodes many of its artifacts and is decrypted (AES-128) after being downloaded.

Name: certutil
Description: certutil  has been used to decode binaries hidden inside certificate files as Base64 information.

Name: Chaes
Description: Chaes  has decrypted an AES encrypted binary file to trigger the download of other files.

Name: CharmPower
Description: CharmPower  can decrypt downloaded modules prior to execution.

Name: Chinoxy
Description: The  Chinoxy  dropping function can initiate decryption of its config file.

Name: Chrommme
Description: Chrommme  can decrypt its encrypted internal code.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  can deobfuscate its payload prior to execution.

Name: Clop
Description: Clop  has used a simple XOR operation to decrypt strings.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can deobfuscate shellcode using a rolling XOR and decrypt metadata from Beacon sessions.

Name: CoinTicker
Description: CoinTicker  decodes the initially-downloaded hidden encoded file using OpenSSL.

Name: ComRAT
Description: ComRAT  has used unique per machine passwords to decrypt the orchestrator payload and a hardcoded XOR key to decrypt its communications module.  ComRAT  has also used a unique password to decrypt the file used for its hidden file system.

Name: Conti
Description: Conti  has decrypted its payload using a hardcoded AES-256 key.

Name: CookieMiner
Description: CookieMiner  has used Google Chrome's decryption and extraction operations.

Name: CostaBricks
Description: CostaBricks  has the ability to use bytecode to decrypt embedded payloads.

Name: Crimson
Description: Crimson  can decode its encoded PE file prior to execution.

Name: Cyclops Blink
Description: Cyclops Blink  can decrypt and parse instructions sent from C2.

Name: DanBot
Description: DanBot  can use a VBA macro to decode its payload prior to installation and execution.

Name: Darkhotel
Description: Darkhotel  has decrypted strings and imports using RC4 during execution.

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla  can decrypt its payload and associated configuration elements using the Rijndael cipher.

Name: DarkWatchman
Description: DarkWatchman  has the ability to self-extract as a RAR archive.

Name: DDKONG
Description: DDKONG  decodes an embedded configuration using XOR.

Name: DEADEYE
Description: DEADEYE  has the ability to combine multiple sections of a binary which were broken up to evade detection into a single .dll prior to execution.

Name: Denis
Description: Denis  will decrypt important strings used for C&C communication.

Name: DropBook
Description: DropBook  can unarchive data downloaded from the C2 to obtain the payload and persistence modules.

Name: Drovorub
Description: Drovorub  has de-obsfuscated XOR encrypted payloads in WebSocket messages.

Name: Dtrack
Description: Dtrack  has used a decryption routine that is part of an executable physical patch.

Name: Dyre
Description: Dyre  decrypts resources needed for targeting the victim.

Name: Earth Lusca
Description: Earth Lusca  has used  certutil  to decode a string into a cabinet file.

Name: Ebury
Description: Ebury  has verified C2 domain ownership by decrypting the TXT record using an embedded RSA public key.

Name: Ecipekac
Description: Ecipekac  has the ability to decrypt fileless loader modules.

Name: Egregor
Description: Egregor  has been decrypted before execution.

Name: Emotet
Description: Emotet  has used a self-extracting RAR file to deliver modules to victims. Emotet has also extracted embedded executables from files using hard-coded buffer offsets.

Name: EnvyScout
Description: EnvyScout  can deobfuscate and write malicious ISO files to disk.

Name: Exaramel for Linux
Description: Exaramel for Linux  can decrypt its configuration file.

Name: Expand
Description: Expand  can be used to decompress a local or remote CAB file into an executable.

Name: FatDuke
Description: FatDuke  can decrypt AES encrypted C2 communications.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has utilized  certutil  to decode base64 encoded versions of custom malware.

Name: Final1stspy
Description: Final1stspy  uses Python code to deobfuscate base64-encoded strings.

Name: FinFisher
Description: FinFisher  extracts and decrypts stage 3 malware, which is stored in encrypted resources.

Name: FIVEHANDS
Description: FIVEHANDS  has the ability to decrypt its payload prior to execution.

Name: FoggyWeb
Description: FoggyWeb  can be decrypted in memory using a Lightweight Encryption Algorithm (LEA)-128 key and decoded using a XOR key.

Name: Frankenstein
Description: During  Frankenstein , the threat actors deobfuscated Base64-encoded commands following the execution of a malicious script, which revealed a small script designed to obtain an additional payload.

Name: FYAnti
Description: FYAnti  has the ability to decrypt an embedded .NET module.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  tools decrypted additional payloads from the C2.  Gamaredon Group  has also decoded base64-encoded source code of a downloader.

Name: Gelsemium
Description: Gelsemium  can decompress and decrypt DLLs and shellcode.

Name: gh0st RAT
Description: gh0st RAT  has decrypted and loaded the  gh0st RAT  DLL into memory, once the initial dropper executable is launched.

Name: GoldMax
Description: GoldMax  has decoded and decrypted the configuration file when executed.

Name: Goopy
Description: Goopy  has used a polymorphic decryptor to decrypt itself at runtime.

Name: Gorgon Group
Description: Gorgon Group  malware can decode contents from a payload that was Base64 encoded and write the contents to a file.

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  can decrypt its encrypted internal strings.

Name: Green Lambert
Description: Green Lambert  can use multiple custom routines to decrypt strings prior to execution.

Name: GrimAgent
Description: GrimAgent  can use a decryption algorithm for strings based on Rotate on Right (RoR) and Rotate on Left (RoL) functionality.

Name: Hancitor
Description: Hancitor  has decoded Base64 encoded URLs to insert a recipient’s name into the filename of the Word document.  Hancitor  has also extracted executables from ZIP files.

Name: HermeticWiper
Description: HermeticWiper  can decompress and copy driver files using  LZCopy .

Name: Heyoka Backdoor
Description: Heyoka Backdoor  can decrypt its payload prior to execution.

Name: HiddenWasp
Description: HiddenWasp  uses a cipher to implement a decoding function.

Name: Higaisa
Description: Higaisa  used certutil to decode Base64 binaries at runtime and a 16-byte XOR key to decrypt data.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has decrypted ELF files with AES.

Name: HyperBro
Description: HyperBro  can unpack and decrypt its payload prior to execution.

Name: IceApple
Description: IceApple  can use a Base64-encoded AES key to decrypt tasking.

Name: Imminent Monitor
Description: Imminent Monitor  has decoded malware components that are then dropped to the system.

Name: Industroyer
Description: Industroyer  decrypts code to connect to a remote C2 server.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can decrypt, unpack and load a DLL from its resources, or from blobs encrypted with Data Protection API, two-key triple DES, and variations of the XOR cipher.

Name: IronNetInjector
Description: IronNetInjector  has the ability to decrypt embedded .NET and PE payloads.

Name: ISMInjector
Description: ISMInjector  uses the  certutil  command to decode a payload file.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  has deobfuscated Base64-encoded shellcode strings prior to loading them.

Name: Kerrdown
Description: Kerrdown  can decode, decrypt, and decompress multiple layers of shellcode.

Name: Kessel
Description: Kessel  has decrypted the binary's configuration once the  main  function was launched.

Name: KEYPLUG
Description: KEYPLUG  can decode its configuration file to determine C2 protocols.

Name: KGH_SPY
Description: KGH_SPY  can decrypt encrypted strings and write them to a newly created folder.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has decoded malicious VBScripts using Base64.

Name: Kobalos
Description: Kobalos  decrypts strings right after the initial communication, but before the authentication process.

Name: KOCTOPUS
Description: KOCTOPUS  has deobfuscated itself before executing its commands.

Name: KONNI
Description: KONNI  has used certutil to download and decode base64 encoded strings and has also devoted a custom section to performing all the components of the deobfuscation process.

Name: Kwampirs
Description: Kwampirs  decrypts and extracts a copy of its main DLL payload when executing.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has used shellcode within macros to decrypt and manually map DLLs and shellcode into memory at runtime.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has used a DLL known as SeDll to decrypt and execute other JavaScript backdoors.

Name: LightNeuron
Description: LightNeuron  has used AES and XOR to decrypt configuration files and commands.

Name: LiteDuke
Description: LiteDuke  has the ability to decrypt and decode multiple layers of obfuscation.

Name: Lizar
Description: Lizar  can decrypt its configuration data.

Name: Lokibot
Description: Lokibot  has decoded and decrypted its stages multiple times using hard-coded keys to deliver the final payload, and has decoded its server response hex string using XOR.

Name: LookBack
Description: LookBack  has a function that decrypts malicious data.

Name: Lucifer
Description: Lucifer  can decrypt its C2 address upon execution.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete ’s downloaded data is decrypted using AES.

Name: MacMa
Description: MacMa  decrypts a downloaded file using AES-128-EBC with a custom delta.

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can decrypt files and data.

Name: MegaCortex
Description: MegaCortex  has used a Base64 key to decode its components.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has used  certutil  in a macro to decode base64-encoded content contained in a dropper document attached to an email. The group has also used  certutil -decode  to decode files on the victim’s machine when dropping  UPPERCUT .

Name: MESSAGETAP
Description: After checking for the existence of two files, keyword_parm.txt and parm.txt,  MESSAGETAP  XOR decodes and read the contents of the files.

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  can decrypt and load other modules.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Upon execution,  Metamorfo  has unzipped itself after being downloaded to the system and has performed string decryption.

Name: MirageFox
Description: MirageFox  has a function for decrypting data containing C2 configuration information.

Name: Molerats
Description: Molerats  decompresses ZIP files once on the victim machine.

Name: Mongall
Description: Mongall  has the ability to decrypt its payload prior to execution.

Name: More_eggs
Description: More_eggs  will decode malware components that are then dropped to the system.

Name: Mori
Description: Mori  can resolve networking APIs from strings that are ADD-encrypted.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  decoded base64-encoded PowerShell commands using a VBS file.

Name: NativeZone
Description: NativeZone  can decrypt and decode embedded   Cobalt Strike  beacon stage shellcode.

Name: Netwalker
Description: Netwalker 's PowerShell script can decode and decrypt multiple layers of obfuscation, leading to the  Netwalker  DLL being loaded into memory.

Name: NOKKI
Description: NOKKI  uses a unique, custom de-obfuscation technique.

Name: OilRig
Description: A  OilRig  macro has run a PowerShell command to decode file contents.  OilRig  has also used  certutil  to decode base64-encoded files on victims.

Name: Okrum
Description: Okrum 's loader can decrypt the backdoor code, embedded within the loader or within a legitimate PNG file. A custom XOR cipher or RC4 is used for decryption.

Name: OnionDuke
Description: OnionDuke  can use a custom decryption algorithm to decrypt strings.

Name: OopsIE
Description: OopsIE  concatenates then decompresses multiple resources to load an embedded .Net Framework assembly.

Name: Operation Dust Storm
Description: During  Operation Dust Storm , attackers used VBS code to decode payloads.

Name: Operation Honeybee
Description: During  Operation Honeybee , malicious files were decoded prior to execution.

Name: Operation Spalax
Description: For  Operation Spalax , the threat actors used a variety of packers and droppers to decrypt malicious payloads.

Name: OSX/Shlayer
Description: OSX/Shlayer  can base64-decode and AES-decrypt downloaded payloads.   Versions of  OSX/Shlayer  pass encrypted and password-protected code to  openssl  and then write the payload to the  /tmp  folder.

Name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D  uses a decode routine combining bit shifting and XOR operations with a variable key that depends on the length of the string that was encoded. If the computation for the variable XOR key turns out to be 0, the default XOR key of 0x1B is used. This routine is also referenced as the  rotate  function in reporting.

Name: P.A.S. Webshell
Description: P.A.S. Webshell  can use a decryption mechanism to process a user supplied password and allow execution.

Name: PcShare
Description: PcShare  has decrypted its strings by applying a XOR operation and a decompression using a custom implemented LZM algorithm.

Name: Pillowmint
Description: Pillowmint  has been decompressed by included shellcode prior to being launched.

Name: PingPull
Description: PingPull  can decrypt received data from its C2 server by using AES.

Name: PipeMon
Description: PipeMon  can decrypt password-protected executables.

Name: PlugX
Description: PlugX  decompresses and decrypts itself using the Microsoft API call RtlDecompressBuffer.

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  has used LZMA and base64 libraries to decode obfuscated scripts.

Name: PolyglotDuke
Description: PolyglotDuke  can use a custom algorithm to decrypt strings used by the malware.

Name: PowerLess
Description: PowerLess  can use base64 and AES ECB decryption prior to execution of downloaded modules.

Name: POWERSTATS
Description: POWERSTATS  can deobfuscate the main backdoor code.

Name: PowGoop
Description: PowGoop  can decrypt PowerShell scripts for execution.

Name: Proton
Description: Proton  uses an encrypted file to store commands and configuration values.

Name: PS1
Description: PS1  can use an XOR key to decrypt a PowerShell loader and payload binary.

Name: Pteranodon
Description: Pteranodon  can decrypt encrypted data strings prior to using them.

Name: PUNCHBUGGY
Description: PUNCHBUGGY  has used  PowerShell  to decode base64-encoded assembly.

Name: PyDCrypt
Description: PyDCrypt  has decrypted and dropped the  DCSrv  payload to disk.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can deobfuscate and re-assemble code strings for execution.

Name: QUADAGENT
Description: QUADAGENT  uses AES and a preshared key to decrypt the custom Base64 routine used to encode strings and scripts.

Name: QUIETCANARY
Description: QUIETCANARY  can use a custom parsing routine to decode the command codes and additional parameters from the C2 before executing them.

Name: Raindrop
Description: Raindrop  decrypted its  Cobalt Strike  payload using an AES-256 encryption algorithm in CBC mode with a unique key per sample.

Name: RainyDay
Description: RainyDay  can decrypt its payload via a XOR key.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can extract its agent from the body of a malicious document.

Name: RDAT
Description: RDAT  can deobfuscate the base64-encoded and AES-encrypted files downloaded from the C2 server.

Name: RegDuke
Description: RegDuke  can decrypt strings with a key either stored in the Registry or hardcoded in the code.

Name: Remexi
Description: Remexi  decrypts the configuration data using XOR with 25-character keys.

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  can decode encrypted strings to enable execution of commands and payloads.

Name: RGDoor
Description: RGDoor  decodes Base64 strings and decrypts strings using a custom XOR algorithm.

Name: Rising Sun
Description: Rising Sun  has decrypted itself using a single-byte XOR scheme. Additionally,  Rising Sun  can decrypt its configuration data at runtime.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  has extracted tar.gz files after downloading them from a C2 server.

Name: RogueRobin
Description: RogueRobin  decodes an embedded executable using base64 and decompresses it.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  can decrypt strings using the victim's hostname as the key.

Name: RotaJakiro
Description: RotaJakiro  uses the AES algorithm, bit shifts in a function called  rotate , and an XOR cipher to decrypt resources required for persistence, process guarding, and file locking. It also performs this same function on encrypted stack strings and the  head  and  key  sections in the network packet structure used for C2 communications.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  can deobfuscate strings and files for execution.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team 's VBS backdoor can decode Base64-encoded data and save it to the %TEMP% folder. The group also decrypted received information using the Triple DES algorithm and decompresses it using GZip.

Name: Sardonic
Description: Sardonic  can first decrypt with the RC4 algorithm using a hardcoded decryption key before decompressing.

Name: SDBbot
Description: SDBbot  has the ability to decrypt and decompress its payload to enable code execution.

Name: ShadowPad
Description: ShadowPad  has decrypted a binary blob to start execution.

Name: Shamoon
Description: Shamoon  decrypts ciphertext using an XOR cipher and a base64-encoded string.

Name: Shark
Description: Shark  can extract and decrypt downloaded .zip files.

Name: SharpStage
Description: SharpStage  has decompressed data received from the C2 server.

Name: ShimRat
Description: ShimRat  has decompressed its core DLL using shellcode once an impersonated antivirus component was running on a system.

Name: Sibot
Description: Sibot  can decrypt data received from a C2 and save to a file.

Name: SideTwist
Description: SideTwist  can decode and decrypt messages received from C2.

Name: Siloscape
Description: Siloscape  has decrypted the password of the C2 server with a simple byte by byte XOR.  Siloscape  also writes both an archive of  Tor  and the  unzip  binary to disk from data embedded within the payload using Visual Studio’s Resource Manager.

Name: Skidmap
Description: Skidmap  has the ability to download, unpack, and decrypt tar.gz files .

Name: Smoke Loader
Description: Smoke Loader  deobfuscates its code.

Name: Snip3
Description: Snip3  can decode its second-stage PowerShell script prior to execution.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used 7-Zip to decode their  Raindrop  malware.

Name: SombRAT
Description: SombRAT  can run  upload  to decrypt and upload files from storage.

Name: SoreFang
Description: SoreFang  can decode and decrypt exfiltrated data sent to C2.

Name: Spark
Description: Spark  has used a custom XOR algorithm to decrypt the payload.

Name: SQLRat
Description: SQLRat  has scripts that are responsible for deobfuscating additional scripts.

Name: Squirrelwaffle
Description: Squirrelwaffle  has decrypted files and payloads using a XOR-based algorithm.

Name: Starloader
Description: Starloader  decrypts and executes shellcode from a file called Stars.jps.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  decrypts resources that are loaded into memory and executed.

Name: SUNSPOT
Description: SUNSPOT  decrypts  SUNBURST , which was stored in AES128-CBC encrypted blobs.

Name: SysUpdate
Description: SysUpdate  can deobfuscate packed binaries in memory.

Name: TA505
Description: TA505  has decrypted packed DLLs with an XOR key.

Name: Taidoor
Description: Taidoor  can use a stream cipher to decrypt stings used by the malware.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has used a script that decodes a Base64-encoded version of WeaveWorks Scope.

Name: TEARDROP
Description: TEARDROP  was decoded using a custom rolling XOR algorithm to execute a customized  Cobalt Strike  payload.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: During execution,  Threat Group-3390  malware deobfuscates and decompresses code that was encoded with Metasploit’s shikata_ga_nai encoder as well as compressed with LZNT1 compression.

Name: ThreatNeedle
Description: ThreatNeedle  can decrypt its payload using RC4, AES, or one-byte XORing.

Name: Torisma
Description: Torisma  has used XOR and Base64 to decode C2 data.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  decodes the configuration data and modules.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  used shellcode with an XOR algorithm to decrypt a payload.  Tropic Trooper  also decrypted image files which contained a payload.

Name: TSCookie
Description: TSCookie  has the ability to decrypt, load, and execute a DLL and its resources.

Name: Turian
Description: Turian  has the ability to use a XOR decryption key to extract C2 server domains and IP addresses.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has used a custom decryption routine, which pulls key and salt values from other artifacts such as a WMI filter or  PowerShell Profile , to decode encrypted PowerShell payloads.

Name: TYPEFRAME
Description: One  TYPEFRAME  variant decrypts an archive using an RC4 key, then decompresses and installs the decrypted malicious DLL module. Another variant decodes the embedded file by XORing it with the value "0x35".

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  can decrypt command parameters sent through C2 and use unpacking code to extract its packed executable.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has used crypto key information stored in the Registry to decrypt Tor clients dropped to disk.

Name: Valak
Description: Valak  has the ability to decode and decrypt downloaded files.

Name: VaporRage
Description: VaporRage  can deobfuscate XOR-encoded shellcode prior to execution.

Name: VERMIN
Description: VERMIN  decrypts code, strings, and commands to use once it's on the victim's machine.

Name: Volgmer
Description: Volgmer  deobfuscates its strings and APIs once its executed.

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  can use XOR 0x45 to decrypt obfuscated code.

Name: WastedLocker
Description: WastedLocker 's custom cryptor, CryptOne, used an XOR based algorithm to decrypt the payload.

Name: Waterbear
Description: Waterbear  has the ability to decrypt its RC4 encrypted payload for execution.

Name: WellMail
Description: WellMail  can decompress scripts received from C2.

Name: WellMess
Description: WellMess  can decode and decrypt data received from C2.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  can deobfuscate downloaded files stored in reverse byte order and decrypt embedded resources using multiple XOR operations.

Name: WindTail
Description: WindTail  has the ability to decrypt strings using hard-coded AES keys.

Name: Winnti for Linux
Description: Winnti for Linux  has decoded XOR encoded strings holding its configuration upon execution.

Name: Winnti for Windows
Description: The  Winnti for Windows  dropper can decrypt and decompresses a data blob.

Name: WIRTE
Description: WIRTE  has used Base64 to decode malicious VBS script.

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  can deobfuscate Base64-encoded strings and scripts.

Name: xCaon
Description: xCaon  has decoded strings from the C2 server before executing commands.

Name: YAHOYAH
Description: YAHOYAH  decrypts downloaded files before execution.

Name: Zebrocy
Description: Zebrocy  decodes its secondary payload and writes it to the victim’s machine.  Zebrocy  also uses AES and XOR to decrypt strings and payloads.

Name: ZeroT
Description: ZeroT  shellcode decrypts and decompresses its RC4-encrypted payload.

Name: Zeus Panda
Description: Zeus Panda  decrypts strings in the code during the execution process.

Name: ZIRCONIUM
Description: ZIRCONIUM  has used the AES256 algorithm with a SHA1 derived key to decrypt exploit code.

Name: ZxxZ
Description: ZxxZ  has used a XOR key to decrypt strings.

Name: HOPLIGHT
Description: HOPLIGHT  can enumerate device drivers located in the registry at  HKLM\Software\WBEM\WDM .

Name: Remsec
Description: Remsec  has a plugin to detect active drivers of some security products.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  created and used a mailing toolkit to use in spearphishing attacks.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  has the ability to perform anti-sandboxing and anti-virtualization checks.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can attempt to overload sandbox analysis by sending 1550 calls to  printf .

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal  can check to determine if the compromised system is running on VMware.

Name: Black Basta
Description: Black Basta  can make a random number of calls to the  kernel32.beep  function to hinder log analysis.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  has the ability to perform anti-virtualization checks.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp  has removed various hooks before installing the trojan or bootkit to evade sandbox analysis or other analysis software.

Name: CHOPSTICK
Description: CHOPSTICK   includes runtime checks to identify an analysis environment and prevent execution on it.

Name: CozyCar
Description: Some versions of  CozyCar  will check to ensure it is not being executed inside a virtual machine or a known malware analysis sandbox environment. If it detects that it is, it will exit.

Name: Darkhotel
Description: Darkhotel  malware has employed just-in-time decryption of strings to evade sandbox detection.

Name: Egregor
Description: Egregor  has used multiple anti-analysis and anti-sandbox techniques to prevent automated analysis by sandboxes.

Name: Gelsemium
Description: Gelsemium  can use junk code to generate random activity to obscure malware behavior.

Name: Hancitor
Description: Hancitor  has used a macro to check that an ActiveDocument shape object in the lure message is present. If this object is not found, the macro will exit without downloading additional payloads.

Name: Kevin
Description: Kevin  can sleep for a time interval between C2 communication attempts.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has embedded a "vmdetect.exe" executable to identify virtual machines at the beginning of execution.

Name: Operation Spalax
Description: During  Operation Spalax , the threat actors used droppers that would run anti-analysis checks before executing malware on a compromised host.

Name: Pteranodon
Description: Pteranodon  has the ability to use anti-detection functions to identify sandbox environments.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  can detect if it is running within a sandbox or other virtualized analysis environment.

Name: Squirrelwaffle
Description: Squirrelwaffle  has contained a hardcoded list of IP addresses to block that belong to sandboxes and analysis platforms.

Name: StoneDrill
Description: StoneDrill  has used several anti-emulation techniques to prevent automated analysis by emulators or sandboxes.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has exploited CVE-2014-4076, CVE-2015-2387, CVE-2015-1701, CVE-2017-0263 to escalate privileges.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has exploited CVE-2021-36934 to escalate privileges on a compromised host.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has used CVE-2016-7255 to escalate privileges.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has used a publicly available exploit for CVE-2017-0213 to escalate privileges on a local system.

Name: BITTER
Description: BITTER  has exploited CVE-2021-1732 for privilege escalation.

Name: C0017
Description: During  C0017 ,  APT41  abused named pipe impersonation for privilege escalation.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp  has exploited multiple Windows vulnerabilities (CVE-2010-2743, CVE-2010-3338, CVE-2010-4398, CVE-2008-1084) and a .NET Runtime Optimization vulnerability for privilege escalation.

Name: Cobalt Group
Description: Cobalt Group  has used exploits to increase their levels of rights and privileges.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can exploit vulnerabilities such as MS14-058.

Name: CosmicDuke
Description: CosmicDuke  attempts to exploit privilege escalation vulnerabilities CVE-2010-0232 or CVE-2010-4398.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can exploit vulnerabilities such as MS16-032 and MS16-135.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has used tools to exploit Windows vulnerabilities in order to escalate privileges. The tools targeted CVE-2013-3660, CVE-2011-2005, and CVE-2010-4398, all of which could allow local users to access kernel-level privileges.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has exploited the CVE-2016-0167 local vulnerability.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has used the BOtB tool which exploits CVE-2019-5736.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  has exploited CVE-2007-5633 vulnerability in the speedfan.sys driver to obtain kernel mode privileges.

Name: JHUHUGIT
Description: JHUHUGIT  has exploited CVE-2015-1701 and CVE-2015-2387 to escalate privileges.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has exploited unpatched vulnerabilities on internally accessible servers including JIRA, GitLab, and Confluence for privilege escalation.

Name: MoustachedBouncer
Description: MoustachedBouncer  has exploited CVE-2021-1732 to execute malware components with elevated rights.

Name: Pandora
Description: Pandora  can use CVE-2017-15303 to bypass Windows Driver Signature Enforcement (DSE) protection and load its driver.

Name: PLATINUM
Description: PLATINUM  has leveraged a zero-day vulnerability to escalate privileges.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  contains modules for local privilege escalation exploits such as CVE-2016-9192 and CVE-2016-0099.

Name: ProLock
Description: ProLock  can use CVE-2019-0859 to escalate privileges on a compromised host.

Name: Remsec
Description: Remsec  has a plugin to drop and execute vulnerable Outpost Sandbox or avast! Virtualization drivers in order to gain kernel mode privileges.

Name: Scattered Spider
Description: Scattered Spider  has deployed a malicious kernel driver through exploitation of CVE-2015-2291 in the Intel Ethernet diagnostics driver for Windows (iqvw64.sys).

Name: Siloscape
Description: Siloscape  has leveraged a vulnerability in Windows containers to perform an  Escape to Host .

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  used MS10-073 and an undisclosed Task Scheduler vulnerability to escalate privileges on local Windows machines.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  has used CVE-2014-6324 and CVE-2017-0213 to escalate privileges.

Name: Tonto Team
Description: Tonto Team  has exploited CVE-2019-0803 and MS16-032 to escalate privileges.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has exploited vulnerabilities in the VBoxDrv.sys driver to obtain kernel mode privileges.

Name: Whitefly
Description: Whitefly  has used an open-source tool to exploit a known Windows privilege escalation vulnerability (CVE-2016-0051) on unpatched computers.

Name: Wingbird
Description: Wingbird  exploits CVE-2016-4117 to allow an executable to gain escalated privileges.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  has used a zero-day exploit in the ssh launchdaemon to elevate privileges and bypass SIP.

Name: ZIRCONIUM
Description: ZIRCONIUM  has exploited CVE-2017-0005 for local privilege escalation.

Name: Zox
Description: Zox  has the ability to leverage local and remote exploits to escalate privileges.

Name: Application Isolation and Sandboxing
Description: Make it difficult for adversaries to advance their operation through exploitation of undiscovered or unpatched vulnerabilities by using sandboxing. Other types of virtualization and application microsegmentation may also mitigate the impact of some types of exploitation. Risks of additional exploits and weaknesses in these systems may still exist.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Consider blocking the execution of known vulnerable drivers that adversaries may exploit to execute code in kernel mode. Validate driver block rules in audit mode to ensure stability prior to production deployment.

Name: Exploit Protection
Description: Security applications that look for behavior used during exploitation such as Windows Defender Exploit Guard (WDEG) and the Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET) can be used to mitigate some exploitation behavior.    Control flow integrity checking is another way to potentially identify and stop a software exploit from occurring.    Many of these protections depend on the architecture and target application binary for compatibility and may not work for software components targeted for privilege escalation.

Name: Threat Intelligence Program
Description: Develop a robust cyber threat intelligence capability to determine what types and levels of threat may use software exploits and 0-days against a particular organization.

Name: Update Software
Description: Update software regularly by employing patch management for internal enterprise endpoints and servers.

Name: esentutl
Description: esentutl  can use the Volume Shadow Copy service to copy locked files such as  ntds.dit .

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of behaviors related to efforts by an adversary to create backups, such as command execution or preventing API calls to backup related services.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Ensure only accounts required to configure and manage backups have the privileges to do so. Monitor these accounts for unauthorized backup activity.

Name: Audit
Description: Identify and correct GPO permissions abuse opportunities (ex: GPO modification privileges) using auditing tools such as  BloodHound  (version 1.5.1 and later)  .

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Use least privilege and protect administrative access to the Domain Controller and Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) server. Do not create service accounts with administrative privileges.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Consider implementing WMI and security filtering to further tailor which users and computers a GPO will apply to.

Name: Data Backup
Description: Consider implementing IT disaster recovery plans that contain procedures for taking regular data backups that can be used to restore organizational data.   Ensure backups are stored off system and is protected from common methods adversaries may use to gain access and destroy the backups to prevent recovery.

Name: AdFind
Description: AdFind  can gather information about organizational units (OUs) and domain trusts from Active Directory.

Name: BADHATCH
Description: BADHATCH  can use  nltest.exe /domain_trusts  to discover domain trust relationships on a compromised machine.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can use  Nltest  tools to obtain information about the domain.

Name: BloodHound
Description: BloodHound  has the ability to map domain trusts and identify misconfigurations for potential abuse.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  can use LDAP queries and  nltest /domain_trusts  for domain trust discovery.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors used the command  nltest /domain_trusts /all_trusts  to enumerate domain trusts.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has  nltest /domain_trusts  to identify domain trust relationships.

Name: dsquery
Description: dsquery  can be used to gather information on domain trusts with  dsquery * -filter "(objectClass=trustedDomain)" -attr * .

Name: Earth Lusca
Description: Earth Lusca  has used  Nltest  to obtain information about domain controllers.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  has modules for enumerating domain trusts.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has retrieved a list of trusted domains by using  nltest.exe /domain_trusts .

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has used a web shell to execute  nltest /trusted_domains  to identify trust relationships.

Name: Nltest
Description: Nltest  may be used to enumerate trusted domains by using commands such as  nltest /domain_trusts .

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  has modules for enumerating domain trusts.

Name: PowerSploit
Description: PowerSploit  has modules such as  Get-NetDomainTrust  and  Get-NetForestTrust  to enumerate domain and forest trusts.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can run  nltest /domain_trusts /all_trusts  for domain trust discovery.

Name: Rubeus
Description: Rubeus  can gather information about domain trusts.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used the  Get-AcceptedDomain  PowerShell cmdlet to enumerate accepted domains through an Exchange Management Shell.   They also used  AdFind  to enumerate domains and to discover trust between federated domains.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  can gather information about domain trusts by utilizing  Nltest .

Name: Audit
Description: Map the trusts within existing domains/forests and keep trust relationships to a minimum.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Employ network segmentation for sensitive domains.  .

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has used multiple layers of encryption within malware to protect C2 communication.

Name: BITTER
Description: BITTER  has encrypted their C2 communications.

Name: Chaes
Description: Chaes  has used encryption for its C2 channel.

Name: Cryptoistic
Description: Cryptoistic  can engage in encrypted communications with C2.

Name: gh0st RAT
Description: gh0st RAT  has encrypted TCP communications to evade detection.

Name: Lizar
Description: Lizar  can support encrypted communications between the client and server.

Name: MacMa
Description: MacMa  has used TLS encryption to initialize a custom protocol for C2 communications.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has used an encrypted http proxy in C2 communications.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can encrypt C2 communications.

Name: PowerLess
Description: PowerLess  can use an encrypted channel for C2 communications.

Name: PowGoop
Description: PowGoop  can receive encrypted commands from C2.

Name: RCSession
Description: RCSession  can use an encrypted beacon to check in with C2.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has encrypted traffic with the C2 to prevent network detection.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: SSL/TLS Inspection
Description: SSL/TLS inspection can be used to see the contents of encrypted sessions to look for network-based indicators of malware communication protocols.

Name: Emotet
Description: Emotet  has been observed leveraging a module that can scrape email addresses from Outlook.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has compromised email credentials in order to steal sensitive data.

Name: Silent Librarian
Description: Silent Librarian  has exfiltrated entire mailboxes from compromised accounts.

Name: Audit
