Description: HyperStack  can add the name of its communication pipe to  HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\lanmanserver\parameters\NullSessionPipes .

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  has a command to create, set, copy, or delete a specified Registry key or value.

Name: KEYMARBLE
Description: KEYMARBLE  has a command to create Registry entries for storing data under  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\WABE\DataPath .

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has modified Registry settings for default file associations to enable all macros and for persistence.

Name: KOCTOPUS
Description: KOCTOPUS  has added and deleted keys from the Registry.

Name: KONNI
Description: KONNI  has modified registry keys of ComSysApp, Svchost, and xmlProv on the machine to gain persistence.

Name: LoJax
Description: LoJax  has modified the Registry key  ‘HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\BootExecute’  from  ‘autocheck autochk  ’  to  ‘autocheck autoche ’ .

Name: Lokibot
Description: Lokibot  has modified the Registry as part of its UAC bypass process.

Name: LuminousMoth
Description: LuminousMoth  has used malware that adds Registry keys for persistence.

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can manipulate the system registry on a compromised host.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has modified Registry settings for security tools.

Name: MegaCortex
Description: MegaCortex  has added entries to the Registry for ransom contact information.

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  can write the process ID of a target process into the  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\DDE\tpid  Registry value as part of its reflective loading activity.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has written process names to the Registry, disabled IE browser features, deleted Registry keys, and changed the ExtendedUIHoverTime key.

Name: Mori
Description: Mori  can write data to  HKLM\Software\NFC\IPA  and  HKLM\Software\NFC\  and delete Registry values.

Name: Mosquito
Description: Mosquito  can modify Registry keys under  HKCU\Software\Microsoft  to store configuration values.  Mosquito  also modifies Registry keys under  HKCR\CLSID...\InprocServer32  with a path to the launcher.

Name: Naid
Description: Naid  creates Registry entries that store information about a created service and point to a malicious DLL dropped to disk.

Name: NanoCore
Description: NanoCore  has the capability to edit the Registry.

Name: Neoichor
Description: Neoichor  has the ability to configure browser settings by modifying Registry entries under  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Internet Explorer .

Name: Nerex
Description: Nerex  creates a Registry subkey that registers a new service.

Name: Netwalker
Description: Netwalker  can add the following registry entry:  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE{8 random characters} .

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can modify the Registry to store its configuration information.

Name: Night Dragon
Description: During  Night Dragon , threat actors used  zwShell  to establish full remote control of the connected machine and manipulate the Registry.

Name: NightClub
Description: NightClub  can modify the Registry to set the ServiceDLL for a service created by the malware for persistence.

Name: njRAT
Description: njRAT  can create, delete, or modify a specified Registry key or value.

Name: Operation Honeybee
Description: During  Operation Honeybee , the threat actors used batch files that modified registry keys.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , the threat actors enabled Wdigest by changing the  HKLM\SYSTEM\\ControlSet001\\Control\\SecurityProviders\\WDigest  registry value from 0 (disabled) to 1 (enabled).

Name: Orz
Description: Orz  can perform Registry operations.

Name: Pandora
Description: Pandora  can write an encrypted token to the Registry to enable processing of remote commands.

Name: Patchwork
Description: A  Patchwork  payload deletes Resiliency Registry keys created by Microsoft Office applications in an apparent effort to trick users into thinking there were no issues during application runs.

Name: PcShare
Description: PcShare  can delete its persistence mechanisms from the registry.

Name: PHOREAL
Description: PHOREAL  is capable of manipulating the Registry.

Name: Pillowmint
Description: Pillowmint  has modified the Registry key  HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\DRM  to store a malicious payload.

Name: PipeMon
Description: PipeMon  has modified the Registry to store its encrypted payload.

Name: PLAINTEE
Description: PLAINTEE  uses  reg add  to add a Registry Run key for persistence.

Name: PlugX
Description: PlugX  has a module to create, delete, or modify Registry keys.

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  has made registry modifications to alter its behavior upon execution.

Name: PoisonIvy
Description: PoisonIvy  creates a Registry subkey that registers a new system device.

Name: PolyglotDuke
Description: PolyglotDuke  can write encrypted JSON configuration files to the Registry.

Name: PowerShower
Description: PowerShower  has added a registry key so future powershell.exe instances are spawned off-screen by default, and has removed all registry entries that are left behind during the dropper process.

Name: Prestige
Description: Prestige  has the ability to register new registry keys for a new extension handler via  HKCR\.enc  and  HKCR\enc\shell\open\command .

Name: Pysa
Description: Pysa  has modified the registry key "SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System" and added the ransom note.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can modify the Registry to store its configuration information in a randomly named subkey under  HKCU\Software\Microsoft .

Name: QUADAGENT
Description: QUADAGENT  modifies an HKCU Registry key to store a session identifier unique to the compromised system as well as a pre-shared key used for encrypting and decrypting C2 communications.

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: QuasarRAT  has a command to edit the Registry on the victim’s machine.

Name: RCSession
Description: RCSession  can write its configuration file to the Registry.

Name: Reg
Description: Reg  may be used to interact with and modify the Windows Registry of a local or remote system at the command-line interface.

Name: RegDuke
Description: RegDuke  can create seemingly legitimate Registry key to store its encryption key.

Name: Regin
Description: Regin  appears to have functionality to modify remote Registry information.

Name: Remcos
Description: Remcos  has full control of the Registry, including the ability to modify it.

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  can modify the Registry to save encryption parameters and system information.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  can modify the  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\  registry key so it can bypass the VB object model (VBOM) on a compromised host.

Name: Rover
Description: Rover  has functionality to remove Registry Run key persistence as a cleanup procedure.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  can delete all Registry entries created during its execution.

Name: ShadowPad
Description: ShadowPad  can modify the Registry to store and maintain a configuration block and virtual file system.

Name: Shamoon
Description: Once  Shamoon  has access to a network share, it enables the RemoteRegistry service on the target system. It will then connect to the system with RegConnectRegistryW and modify the Registry to disable UAC remote restrictions by setting  SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System\LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy  to 1.

Name: ShimRat
Description: ShimRat  has registered two registry keys for shim databases.

Name: Sibot
Description: Sibot  has modified the Registry to install a second-stage script in the  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\sibot .

Name: Silence
Description: Silence  can create, delete, or modify a specified Registry key or value.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can modify registry keys, including to enable or disable Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP).

Name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
Description: SLOTHFULMEDIA  can add, modify, and/or delete registry keys. It has changed the proxy configuration of a victim system by modifying the  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ZoneMap  registry.

Name: SMOKEDHAM
Description: SMOKEDHAM  has modified registry keys for persistence, to enable credential caching for credential access, and to facilitate lateral movement via RDP.

Name: SOUNDBITE
Description: SOUNDBITE  is capable of modifying the Registry.

Name: StreamEx
Description: StreamEx  has the ability to modify the Registry.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  can create registry keys to load driver files.

Name: SUNBURST
Description: SUNBURST  had commands that allow an attacker to write or delete registry keys, and was observed stopping services by setting their  HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\services\\Start  registry entries to value 4.    It also deleted previously-created Image File Execution Options (IFEO) Debugger registry values and registry keys related to HTTP proxy to clean up traces of its activity.

Name: SynAck
Description: SynAck  can manipulate Registry keys.

Name: SysUpdate
Description: SysUpdate  can write its configuration file to  Software\Classes\scConfig  in either  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE  or  HKEY_CURRENT_USER .

Name: TA505
Description: TA505  has used malware to disable Windows Defender through modification of the Registry.

Name: Taidoor
Description: Taidoor  has the ability to modify the Registry on compromised hosts using  RegDeleteValueA  and  RegCreateKeyExA .

Name: TajMahal
Description: TajMahal  can set the  KeepPrintedJobs  attribute for configured printers in  SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Print\Printers  to enable document stealing.

Name: Tarrask
Description: Tarrask  is able to delete the Security Descriptor ( SD ) registry subkey in order to "hide" scheduled tasks.

Name: TEARDROP
Description: TEARDROP  modified the Registry to create a Windows service for itself on a compromised host.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: A  Threat Group-3390  tool has created new Registry keys under  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\  and  HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\services .

Name: ThreatNeedle
Description: ThreatNeedle  can modify the Registry to save its configuration data as the following RC4-encrypted Registry key:  HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\GameCon .

Name: TinyTurla
Description: TinyTurla  can set its configuration parameters in the Registry.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  can modify registry entries.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has modify Registry values to store payloads.

Name: TYPEFRAME
Description: TYPEFRAME  can install encrypted configuration data under the Registry key  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\ShellCompatibility\Applications\laxhost.dll  and  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\PrintConfigs .

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  can store configuration information in the Registry including the initialization vector and AES key needed to find and decrypt other  Uroburos  components.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has used Registry modifications as part of its installation routine.

Name: Valak
Description: Valak  has the ability to modify the Registry key  HKCU\Software\ApplicationContainer\Appsw64  to store information regarding the C2 server and downloads.

Name: Volgmer
Description: Volgmer  modifies the Registry to store an encoded configuration file in  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\WMI\Security .

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  can create  HKCU\Software\Classes\Folder\shell\open\command  as a new registry key during privilege escalation.

Name: WastedLocker
Description: WastedLocker  can modify registry values within the  Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ZoneMap  registry key.

Name: Waterbear
Description: Waterbear  has deleted certain values from the Registry to load a malicious DLL.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has modified the Registry key  HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\WDigest  by setting the  UseLogonCredential  registry value to  1  in order to force credentials to be stored in clear text in memory.  Wizard Spider  has also modified the WDigest registry key to allow plaintext credentials to be cached in memory.

Name: Zeus Panda
Description: Zeus Panda  modifies several Registry keys under  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Internet Explorer\ PhishingFilter\  to disable phishing filters.

Name: zwShell
Description: zwShell  can modify the Registry.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  can create Registry entries to enable services to run.

Name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Description: Ensure proper permissions are set for Registry hives to prevent users from modifying keys for system components that may lead to privilege escalation.

Name: 2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  moved their tools laterally within the corporate network and between the ICS and corporate network.

Name: 2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  used  move  to transfer files to a network share.

Name: Aoqin Dragon
Description: Aoqin Dragon  has spread malware in target networks by copying modules to folders masquerading as removable devices.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has deployed tools after moving laterally using administrative accounts.

Name: BITSAdmin
Description: BITSAdmin  can be used to create  BITS Jobs  to upload and/or download files from SMB file servers.

Name: BlackCat
Description: BlackCat  can replicate itself across connected servers via  psexec .

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors used WMI to load  Cobalt Strike  onto additional hosts within a compromised network.

Name: C0018
Description: During  C0018 , the threat actors transferred the SoftPerfect Network Scanner and other tools to machines in the network using AnyDesk and PDQ Deploy.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has copied tools between compromised hosts using SMB.

Name: cmd
Description: cmd  can be used to copy files to/from a remotely connected internal system.

Name: DustySky
Description: DustySky  searches for network drives and removable media and duplicates itself onto them.

Name: Emotet
Description: Emotet  has copied itself to remote systems using the  service.exe  filename.

Name: esentutl
Description: esentutl  can be used to copy files to/from a remote share.

Name: Expand
Description: Expand  can be used to download or upload a file over a network share.

Name: FIN10
Description: FIN10  has deployed Meterpreter stagers and SplinterRAT instances in the victim network after moving laterally.

Name: ftp
Description: ftp  may be abused by adversaries to transfer tools or files between systems within a compromised environment.

Name: GALLIUM
Description: GALLIUM  has used  PsExec  to move laterally between hosts in the target network.

Name: HermeticWizard
Description: HermeticWizard  can copy files to other machines on a compromised network.

Name: LockerGoga
Description: LockerGoga  has been observed moving around the victim network via SMB, indicating the actors behind this ransomware are manually copying files form computer to computer instead of self-propagating.

Name: Lucifer
Description: Lucifer  can use  certutil  for propagation on Windows hosts within intranets.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has copied tools within a compromised network using RDP.

Name: Netwalker
Description: Operators deploying  Netwalker  have used psexec to copy the  Netwalker  payload across accessible systems.

Name: Olympic Destroyer
Description: Olympic Destroyer  attempts to copy itself to remote machines on the network.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used SMB to copy files to and from target systems.

Name: PsExec
Description: PsExec  can be used to download or upload a file over a network share.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has used  move  to transfer files to a network share and has copied payloads--such as  Prestige  ransomware--to an Active Directory Domain Controller and distributed via the Default Domain Group Policy Object.

Name: Shamoon
Description: Shamoon  attempts to copy itself to remote machines on the network.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  uses an RPC server that contains a file dropping routine and support for payload version updates for P2P communications within a victim network.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  RPC backdoors can be used to transfer files to/from victim machines on the local network.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has copied web shells between servers in targeted environments.

Name: WannaCry
Description: WannaCry  attempts to copy itself to remote computers after gaining access via an SMB exploit.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used stolen credentials to copy tools into the  %TEMP%  directory of domain controllers.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Consider using the host firewall to restrict file sharing communications such as SMB.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware or unusual data transfer over known tools and protocols like FTP can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific obfuscation technique used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can query the Registry for installed applications.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  has used tools to enumerate software installed on an infected host.

Name: Bundlore
Description: Bundlore  has the ability to enumerate what browser is being used as well as version information for Safari.

Name: CharmPower
Description: CharmPower  can list the installed applications on a compromised host.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: The  Cobalt Strike  System Profiler can discover applications through the browser and identify the version of Java the target has.

Name: ComRAT
Description: ComRAT  can check the victim's default browser to determine which process to inject its communications module into.

Name: down_new
Description: down_new  has the ability to gather information on installed applications.

Name: Dridex
Description: Dridex  has collected a list of installed software on the system.

Name: DustySky
Description: DustySky  lists all installed software for the infected machine.

Name: Dyre
Description: Dyre  has the ability to identify installed programs on a compromised host.

Name: HEXANE
Description: HEXANE  has enumerated programs installed on an infected machine.

Name: HotCroissant
Description: HotCroissant  can retrieve a list of applications from the  SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\App Paths  registry key.

Name: Inception
Description: Inception  has enumerated installed software on compromised systems.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can collect information about installed software used by specific users, software executed on user login, and software executed by each system.

Name: KGH_SPY
Description: KGH_SPY  can collect information on installed applications.

Name: MarkiRAT
Description: MarkiRAT  can check for the Telegram installation directory by enumerating the files on disk.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has searched the compromised system for banking applications.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has used a PowerShell backdoor to check for Skype connectivity on the target machine.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has searched the victim system for the  InstallUtil.exe  program and its version.

Name: Operation Dust Storm
Description: During  Operation Dust Storm , the threat actors deployed a file called  DeployJava.js  to fingerprint installed software on a victim system prior to exploit delivery.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors collected a list of installed software on the infected system.

Name: Orz
Description: Orz  can gather the victim's Internet Explorer version.

Name: P.A.S. Webshell
Description: P.A.S. Webshell  can list PHP server configuration details.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can enumerate a list of installed programs.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  can scan victim drives to look for specific banking software on the machine to determine next actions.

Name: ShimRatReporter
Description: ShimRatReporter  gathered a list of installed software on the infected host.

Name: SideCopy
Description: SideCopy  has collected browser information from a compromised host.

Name: Sidewinder
Description: Sidewinder  has used tools to enumerate software installed on an infected host.

Name: Siloscape
Description: Siloscape  searches for the kubectl binary.

Name: SpicyOmelette
Description: SpicyOmelette  can enumerate running software on a targeted system.

Name: SUGARDUMP
Description: SUGARDUMP  can identify Chrome, Opera, Edge Chromium, and Firefox browsers, including version number, on a compromised host.

Name: SVCReady
Description: SVCReady  can collect a list of installed software from an infected host.

Name: TajMahal
Description: TajMahal  has the ability to identify the Internet Explorer (IE) version on an infected host.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper 's backdoor could list the infected system's installed software.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has queried the Registry on compromised systems for information on installed software.

Name: Windigo
Description: Windigo  has used a script to detect installed software on targeted systems.

Name: Windshift
Description: Windshift  has used malware to identify installed software.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has utilized the PowerShell script  Get-DataInfo.ps1  to collect installed backup software information from a compromised machine.

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  can collect .NET, PowerShell, and Python information from an infected host.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  uses  ps aux  with the  grep  command to enumerate common browsers and system processes potentially impacting  XCSSET 's exfiltration capabilities.

Name: Pacu
Description: Pacu  can collect CloudTrail event histories and CloudWatch logs.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has used  wevtutil.exe  and the PowerShell command  Get-EventLog security  to enumerate Windows logs to search for successful logons.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit the ability to access and export sensitive logs to privileged accounts where possible.

Name: Cyclops Blink
Description: Cyclops Blink  has the ability to create a pipe to enable inter-process communication.

Name: HyperStack
Description: HyperStack  can connect to the IPC$ share on remote machines.

Name: RotaJakiro
Description: When executing with non-root permissions,  RotaJakiro  uses the the  shmget API  to create shared memory between other known  RotaJakiro  processes. This allows processes to communicate with each other and share their PID.

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  has the ability to move data between its kernel and user mode components, generally using named pipes.

Name: Application Developer Guidance
Description: Enable the Hardened Runtime capability when developing applications. Do not include the  com.apple.security.get-task-allow  entitlement with the value set to any variation of true.

Name: Application Isolation and Sandboxing
Description: Ensure all COM alerts and Protected View are enabled.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: On Windows 10, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to prevent DDE attacks and spawning of child processes from Office programs.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Registry keys specific to Microsoft Office feature control security can be set to disable automatic DDE/OLE execution.      Microsoft also created, and enabled by default, Registry keys to completely disable DDE execution in Word and Excel.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Modify Registry settings (directly or using Dcomcnfg.exe) in  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SOFTWARE\\Classes\\AppID\\{AppID_GUID}  associated with the process-wide security of individual COM applications.  Modify Registry settings (directly or using Dcomcnfg.exe) in  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Ole  associated with system-wide security defaults for all COM applications that do no set their own process-wide security.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: Consider disabling embedded files in Office programs, such as OneNote, that do not work with Protected View.

Name: Avaddon
Description: Avaddon  deletes backups and shadow copies using native system tools.

Name: Babuk
Description: Babuk  has the ability to delete shadow volumes using  vssadmin.exe delete shadows /all /quiet .

Name: BitPaymer
Description: BitPaymer  attempts to remove the backup shadow files from the host using  vssadmin.exe Delete Shadows /All /Quiet .

Name: Black Basta
Description: Black Basta  can delete shadow copies using vssadmin.exe.

Name: BlackCat
Description: BlackCat  can delete shadow copies using  vssadmin.exe delete shadows /all /quiet  and  wmic.exe Shadowcopy Delete ; it can also modify the boot loader using  bcdedit /set {default} recoveryenabled No .

Name: Clop
Description: Clop  can delete the shadow volumes with  vssadmin Delete Shadows /all /quiet  and can use bcdedit to disable recovery options.

Name: Conficker
Description: Conficker  resets system restore points and deletes backup files.

Name: Conti
Description: Conti  can delete Windows Volume Shadow Copies using  vssadmin .

Name: DarkWatchman
Description: DarkWatchman  can delete shadow volumes using  vssadmin.exe .

Name: DEATHRANSOM
Description: DEATHRANSOM  can delete volume shadow copies on compromised hosts.

Name: Diavol
Description: Diavol  can delete shadow copies using the  IVssBackupComponents  COM object to call the  DeleteSnapshots  method.

Name: EKANS
Description: EKANS  removes backups of Volume Shadow Copies to disable any restoration capabilities.

Name: FIVEHANDS
Description: FIVEHANDS  has the ability to delete volume shadow copies on compromised hosts.

Name: H1N1
Description: H1N1  disable recovery options and deletes shadow copies from the victim.

Name: HELLOKITTY
Description: HELLOKITTY  can delete volume shadow copies on compromised hosts.

Name: HermeticWiper
Description: HermeticWiper  can disable the VSS service on a compromised host using the service control manager.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can can remove all system restore points.

Name: JCry
Description: JCry  has been observed deleting shadow copies to ensure that data cannot be restored easily.

Name: Maze
Description: Maze  has attempted to delete the shadow volumes of infected machines, once before and once after the encryption process.

Name: MegaCortex
Description: MegaCortex  has deleted volume shadow copies using  vssadmin.exe .

Name: Meteor
Description: Meteor  can use  bcdedit  to delete different boot identifiers on a compromised host; it can also use  vssadmin.exe delete shadows /all /quiet  and  C:\\Windows\\system32\\wbem\\wmic.exe shadowcopy delete .

Name: Netwalker
Description: Netwalker  can delete the infected system's Shadow Volumes to prevent recovery.

Name: Olympic Destroyer
Description: Olympic Destroyer  uses the native Windows utilities  vssadmin ,  wbadmin , and  bcdedit  to delete and disable operating system recovery features such as the Windows backup catalog and Windows Automatic Repair.

Name: Prestige
Description: Prestige  can delete the backup catalog from the target system using:  c:\Windows\System32\wbadmin.exe delete catalog -quiet  and can also delete volume shadow copies using:  \Windows\System32\vssadmin.exe delete shadows /all /quiet .

Name: ProLock
Description: ProLock  can use vssadmin.exe to remove volume shadow copies.

Name: Pysa
Description: Pysa  has the functionality to delete shadow copies.

Name: Ragnar Locker
Description: Ragnar Locker  can delete volume shadow copies using  vssadmin delete shadows /all /quiet .

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  can use vssadmin to delete volume shadow copies and bcdedit to disable recovery features.

Name: RobbinHood
Description: RobbinHood  deletes shadow copies to ensure that all the data cannot be restored easily.

Name: Royal
Description: Royal  can delete shadow copy backups with vssadmin.exe using the command  delete shadows /all /quiet .

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  has used  vssadmin Delete Shadows /all /quiet  to to delete volume shadow copies and  vssadmin resize shadowstorage  to force deletion of shadow copies created by third-party applications.

Name: WannaCry
Description: WannaCry  uses  vssadmin ,  wbadmin ,  bcdedit , and  wmic  to delete and disable operating system recovery features.

Name: WastedLocker
Description: WastedLocker  can delete shadow volumes.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used WMIC and vssadmin to manually delete volume shadow copies.  Wizard Spider  has also used  Conti  ransomware to delete volume shadow copies automatically with the use of vssadmin.

Name: Data Backup
Description: Consider implementing IT disaster recovery plans that contain procedures for taking regular data backups that can be used to restore organizational data.   Ensure backups are stored off system and is protected from common methods adversaries may use to gain access and destroy the backups to prevent recovery. In cloud environments, enable versioning on storage objects where possible, and copy backups to other accounts or regions to isolate them from the original copies.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Consider technical controls to prevent the disabling of services or deletion of files involved in system recovery. Additionally, ensure that WinRE is enabled using the following command:  reagentc /enable .

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit the user accounts that have access to backups to only those required.

Name: 2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  remotely discovered systems over LAN connections. OT systems were visible from the IT network   as well, giving adversaries the ability to discover operational assets.

Name: 2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  checked for connectivity to resources within the network and used LDAP to query Active Directory, discovering information about computers listed in AD.

Name: AdFind
Description: AdFind  has the ability to query Active Directory for computers.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  has a tool that can detect the existence of remote systems.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has enumerated DC servers using the command  net group "Domain Controllers" /domain . The group has also used the  ping  command.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used  NBTscan  and custom tools to discover remote systems.

Name: Arp
Description: Arp  can be used to display a host's ARP cache, which may include address resolutions for remote systems.

Name: Backdoor.Oldrea
Description: Backdoor.Oldrea  can enumerate and map ICS-specific systems in victim environments.

Name: BADHATCH
Description: BADHATCH  can use a PowerShell object such as,  System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping  to ping a computer.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can enumerate remote systems using   Net View .

Name: BitPaymer
Description: BitPaymer  can use  net view  to discover remote systems.

Name: Black Basta
Description: Black Basta  can use LDAP queries to connect to AD and iterate over connected workstations.

Name: BlackCat
Description: BlackCat  can broadcasts NetBIOS Name Service (NBNC) messages to search for servers connected to compromised networks.

Name: BloodHound
Description: BloodHound  can enumerate and collect the properties of domain computers, including domain controllers.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  typically use  ping  and  Net  to enumerate systems.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors used the commands  net view /all /domain  and  ping  to discover remote systems. They also used PowerView's PowerShell Invoke-ShareFinder script for file share enumeration.

Name: Carbon
Description: Carbon  uses the  net view  command.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has utilized various scans and queries to find domain controllers and remote services in the target environment.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  uses the native Windows Network Enumeration APIs to interrogate and discover targets in a Windows Active Directory network.

Name: Comnie
Description: Comnie  runs the  net view  command

Name: Conti
Description: Conti  has the ability to discover hosts on a target network.

Name: CrackMapExec
Description: CrackMapExec  can discover active IP addresses, along with the machine name, within a targeted network.

Name: Deep Panda
Description: Deep Panda  has used ping to identify other machines of interest.

Name: Diavol
Description: Diavol  can use the ARP table to find remote hosts to scan.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has likely obtained a list of hosts in the victim environment.

Name: DRATzarus
Description: DRATzarus  can search for other machines connected to compromised host and attempt to map the network.

Name: Earth Lusca
Description: Earth Lusca  used the command  powershell "Get-EventLog -LogName security -Newest 500 | where {$_.EventID -eq 4624} | format-list -property * | findstr "Address""  to find the network information of successfully logged-in accounts to discovery addresses of other machines.  Earth Lusca  has also used multiple scanning tools to discover other machines within the same compromised network.

Name: Epic
Description: Epic  uses the  net view  command on the victim’s machine.

Name: FIN5
Description: FIN5  has used the open source tool Essential NetTools to map the network and build a list of targets.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  used publicly available tools (including Microsoft's built-in SQL querying tool, osql.exe) to map the internal network and conduct reconnaissance against Active Directory, Structured Query Language (SQL) servers, and NetBIOS.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has used  dsquery  and other Active Directory utilities to enumerate hosts; they have also used  nltest.exe /dclist  to retrieve a list of domain controllers.

Name: Flagpro
Description: Flagpro  has been used to execute  net view  on a targeted system.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has used Angry IP Scanner to detect remote systems.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: FunnyDream  can collect information about hosts on the victim network.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: During  FunnyDream , the threat actors used several tools and batch files to map victims' internal networks.

Name: GALLIUM
Description: GALLIUM  used a modified version of  NBTscan  to identify available NetBIOS name servers over the network as well as  ping  to identify remote systems.

Name: HAFNIUM
Description: HAFNIUM  has enumerated domain controllers using  net group "Domain computers"  and  nltest /dclist .

Name: HermeticWizard
Description: HermeticWizard  can find machines on the local network by gathering known local IP addresses through  DNSGetCacheDataTable ,  GetIpNetTable , WNetOpenEnumW(RESOURCE_GLOBALNET, RESOURCETYPE_ANY) , NetServerEnum , GetTcpTable , and  GetAdaptersAddresses.

Name: HEXANE
Description: HEXANE  has used  net view  to enumerate domain machines.

Name: Indrik Spider
Description: Indrik Spider  has used PowerView to enumerate all Windows Server, Windows Server 2003, and Windows 7 instances in the Active Directory database.

Name: Industroyer
Description: Industroyer  can enumerate remote computers in the compromised network.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  has used network scanning and enumeration tools, including  Ping .

Name: Kinsing
Description: Kinsing  has used a script to parse files like  /etc/hosts  and SSH  known_hosts  to discover remote systems.

Name: Kwampirs
Description: Kwampirs  collects a list of available servers with the command  net view .

Name: Leafminer
Description: Leafminer  used Microsoft’s Sysinternals tools to gather detailed information about remote systems.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has used  Ping  for discovery on targeted networks.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  uses scripts to enumerate IP ranges on the victim network.  menuPass  has also issued the command  net view /domain  to a  PlugX  implant to gather information about remote systems on the network.

Name: MURKYTOP
Description: MURKYTOP  has the capability to identify remote hosts on connected networks.

Name: Naikon
Description: Naikon  has used a netbios scanner for remote machine identification.

Name: NBTscan
Description: NBTscan  can list NetBIOS computer names.

Name: Net
Description: Commands such as  net view  can be used in  Net  to gather information about available remote systems.

Name: njRAT
Description: njRAT  can identify remote hosts on connected networks.

Name: Nltest
Description: Nltest  may be used to enumerate remote domain controllers using options such as  /dclist  and  /dsgetdc .

Name: Olympic Destroyer
Description: Olympic Destroyer  uses  Windows Management Instrumentation  to enumerate all systems in the network.

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , the threat actors used the  net view  and  ping  commands as part of their advanced reconnaissance.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used  nbtscan  and  ping  to discover remote systems, as well as  dsquery subnet  on a domain controller to retrieve all subnets in the Active Directory.

Name: OSInfo
Description: OSInfo  performs a connection test to discover remote systems in the network

Name: Ping
Description: Ping  can be used to identify remote systems within a network.

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  used Nmap for remote system discovery.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can identify remote systems through the  net view  command.

Name: RATANKBA
Description: RATANKBA  runs the  net view /domain  and  net view  commands.

Name: Remsec
Description: Remsec  can ping or traceroute a remote host.

Name: ROADTools
Description: ROADTools  can enumerate Azure AD systems and devices.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  has looked for IP addresses in the known_hosts file on the infected system and attempted to SSH into them.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has used a tool to query Active Directory using LDAP, discovering information about computers listed in AD.

Name: Shamoon
Description: Shamoon  scans the C-class subnet of the IPs on the victim's interfaces.

Name: SHOTPUT
Description: SHOTPUT  has a command to list all servers in the domain, as well as one to locate domain controllers on a domain.

Name: Silence
Description: Silence  has used Nmap to scan the corporate network, build a network topology, and identify vulnerable hosts.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can enumerate and collect the properties of domain computers.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used  AdFind  to enumerate remote systems.

Name: SpicyOmelette
Description: SpicyOmelette  can identify payment systems, payment gateways, and ATM systems in compromised environments.

Name: Sykipot
Description: Sykipot  may use  net view /domain  to display hostnames of available systems on a network.

Name: TAINTEDSCRIBE
Description: The  TAINTEDSCRIBE  command and execution module can perform target system enumeration.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  has used the  net view  command.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  can enumerate computers and network devices.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  surveys a system upon check-in to discover remote systems on a local network using the  net view  and  net view /DOMAIN  commands.  Turla  has also used  net group "Domain Computers" /domain ,  net group "Domain Controllers" /domain , and  net group "Exchange Servers" /domain  to enumerate domain computers, including the organization's DC and Exchange Server.

Name: USBferry
Description: USBferry  can use  net view  to gather information about remote systems.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has used multiple methods, including  Ping , to enumerate systems on compromised networks.

Name: WannaCry
Description: WannaCry  scans its local network segment for remote systems to try to exploit and copy itself to.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used networkdll for network discovery and psfin specifically for financial and point of sale indicators.  Wizard Spider  has also used  AdFind ,  nltest/dclist , and PowerShell script Get-DataInfo.ps1 to enumerate domain computers, including the domain controller.

Name: yty
Description: yty  uses the  net view  command for discovery.

Name: Audit
Description: Routinely monitor user permissions to ensure only the expected users have the capability to modify cloud compute infrastructure components.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit permissions for creating, deleting, and otherwise altering compute components in accordance with least privilege. Organizations should limit the number of users within the organization with an IAM role that has administrative privileges, strive to reduce all permanent privileged role assignments, and conduct periodic entitlement reviews on IAM users, roles and policies.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  can disguise JavaScript files as PDFs.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has renamed the WinRAR utility to avoid detection.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has disguised a Cobalt Strike beacon as a Flash Installer.

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal  dropped a decoy payload with a .jpg extension that contained a malicious Visual Basic script.

Name: BoomBox
Description: BoomBox  has the ability to mask malicious data strings as PDF files.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  has masked executables with document file icons including Word and Adobe PDF.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors named a binary file  compareForfor.jpg  to disguise it as a JPG file.

Name: C0018
Description: During  C0018 ,  AvosLocker  was disguised using the victim company name as the filename.

Name: Dacls
Description: The  Dacls  Mach-O binary has been disguised as a .nib file.

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla 's payload has been renamed  PowerShellInfo.exe .

Name: DarkWatchman
Description: DarkWatchman  has used an icon mimicking a text file to mask a malicious executable.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has created accounts disguised as legitimate backup and service accounts as well as an email administration account.

Name: EnvyScout
Description: EnvyScout  has used folder icons for malicious files to lure victims into opening them.

Name: FatDuke
Description: FatDuke  has attempted to mimic a compromised user's traffic by using the same user agent as the installed browser.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has masqueraded staged data by using the Windows  certutil  utility to generate fake Base64 encoded certificates with the input file.

Name: Flagpro
Description: Flagpro  can download malicious files with a .tmp extension and append them with .exe prior to execution.

Name: FoggyWeb
Description: FoggyWeb  can masquerade the output of C2 commands as a fake, but legitimately formatted WebP file.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has disguised its C2 addresses as the websites of shopping malls, governments, universities, and others.

Name: LazyScripter
Description: LazyScripter  has used several different security software icons to disguise executables.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has used  esentutl  to change file extensions to their true type that were masquerading as .txt files.

Name: Milan
Description: Milan  has used an executable named  companycatalogue  to appear benign.

Name: NativeZone
Description: NativeZone  has, upon execution, displayed a message box that appears to be related to a Ukrainian electronic document management system.

Name: Nomadic Octopus
Description: Nomadic Octopus  attempted to make  Octopus  appear as a  Telegram Messenger with a Russian interface.

Name: NotPetya
Description: NotPetya  drops  PsExec  with the filename dllhost.dat.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used .doc file extensions to mask malicious executables.

Name: Operation Dust Storm
Description: For  Operation Dust Storm , the threat actors disguised some executables as JPG files.

Name: Operation Honeybee
Description: During  Operation Honeybee , the threat actors modified the MaoCheng dropper so its icon appeared as a Word document.

Name: PLATINUM
Description: PLATINUM  has renamed rar.exe to avoid detection.

Name: PowGoop
Description: PowGoop  has disguised a PowerShell script as a .dat file (goopdate.dat).

Name: Raindrop
Description: Raindrop  was built to include a modified version of 7-Zip source code (including associated export names) and Far Manager source code.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  has masqueraded as a JPG image file.

Name: RCSession
Description: RCSession  has used a file named English.rtf to appear benign on victim hosts.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  has been delivered as archived Windows executable files masquerading as PDF documents.

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  can create .dll files that actually contain a Rich Text File format document.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  has renamed malicious binaries as  wallpaper.mp4  and  slideshow.mp4  to avoid detection.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  set the hostnames of their C2 infrastructure to match legitimate hostnames in the victim environment. They also used IP addresses originating from the same country as the victim for their VPN infrastructure.

Name: SombRAT
Description: SombRAT  can use a legitimate process name to hide itself.

Name: TA551
Description: TA551  has masked malware DLLs as dat and jpg files.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has disguised their scripts with docker-related file names.

Name: TrailBlazer
Description: TrailBlazer  has used filenames that match the name of the compromised system in attempt to avoid detection.

Name: TrickBot
Description: The  TrickBot  downloader has used an icon to appear as a Microsoft Word document.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  has been disguised as a JPG extension to avoid detection as a malicious PE file.

Name: Windshift
Description: Windshift  has used icons mimicking MS Office files to mask malicious executables.    Windshift  has also attempted to hide executables by changing the file extension to ".scr" to mimic Windows screensavers.

Name: WindTail
Description: WindTail  has used icons mimicking MS Office files to mask payloads.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  builds a malicious application bundle to resemble Safari through using the Safari icon and  Info.plist .

Name: ZIRCONIUM
Description: ZIRCONIUM  has spoofed legitimate applications in phishing lures and changed file extensions to conceal  installation of malware.

Name: Antivirus/Antimalware
Description: Anti-virus can be used to automatically quarantine suspicious files.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: Implement security controls on the endpoint, such as a Host Intrusion Prevention System (HIPS), to identify and prevent execution of potentially malicious files (such as those with mismatching file signatures).

Name: Code Signing
Description: Require signed binaries.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use tools that restrict program execution via application control by attributes other than file name for common operating system utilities that are needed.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Use file system access controls to protect folders such as C:\Windows\System32.

Name: User Training
Description: Train users not to open email attachments or click unknown links (URLs). Such training fosters more secure habits within your organization and will limit many of the risks.

Name: Ebury
Description: Ebury  can intercept private keys using a trojanized  ssh-add  function.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has replaced legitimate KeePass binaries with trojanized versions to collect passwords from numerous applications.

Name: Kessel
Description: Kessel  has trojanized the  ssh_login and  user-auth_pubkey  functions to steal plaintext credentials.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can create a backdoor in KeePass using a malicious config file and in TortoiseSVN using a registry hook.

Name: Audit
Description: Review authentication logs to ensure that mechanisms such as enforcement of MFA are functioning as intended. Periodically review the hybrid identity solution in use for any discrepancies. For example, review all Pass Through Authentication (PTA) agents in the Azure Management Portal to identify any unwanted or unapproved ones.   If ADFS is in use, review DLLs and executable files in the AD FS and Global Assembly Cache directories to ensure that they are signed by Microsoft. Note that in some cases binaries may be catalog-signed, which may cause the file to appear unsigned when viewing file properties.  Periodically review for new and unknown network provider DLLs within the Registry ( HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\<NetworkProviderName>\NetworkProvider\ProviderPath ). Ensure only valid network provider DLLs are registered. The name of these can be found in the Registry key at  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\NetworkProvider\Order , and have corresponding service subkey pointing to a DLL at  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentC ontrolSet\Services\<NetworkProviderName>\NetworkProvider .

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Integrating multi-factor authentication (MFA) as part of organizational policy can greatly reduce the risk of an adversary gaining control of valid credentials that may be used for additional tactics such as initial access, lateral movement, and collecting information. MFA can also be used to restrict access to cloud resources and APIs.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Ensure only valid password filters are registered. Filter DLLs must be present in Windows installation directory ( C:\Windows\System32\  by default) of a domain controller and/or local computer with a corresponding entry in  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\Notification Packages .  Starting in Windows 11 22H2, the  EnableMPRNotifications  policy can be disabled through Group Policy or through a configuration service provider to prevent Winlogon from sending credentials to network providers.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Ensure that  AllowReversiblePasswordEncryption  property is set to disabled unless there are application requirements.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Audit domain and local accounts as well as their permission levels routinely to look for situations that could allow an adversary to gain wide access by obtaining credentials of a privileged account.       These audits should also include if default accounts have been enabled, or if new local accounts are created that have not be authorized. Follow best practices for design and administration of an enterprise network to limit privileged account use across administrative tiers.   Limit access to the root account and prevent users from modifying protected components through proper privilege separation (ex SELinux, grsecurity, AppArmor, etc.) and limiting Privilege Escalation opportunities. Limit on-premises accounts with access to the hybrid identity solution in place. For example, limit Azure AD Global Administrator accounts to only those required, and ensure that these are dedicated cloud-only accounts rather than hybrid ones.

Name: Privileged Process Integrity
Description: Enabled features, such as Protected Process Light (PPL), for LSA.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Restrict write access to the  /Library/Security/SecurityAgentPlugins  directory.

Name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Description: Restrict Registry permissions to disallow the modification of sensitive Registry keys such as  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\NetworkProvider\Order .

Name: User Account Management
Description: Ensure that proper policies are implemented to dictate the the secure enrollment and deactivation of authentication mechanisms, such as MFA, for user accounts.

Name: Boot Integrity
Description: Some vendors of embedded network devices provide cryptographic signing to ensure the integrity of operating system images at boot time.  Implement where available, following vendor guidelines.

Name: Code Signing
Description: Many vendors provide digitally signed operating system images to validate the integrity of the software used on their platform.  Make use of this feature where possible in order to prevent and/or detect attempts by adversaries to compromise the system image.

Name: Credential Access Protection
Description: Some embedded network devices are capable of storing passwords for local accounts in either plain-text or encrypted formats.  Ensure that, where available, local passwords are always encrypted, per vendor recommendations.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Use multi-factor authentication for user and privileged accounts. Most embedded network devices support TACACS+ and/or RADIUS.  Follow vendor prescribed best practices for hardening access control.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Refer to NIST guidelines when creating password policies.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Restrict administrator accounts to as few individuals as possible, following least privilege principles.  Prevent credential overlap across systems of administrator and privileged accounts, particularly between network and non-network platforms, such as servers or endpoints.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has used repeated MFA requests to gain access to victim accounts.

Name: C0027
Description: During  C0027 ,  Scattered Spider  attempted to gain access by continuously sending MFA messages to the victim until they accept the MFA push challenge.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has spammed target users with MFA prompts in the hope that the legitimate user will grant necessary approval.

Name: Scattered Spider
Description: Scattered Spider  has used multifactor authentication (MFA) fatigue by sending repeated MFA authentication requests to targets.

Name: Account Use Policies
Description: Enable account restrictions to prevent login attempts, and the subsequent 2FA/MFA service requests, from being initiated from suspicious locations or when the source of the login attempts do not match the location of the 2FA/MFA smart device. Use conditional access policies to block logins from non-compliant devices or from outside defined organization IP ranges.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Implement more secure 2FA/MFA mechanisms in replacement of simple push or one-click 2FA/MFA options. For example, having users enter a one-time code provided by the login screen into the 2FA/MFA application or utilizing other out-of-band 2FA/MFA mechanisms (such as rotating code-based hardware tokens providing rotating codes that need an accompanying user pin) may be more secure. Furthermore, change default configurations and implement limits upon the maximum number of 2FA/MFA request prompts that can be sent to users in period of time.

Name: User Training
Description: Train users to only accept 2FA/MFA requests from login attempts they initiated, to review source location of the login attempt prompting the 2FA/MFA requests, and to report suspicious/unsolicited prompts.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has registered alternate phone numbers for compromised users to intercept 2FA codes sent via SMS.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used a proprietary tool to intercept one time passwords required for two-factor authentication.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has replayed stolen session token and passwords to trigger simple-approval MFA prompts in hope of the legitimate user will grant necessary approval.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used a custom collection method to intercept two-factor authentication soft tokens.

Name: Sykipot
Description: Sykipot  is known to contain functionality that enables targeting of smart card technologies to proxy authentication for connections to restricted network resources using detected hardware tokens.

Name: User Training
Description: Remove smart cards when not in use.

Name: APT1
Description: APT1  listed connected network shares.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  used the  net view  command to show all shares available, including the administrative shares such as  C$  and  ADMIN$ .

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has enumerated network shares on a compromised host.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used the post exploitation tool  CrackMapExec  to enumerate network shares.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  used the  net share  command as part of network reconnaissance.

Name: Avaddon
Description: Avaddon  has enumerated shared folders and mapped volumes.

Name: AvosLocker
Description: AvosLocker  has enumerated shared drives on a compromised network.

Name: Babuk
Description: Babuk  has the ability to enumerate network shares.

Name: Bad Rabbit
Description: Bad Rabbit  enumerates open SMB shares on internal victim networks.

Name: BADHATCH
Description: BADHATCH  can check a user's access to the C$ share on a compromised machine.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can enumerate shared drives on the domain.

Name: BitPaymer
Description: BitPaymer  can search for network shares on the domain or workgroup using  net view  .

Name: BlackCat
Description: BlackCat  has the ability to discover network shares on compromised networks.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors executed the PowerView ShareFinder module to identify open shares.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has used  net share  and  net view  to identify network shares of interest.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  has the ability to enumerate network shares.

Name: Clop
Description: Clop  can enumerate network shares.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can query shared drives on the local system.

Name: Conti
Description: Conti  can enumerate remote open SMB network shares using  NetShareEnum() .

Name: CrackMapExec
Description: CrackMapExec  can enumerate the shared folders and associated permissions for a targeted network.

Name: Cuba
Description: Cuba  can discover shared resources using the  NetShareEnum  API call.

Name: DarkVishnya
Description: DarkVishnya  scanned the network for public shared folders.

Name: DEATHRANSOM
Description: DEATHRANSOM  has the ability to use loop operations to enumerate network resources.

Name: Diavol
Description: Diavol  has a  ENMDSKS  command to enumerates available network shares.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has identified and browsed file servers in the victim network, sometimes , viewing files pertaining to ICS or Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems.

Name: Emotet
Description: Emotet  has enumerated non-hidden network shares using  WNetEnumResourceW .

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can find shared drives on the local system.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has executed net view commands for enumeration of open shares on compromised machines.

Name: FIVEHANDS
Description: FIVEHANDS  can enumerate network shares and mounted drives on a network.

Name: Flagpro
Description: Flagpro  has been used to execute  net view  to discover mapped network shares.

Name: HELLOKITTY
Description: HELLOKITTY  has the ability to enumerate network resources.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can gather network share information.

Name: Koadic
Description: Koadic  can scan local network for open SMB.

Name: KOPILUWAK
Description: KOPILUWAK  can use  netstat  and  Net  to discover network shares.

Name: Kwampirs
Description: Kwampirs  collects a list of network shares with the command  net share .

Name: MURKYTOP
Description: MURKYTOP  has the capability to retrieve information about shares on remote hosts.

Name: Net
Description: The  net view \remotesystem  and  net share  commands in  Net  can be used to find shared drives and directories on remote and local systems respectively.

Name: Olympic Destroyer
Description: Olympic Destroyer  will attempt to enumerate mapped network shares to later attempt to wipe all files on those shares.

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , the threat actors used the  net share  command as part of their advanced reconnaissance.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors discovered network disks mounted to the system using  netstat .

Name: OSInfo
Description: OSInfo  discovers shares on the network

Name: PlugX
Description: PlugX  has a module to enumerate network shares.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  can list local and remote shared drives and folders over SMB.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can use  net share  to identify network shares for use in lateral movement.

Name: QuietSieve
Description: QuietSieve  can identify and search networked drives for specific file name extensions.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can scan for network drives which may contain documents for collection.

Name: Royal
Description: Royal  can enumerate the shared resources of a given IP addresses using the API call  NetShareEnum .

Name: Sardonic
Description: Sardonic  has the ability to execute the  net view  command.

Name: ShimRat
Description: ShimRat  can enumerate connected drives for infected host machines.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can enumerate shares on a compromised host.

Name: Sowbug
Description: Sowbug  listed remote shared drives that were accessible from a victim.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  enumerates the directories of a network resource.

Name: Tonto Team
Description: Tonto Team  has used tools such as  NBTscan  to enumerate network shares.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  module shareDll/mshareDll discovers network shares via the WNetOpenEnumA API.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  used  netview  to scan target systems for shared resources.

Name: WastedLocker
Description: WastedLocker  can identify network adjacent and accessible drives.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  can enumerate connected remote logical drives.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used the "net view" command to locate mapped network shares.

Name: Zebrocy
Description: Zebrocy  identifies network drives when they are added to victim systems.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Enable Windows Group Policy "Do Not Allow Anonymous Enumeration of SAM Accounts and Shares" security setting to limit users who can enumerate network shares.

Name: Credential Access Protection
Description: Some embedded network devices are capable of storing passwords for local accounts in either plain-text or encrypted formats.  Ensure that, where available, local passwords are always encrypted, per vendor recommendations.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Upon identifying a compromised network device being used to bridge a network boundary, block the malicious packets using an unaffected network device in path, such as a firewall or a router that has not been compromised.  Continue to monitor for additional activity and to ensure that the blocks are indeed effective.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Use multi-factor authentication for user and privileged accounts. Most embedded network devices support TACACS+ and/or RADIUS.  Follow vendor prescribed best practices for hardening access control.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Refer to NIST guidelines when creating password policies.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Restrict administrator accounts to as few individuals as possible, following least privilege principles.  Prevent credential overlap across systems of administrator and privileged accounts, particularly between network and non-network platforms, such as servers or endpoints.

Name: APT28
Description: In 2016,  APT28  conducted a distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack against the World Anti-Doping Agency.

Name: Lucifer
Description: Lucifer  can execute TCP, UDP,  and HTTP denial of service (DoS) attacks.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: When flood volumes exceed the capacity of the network connection being targeted, it is typically necessary to intercept the incoming traffic upstream to filter out the attack traffic from the legitimate traffic. Such defenses can be provided by the hosting Internet Service Provider (ISP) or by a 3rd party such as a Content Delivery Network (CDN) or providers specializing in DoS mitigations.  Depending on flood volume, on-premises filtering may be possible by blocking source addresses sourcing the attack, blocking ports that are being targeted, or blocking protocols being used for transport.  As immediate response may require rapid engagement of 3rd parties, analyze the risk associated to critical resources being affected by Network DoS attacks and create a disaster recovery plan/business continuity plan to respond to incidents.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  performed network scanning on the network to search for open ports, services, OS finger-printing, and other vulnerabilities.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used  CrackMapExec  and a custom port scanner known as BLUETORCH for network scanning.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  used a malware variant called WIDETONE to conduct port scans on specified subnets.

Name: Backdoor.Oldrea
Description: Backdoor.Oldrea  can use a network scanning module to identify ICS-related ports.

Name: BackdoorDiplomacy
Description: BackdoorDiplomacy  has used SMBTouch, a vulnerability scanner, to determine whether a target is vulnerable to EternalBlue malware.

Name: BADHATCH
Description: BADHATCH  can check for open ports on a computer by establishing a TCP connection.

Name: BlackEnergy
Description: BlackEnergy  has conducted port scans on a host.

Name: BlackTech
Description: BlackTech  has used the SNScan tool to find other potential targets on victim networks.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  can conduct port scanning against targeted systems.

Name: C0018
Description: During  C0018 , the threat actors used the SoftPerfect Network Scanner for network scanning.

Name: C0027
Description: During  C0027 , used RustScan to scan for open ports on targeted ESXi appliances.

Name: Caterpillar WebShell
Description: Caterpillar WebShell  has a module to use a port scanner on a system.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has used the  get -b   -e   -p  command for network scanning as well as a custom Python tool  packed into a Windows executable named Get.exe to scan IP ranges for HTTP.

Name: China Chopper
Description: China Chopper 's server component can spider authentication portals.

Name: Cobalt Group
Description: Cobalt Group  leveraged an open-source tool called SoftPerfect Network Scanner to perform network scanning.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can perform port scans from an infected host.

Name: Conficker
Description: Conficker  scans for other machines to infect.

Name: CostaRicto
Description: During  CostaRicto , the threat actors employed nmap and pscan to scan target environments.

Name: DarkVishnya
Description: DarkVishnya  performed port scanning to obtain the list of active services.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can perform port scans from an infected host.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has utilized  nmap  for reconnaissance efforts.  FIN13  has also scanned for internal MS-SQL servers in a compromised network.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  used publicly available tools (including Microsoft's built-in SQL querying tool, osql.exe) to map the internal network and conduct reconnaissance against Active Directory, Structured Query Language (SQL) servers, and NetBIOS.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has used tools including NMAP to conduct broad scanning to identify open ports.

Name: HDoor
Description: HDoor  scans to identify open ports on the victim.

Name: HermeticWizard
Description: HermeticWizard  has the ability to scan ports on a compromised network.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has used masscan to look for kubelets in the internal Kubernetes network.

Name: Industroyer
Description: Industroyer  uses a custom port scanner to map out a network.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can scan the network for open ports and vulnerable instances of RDP and SMB protocols.

Name: Koadic
Description: Koadic  can scan for open TCP ports on the target network.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has used nmap from a router VM to scan ports on systems within the restricted segment of an enterprise network.

Name: Leafminer
Description: Leafminer  scanned network services to search for vulnerabilities in the victim system.

Name: Lucifer
Description: Lucifer  can scan for open ports including TCP ports 135 and 1433.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has used KPortScan 3.0 to perform SMB, RDP, and LDAP scanning.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has used tcping.exe, similar to  Ping , to probe port status on systems of interest.

Name: MURKYTOP
Description: MURKYTOP  has the capability to scan for open ports on hosts in a connected network.

Name: Naikon
Description: Naikon  has used the LadonGo scanner to scan target networks.

Name: NBTscan
Description: NBTscan  can be used to scan IP networks.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used the publicly available tool SoftPerfect Network Scanner as well as a custom tool called GOLDIRONY to conduct network scanning.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors scanned for open ports and used nbtscan to find NETBIOS nameservers.

Name: P.A.S. Webshell
Description: P.A.S. Webshell  can scan networks for open ports and listening services.

Name: Peirates
Description: Peirates  can initiate a port scan against a given IP address.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  can perform port scans from an infected host.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  has a built-in module for port scanning.

Name: Pysa
Description: Pysa  can perform network reconnaissance using the Advanced Port Scanner tool.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can scan for systems that are vulnerable to the EternalBlue exploit.

Name: Remsec
Description: Remsec  has a plugin that can perform ARP scanning as well as port scanning.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  conducted scanning for exposed TCP port 7001 as well as SSH and Redis servers.

Name: Royal
Description: Royal  can scan the network interfaces of targeted systems.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can scan for open ports on a compromised machine.

Name: SpeakUp
Description: SpeakUp  checks for availability of specific ports on servers.

Name: Suckfly
Description: Suckfly  the victim's internal network for hosts with ports 8080, 5900, and 40 open.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has used masscan to search for open Docker API ports and Kubernetes clusters.      TeamTNT  has also used malware that utilizes zmap and zgrab to search for vulnerable services in cloud environments.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  actors use the Hunter tool to conduct network service discovery for vulnerable systems.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  used  pr  and an openly available tool to scan for open ports on target systems.

Name: Xbash
Description: Xbash  can perform port scanning of TCP and UDP ports.

Name: XTunnel
Description: XTunnel  is capable of probing the network for open ports.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  can launch port scans.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Ensure that unnecessary ports and services are closed to prevent risk of discovery and potential exploitation.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Use network intrusion detection/prevention systems to detect and prevent remote service scans.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Ensure proper network segmentation is followed to protect critical servers and devices.

Name: APT3
Description: An  APT3  downloader first establishes a SOCKS5 connection to 192.157.198103 using TCP port 1913; once the server response is verified, it then requests a connection to 192.184.60229 on TCP port 81.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  used the storescyncsvc.dll BEACON backdoor to download a secondary backdoor.

Name: BACKSPACE
Description: BACKSPACE  attempts to avoid detection by checking a first stage command and control server to determine if it should connect to the second stage server, which performs "louder" interactions with the malware.

Name: Bazar
Description: The  Bazar  loader is used to download and execute the  Bazar  backdoor.

Name: BLACKCOFFEE
Description: BLACKCOFFEE  uses Microsoft’s TechNet Web portal to obtain an encoded tag containing the IP address of a command and control server and then communicates separately with that IP address for C2. If the C2 server is discovered or shut down, the threat actors can update the encoded IP address on TechNet to maintain control of the victims’ machines.

Name: Chaos
Description: After initial compromise,  Chaos  will download a second stage to establish a more permanent presence on the affected system.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has used multi-stage malware components that inject later stages into separate processes.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has used one C2 to obtain enumeration scripts and monitor web logs, but a different C2 to send data back.

Name: Snip3
Description: Snip3  can download and execute additional payloads and modules over separate communication channels.

Name: Uroburos
Description: Individual  Uroburos  implants can use multiple communication channels based on one of four available modes of operation.

Name: Valak
Description: Valak  can download additional modules and malware capable of using separate C2 channels.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: ADVSTORESHELL
Description: ADVSTORESHELL  can list connected devices.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  uses a module to receive a notification every time a USB mass storage device is inserted into a victim.

Name: APT37
Description: APT37  has a Bluetooth device harvester, which uses Windows Bluetooth APIs to find information on connected Bluetooth devices.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  has a plugin that collects information about inserted storage devices, modems, and phone devices.

Name: BackdoorDiplomacy
Description: BackdoorDiplomacy  has used an executable to detect removable media, such as USB flash drives.

Name: BADNEWS
Description: BADNEWS  checks for new hard drives on the victim, such as USB devices, by listening for the WM_DEVICECHANGE window message.

Name: Bandook
Description: Bandook  can detect USB devices.

Name: BlackEnergy
Description: BlackEnergy  can gather very specific information about attached USB devices, to include device instance ID and drive geometry.

Name: Cadelspy
Description: Cadelspy  has the ability to steal information about printers and the documents sent to printers.

Name: Crimson
Description: Crimson  has the ability to discover pluggable/removable drives to extract files from.

Name: Crutch
Description: Crutch  can monitor for removable drives being plugged into the compromised machine.

Name: DarkWatchman
Description: DarkWatchman  can list signed PnP drivers for smartcard readers.

Name: DustySky
Description: DustySky  can detect connected USB devices.

Name: Equation
Description: Equation  has used tools with the functionality to search for specific information about the attached hard drive that could be used to identify and overwrite the firmware.

Name: Ferocious
Description: Ferocious  can run  GET.WORKSPACE  in Microsoft Excel to check if a mouse is present.

Name: FlawedAmmyy
Description: FlawedAmmyy  will attempt to detect if a usable smart card is current inserted into a card reader.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: The  FunnyDream  FilepakMonitor component can detect removable drive insertion.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  tools have contained an application to check performance of USB flash drives.  Gamaredon Group  has also used malware to scan for removable drives.

Name: Heyoka Backdoor
Description: Heyoka Backdoor  can identify removable media attached to victim's machines.

Name: jRAT
Description: jRAT  can map UPnP ports.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  detects the insertion of new devices by listening for the WM_DEVICECHANGE window message.

Name: Mongall
Description: Mongall  can identify removable media attached to compromised hosts.

Name: MoonWind
Description: MoonWind  obtains the number of removable drives from the victim.

Name: NightClub
Description: NightClub  has the ability to monitor removable drives.

Name: njRAT
Description: njRAT  will attempt to detect if the victim system has a camera during the initial infection.  njRAT  can also detect any removable drives connected to the system.

Name: ObliqueRAT
Description: ObliqueRAT  can discover pluggable/removable drives to extract files from.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used tools to identify if a mouse is connected to a targeted system.

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , the threat actors used the  fsutil fsinfo drives  command as part of their advanced reconnaissance.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors discovered removable disks attached to a system.

Name: Prikormka
Description: A module in  Prikormka  collects information on available printers and disk drives.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can identify peripheral devices on targeted systems.

Name: QuietSieve
Description: QuietSieve  can identify and search removable drives for specific file name extensions.

Name: Ragnar Locker
Description: Ragnar Locker  may attempt to connect to removable drives and mapped network drives.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can scan for removable media which may contain documents for collection.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  can obtain a list of smart card readers attached to the victim.
