Name: SharpDisco
Description: SharpDisco  has dropped a plugin to monitor external drives to  C:\Users\Public\It3.exe .

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  enumerates removable drives for infection.

Name: SVCReady
Description: SVCReady  can check for the number of devices plugged into an infected host.

Name: T9000
Description: T9000  searches through connected drives for removable storage devices.

Name: TajMahal
Description: TajMahal  has the ability to identify connected Apple devices.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has searched for attached VGA devices using lspci.

Name: Turian
Description: Turian  can scan for removable media to collect data.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has used  fsutil fsinfo drives  to list connected drives.

Name: USBferry
Description: USBferry  can check for connected USB devices.

Name: USBStealer
Description: USBStealer  monitors victims for insertion of removable drives. When dropped onto a second victim, it also enumerates drives connected to the system.

Name: WannaCry
Description: WannaCry  contains a thread that will attempt to scan for new attached drives every few seconds. If one is identified, it will encrypt the files on the attached device.

Name: WastedLocker
Description: WastedLocker  can enumerate removable drives prior to the encryption process.

Name: Zebrocy
Description: Zebrocy  enumerates information about connected storage devices.

Name: FoggyWeb
Description: FoggyWeb  can allow abuse of a compromised AD FS server's SAML token.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used forged SAML tokens that allowed the actors to impersonate users and bypass MFA, enabling  APT29  to access enterprise cloud applications and services.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Limit credential overlap across systems to prevent the damage of credential compromise and reduce the adversary's ability to perform Lateral Movement between systems.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Enforce the principle of least-privilege. Do not allow a domain user to be in the local administrator group on multiple systems.

Name: APT-C-36
Description: APT-C-36  has used port 4050 for C2 communications.

Name: APT32
Description: An  APT32  backdoor can use HTTP over a non-standard TCP port (e.g 14146) which is specified in the backdoor configuration.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has used HTTP over TCP ports 808 and 880 for command and control.

Name: BADCALL
Description: BADCALL  communicates on ports 443 and 8000 with a FakeTLS method.

Name: Bankshot
Description: Bankshot  binds and listens on port 1058 for HTTP traffic while also utilizing a FakeTLS method.

Name: BendyBear
Description: BendyBear  has used a custom RC4 and XOR encrypted protocol over port 443 for C2.

Name: C0018
Description: During  C0018 , the threat actors opened a variety of ports, including ports 28035, 32467, 41578, and 46892, to establish RDP connections.

Name: Cyclops Blink
Description: Cyclops Blink  can use non-standard ports for C2 not typically associated with HTTP or HTTPS traffic.

Name: DarkVishnya
Description: DarkVishnya  used ports 5190 and 7900 for shellcode listeners, and 4444, 4445, 31337 for shellcode C2.

Name: Derusbi
Description: Derusbi  has used unencrypted HTTP on port 443 for C2.

Name: Emotet
Description: Emotet  has used HTTP over ports such as 20, 22, 443, 7080, and 50000, in addition to using ports commonly associated with HTTP/S.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  has used port-protocol mismatches on ports such as 53, 80, 443, and 8080 during C2.

Name: GoldenSpy
Description: GoldenSpy  has used HTTP over ports 9005 and 9006 for network traffic, 9002 for C2 requests, 33666 as a WebSocket, and 8090 to download files.

Name: GravityRAT
Description: GravityRAT  has used HTTP over a non-standard port, such as TCP port 46769.

Name: HARDRAIN
Description: HARDRAIN  binds and listens on port 443 with a FakeTLS method.

Name: HOPLIGHT
Description: HOPLIGHT  has connected outbound over TCP port 443 with a FakeTLS method.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Some  Lazarus Group  malware uses a list of ordered port numbers to choose a port for C2 traffic, creating port-protocol mismatches.

Name: MacMa
Description: MacMa  has used TCP port 5633 for C2 Communication.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  malware has communicated with its C2 server over TCP ports 4443 and 10151 using HTTP.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has communicated with hosts over raw TCP on port 9999.

Name: MoonWind
Description: MoonWind  communicates over ports 80, 443, 53, and 8080 via raw sockets instead of the protocols usually associated with the ports.

Name: njRAT
Description: njRAT  has used port 1177 for HTTP C2 communications.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , the threat actors used uncommon high ports for its backdoor C2, including ports 25667 and 47000.

Name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D  has used a custom binary protocol over TCP port 443 for C2.

Name: PingPull
Description: PingPull  can use HTTPS over port 8080 for C2.

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  used TLS to encrypt communications over port 143

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: QuasarRAT  can use port 4782 on the compromised host for TCP callbacks.

Name: RedLeaves
Description: RedLeaves  can use HTTP over non-standard ports, such as 995, for C2.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke 's miner connects to a C2 server using port 51640.

Name: RotaJakiro
Description: RotaJakiro  uses a custom binary protocol over TCP port 443.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  used Port 44443 for its VNC module.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has used port 6789 to accept connections on the group's SSH server.

Name: Sardonic
Description: Sardonic  has the ability to connect with actor-controlled C2 servers using a custom binary protocol over port 443.

Name: Silence
Description: Silence  has used port 444 when sending data about the system from the client to the server.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  has used HTTPS over port 1402 in C2 communication.

Name: SUGARUSH
Description: SUGARUSH  has used port 4585 for a TCP connection to its C2.

Name: TEMP.Veles
Description: TEMP.Veles  has used port-protocol mismatches on ports such as 443, 4444, 8531, and 50501 during C2.

Name: TrickBot
Description: Some  TrickBot  samples have used HTTP over ports 447 and 8082 for C2.     Newer versions of  TrickBot  have been known to use a custom communication protocol which sends the data unencrypted over port 443.

Name: TYPEFRAME
Description: TYPEFRAME  has used ports 443, 8080, and 8443 with a FakeTLS method.

Name: WellMail
Description: WellMail  has been observed using TCP port 25, without using SMTP, to leverage an open port for secure command and control communications.

Name: WIRTE
Description: WIRTE  has used HTTPS over ports 2083 and 2087 for C2.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  can use ports 1985 and 1986 in HTTP/S communication.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Properly configure firewalls and proxies to limit outgoing traffic to only necessary ports for that particular network segment.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has recruited target organization employees or contractors who provide credentials and approve an associated MFA prompt, or install remote management software onto a corporate workstation, allowing  LAPSUS$  to take control of an authenticated system.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: On Windows 10, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to prevent executable files from running unless they meet a prevalence, age, or trusted list criteria and to prevent Office applications from creating potentially malicious executable content by blocking malicious code from being written to disk. Note: cloud-delivered protection must be enabled to use certain rules.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Application control may be able to prevent the running of executables masquerading as other files.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: If a link is being visited by a user, network intrusion prevention systems and systems designed to scan and remove malicious downloads can be used to block activity.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: If a link is being visited by a user, block unknown or unused files in transit by default that should not be downloaded or by policy from suspicious sites as a best practice to prevent some vectors, such as .scr, .exe, .pif, .cpl, etc. Some download scanning devices can open and analyze compressed and encrypted formats, such as zip and rar that may be used to conceal malicious files.

Name: User Training
Description: Use user training as a way to bring awareness to common phishing and spearphishing techniques and how to raise suspicion for potentially malicious events.

Name: BloodHound
Description: BloodHound  can collect password policy information on the target environment.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has used the NtdsAudit utility to collect information related to accounts and passwords.

Name: CrackMapExec
Description: CrackMapExec  can discover the password policies applied to the target system.

Name: Kwampirs
Description: Kwampirs  collects password policy information with the command  net accounts .

Name: Net
Description: The  net accounts  and  net accounts /domain  commands with  Net  can be used to obtain password policy information.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used net.exe in a script with  net accounts /domain  to find the password policy of a domain.

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , the threat actors used the  net accounts  command as part of their advanced reconnaissance.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  can use  Get-PassPol  to enumerate the domain password policy.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has used  net accounts  and  net accounts /domain  to acquire password policy information.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Ensure only valid password filters are registered. Filter DLLs must be present in Windows installation directory ( C:\Windows\System32\  by default) of a domain controller and/or local computer with a corresponding entry in  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\Notification Packages .

Name: Anchor
Description: Anchor  has used ICMP in C2 communications.

Name: APT3
Description: An  APT3  downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections for its initial C2.

Name: Aria-body
Description: Aria-body  has used TCP in C2 communications.

Name: AuTo Stealer
Description: AuTo Stealer  can use TCP to communicate with command and control servers.

Name: BackdoorDiplomacy
Description: BackdoorDiplomacy  has used EarthWorm for network tunneling with a SOCKS5 server and port transfer functionalities.

Name: Bandook
Description: Bandook  has a command built in to use a raw TCP socket.

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal  has used raw sockets for network communication.

Name: BITTER
Description: BITTER  has used TCP for C2 communications.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  has the ability to use TCP for external C2.

Name: BUBBLEWRAP
Description: BUBBLEWRAP  can communicate using SOCKS.

Name: C0021
Description: During  C0021 , the threat actors used TCP for some C2 communications.

Name: Carbon
Description: Carbon  uses TCP and UDP for C2.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  has the ability to use TCP and UDP for communication.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can be configured to use TCP, ICMP, and UDP for C2 communications.

Name: Crimson
Description: Crimson  uses a custom TCP protocol for C2.

Name: Cryptoistic
Description: Cryptoistic  can use TCP in communications with C2.

Name: Derusbi
Description: Derusbi  binds to a raw socket on a random source port between 31800 and 31900 for C2.

Name: Drovorub
Description: Drovorub  can use TCP to communicate between its agent and client modules.

Name: FakeM
Description: Some variants of  FakeM  use SSL to communicate with C2 servers.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has used Metasploit Bind and Reverse TCP stagers.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: FunnyDream  can communicate with C2 over TCP and UDP.

Name: Gelsemium
Description: Gelsemium  has the ability to use TCP and UDP in C2 communications.

Name: gh0st RAT
Description: gh0st RAT  has used an encrypted protocol within TCP segments to communicate with the C2.

Name: HAFNIUM
Description: HAFNIUM  has used TCP for C2.

Name: HiddenWasp
Description: HiddenWasp  communicates with a simple network protocol over TCP.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  has used TCP to download additional modules.

Name: KEYPLUG
Description: KEYPLUG  can use TCP and KCP (KERN Communications Protocol) over UDP for C2 communication.

Name: LookBack
Description: LookBack  uses a custom binary protocol over sockets for C2 communications.

Name: MacMa
Description: MacMa  has used a custom JSON-based protocol for its C&C communications.

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can use raw TCP for C2.

Name: Metador
Description: Metador  has used TCP for C2.

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  can establish an indirect and raw TCP socket-based connection to the C2 server.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has used raw TCP for C2.

Name: Mis-Type
Description: Mis-Type  network traffic can communicate over a raw socket.

Name: Misdat
Description: Misdat  network traffic communicates over a raw socket.

Name: MoonWind
Description: MoonWind  completes network communication via raw sockets.

Name: Mythic
Description: Mythic  supports WebSocket and TCP-based C2 profiles.

Name: Nebulae
Description: Nebulae  can use TCP in C2 communications.

Name: NETEAGLE
Description: If  NETEAGLE  does not detect a proxy configured on the infected machine, it will send beacons via UDP/6000. Also, after retrieving a C2 IP address and Port Number,  NETEAGLE  will initiate a TCP connection to this socket. The ensuing connection is a plaintext C2 channel in which commands are specified by DWORDs.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can use TCP in C2 communications.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used a custom protocol for command and control.

Name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D  has used a custom binary protocol over port 443 for C2 traffic.

Name: Pay2Key
Description: Pay2Key  has sent its public key to the C2 server over TCP.

Name: Penquin
Description: The  Penquin  C2 mechanism is based on TCP and UDP packets.

Name: PHOREAL
Description: PHOREAL  communicates via ICMP for C2.

Name: PingPull
Description: PingPull  variants have the ability to communicate with C2 servers using ICMP or TCP.

Name: PipeMon
Description: The  PipeMon  communication module can use a custom protocol based on TLS over TCP.

Name: PLATINUM
Description: PLATINUM  has used the Intel® Active Management Technology (AMT) Serial-over-LAN (SOL) channel for command and control.

Name: PlugX
Description: PlugX  can be configured to use raw TCP or UDP for command and control.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  has the ability use TCP to send or receive C2 packets.

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: QuasarRAT  can use TCP for C2 communication.

Name: QUIETEXIT
Description: QUIETEXIT  can establish a TCP connection as part of its initial connection to the C2.

Name: RainyDay
Description: RainyDay  can use TCP in C2 communications.

Name: RARSTONE
Description: RARSTONE  uses SSL to encrypt its communication with its C2 server.

Name: RCSession
Description: RCSession  has the ability to use TCP and UDP in C2 communications.

Name: Reaver
Description: Some  Reaver  variants use raw TCP for C2.

Name: Regin
Description: The  Regin  malware platform can use ICMP to communicate between infected computers.

Name: Remsec
Description: Remsec  is capable of using ICMP, TCP, and UDP for C2.

Name: RotaJakiro
Description: RotaJakiro  uses a custom binary protocol using a type, length, value format over TCP.

Name: Royal
Description: Royal  establishes a TCP socket for C2 communication using the API  WSASocketW .

Name: Sardonic
Description: Sardonic  can communicate with actor-controlled C2 servers by using a custom little-endian binary protocol.

Name: SDBbot
Description: SDBbot  has the ability to communicate with C2 with TCP over port 443.

Name: ShadowPad
Description: ShadowPad  has used UDP for C2 communications.

Name: SombRAT
Description: SombRAT  has the ability to use TCP sockets to send data and ICMP to ping the C2 server.

Name: SUGARUSH
Description: SUGARUSH  has used TCP for C2.

Name: Taidoor
Description: Taidoor  can use TCP for C2 communications.

Name: TSCookie
Description: TSCookie  can use ICMP to receive information on the destination server.

Name: Umbreon
Description: Umbreon  provides access to the system via SSH or any other protocol that uses PAM to authenticate.

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  can communicate through custom methodologies for UDP,  ICMP, and TCP that use distinct sessions to ride over the legitimate protocols.

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  can communicate with its C2 server via TCP over port 5200.

Name: WellMail
Description: WellMail  can use TCP for C2 communications.

Name: WINDSHIELD
Description: WINDSHIELD  C2 traffic can communicate via TCP raw sockets.

Name: Winnti for Linux
Description: Winnti for Linux  has used ICMP, custom TCP, and UDP in outbound communications.

Name: Winnti for Windows
Description: Winnti for Windows  can communicate using custom TCP.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Filter network traffic to prevent use of protocols across the network boundary that are unnecessary.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Properly configure firewalls and proxies to limit outgoing traffic to only necessary ports and through proper network gateway systems. Also ensure hosts are only provisioned to communicate over authorized interfaces.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  has a tool that can enumerate the permissions associated with Windows groups.

Name: Carbon
Description: Carbon  uses the  net group  command.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has enumerated all users and roles from a victim's main treasury system.

Name: IcedID
Description: IcedID  has the ability to identify Workgroup membership.

Name: MURKYTOP
Description: MURKYTOP  has the capability to retrieve information about groups.

Name: ShimRatReporter
Description: ShimRatReporter  gathered the local privileges for the infected host.

Name: Siloscape
Description: Siloscape  checks for Kubernetes node permissions.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used the  Get-ManagementRoleAssignment  PowerShell cmdlet to enumerate Exchange management role assignments through an Exchange Management Shell.

Name: TA505
Description: TA505  has used TinyMet to enumerate members of privileged groups.    TA505  has also run  net group /domain .

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  can identify the groups the user on a compromised host belongs to.

Name: Axiom
Description: Axiom  has used digital certificates to deliver malware.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: System settings can prevent applications from running that haven't been downloaded through the Apple Store (or other legitimate repositories) which can help mitigate some of these issues. Also enable application control solutions such as AppLocker and/or Device Guard to block the loading of malicious content.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Windows Group Policy can be used to manage root certificates and the  Flags  value of  HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\SystemCertificates\Root\ProtectedRoots  can be set to 1 to prevent non-administrator users from making further root installations into their own HKCU certificate store.

Name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Description: Ensure proper permissions are set for Registry hives to prevent users from modifying keys related to SIP and trust provider components. Components may still be able to be hijacked to suitable functions already present on disk if malicious modifications to Registry keys are not prevented.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: HTTP Public Key Pinning (HPKP) is one method to mitigate potential  Adversary-in-the-Middle  situations where and adversary uses a mis-issued or fraudulent certificate to intercept encrypted communications by enforcing use of an expected certificate.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  have replaced Microsoft Outlook's VbaProject.OTM file to install a backdoor macro for persistence.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  has inserted malicious macros into existing documents, providing persistence when they are reopened.  Gamaredon Group  has loaded the group's previously delivered VBA project by relaunching Microsoft Outlook with the  /altvba  option, once the Application.Startup event is received.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: On Windows 10, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to prevent Office applications from creating child processes and from writing potentially malicious executable content to disk.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Follow Office macro security best practices suitable for your environment. Disable Office VBA macros from executing. Disable Office add-ins. If they are required, follow best practices for securing them by requiring them to be signed and disabling user notification for allowing add-ins. For some add-ins types (WLL, VBA) additional mitigation is likely required as disabling add-ins in the Office Trust Center does not disable WLL nor does it prevent VBA code from executing.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: For the Office Test method, create the Registry key used to execute it and set the permissions to "Read Control" to prevent easy access to the key without administrator permissions or requiring Privilege Escalation.

Name: Update Software
Description: For the Outlook methods, blocking macros may be ineffective as the Visual Basic engine used for these features is separate from the macro scripting engine.   Microsoft has released patches to try to address each issue. Ensure KB3191938 which blocks Outlook Visual Basic and displays a malicious code warning, KB4011091 which disables custom forms by default, and KB4011162 which removes the legacy Home Page feature, are applied to systems.

Name: Audit
Description: Periodically inspect systems for abnormal and unexpected power settings that may indicate malicious activty.

Name: BADHATCH
Description: BADHATCH  can copy a large byte array of 64-bit shellcode into process memory and execute it with a call to  CreateThread .

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  has used reflective loading to execute malicious DLLs.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike 's  execute-assembly  command can run a .NET executable within the memory of a sacrificial process by loading the CLR.

Name: Cuba
Description: Cuba  loaded the payload into memory using PowerShell.

Name: Donut
Description: Donut  can generate code modules that enable in-memory execution of VBScript, JScript, EXE, DLL, and dotNET payloads.

Name: Emotet
Description: Emotet  has reflectively loaded payloads into memory.

Name: FoggyWeb
Description: FoggyWeb 's loader has reflectively loaded .NET-based assembly/payloads into memory.

Name: Gelsemium
Description: Gelsemium  can use custom shellcode to map embedded DLLs into memory.

Name: IceApple
Description: IceApple  can use reflective code loading to load .NET assemblies into  MSExchangeOWAAppPool  on targeted Exchange servers.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has changed memory protection permissions then overwritten in memory DLL function code with shellcode, which was later executed via  KernelCallbackTable  hijacking.  Lazarus Group  has also used shellcode within macros to decrypt and manually map DLLs into memory at runtime.

Name: Lokibot
Description: Lokibot  has reflectively loaded the decoded DLL into memory.

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  has reflectively loaded a DLL to read, decrypt, and load an orchestrator file.

Name: PowerSploit
Description: PowerSploit  reflectively loads a Windows PE file into a process.

Name: Sardonic
Description: Sardonic  has a plugin system that can load specially made DLLs into memory and execute their functions.

Name: ThiefQuest
Description: ThiefQuest  uses various API functions such as  NSCreateObjectFileImageFromMemory  to load and link in-memory payloads.

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  has the ability to load new modules directly into memory using its  Load Modules Mem  command.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate 's downloader can reverse its third stage file bytes and reflectively load the file as a .NET assembly.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  can use DNS over HTTPS for C2.

Name: C0027
Description: During  C0027 ,  Scattered Spider  used SSH tunneling in targeted environments.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has encapsulated  Cobalt Strike 's C2 protocol in DNS and HTTPS.

Name: Cobalt Group
Description: Cobalt Group  has used the Plink utility to create SSH tunnels.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  uses a custom command and control protocol that is encapsulated in HTTP, HTTPS, or DNS. In addition, it conducts peer-to-peer communication over Windows named pipes encapsulated in the SMB protocol. All protocols use their standard assigned ports.

Name: CostaRicto
Description: During  CostaRicto , the threat actors set up remote SSH tunneling into the victim's environment from a malicious domain.

Name: Cyclops Blink
Description: Cyclops Blink  can use DNS over HTTPS (DoH) to resolve C2 nodes.

Name: Duqu
Description: Duqu  uses a custom command and control protocol that communicates over commonly used ports, and is frequently encapsulated by application layer protocols.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has utilized web shells and Java tools for tunneling capabilities to and from compromised assets.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  used the Plink command-line utility to create SSH tunnels to C2 servers.

Name: FLIPSIDE
Description: FLIPSIDE  uses RDP to tunnel traffic from a victim environment.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has used protocol tunneling for communication and RDP activity on compromised hosts through the use of open source tools such as  ngrok  and custom tool SSHMinion.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: FunnyDream  can connect to HTTP proxies via TCP to create a tunnel to C2.

Name: Heyoka Backdoor
Description: Heyoka Backdoor  can use spoofed DNS requests to create a bidirectional tunnel between a compromised host and its C2 servers.

Name: Industroyer
Description: Industroyer  attempts to perform an HTTP CONNECT via an internal proxy to establish a tunnel.

Name: Kevin
Description: Kevin  can use a custom protocol tunneled through DNS or HTTP.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has used protocol tunneling to further conceal C2 communications and infrastructure.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has used Plink to tunnel RDP over SSH.

Name: Milan
Description: Milan  can use a custom protocol tunneled through DNS or HTTP.

Name: Mythic
Description: Mythic  can use SOCKS proxies to tunnel traffic through another protocol.

Name: ngrok
Description: ngrok  can tunnel RDP and other services securely over internet connections.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used the Plink utility and other tools to create tunnels to C2 servers.

Name: QakBot
Description: The  QakBot  proxy module can encapsulate SOCKS5 protocol within its own proxy protocol.

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  has the ability to communicate over custom communications methodologies that ride over common network protocols including raw TCP and UDP sockets, HTTP, SMTP, and DNS.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Consider filtering network traffic to untrusted or known bad domains and resources.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: 2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  loaded  BlackEnergy  into svchost.exe, which then launched iexplore.exe for their C2.

Name: ABK
Description: ABK  has the ability to inject shellcode into svchost.exe.

Name: Agent Tesla

Name: ANDROMEDA

Name: APT32

Name: APT37
Description: APT37  injects its malware variant,  ROKRAT , into the cmd.exe process.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  malware TIDYELF loaded the main WINTERLOVE component by injecting it into the iexplore.exe process.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor 's dispatcher can inject itself into running processes to gain higher privileges and to evade detection.

Name: AuditCred
Description: AuditCred  can inject code from files to other running processes.

Name: Avenger
Description: Avenger  has the ability to inject shellcode into svchost.exe.

Name: Backdoor.Oldrea
Description: Backdoor.Oldrea  injects itself into explorer.exe.

Name: BADHATCH
Description: BADHATCH  can inject itself into an existing explorer.exe process by using  RtlCreateUserThread .

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can inject code through calling  VirtualAllocExNuma .

Name: BBK
Description: BBK  has the ability to inject shellcode into svchost.exe.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  can inject code into multiple processes on infected endpoints.

Name: Cardinal RAT
Description: Cardinal RAT  injects into a newly spawned process created from a native Windows executable.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  can inject into the  svchost.exe  process for execution.

Name: Cobalt Group
Description: Cobalt Group  has injected code into trusted processes.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can inject a variety of payloads into processes dynamically chosen by the adversary.

Name: CostaBricks
Description: CostaBricks  can inject a payload into the memory of a compromised host.

Name: Donut
Description: Donut  includes a subproject  DonutTest  to inject shellcode into a target process.

Name: Dyre

Name: Egregor
Description: Egregor  can inject its payload into iexplore.exe process.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  contains multiple modules for injecting into processes, such as  Invoke-PSInject .

Name: Gazer

Name: gh0st RAT

Name: GuLoader

Name: HOPLIGHT
Description: HOPLIGHT  has injected into running processes.

Name: HTRAN
Description: HTRAN  can inject into into running processes.

Name: HyperBro
Description: HyperBro  can run shellcode it injects into a newly created process.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can inject itself into another process to avoid detection including use of a technique called ListPlanting that customizes the sorting algorithm in a ListView structure.

Name: IronNetInjector
Description: IronNetInjector  can use an IronPython scripts to load a .NET injector to inject a payload into its own or a remote process.

Name: JHUHUGIT
Description: JHUHUGIT  performs code injection injecting its own functions to browser processes.

Name: JPIN
Description: JPIN  can inject content into lsass.exe to load a module.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used Win7Elevate to inject malicious code into explorer.exe.

Name: Lizar
Description: Lizar  can migrate the loader into another process.

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  can inject the loader file, Speech02.db, into a process.

Name: Mis-Type
Description: Mis-Type  has been injected directly into a running process, including  explorer.exe .

Name: NavRAT
Description: NavRAT  copies itself into a running Internet Explorer process to evade detection.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can inject code into system processes including notepad.exe, svchost.exe, and vbc.exe.

Name: Operation Sharpshooter
Description: During  Operation Sharpshooter , threat actors leveraged embedded shellcode to inject a downloader into the memory of Word.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors injected code into a selected process, which in turn launches a command as a child process of the original.

Name: Pandora
Description: Pandora  can start and inject code into a new  svchost  process.

Name: PcShare
Description: The  PcShare  payload has been injected into the  logagent.exe  and  rdpclip.exe  processes.

Name: PLATINUM
Description: PLATINUM  has used various methods of process injection including hot patching.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  contains multiple modules for injecting into processes, such as  Invoke-PSInject .

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can inject itself into processes including explore.exe, Iexplore.exe, Mobsync.exe., and wermgr.exe.

Name: Remcos
Description: Remcos  has a command to hide itself through injecting into another process.

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  can inject itself into running processes on a compromised host.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  can use  VirtualAlloc ,  WriteProcessMemory , and then  CreateRemoteThread  to execute shellcode within the address space of  Notepad.exe .

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  has injected itself into remote processes to encrypt files using a combination of  VirtualAlloc ,  WriteProcessMemory , and  CreateRemoteThread .

Name: ShadowPad
Description: ShadowPad  has injected an install module into a newly created process.

Name: Silence
Description: Silence  has injected a DLL library containing a Trojan into the fwmain32.exe process.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can inject shellcode directly into Excel.exe or a specific process.

Name: Sliver
Description: Sliver  can inject code into local and remote processes.

Name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
Description: SLOTHFULMEDIA  can inject into running processes on a compromised host.

Name: Smoke Loader
Description: Smoke Loader  injects into the Internet Explorer process.

Name: StoneDrill
Description: StoneDrill  has relied on injecting its payload directly into the process memory of the victim's preferred browser.

Name: TA2541
Description: TA2541  has injected malicious code into legitimate .NET related processes including  regsvcs.exe, msbuild.exe, and installutil.exe.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  has used  Nt*   Native API  functions to inject code into legitimate processes such as  wermgr.exe .

Name: TSCookie
Description: TSCookie  has the ability to inject code into the svchost.exe, iexplorer.exe, explorer.exe, and default browser processes.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has also used  PowerSploit 's  Invoke-ReflectivePEInjection.ps1  to reflectively load a PowerShell payload into a random process on the victim system.

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  has the ability to inject malicious DLLs into a specific process for privilege escalation.

Name: Waterbear
Description: Waterbear  can inject decrypted shellcode into the LanmanServer service.

Name: Wiarp
Description: Wiarp  creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can inject files into running processes.

Name: Wingbird
Description: Wingbird  performs multiple process injections to hijack system processes and execute malicious code.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used process injection to execute payloads to escalate privileges.

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  can inject code into a targeted process by writing to the remote memory of an infected system and then create a remote thread.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process. For example, on Windows 10, Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules may prevent Office applications from code injection.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Utilize Yama (ex: /proc/sys/kernel/yama/ptrace_scope) to mitigate ptrace based process injection by restricting the use of ptrace to privileged users only. Other mitigation controls involve the deployment of security kernel modules that provide advanced access control and process restrictions such as SELinux, grsecurity, and AppArmor.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  used a tool called CLASSFON to covertly proxy network communications.

Name: Aria-body
Description: Aria-body  has the ability to use a reverse SOCKS proxy module.

Name: AuditCred
Description: AuditCred  can utilize proxy for communications.

Name: BADCALL
Description: BADCALL  functions as a proxy server between the victim and C2 server.

Name: BADHATCH
Description: BADHATCH  can use SOCKS4 and SOCKS5 proxies to connect to actor-controlled C2 servers.  BADHATCH  can also emulate a reverse proxy on a compromised machine to connect with actor-controlled C2 servers.

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal  has supported use of a proxy server.

Name: Blue Mockingbird
Description: Blue Mockingbird  has used frp, ssf, and Venom to establish SOCKS proxy connections.

Name: C0017
Description: During  C0017 ,  APT41  used the Cloudflare CDN to proxy C2 traffic.

Name: C0027
Description: During  C0027 ,  Scattered Spider  installed the open-source rsocx reverse proxy tool on a targeted ESXi appliance.

Name: Cardinal RAT
Description: Cardinal RAT  can act as a reverse proxy.

Name: CopyKittens
Description: CopyKittens  has used the AirVPN service for operational activity.

Name: Dridex
Description: Dridex  contains a backconnect module for tunneling network traffic through a victim's computer. Infected computers become part of a P2P botnet that can relay C2 traffic to other infected peers.

Name: Earth Lusca
Description: Earth Lusca  adopted Cloudflare as a proxy for compromised servers.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has used the open source reverse proxy tools including FRPC and Go Proxy to establish connections from C2 to local servers.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: FunnyDream  can identify and use configured proxies in a compromised network for C2 communication.

Name: Green Lambert
Description: Green Lambert  can use proxies for C2 traffic.

Name: HARDRAIN
Description: HARDRAIN  uses the command  cmd.exe /c netsh firewall add portopening TCP 443 "adp"  and makes the victim machine function as a proxy server.

Name: HOPLIGHT
Description: HOPLIGHT  has multiple proxy options that mask traffic between the malware and the remote operators.

Name: HTRAN
Description: HTRAN  can proxy TCP socket connections to obfuscate command and control infrastructure.

Name: jRAT
Description: jRAT  can serve as a SOCKS proxy server.

Name: Kessel
Description: Kessel  can use a proxy during exfiltration if set in the configuration.

Name: KEYPLUG
Description: KEYPLUG  has used Cloudflare CDN associated infrastructure to redirect C2 communications to malicious domains.

Name: KOCTOPUS
Description: KOCTOPUS  has deployed a modified version of Invoke-Ngrok to expose open local ports to the Internet.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has leverage NordVPN for its egress points when targeting intended victims.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has used Fast Reverse Proxy (FRP) for RDP traffic.

Name: MoustachedBouncer
Description: MoustachedBouncer  has used a reverse proxy tool similar to the GitHub repository revsocks.

Name: netsh
Description: netsh  can be used to set up a proxy tunnel to allow remote host access to an infected host.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can implement use of proxies to pivot traffic.

Name: ngrok
Description: ngrok  can be used to proxy connections to machines located behind NAT or firewalls.

Name: Operation Sharpshooter
Description: For  Operation Sharpshooter , the threat actors used the ExpressVPN service to hide their location.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used a custom proxy tool called "Agent" which has support for multiple hops.

Name: PLEAD
Description: PLEAD  has the ability to proxy network communications.

Name: POLONIUM
Description: POLONIUM  has used the AirVPN service for operational activity.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  contains modules that allow for use of proxies in command and control.

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: QuasarRAT  can communicate over a reverse proxy using SOCKS5.

Name: RainyDay
Description: RainyDay  can use proxy tools including boost_proxy_client for reverse proxy functionality.

Name: Remcos
Description: Remcos  uses the infected hosts as SOCKS5 proxies to allow for tunneling and proxying.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team 's BCS-server tool can create an internal proxy server to redirect traffic from the adversary-controlled C2 to internal servers which may not be connected to the internet, but are interconnected locally.

Name: SDBbot
Description: SDBbot  has the ability to use port forwarding to establish a proxy between a target host and C2.

Name: Socksbot
Description: Socksbot  can start SOCKS proxy threads.

Name: SombRAT
Description: SombRAT  has the ability to use an embedded SOCKS proxy in C2 communications.

Name: TSCookie
Description: TSCookie  has the ability to proxy communications with command and control (C2) servers.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  RPC backdoors have included local UPnP RPC proxies.

Name: TYPEFRAME
Description: A  TYPEFRAME  variant can force the compromised system to function as a proxy server.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has used a peer-to-peer (P2P) network for C2.

Name: Vasport
Description: Vasport  is capable of tunneling though a proxy.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has used compromised devices and customized versions of open source tools  such as Fast Reverse Proxy (FRP), Earthworm, and  Impacket  to proxy network traffic.

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  has the capability to act as a reverse proxy.

Name: Windigo
Description: Windigo  has delivered a generic Windows proxy Win32/Glubteta.M.  Windigo  has also used multiple reverse proxy chains as part of their C2 infrastructure.

Name: XTunnel
Description: XTunnel  relays traffic between a C2 server and a victim.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  can set up an HTTP or SOCKS proxy.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Traffic to known anonymity networks and C2 infrastructure can be blocked through the use of network allow and block lists. It should be noted that this kind of blocking may be circumvented by other techniques like  Domain Fronting .

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific C2 protocol used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool C2 signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way as to avoid detection by common defensive tools.

Name: SSL/TLS Inspection
Description: If it is possible to inspect HTTPS traffic, the captures can be analyzed for connections that appear to be domain fronting.

Name: Mimikatz
Description: Mimikatz ’s  LSADUMP::DCShadow  module can be used to make AD updates by temporarily setting a computer to be a DC.

Name: Boot Integrity
Description: Use Trusted Platform Module technology and a secure or trusted boot process to prevent system integrity from being compromised. Check the integrity of the existing BIOS or EFI to determine if it is vulnerable to modification.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Ensure proper permissions are in place to help prevent adversary access to privileged accounts necessary to perform these actions

Name: Update Software
Description: Patch the BIOS and EFI as necessary.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors installed the AnyDesk remote desktop application onto the compromised network.

Name: C0018
Description: During  C0018 , the threat actors used AnyDesk to transfer tools between systems.

Name: C0027
Description: During  C0027 ,  Scattered Spider  directed victims to run remote monitoring and management (RMM) tools.

Name: Carbanak
Description: Carbanak  has a plugin for VNC and Ammyy Admin Tool.

Name: Carbanak
Description: Carbanak  used legitimate programs such as AmmyyAdmin and Team Viewer for remote interactive C2 to target systems.

Name: Cobalt Group
Description: Cobalt Group  used the Ammyy Admin tool as well as TeamViewer for remote access, including to preserve remote access if a Cobalt Strike module was lost.

Name: DarkVishnya
Description: DarkVishnya  used DameWare Mini Remote Control for lateral movement.

Name: Dridex
Description: Dridex  contains a module for VNC.

Name: Egregor
Description: Egregor  has checked for the LogMein event log in an attempt to encrypt files in remote machines.

Name: Evilnum
Description: EVILNUM  has used the malware variant, TerraTV, to run a legitimate TeamViewer application to connect to compromrised machines.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  has utilized the remote management tool Atera to download malware to a compromised system.

Name: GOLD SOUTHFIELD
Description: GOLD SOUTHFIELD  has used the cloud-based remote management and monitoring tool "ConnectWise Control" to deploy  REvil .

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has established tmate sessions for C2 communications.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used a modified TeamViewer client as a command and control channel.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has used a legitimate application, ScreenConnect, to manage systems remotely and move laterally.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has installed TeamViewer on targeted systems.

Name: Night Dragon
Description: During  Night Dragon , threat actors used several remote administration tools as persistent infiltration channels.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  has the capability to download a VNC module from command and control (C2).

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  has used a modified version of TeamViewer and Remote Utilities for remote access.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has used remote administration tools or remote industrial control system client software for execution and to maliciously release electricity breakers.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has established tmate sessions for C2 communications.

Name: Thrip
Description: Thrip  used a cloud-based remote access software called LogMeIn for their attacks.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  uses vncDll module to remote control the victim machine.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use application control to mitigate installation and use of unapproved software that can be used for remote access.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Properly configure firewalls, application firewalls, and proxies to limit outgoing traffic to sites and services used by remote access software.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures may be able to prevent traffic to remote access services.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable the remote service (ex: SSH, RDP, etc.) if it is unnecessary.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Enable firewall rules to block unnecessary traffic between network security zones within a network.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Do not allow remote access to services as a privileged account unless necessary.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit remote user permissions if remote access is necessary.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  deployed a Monero cryptocurrency mining tool in a victim’s environment.

Name: Blue Mockingbird
Description: Blue Mockingbird  has used XMRIG to mine cryptocurrency on victim systems.

Name: Bonadan
Description: Bonadan  can download an additional module which has a cryptocurrency mining extension.

Name: CookieMiner
Description: CookieMiner  has loaded coinmining software onto systems to mine for Koto cryptocurrency.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has used xmrig to mine cryptocurrency.

Name: Imminent Monitor
Description: Imminent Monitor  has the capability to run a cryptocurrency miner on the victim machine.

Name: Kinsing
Description: Kinsing  has created and run a Bitcoin cryptocurrency miner.

Name: LoudMiner
Description: LoudMiner  harvested system resources to mine cryptocurrency, using XMRig to mine Monero.

Name: Lucifer
Description: Lucifer  can use system resources to mine cryptocurrency, dropping XMRig to mine Monero.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  has distributed cryptomining malware.

Name: Skidmap
Description: Skidmap  is a kernel-mode rootkit used for cryptocurrency mining.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has deployed XMRig Docker images to mine cryptocurrency.     TeamTNT  has also infected Docker containers and Kubernetes clusters with XMRig, and used RainbowMiner and lolMiner for mining cryptocurrency.

Name: ADVSTORESHELL
Description: ADVSTORESHELL  can enumerate registry keys.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32 's backdoor can query the Windows Registry to gather system information.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used various strains of malware to query the Registry.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  has opened the registry and performed query searches.

Name: Azorult
Description: Azorult  can check for installed software on the system under the Registry key  Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall .

Name: BabyShark
Description: BabyShark  has executed the  reg query  command for  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Terminal Server Client\Default .

Name: BACKSPACE
Description: BACKSPACE  is capable of enumerating and making modifications to an infected system's Registry.

Name: Bankshot
Description: Bankshot  searches for certain Registry keys to be configured before executing the payload.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can query  Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall  for installed applications.

Name: BendyBear
Description: BendyBear  can query the host's Registry key at  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Console\QuickEdit  to retrieve data.

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal  has used the RegQueryValueExA function to retrieve proxy information in the Registry.

Name: BitPaymer
Description: BitPaymer  can use the RegEnumKeyW to iterate through Registry keys.

Name: Brave Prince
Description: Brave Prince  gathers information about the Registry.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  can check the Registry for specific keys.

Name: Carbanak
Description: Carbanak  checks the Registry key  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings  for proxy configurations information.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp  has searched the Image File Execution Options registry key for "Debugger" within every subkey.

Name: Carbon
Description: Carbon  enumerates values in the Registry.

Name: Cardinal RAT
Description: Cardinal RAT  contains watchdog functionality that periodically ensures  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\Load  is set to point to its executable.

Name: CharmPower
Description: CharmPower  has the ability to enumerate  Uninstall  registry values.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has queried Registry keys using  reg query \ \HKU\ \SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Terminal Server Client\Servers  and  reg query \ \HKU\ \Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings .

Name: CHOPSTICK
Description: CHOPSTICK  provides access to the Windows Registry, which can be used to gather information.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  has the ability to enumerate Registry keys, including  KEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Bitcoin\Bitcoin-Qt\strDataDir  to search for a bitcoin wallet.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can query  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\ \Excel\Security\AccessVBOM\   to determine if the security setting for restricting default programmatic access is enabled.

Name: ComRAT
Description: ComRAT  can check the default browser by querying  HKCR\http\shell\open\command .

Name: Crimson
Description: Crimson  can check the Registry for the presence of  HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\last_edate  to determine how long it has been installed on a host.

Name: DarkWatchman
Description: DarkWatchman  can query the Registry to determine if it has already been installed on the system.

Name: Denis
Description: Denis  queries the Registry for keys and values.

Name: Derusbi
Description: Derusbi  is capable of enumerating Registry keys and values.

Name: DownPaper
Description: DownPaper  searches and reads the value of the Windows Update Registry Run key.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has queried the Registry to identify victim information.

Name: Dtrack
Description: Dtrack  can collect the RegisteredOwner, RegisteredOrganization, and InstallDate registry values.

Name: Epic
Description: Epic  uses the  rem reg query  command to obtain values from Registry keys.

Name: FatDuke
Description: FatDuke  can get user agent strings for the default browser from  HKCU\Software\Classes\http\shell\open\command .

Name: FELIXROOT
Description: FELIXROOT  queries the Registry for specific keys for potential privilege escalation and proxy information.  FELIXROOT  has also used WMI to query the Windows Registry.

Name: FinFisher
Description: FinFisher  queries Registry values as part of its anti-sandbox checks.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has accessed Registry hives ntuser.dat and UserClass.dat.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: FunnyDream  can check  Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings  to extract the  ProxyServer  string.

Name: Gelsemium
Description: Gelsemium  can open random files and Registry keys to obscure malware behavior from sandbox analysis.

Name: gh0st RAT
Description: gh0st RAT  has checked for the existence of a Service key to determine if it has already been installed on the system.

Name: Gold Dragon
Description: Gold Dragon  enumerates registry keys with the command  regkeyenum  and obtains information for the Registry key  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run .

Name: HOPLIGHT
Description: A variant of  HOPLIGHT  hooks lsass.exe, and lsass.exe then checks the Registry for the data value 'rdpproto' under the key  SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa Name .

Name: Hydraq
Description: Hydraq  creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve system information, such as CPU speed, from Registry keys.

Name: Industroyer
Description: Industroyer  has a data wiper component that enumerates keys in the Registry  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services .

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can enumerate Registry values, keys, and data.

Name: JPIN
Description: JPIN  can enumerate Registry keys.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has obtained specific Registry keys and values on a compromised host.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  malware IndiaIndia checks Registry keys within HKCU and HKLM to determine if certain applications are present, including SecureCRT, Terminal Services, RealVNC, TightVNC, UltraVNC, Radmin, mRemote, TeamViewer, FileZilla, pcAnyware, and Remote Desktop. Another  Lazarus Group  malware sample checks for the presence of the following Registry key: HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Bitcoin\Bitcoin-Qt .

Name: LiteDuke
Description: LiteDuke  can query the Registry to check for the presence of  HKCU\Software\KasperskyLab .

Name: LitePower
Description: LitePower  can query the Registry for keys added to execute COM hijacking.

Name: Lucifer
Description: Lucifer  can check for existing stratum cryptomining information in  HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\spreadCpuXmr – %stratum info% .

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can enumerate Registry keys with all subkeys and values.

Name: Milan
Description: Milan  can query  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Cryptography MachineGuid  to retrieve the machine GUID.

Name: Mori
Description: Mori  can read data from the Registry including from  HKLM\Software\NFC\IPA  and HKLM\Software\NFC\ .

Name: njRAT
Description: njRAT  can read specific registry values.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used  reg query "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Terminal Server Client\Default"  on a victim to query the Registry.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , the threat actors executed  /c cd /d c:\windows\temp\ & reg query HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\<username>\PuTTY\Sessions\  to detect recent PuTTY sessions, likely to further lateral movement.

Name: OSInfo
Description: OSInfo  queries the registry to look for information about Terminal Services.

Name: PcShare

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary command and control infrastructure and malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific obfuscation technique used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool command and control signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way to avoid detection by common defensive tools.

Name: DEADEYE
Description: DEADEYE  has used the scheduled tasks  \Microsoft\Windows\PLA\Server Manager Performance Monitor ,  \Microsoft\Windows\Ras\ManagerMobility ,  \Microsoft\Windows\WDI\SrvSetupResults , and  \Microsoft\Windows\WDI\USOShared  to establish persistence.

Name: Audit
Description: Toolkits like the PowerSploit framework contain PowerUp modules that can be used to explore systems for permission weaknesses in scheduled tasks that could be used to escalate privileges.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Configure settings for scheduled tasks to force tasks to run under the context of the authenticated account instead of allowing them to run as SYSTEM. The associated Registry key is located at  HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\SubmitControl . The setting can be configured through GPO: Computer Configuration >  > Windows Settings > Security Settings > Local Policies > Security Options: Domain Controller: Allow server operators to schedule tasks, set to disabled.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Configure the Increase Scheduling Priority option to only allow the Administrators group the rights to schedule a priority process. This can be can be configured through GPO: Computer Configuration >  > Windows Settings > Security Settings > Local Policies > User Rights Assignment: Increase scheduling priority.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit privileges of user accounts and remediate Privilege Escalation vectors so only authorized administrators can create scheduled tasks on remote systems.

Name: Stuxnet

Name: TeamTNT

Name: Umbreon

Name: Uroburos

Name: WarzoneRAT

Name: Zeroaccess

Name: EXOTIC LILY
