Description: LookBack  can enumerate services on the victim machine.

Name: Net
Description: The  net start  command can be used in  Net  to find information about Windows services.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used  sc query  on a victim to gather information about services.

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , the threat actors used the  net start  command as part of their initial reconnaissance.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used the  tasklist  command to search for one of its backdoors.

Name: Poseidon Group
Description: After compromising a victim,  Poseidon Group  discovers all running services.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  can enumerate service and service permission information.

Name: RainyDay
Description: RainyDay  can create and register a service for execution.

Name: RATANKBA
Description: RATANKBA  uses  tasklist /svc  to display running tasks.

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  can enumerate active services.

Name: S-Type
Description: S-Type  runs the command  net start  on a victim.

Name: Sardonic
Description: Sardonic  has the ability to execute the  net start  command.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can search for modifiable services that could be used for privilege escalation.

Name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
Description: SLOTHFULMEDIA  has the capability to enumerate services.

Name: SombRAT
Description: SombRAT  can enumerate services on a victim machine.

Name: SUNBURST
Description: SUNBURST  collected a list of service names that were hashed using a FNV-1a + XOR algorithm to check against similarly-hashed hardcoded blocklists.

Name: Sykipot
Description: Sykipot  may use  net start  to display running services.

Name: SynAck
Description: SynAck  enumerates all running services.

Name: SysUpdate
Description: SysUpdate  can collect a list of services on a victim machine.

Name: Tasklist
Description: Tasklist  can be used to discover services running on a system.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has searched for services such as Alibaba Cloud Security's aliyun service and BMC Helix Cloud Security's bmc-agent service in order to disable them.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  collects a list of install programs and services on the system’s machine.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  surveys a system upon check-in to discover running services and associated processes using the  tasklist /svc  command.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has gathered information about running services.

Name: Volgmer
Description: Volgmer  queries the system to identify existing services.

Name: WINERACK
Description: WINERACK  can enumerate services.

Name: ZLib
Description: ZLib  has the ability to discover and manipulate Windows services.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  can check the services on the system.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  used weaponized Microsoft Word documents abusing the remote template function to retrieve a malicious macro.

Name: Chaes
Description: Chaes  changed the template target of the settings.xml file embedded in the Word document and populated that field with the downloaded URL of the next payload.

Name: Confucius
Description: Confucius  has used a weaponized Microsoft Word document with an embedded RTF exploit.

Name: DarkHydrus
Description: DarkHydrus  used an open-source tool, Phishery, to inject malicious remote template URLs into Microsoft Word documents and then sent them to victims to enable  Forced Authentication .

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has injected SMB URLs into malicious Word spearphishing attachments to initiate  Forced Authentication .

Name: Frankenstein
Description: During  Frankenstein , the threat actors used trojanized documents that retrieved remote templates from an adversary-controlled website.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  has used DOCX files to download malicious DOT document templates and has used RTF template injection to download malicious payloads.    Gamaredon Group  can also inject malicious macros or remote templates into documents already present on compromised systems.

Name: Inception
Description: Inception  has used decoy documents to load malicious remote payloads via HTTP.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  used DOCX files to retrieve a malicious document template/DOTM file.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  delivered malicious documents with the XLSX extension, typically used by OpenXML documents, but the file itself was actually an OLE (XLS) document.

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  has been install via template injection through a malicious DLL embedded within a template RTF in a Word document.

Name: Antivirus/Antimalware
Description: Network/Host intrusion prevention systems, antivirus, and detonation chambers can be employed to prevent documents from fetching and/or executing malicious payloads.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Consider disabling Microsoft Office macros/active content to prevent the execution of malicious payloads in documents   , though this setting may not mitigate the  Forced Authentication  use for this technique.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network/Host intrusion prevention systems, antivirus, and detonation chambers can be employed to prevent documents from fetching and/or executing malicious payloads.

Name: User Training
Description: Train users to identify social engineering techniques and spearphishing emails that could be used to deliver malicious documents.

Name: APT28
Description: Once  APT28  gained access to the DCCC network, the group then proceeded to use that access to compromise the DNC network.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has compromised IT, cloud services, and managed services providers to gain broad access to multiple customers for subsequent operations.

Name: GOLD SOUTHFIELD
Description: GOLD SOUTHFIELD  has breached Managed Service Providers (MSP's) to deliver malware to MSP customers.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has accessed internet-facing identity providers such as Azure Active Directory and Okta to target specific organizations.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has used legitimate access granted to Managed Service Providers in order to access victims of interest.

Name: POLONIUM
Description: POLONIUM  has used compromised credentials from an IT company to target downstream customers including a law firm and aviation company.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has used dedicated network connections from one victim organization to gain unauthorized access to a separate organization.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  gained access through compromised accounts at cloud solution partners, and used compromised certificates issued by Mimecast to authenticate to Mimecast customer systems.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  has compromised third party service providers to gain access to victim's environments.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Require MFA for all delegated administrator accounts.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Network segmentation can be used to isolate infrastructure components that do not require broad network access.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Properly manage accounts and permissions used by parties in trusted relationships to minimize potential abuse by the party and if the party is compromised by an adversary. In Office 365 environments, partner relationships and roles can be viewed under the "Partner Relationships" page.

Name: 4H RAT
Description: 4H RAT  sends an OS version identifier in its beacons.

Name: Action RAT
Description: Action RAT  has the ability to collect the hostname, OS version, and OS architecture of an infected host.

Name: admin@338
Description: admin@338  actors used the following commands after exploiting a machine with  LOWBALL  malware to obtain information about the OS:  ver >> %temp%\download   systeminfo >> %temp%\download

Name: ADVSTORESHELL
Description: ADVSTORESHELL  can run  Systeminfo  to gather information about the victim.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  can collect the system's computer name and also has the capability to collect information on the processor, memory, OS, and video card from the system.

Name: Amadey
Description: Amadey  has collected the computer name and OS version from a compromised machine.

Name: Anchor
Description: Anchor  can determine the hostname and linux version on a compromised host.

Name: AppleJeus
Description: AppleJeus  has collected the victim host information after infection.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  can identify the OS version of a targeted system.

Name: APT18
Description: APT18  can collect system information from the victim’s machine.

Name: APT19
Description: APT19  collected system architecture information.  APT19  used an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant to gather the hostname and CPU information from the victim’s machine.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  has a tool that can obtain information about the local system.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has collected the OS version and computer name from victims. One of the group's backdoors can also query the Windows Registry to gather system information, and another macOS backdoor performs a fingerprint of the machine on its first connection to the C&C server.  APT32  executed shellcode to identify the name of the infected host.

Name: APT37
Description: APT37  collects the computer name, the BIOS model, and execution path.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has attempted to get detailed information about a compromised host, including the operating system, version, patches, hotfixes, and service packs.

Name: Aquatic Panda
Description: Aquatic Panda  has used native OS commands to understand privilege levels and system details.

Name: Aria-body
Description: Aria-body  has the ability to identify the hostname, computer name, Windows version, processor speed, machine GUID, and disk information on a compromised host.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  collects the machine name and keyboard language from the system.

Name: AsyncRAT
Description: AsyncRAT  can check the disk size through the values obtained with  DeviceInfo.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  monitors the free disk space on the system.

Name: AuTo Stealer
Description: AuTo Stealer  has the ability to collect the hostname and OS information from an infected host.

Name: Avenger
Description: Avenger  has the ability to identify the host volume ID and the OS architecture on a compromised host.

Name: Azorult
Description: Azorult  can collect the machine information, system architecture, the OS version, computer name, Windows product name, the number of CPU cores, video card information, and the system language.

Name: Babuk
Description: Babuk  can enumerate disk volumes, get disk information, and query service status.

Name: BabyShark
Description: BabyShark  has executed the  ver  command.

Name: BackConfig
Description: BackConfig  has the ability to gather the victim's computer name.

Name: Backdoor.Oldrea
Description: Backdoor.Oldrea  collects information about the OS and computer name.

Name: BACKSPACE
Description: During its initial execution,  BACKSPACE  extracts operating system information from the infected host.

Name: BADCALL
Description: BADCALL  collects the computer name and host name on the compromised system.

Name: BADFLICK
Description: BADFLICK  has captured victim computer name, memory space, and CPU details.

Name: BADHATCH
Description: BADHATCH  can obtain current system information from a compromised machine such as the  SHELL PID ,  PSVERSION ,  HOSTNAME ,  LOGONSERVER ,  LASTBOOTUP ,  UPTIME , drive information, OS type/version, bitness, and hostname.

Name: BadPatch
Description: BadPatch  collects the OS system, OS version, MAC address, and the computer name from the victim’s machine.

Name: Bandook
Description: Bandook  can collect information about the drives available on the system.

Name: Bankshot
Description: Bankshot  gathers system information, network addresses, disk type, disk free space, and the operation system version.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can fingerprint architecture, computer name, and OS version on the compromised host.  Bazar  can also check if the Russian language is installed on the infected machine and terminate if it is found.

Name: BISCUIT
Description: BISCUIT  has a command to collect the processor type, operation system, computer name, uptime, and whether the system is a laptop or PC.

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal  has used commands and API calls to gather system information.

Name: Black Basta
Description: Black Basta  can enumerate volumes and collect system boot configuration and CPU information.

Name: BlackCat
Description: BlackCat  can obtain the computer name and UUID, and enumerate local drives.

Name: BlackEnergy
Description: BlackEnergy  has used  Systeminfo  to gather the OS version, as well as information on the system configuration, BIOS, the motherboard, and the processor.

Name: BlackMould
Description: BlackMould  can enumerate local drives on a compromised host.

Name: BLINDINGCAN
Description: BLINDINGCAN  has collected from a victim machine the system name, processor information, OS version, and disk information, including type and free space available.

Name: Blue Mockingbird
Description: Blue Mockingbird  has collected hardware details for the victim's system, including CPU and memory information.

Name: BLUELIGHT
Description: BLUELIGHT  has collected the computer name and OS version from victim machines.

Name: Bonadan
Description: Bonadan  has discovered the OS version, CPU model, and RAM size of the system it has been installed on.

Name: BoomBox
Description: BoomBox  can enumerate the hostname, domain, and IP of a compromised host.

Name: Brave Prince
Description: Brave Prince  collects hard drive content and system configuration information.

Name: BUBBLEWRAP
Description: BUBBLEWRAP  collects system information, including the operating system version and hostname.

Name: build_downer
Description: build_downer  has the ability to send system volume information to C2.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  can enumerate the OS version and domain on a targeted system.

Name: Bundlore
Description: Bundlore  will enumerate the macOS version to determine which follow-on behaviors to execute using  /usr/bin/sw_vers -productVersion .

Name: C0017
Description: During  C0017 ,  APT41  issued  ping -n 1 ((cmd /c dir c:\|findstr Number).split()+  commands to find the volume serial number of compromised systems.

Name: CaddyWiper
Description: CaddyWiper  can use  DsRoleGetPrimaryDomainInformation  to determine the role of the infected machine.  CaddyWiper  can also halt execution if the compromised host is identified as a domain controller.

Name: Cadelspy
Description: Cadelspy  has the ability to discover information about the compromised host.

Name: Cannon
Description: Cannon  can gather system information from the victim’s machine such as the OS version, machine name, and drive information.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp  has collected the operating system version from the infected system.

Name: Cardinal RAT
Description: Cardinal RAT  can collect the hostname, Microsoft Windows version, and processor architecture from a victim machine.

Name: CARROTBAT
Description: CARROTBAT  has the ability to determine the operating system of the compromised host and whether Windows is being run with x86 or x64 architecture.

Name: Caterpillar WebShell
Description: Caterpillar WebShell  has a module to gather information from the compromrised asset, including the computer version, computer name, IIS version, and more.

Name: Chaes
Description: Chaes  has collected system information, including the machine name and OS version.

Name: CharmPower
Description: CharmPower  can enumerate the OS version and computer name on a targeted system.

Name: ChChes
Description: ChChes  collects the victim hostname, window resolution, and Microsoft Windows version.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has used  fsutil fsinfo drives ,  systeminfo , and  vssadmin list shadows  for system information including shadow volumes and drive information.

Name: Chrommme
Description: Chrommme  has the ability to list drives and obtain the computer name of a compromised host.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  can discover the hostname, computer name, and Windows version of a targeted machine.

Name: cmd
Description: cmd  can be used to find information about the operating system.

Name: Comnie
Description: Comnie  collects the hostname of the victim machine.

Name: Confucius
Description: Confucius  has used a file stealer that can examine system drives, including those other than the C drive.

Name: CORESHELL
Description: CORESHELL  collects hostname, volume serial number and OS version data from the victim and sends the information to its C2 server.

Name: CozyCar
Description: A system info module in  CozyCar  gathers information on the victim host’s configuration.

Name: CrackMapExec
Description: CrackMapExec  can enumerate the system drives and associated system name.

Name: Crimson
Description: Crimson  contains a command to collect the victim PC name, disk drive information, and operating system.

Name: Cuba
Description: Cuba  can enumerate local drives, disk type, and disk free space.

Name: Cyclops Blink
Description: Cyclops Blink  has the ability to query device information.

Name: DarkComet
Description: DarkComet  can collect the computer name, RAM used, and operating system version from the victim’s machine.

Name: Darkhotel
Description: Darkhotel  has collected the hostname, OS version, service pack version, and the processor architecture from the victim’s machine.

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla  can obtain system information by querying the  Win32_ComputerSystem ,  Win32_BIOS ,  Win32_MotherboardDevice ,  Win32_PnPEntity , and  Win32_DiskDrive  WMI objects.

Name: DarkWatchman
Description: DarkWatchman  can collect the OS version, system architecture, uptime, and computer name.

Name: DEADEYE
Description: DEADEYE  can enumerate a victim computer's volume serial number and host name.

Name: DEATHRANSOM
Description: DEATHRANSOM  can enumerate logical drives on a target system.

Name: Denis
Description: Denis  collects OS information and the computer name from the victim’s machine.

Name: Derusbi
Description: Derusbi  gathers the name of the local host, version of GNU Compiler Collection (GCC), and the system information about the CPU, machine, and operating system.

Name: Diavol
Description: Diavol  can collect the computer name and OS version from the system.

Name: down_new
Description: down_new  has the ability to identify the system volume information of a compromised host.

Name: DownPaper
Description: DownPaper  collects the victim host name and serial number, and then sends the information to the C2 server.

Name: Dridex
Description: Dridex  has collected the computer name and OS architecture information from the system.

Name: DropBook
Description: DropBook  has checked for the presence of Arabic language in the infected machine's settings.

Name: dsquery
Description: dsquery  has the ability to enumerate various information, such as the operating system and host name, for systems within a domain.

Name: Dtrack
Description: Dtrack  can collect the victim's computer name, hostname and adapter information to create a unique identifier.

Name: DustySky
Description: DustySky  extracts basic information about the operating system.

Name: Dyre
Description: Dyre  has the ability to identify the computer name, OS version, and hardware configuration on a compromised host.

Name: Egregor
Description: Egregor  can perform a language check of the infected system and can query the CPU information (cupid).

Name: Elise
Description: Elise  executes  systeminfo  after initial communication is made to the remote server.

Name: Emissary
Description: Emissary  has the capability to execute ver and systeminfo commands.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can enumerate host system information like OS, architecture, domain name, applied patches, and more.

Name: EnvyScout
Description: EnvyScout  can determine whether the ISO payload was received by a Windows or iOS device.

Name: Epic
Description: Epic  collects the OS version, hardware information, computer name, available system memory status, disk space information, and system and user language settings.

Name: EVILNUM
Description: EVILNUM  can obtain the computer name from the victim's system.

Name: Explosive
Description: Explosive  has collected the computer name from the infected host.

Name: FALLCHILL
Description: FALLCHILL  can collect operating system (OS) version information, processor information, system name, and information about installed disks from the victim.

Name: FatDuke
Description: FatDuke  can collect the user name, Windows version, computer name, and available space on discs from a compromised host.

Name: Felismus
Description: Felismus  collects the system information, including hostname and OS version, and sends it to the C2 server.

Name: FELIXROOT
Description: FELIXROOT  collects the victim’s computer name, processor architecture, OS version, volume serial number, and system type.

Name: Ferocious
Description: Ferocious  can use  GET.WORKSPACE  in Microsoft Excel to determine the OS version of the compromised host.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has collected local host information by utilizing Windows commands  systeminfo ,  fsutil , and  fsinfo .  FIN13  has also utilized a compromised Symantex Altiris console and LanDesk account to retrieve host information.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has used PowerShell Scripts to check the architecture of a compromised machine before the selection of a 32-bit or 64-bit version of a malicious .NET loader.

Name: Final1stspy
Description: Final1stspy  obtains victim Microsoft Windows version information and CPU architecture.

Name: FinFisher
Description: FinFisher  checks if the victim OS is 32 or 64-bit.

Name: FlawedAmmyy
Description: FlawedAmmyy  can collect the victim's operating system and computer name during the initial infection.

Name: Frankenstein
Description: During  Frankenstein , the threat actors used  Empire  to obtain the compromised machine's name.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: FunnyDream  can enumerate all logical drives on a targeted machine.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: During  FunnyDream , the threat actors used  Systeminfo  to collect information on targeted hosts.

Name: Fysbis
Description: Fysbis  has used the command  ls /etc | egrep -e"fedora*|debian*|gentoo*|mandriva*|mandrake*|meego*|redhat*|lsb-*|sun-*|SUSE*|release"  to determine which Linux OS version is running.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: A  Gamaredon Group  file stealer can gather the victim's computer name and drive serial numbers to send to a C2 server.

Name: Gelsemium
Description: Gelsemium  can determine the operating system and whether a targeted machine has a 32 or 64 bit architecture.

Name: Get2
Description: Get2  has the ability to identify the computer name and Windows version of an infected host.

Name: gh0st RAT
Description: gh0st RAT  has gathered system architecture, processor, OS configuration, and installed hardware information.

Name: Gold Dragon
Description: Gold Dragon  collects endpoint information using the  systeminfo  command.

Name: GoldenSpy
Description: GoldenSpy  has gathered operating system information.

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  can collect the computer name and OS version from a compromised host.

Name: GravityRAT
Description: GravityRAT  collects the MAC address, computer name, and CPU information.

Name: Green Lambert
Description: Green Lambert  can use  uname  to identify the operating system name, version, and processor type.

Name: GRIFFON
Description: GRIFFON  has used a reconnaissance module that can be used to retrieve information about a victim's computer, including the resolution of the workstation .

Name: GrimAgent
Description: GrimAgent  can collect the OS, and build version on a compromised host.

Name: HALFBAKED
Description: HALFBAKED  can obtain information about the OS, processor, and BIOS.

Name: HAPPYWORK
Description: can collect system information, including computer name, system manufacturer, IsDebuggerPresent state, and execution path.

Name: HAWKBALL
Description: HAWKBALL  can collect the OS version, architecture information, and computer name.

Name: HELLOKITTY
Description: HELLOKITTY  can enumerate logical drives on a target system.

Name: HermeticWiper
Description: HermeticWiper  can determine the OS version, bitness, and enumerate physical drives on a targeted host.

Name: HEXANE
Description: HEXANE  has collected the hostname of a compromised machine.

Name: Heyoka Backdoor
Description: Heyoka Backdoor  can enumerate drives on a compromised host.

Name: Higaisa
Description: Higaisa  collected the system volume serial number, GUID, and computer name.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has collected the host's OS, CPU, and memory information.

Name: HOPLIGHT
Description: HOPLIGHT  has been observed collecting victim machine information like OS version, volume information, and more.

Name: HotCroissant
Description: HotCroissant  has the ability to determine if the current user is an administrator, Windows product name, processor name, screen resolution, and physical RAM of the infected host.

Name: Hydraq
Description: Hydraq  creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve information such as computer name, OS version, processor speed, memory size, and CPU speed.

Name: IceApple
Description: The  IceApple  Server Variable Dumper module iterates over all server variables present for the current request and returns them to the adversary.

Name: IcedID
Description: IcedID  has the ability to identify the computer name and OS version on a compromised host.

Name: Inception
Description: Inception  has used a reconnaissance module to gather information about the operating system and hardware on the infected host.

Name: Industroyer
Description: Industroyer  collects the victim machine’s Windows GUID.

Name: InnaputRAT
Description: InnaputRAT  gathers volume drive information and system information.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can gather information on the mapped drives, OS version, computer name, DEP policy, memory size, and system volume serial number.

Name: Ixeshe
Description: Ixeshe  collects the computer name of the victim's system during the initial infection.

Name: JHUHUGIT
Description: JHUHUGIT  obtains a build identifier as well as victim hard drive information from Windows registry key  HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Disk\Enum . Another  JHUHUGIT  variant gathers the victim storage volume serial number and the storage device name.

Name: JPIN
Description: JPIN  can obtain system information such as OS version and disk space.

Name: jRAT
Description: jRAT  collects information about the OS (version, build type, install date) as well as system up-time upon receiving a connection from a backdoor.

Name: KARAE
Description: KARAE  can collect system information.

Name: Kasidet
Description: Kasidet  has the ability to obtain a victim's system name and operating system version.

Name: Kazuar
Description: Kazuar  gathers information on the system and local drives.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  performs operating system information discovery using  systeminfo  and has used implants to identify the system language and computer name.

Name: Kerrdown
Description: Kerrdown  has the ability to determine if the compromised host is running a 32 or 64 bit OS architecture.

Name: Kessel
Description: Kessel  has collected the system architecture, OS version, and MAC address information.

Name: Kevin
Description: Kevin  can enumerate the OS version and hostname of a targeted machine.

Name: KeyBoy
Description: KeyBoy  can gather extended system information, such as information about the operating system, disks, and memory.

Name: KEYMARBLE
Description: KEYMARBLE  has the capability to collect the computer name, language settings, the OS version, CPU information, disk devices, and time elapsed since system start.

Name: KGH_SPY
Description: KGH_SPY  can collect drive information from a compromised host.

Name: KillDisk
Description: KillDisk  retrieves the hard disk name by calling the  CreateFileA to \.\PHYSICALDRIVE0  API.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has enumerated drives, OS type, OS version, and other information using a script or the "systeminfo" command.

Name: Koadic
Description: Koadic  can obtain the OS version and build, computer name, and processor architecture from a compromised host.

Name: Kobalos
Description: Kobalos  can record the hostname and kernel version of the target machine.

Name: KOCTOPUS
Description: KOCTOPUS  has checked the OS version using  wmic.exe  and the  find  command.

Name: KOMPROGO
Description: KOMPROGO  is capable of retrieving information about the infected system.

Name: KONNI
Description: KONNI  can gather the OS version, architecture information, connected drives, hostname, RAM size, and disk space information from the victim’s machine and has used  cmd /c systeminfo  command to get a snapshot of the current system state of the target machine.

Name: KOPILUWAK
Description: KOPILUWAK  can discover logical drive information on compromised hosts.

Name: Kwampirs
Description: Kwampirs  collects OS version information such as registered owner details, manufacturer details, processor type, available storage, installed patches, hostname, version info, system date, and other system information by using the commands  systeminfo ,  net config workstation ,  hostname ,  ver ,  set , and  date /t .

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Several  Lazarus Group  malware families collect information on the type and version of the victim OS, as well as the victim computer name and CPU information. A Destover-like variant used by  Lazarus Group  also collects disk space information and sends it to its C2 server.

Name: LightNeuron
Description: LightNeuron  gathers the victim computer name using the Win32 API call  GetComputerName .

Name: Linfo
Description: Linfo  creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve system information.

Name: LiteDuke
Description: LiteDuke  can enumerate the CPUID and BIOS version on a compromised system.

Name: LitePower
Description: LitePower  has the ability to list local drives and enumerate the OS architecture.

Name: Lizar
Description: Lizar  can collect the computer name from the machine,.

Name: Lokibot
Description: Lokibot  has the ability to discover the computer name and Windows product name/version.

Name: LoudMiner
Description: LoudMiner  has monitored CPU usage.

Name: Lucifer
Description: Lucifer  can collect the computer name, system architecture, default language, and processor frequency of a compromised host.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  collects the hostname of the target computer.

Name: MacMa
Description: MacMa  can collect information about a compromised computer, including: Hardware UUID, Mac serial number, macOS version, and disk sizes.

Name: macOS.OSAMiner
Description: macOS.OSAMiner  can gather the device serial number and has checked to ensure there is enough disk space using the Unix utility  df .

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can collect the computer name and enumerate all drives on a compromised host.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  malware has used a PowerShell command to check the victim system architecture to determine if it is an x64 machine. Other malware has obtained the OS version, UUID, and computer/host name to send to the C2 server.

Name: MarkiRAT
Description: MarkiRAT  can obtain the computer name from a compromised host.

Name: Maze
Description: Maze  has checked the language of the infected system using the "GetUSerDefaultUILanguage" function.

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  can collect the computer name from a compromised host.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has collected the hostname and operating system version from the compromised host.

Name: Meteor
Description: Meteor  has the ability to discover the hostname of a compromised host.

Name: Micropsia
Description: Micropsia  gathers the hostname and OS version from the victim’s machine.

Name: Milan
Description: Milan  can enumerate the targeted machine's name and GUID.

Name: MiniDuke
Description: MiniDuke  can gather the hostname on a compromised machine.

Name: MirageFox
Description: MirageFox  can collect CPU and architecture information from the victim’s machine.

Name: Mis-Type
Description: The initial beacon packet for  Mis-Type  contains the operating system version and file system of the victim.

Name: Misdat
Description: The initial beacon packet for  Misdat  contains the operating system version of the victim.

Name: MobileOrder
Description: MobileOrder  has a command to upload to its C2 server victim mobile device information, including IMEI, IMSI, SIM card serial number, phone number, Android version, and other information.

Name: MoleNet
Description: MoleNet  can collect information about the about the system.

Name: Mongall
Description: Mongall  can identify drives on compromised hosts and retrieve the hostname via  gethostbyname .

Name: MoonWind
Description: MoonWind  can obtain the victim hostname, Windows version, RAM amount, number of drives, and screen resolution.

Name: More_eggs
Description: More_eggs  has the capability to gather the OS version and computer name.

Name: Moses Staff
Description: Moses Staff  collected information about the infected host, including the machine names and OS architecture.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has used malware that can collect the victim’s OS version and machine name.

Name: MURKYTOP
Description: MURKYTOP  has the capability to retrieve information about the OS.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has gathered system information using  systeminfo .

Name: Naid
Description: Naid  collects a unique identifier (UID) from a compromised host.

Name: NanHaiShu
Description: NanHaiShu  can gather the victim computer name and serial number.

Name: NavRAT
Description: NavRAT  uses  systeminfo  on a victim’s machine.

Name: NDiskMonitor
Description: NDiskMonitor  obtains the victim computer name and encrypts the information to send over its C2 channel.

Name: Nebulae
Description: Nebulae  can discover logical drive information including the drive type, free space, and volume information.

Name: Neoichor
Description: Neoichor  can collect the OS version and computer name from a compromised host.

Name: Netwalker
Description: Netwalker  can determine the system architecture it is running on to choose which version of the DLL to use.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can discover and collect victim system information.

Name: njRAT
Description: njRAT  enumerates the victim operating system and computer name during the initial infection.

Name: NOKKI
Description: NOKKI  can gather information on drives and the operating system on the victim’s machine.

Name: ObliqueRAT
Description: ObliqueRAT  has the ability to check for blocklisted computer names on infected endpoints.

Name: OceanSalt
Description: OceanSalt  can collect the computer name from the system.

Name: Octopus
Description: Octopus  can collect system drive information, the computer name, the size of the disk, OS version, and OS architecture information.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has run  hostname  and  systeminfo  on a victim.

Name: Okrum
Description: Okrum  can collect computer name, locale information, and information about the OS and architecture.

Name: OopsIE
Description: OopsIE  checks for information on the CPU fan, temperature, mouse, hard disk, and motherboard as part of its anti-VM checks.

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , the threat actors used the  systeminfo  command to gather details about a compromised system.

Name: Operation Honeybee
Description: During  Operation Honeybee , the threat actors collected the computer name, OS, and other system information using  cmd /c systeminfo > %temp%\ temp.ini .

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors discovered the local disks attached to the system and their hardware information including manufacturer and model, as well as the OS versions of systems connected to a targeted network.

Name: Orz
Description: Orz  can gather the victim OS version and whether it is 64 or 32 bit.

Name: OSInfo
Description: OSInfo  discovers information about the infected machine.

Name: OSX/Shlayer
Description: OSX/Shlayer  has collected the IOPlatformUUID, session UID, and the OS version using the command  sw_vers -productVersion .

Name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D  collects processor information, memory information, computer name, hardware UUID, serial number, and operating system version.  OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D  has used the  ioreg  command to gather some of this information.

Name: Pasam
Description: Pasam  creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve information such as hostname and free disk space.

Name: Patchwork
Description: Patchwork  collected the victim computer name, OS version, and architecture type and sent the information to its C2 server.  Patchwork  also enumerated all available drives on the victim's machine.

Name: Pay2Key
Description: Pay2Key  has the ability to gather the hostname of the victim machine.

Name: Penquin
Description: Penquin  can report the file system type and disk space of a compromised host to C2.

Name: PinchDuke
Description: PinchDuke  gathers system configuration information.

Name: PingPull
Description: PingPull  can retrieve the hostname of a compromised host.

Name: PipeMon
Description: PipeMon  can collect and send OS version and computer name as a part of its C2 beacon.

Name: Pisloader
Description: Pisloader  has a command to collect victim system information, including the system name and OS version.

Name: PLAINTEE
Description: PLAINTEE  collects general system enumeration data about the infected machine and checks the OS version.

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  has the ability to gather information about the compromised host.

Name: Pony
Description: Pony  has collected the Service Pack, language, and region information to send to the C2.

Name: POORAIM
Description: POORAIM  can identify system information, including battery status.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  contains modules, such as  Get-ComputerInfo , for enumerating common system information.

Name: PowerDuke
Description: PowerDuke  has commands to get information about the victim's name, build, version, serial number, and memory usage.

Name: PowerShower
Description: PowerShower  has collected system information on the infected host.

Name: POWERSTATS
Description: POWERSTATS  can retrieve OS name/architecture and computer/domain name information from compromised hosts.

Name: POWRUNER
Description: POWRUNER  may collect information about the system by running  hostname  and  systeminfo  on a victim.

Name: Prikormka
Description: A module in  Prikormka  collects information from the victim about Windows OS version, computer name, battery info, and physical memory.

Name: Proxysvc
Description: Proxysvc  collects the OS version, country name, MAC address, computer name, physical memory statistics, and volume information for all drives on the system.

Name: PUNCHBUGGY
Description: PUNCHBUGGY  can gather system information such as computer names.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  can grab a system’s information including the OS version, architecture, etc.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can collect system information including the OS version and domain on a compromised host.

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: QuasarRAT  can gather system information from the victim’s machine including the OS type.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can detect system information--including disk names, total space, and remaining space--to create a hardware profile GUID which acts as a system identifier for operators.

Name: RATANKBA
Description: RATANKBA  gathers information about the OS architecture, OS name, and OS version/Service pack.

Name: RCSession
Description: RCSession  can gather system information from a compromised host.

Name: Reaver
Description: Reaver  collects system information from the victim, including CPU speed, computer name, volume serial number, ANSI code page, OEM code page identifier for the OS, Microsoft Windows version, and memory information.

Name: RedLeaves
Description: RedLeaves  can gather extended system information including the hostname, OS version number, platform, memory information, time elapsed since system startup, and CPU information.

Name: Remsec
Description: Remsec  can obtain the OS version information, computer name, processor architecture, machine role, and OS edition.

Name: Revenge RAT
Description: Revenge RAT  collects the CPU information, OS information, and system language.

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  can identify the username, machine name, system language, keyboard layout, OS version, and system drive information on a compromised host.

Name: Rifdoor
Description: Rifdoor  has the ability to identify the Windows version on the compromised host.

Name: Rising Sun
Description: Rising Sun  can detect the computer name, operating system, and drive information, including drive type, total number of bytes on disk, total number of free bytes on disk, and name of a specified volume.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  has used uname -m to collect the name and information about the infected system's kernel.

Name: RogueRobin
Description: RogueRobin  gathers BIOS versions and manufacturers, the number of CPU cores, the total physical memory, and the computer name.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  can gather the hostname and the OS version to ensure it doesn’t run on a Windows XP or Windows Server 2003 systems.

Name: RotaJakiro
Description: RotaJakiro  executes a set of commands to collect device information, including  uname .  Another example is the  cat /etc/*release | uniq  command used to collect the current OS distribution.

Name: Royal
Description: Royal  can use  GetNativeSystemInfo  and  GetLogicalDrives  to enumerate system processors and logical drives.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  can obtain the computer name, OS version, and default language identifier.

Name: RunningRAT
Description: RunningRAT  gathers the OS version, logical drives information, processor information, and volume information.

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  has called  GetLogicalDrives  to emumerate all mounted drives, and  GetDriveTypeW  to determine the drive type.

Name: S-Type
Description: The initial beacon packet for  S-Type  contains the operating system version and file system of the victim.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  can identify the OS version, CPU, and other details from a victim's machine.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  used a backdoor to enumerate information about the infected system's operating system.

Name: Sardonic
Description: Sardonic  has the ability to collect the computer name, CPU manufacturer name, and C:\ drive serial number from a compromised machine.  Sardonic  also has the ability to execute the  ver  and  systeminfo  commands.

Name: SDBbot
Description: SDBbot  has the ability to identify the OS version, OS bit information and computer name.

Name: ServHelper
Description: ServHelper  will attempt to enumerate Windows version and system architecture.

Name: ShadowPad
Description: ShadowPad  has discovered system information including memory status, CPU frequency, OS versions, and volume serial numbers.

Name: Shamoon
Description: Shamoon  obtains the victim's operating system version and keyboard layout and sends the information to the C2 server.

Name: Shark
Description: Shark  can collect the GUID of a targeted machine.

Name: SharpDisco
Description: SharpDisco  can use a plugin to enumerate system drives.

Name: SharpStage
Description: SharpStage  has checked the system settings to see if Arabic is the configured language.

Name: SHARPSTATS
Description: SHARPSTATS  has the ability to identify the IP address, machine name, and OS of the compromised host.

Name: ShimRatReporter
Description: ShimRatReporter  gathered the operating system name and specific Windows version of an infected machine.

Name: SHUTTERSPEED
Description: SHUTTERSPEED  can collect system information.

Name: SideCopy
Description: SideCopy  has identified the OS version of a compromised host.

Name: SideTwist
Description: SideTwist  can collect the computer name of a targeted system.

Name: Sidewinder
Description: Sidewinder  has used tools to collect the computer name, OS version, installed hotfixes, as well as information regarding the memory and processor on a compromised host.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can collect information related to a compromised host, including OS version and a list of drives.

Name: Skidmap
Description: Skidmap  has the ability to check whether the infected system’s OS is Debian or RHEL/CentOS to determine which cryptocurrency miner it should use.

Name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
Description: SLOTHFULMEDIA  has collected system name, OS version, adapter information, memory usage, and disk information from a victim machine.

Name: SLOWDRIFT
Description: SLOWDRIFT  collects and sends system information to its C2.

Name: SMOKEDHAM
Description: SMOKEDHAM  has used the  systeminfo  command on a compromised host.

Name: Snip3
Description: Snip3  has the ability to query  Win32_ComputerSystem  for system information.

Name: SodaMaster
Description: SodaMaster  can enumerate the host name and OS version on a target system.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used  fsutil  to check available free space before executing actions that might create large files on disk.

Name: SombRAT
Description: SombRAT  can execute  getinfo  to enumerate the computer name and OS version of a compromised system.

Name: SoreFang
Description: SoreFang  can collect the hostname, operating system configuration, product ID, and disk space on victim machines by executing  Systeminfo .

Name: SOUNDBITE
Description: SOUNDBITE  is capable of gathering system information.

Name: Sowbug
Description: Sowbug  obtained OS version and hardware configuration from a victim.

Name: Spark
Description: Spark  can collect the hostname, keyboard layout, and language from the system.

Name: SpeakUp
Description: SpeakUp  uses the  cat /proc/cpuinfo | grep -c "cpu family" 2>&1  command to gather system information.

Name: SpicyOmelette
Description: SpicyOmelette  can identify the system name of a compromised host.

Name: Squirrelwaffle
Description: Squirrelwaffle  has gathered victim computer information and configurations.

Name: SslMM
Description: SslMM  sends information to its hard-coded C2, including OS version, service pack information, processor speed, system name, and OS install date.

Name: STARWHALE
Description: STARWHALE  can gather the computer name of an infected host.

Name: Stealth Falcon
Description: Stealth Falcon  malware gathers system information via WMI, including the system directory, build number, serial number, version, manufacturer, model, and total physical memory.

Name: StoneDrill
Description: StoneDrill  has the capability to discover the system OS, Windows version, architecture and environment.

Name: StreamEx
Description: StreamEx  has the ability to enumerate system information.

Name: StrifeWater
Description: StrifeWater  can collect the OS version, architecture, and machine name to create a unique token for the infected host.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  can identify the hard disk volume serial number on a compromised host.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  collects system information including computer and domain names, OS version, and S7P paths.

Name: SUNBURST
Description: SUNBURST  collected hostname, OS version, and device uptime.

Name: SVCReady
Description: SVCReady  has the ability to collect information such as computer name, computer manufacturer, BIOS, operating system, and firmware, including through the use of  systeminfo.exe .

Name: SynAck
Description: SynAck  gathers computer names, OS version info, and also checks installed keyboard layouts to estimate if it has been launched from a certain list of countries.

Name: Sys10
Description: Sys10  collects the computer name, OS versioning information, and OS install date and sends the information to the C2.

Name: SYSCON
Description: SYSCON  has the ability to use  Systeminfo  to identify system information.

Name: Systeminfo
Description: Systeminfo  can be used to gather information about the operating system.

Name: SysUpdate
Description: SysUpdate  can collect a system's architecture, operating system version, hostname, and drive information.

Name: T9000
Description: T9000  gathers and beacons the operating system build number and CPU Architecture (32-bit/64-bit) during installation.

Name: TA2541
Description: TA2541  has collected system information prior to downloading malware on the targeted host.

Name: TAINTEDSCRIBE
Description: TAINTEDSCRIBE  can use  DriveList  to retrieve drive information.

Name: TajMahal
Description: TajMahal  has the ability to identify hardware information, the computer name, and OS information on an infected host.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has searched for system version, architecture, disk partition, logical volume, and hostname information.

Name: ThreatNeedle
Description: ThreatNeedle  can collect system profile information from a compromised host.

Name: Torisma
Description: Torisma  can use  GetlogicalDrives  to get a bitmask of all drives available on a compromised system. It can also use  GetDriveType  to determine if a new drive is a CD-ROM drive.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  gathers the OS version, machine name, CPU type, amount of RAM available, and UEFI/BIOS firmware information from the victim’s machine.

Name: Trojan.Karagany
Description: Trojan.Karagany  can capture information regarding the victim's OS, security, and hardware configuration.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has detected a target system’s OS version and system volume information.

Name: Turian
Description: Turian  can retrieve system information including OS version, memory usage, local hostname, and system adapter information.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  surveys a system upon check-in to discover operating system configuration details using the  systeminfo  and  set  commands.

Name: TURNEDUP
Description: TURNEDUP  is capable of gathering system information.

Name: TYPEFRAME
Description: TYPEFRAME  can gather the disk volume information.

Name: Unknown Logger
Description: Unknown Logger  can obtain information about the victim computer name, physical memory, country, and date.

Name: UPPERCUT
Description: UPPERCUT  has the capability to gather the system’s hostname and OS version.

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  has the ability to gather basic system information and run the POSIX API  gethostbyname .

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has used  Systeminfo  to gather system information.

Name: Valak
Description: Valak  can determine the Windows version and computer name on a compromised host.

Name: VERMIN
Description: VERMIN  collects the OS name, machine name, and architecture information.

Name: Volgmer
Description: Volgmer  can gather system information, the computer name, OS version, drive and serial information from the victim's machine.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has discovered file system types, drive names, size, and free space on compromised systems.

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  can collect compromised host information, including OS version, PC name, RAM size, and CPU details.

Name: WellMess
Description: WellMess  can identify the computer name of a compromised host.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  has the ability to enumerate fixed logical drives on a targeted system.

Name: Windigo
Description: Windigo  has used a script to detect which Linux distribution and version is currently installed on the system.

Name: WINDSHIELD
Description: WINDSHIELD  can gather the victim computer name.

Name: Windshift
Description: Windshift  has used malware to identify the computer name of a compromised host.

Name: WINERACK
Description: WINERACK  can gather information about the host.

Name: Wingbird
Description: Wingbird  checks the victim OS version after executing to determine where to drop files based on whether the victim is 32-bit or 64-bit.

Name: WinMM
Description: WinMM  collects the system name, OS version including service pack, and system install date and sends the information to the C2 server.

Name: Winnti for Windows
Description: Winnti for Windows  can determine if the OS on a compromised host is newer than Windows XP.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used  Systeminfo  and similar commands to acquire detailed configuration information of a victim's machine.  Wizard Spider  has also utilized the PowerShell cmdlet  Get-ADComputer  to collect DNS hostnames, last logon dates, and operating system information from Active Directory.

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  can retrieve the following information from an infected machine: OS, architecture, computer name, OS build version, environment variables, and storage drives.

Name: XAgentOSX
Description: XAgentOSX  contains the getInstalledAPP function to run  ls -la /Applications  to gather what applications are installed.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  identifies the macOS version and uses  ioreg  to determine serial number.

Name: YAHOYAH
Description: YAHOYAH  checks for the system’s Windows OS version and hostname.

Name: yty
Description: yty  gathers the computer name, the serial number of the main disk volume, CPU information, Microsoft Windows version, and runs the command  systeminfo .

Name: Zebrocy
Description: Zebrocy  collects the OS version, computer name and serial number for the storage volume C:.  Zebrocy  also runs the  systeminfo  command to gather system information.

Name: ZeroT
Description: ZeroT  gathers the victim's computer name, Windows version, and system language, and then sends it to its C2 server.

Name: Zeus Panda
Description: Zeus Panda  collects the OS version, system architecture, computer name, product ID, install date, and information on the keyboard mapping to determine the language used on the system.

Name: ZIRCONIUM
Description: ZIRCONIUM  has used a tool to capture the processor architecture of a compromised host in order to register it with C2.

Name: ZLib
Description: ZLib  has the ability to enumerate system information.

Name: Zox
Description: Zox  can enumerate attached drives.

Name: zwShell
Description: zwShell  can obtain the victim PC name and OS version.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  can collect the local hostname, operating system details, CPU speed, and total physical memory.

Name: ZxxZ
Description: ZxxZ  has collected the host name and operating system product name from a compromised machine.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  has placed malware on file shares and given it the same name as legitimate documents on the share.

Name: Conti
Description: Conti  can spread itself by infecting other remote machines via network shared drives.

Name: Darkhotel
Description: Darkhotel  used a virus that propagates by infecting executables stored on shared drives.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  has injected malicious macros into all Word and Excel documents on mapped network drives.

Name: H1N1
Description: H1N1  has functionality to copy itself to network shares.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can replace legitimate software or documents in the compromised network with their trojanized versions, in an attempt to propagate itself within the network.

Name: Miner-C
Description: Miner-C  copies itself into the public folder of Network Attached Storage (NAS) devices and infects new victims who open the file.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can spread itself by infecting other portable executable files on networks shared drives.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  infects remote servers via network shares and by infecting WinCC database views with malicious code.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has copied itself to and infected files in network drives for propagation.

Name: Antivirus/Antimalware
Description: Anti-virus can be used to automatically quarantine suspicious files.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Identify potentially malicious software that may be used to taint content or may result from it and audit and/or block the unknown programs by using application control    tools, like AppLocker,       or Software Restriction Policies    where appropriate.

Name: Exploit Protection
Description: Use utilities that detect or mitigate common features used in exploitation, such as the Microsoft Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET).

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Protect shared folders by minimizing users who have write access.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Specific developer utilities may not be necessary within a given environment and should be removed if not used.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Certain developer utilities should be blocked or restricted if not required.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Implement network-based filtering restrictions to prohibit data transfers to untrusted VPCs.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Consider rotating access keys within a certain number of days to reduce the effectiveness of stolen credentials.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit user account and IAM policies to the least privileges required. Consider using temporary credentials for accounts that are only valid for a certain period of time to reduce the effectiveness of compromised accounts.

Name: Chaos
Description: Chaos  provides a reverse shell is triggered upon receipt of a packet with a special string, sent to any port.

Name: Kobalos
Description: Kobalos  is triggered by an incoming TCP connection to a legitimate service from a specific source port.

Name: Pandora
Description: Pandora  can identify if incoming HTTP traffic contains a token and if so it will intercept the traffic and process the received command.

Name: Penquin
Description: Penquin  will connect to C2 only after sniffing a "magic packet" value in TCP or UDP packets matching specific conditions.

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  has used Wake-on-Lan to power on turned off systems for lateral movement.

Name: SYNful Knock
Description: SYNful Knock  can be sent instructions via special packets to change its functionality. Code for new functionality can be included in these messages.

Name: Umbreon
Description: Umbreon  provides additional access using its backdoor Espeon, providing a reverse shell upon receipt of a special packet.

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  can intercept the first client to server packet in the 3-way TCP handshake to determine if the packet contains the correct unique value for a specific  Uroburos  implant. If the value does not match, the packet and the rest of the TCP session are passed to the legitimate listening application.

Name: Winnti for Linux
Description: Winnti for Linux  has used a passive listener, capable of identifying a specific magic value before executing tasking, as a secondary command and control (C2) mechanism.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable Wake-on-LAN if it is not needed within an environment.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Mitigation of some variants of this technique could be achieved through the use of stateful firewalls, depending upon how it is implemented.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: Cloud service providers may allow customers to deactivate unused regions.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  uses an external software known as NetPass to recover passwords.

Name: Pacu
Description: Pacu  can search for sensitive data: for example, in Code Build environment variables, EC2 user data, and Cloud Formation templates.

Name: Active Directory Configuration
Description: Remove vulnerable Group Policy Preferences.

Name: Audit
Description: Preemptively search for files containing passwords or other credentials and take actions to reduce the exposure risk when found.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: When possible, store keys on separate cryptographic hardware instead of on the local system.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Limit access to the Instance Metadata API. A properly configured Web Application Firewall (WAF) may help prevent external adversaries from exploiting Server-side Request Forgery (SSRF) attacks that allow access to the Cloud Instance Metadata API.

Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Description: Limit network access to sensitive services, such as the Instance Metadata API.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: There are multiple methods of preventing a user's command history from being flushed to their .bash_history file, including use of the following commands: set +o history  and  set -o history  to start logging again; unset HISTFILE  being added to a user's .bash_rc file; and ln -s /dev/null ~/.bash_history  to write commands to  /dev/null instead.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Use strong passphrases for private keys to make cracking difficult. Do not store credentials within the Registry. Establish an organizational policy that prohibits password storage in files.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: If it is necessary that software must store credentials in the Registry, then ensure the associated accounts have limited permissions so they cannot be abused if obtained by an adversary.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Restrict file shares to specific directories with access only to necessary users.

Name: Update Software
Description: Apply patch KB2962486 which prevents credentials from being stored in GPPs.

Name: User Training
Description: Ensure that developers and system administrators are aware of the risk associated with having plaintext passwords in software configuration files that may be left on endpoint systems or servers.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  executes embedded JScript or VBScript in an XSL stylesheet located on a remote domain.

Name: Cobalt Group
Description: Cobalt Group  used msxsl.exe to bypass AppLocker and to invoke Jscript code from an XSL file.

Name: Higaisa
Description: Higaisa  used an XSL file to run VBScript code.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  used a remote XSL script to download a Base64-encoded DLL custom downloader.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: If msxsl.exe is unnecessary, then block its execution to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Name: Monokle
Description: Monokle  can reset the user's password/PIN.

Name: User Guidance
Description: Users should be taught that Device Administrator permissions are very dangerous, and very few applications need it.

Name: KeyRaider
Description: Most  KeyRaider  samples hook SSLRead and SSLWrite functions in the itunesstored process to intercept device communication with the Apple App Store.

Name: Monokle
Description: Monokle  can install attacker-specified certificates to the device's trusted certificate store, enabling an adversary to perform adversary-in-the-middle attacks.

Name: S.O.V.A.
Description: S.O.V.A.  has included adversary-in-the-middle capabilities.

Name: Encrypt Network Traffic
Description: Applications that properly encrypt network traffic may evade some forms of AiTM behavior.

Name: Use Recent OS Version
Description: Recent OS versions have made it more difficult for applications to register as VPN providers.

Name: AbstractEmu
Description: AbstractEmu  can monitor notifications.

Name: Bread
Description: Bread  can collect device notifications.

Name: Chameleon
Description: Chameleon  can register as an  SMSBroadcast  receiver to monitor incoming SMS messages.

Name: Corona Updates
Description: Corona Updates  can collect messages from GSM, WhatsApp, Telegram, Facebook, and Threema by reading the application’s notification content.

Name: Escobar

Name: Enterprise Policy
Description: On Android devices with a work profile, the  DevicePolicyManager.setPermittedCrossProfileNotificationListeners  method can be used to manage the list of applications running within the personal profile that can access notifications generated within the work profile. This policy would not affect notifications generated by the rest of the device. The  DevicePolicyManager.setApplicationHidden  method can be used to disable notification access for unwanted applications, but this method would also block that entire application from running.

Name: User Guidance

Name: User Guidance

Name: CarbonSteal

Name: Hornbill

Name: SilkBean

Name: Tiktok Pro

Name: Use Recent OS Version

Name: DressCode

Name: NotCompatible

Name: Enterprise Policy

Name: Deploy Compromised Device Detection Method
Description: Mobile security software can typically detect if a device has been rooted or jailbroken and can inform the user, who can then take appropriate action.

Name: Enterprise Policy
Description: An EMM/MDM can use the Android  DevicePolicyManager.setPermittedAccessibilityServices  method to set an explicit list of applications that are allowed to use Android's accessibility features.

Name: Security Updates
Description: Security updates often contain patches for vulnerabilities that could be exploited for root access. Root access is often a requirement to impairing defenses.

Name: System Partition Integrity

Name: User Guidance
Description: Providing user guidance around commonly abused features, such as the modal that requests for administrator permissions, should aid in preventing impairing defenses.

Name: Monokle

Name: Attestation

Name: Gooligan

Name: Judy

Name: RedDrop

Name: SimBad

Name: Triada

Name: Zen

Name: Attestation

Name: System Partition Integrity

Name: Attestation

Name: Security Updates

Name: Enterprise Policy

An EMM/MDM can use the Android  DevicePolicyManager.setPermittedAccessibilityServices  method to set an explicit list of applications that are allowed to use Android's accessibility features.

Name: User Guidance

Name: AbstractEmu

Name: Chameleon

Name: RedDrop

Name: SharkBot

Name: Sunbird

Name: ViceLeaker

Name: User Guidance

Name: Ginp

Name: Gustuff

Name: Mandrake

Name: Riltok
Description: Riltok  injects input to set itself as the default SMS handler by clicking the appropriate places on the screen. It can also close or minimize targeted antivirus applications and the device security settings screen.

Name: S.O.V.A.

Name: SharkBot

Name: TERRACOTTA

Name: TrickMo

Name: Zen

Name: Enterprise Policy
Description: An EMM/MDM can use the Android  DevicePolicyManager.setPermittedAccessibilityServices  method to set an explicit list of applications that are allowed to use Android's accessibility features.

Name: User Guidance
Description: Users should be warned against granting access to accessibility features, and to carefully scrutinize applications that request this dangerous permission.

Name: Escobar

Name: Enterprise Policy
Description: Enterprises can provision policies to mobile devices that require a minimum complexity (length, character requirements, etc.) for the device passcode, and cause the device to wipe all data if an incorrect passcode is entered too many times. Both policies would mitigate brute-force, guessing, or shoulder surfing of the device passcode. Enterprises can also provision policies to disable biometric authentication, however, biometric authentication can help make using a longer, more complex passcode more practical because it does not need to be entered as frequently.

Name: Security Updates

Name: Enterprise Policy

Name: Use Recent OS Version

Description: CarbonSteal  has seen native libraries used in some reported samples

Name: CHEMISTGAMES
Description: CHEMISTGAMES  has utilized native code to decrypt its malicious payload.

Name: HenBox
Description: HenBox  has contained native libraries.

Name: TERRACOTTA
Description: TERRACOTTA  has included native modules.

Name: AbstractEmu

Name: Android/AdDisplay.Ashas
Description: Android/AdDisplay.Ashas  has hidden the C2 server address using base-64 encoding.

Name: AndroidOS/MalLocker.B
Description: AndroidOS/MalLocker.B  has employed both name mangling and meaningless variable names in source.  AndroidOS/MalLocker.B  has stored encrypted payload code in the Assets directory, coupled with a custom decryption routine that assembles a .dex file by passing data through Android Intent objects.

Name: Asacub
Description: Asacub  has stored encrypted strings in the APK file.

Name: BrainTest
Description: BrainTest  stores a secondary Android app package (APK) in its assets directory in encrypted form, and decrypts the payload at runtime.

Name: Bread
Description: Bread  uses various tricks to obfuscate its strings including standard and custom encryption, programmatically building strings at runtime, and splitting unencrypted strings with repeated delimiters to break up keywords.  Bread  has also abused Java and JavaScript features to obfuscate code.  Bread  payloads have hidden code in native libraries and encrypted JAR files in the data section of an ELF file.  Bread  has stored DEX payloads as base64-encoded strings in the Android manifest and internal Java classes.

Name: CarbonSteal
Description: CarbonSteal  has used incorrect file extensions and encryption to hide most of its assets, including secondary APKs, configuration files, and JAR or DEX files.

Name: Cerberus
Description: Cerberus  uses standard payload and string obfuscation techniques.

Name: Charger
Description: Charger  encodes strings into binary arrays to make it difficult to inspect them. It also loads code from encrypted resources dynamically and includes meaningless commands that mask the actual commands passing through.

Name: CHEMISTGAMES
Description: CHEMISTGAMES  has encrypted its DEX payload.

Name: DoubleAgent
Description: DoubleAgent  has used an AES encrypted file in the assets folder with an unsuspecting name (e.g. ‘GoogleMusic.png’) for holding configuration and C2 information.

Name: Drinik
Description: Drinik  has used custom encryption to hide strings, potentially to evade antivirus products.

Name: Dvmap
Description: Dvmap  decrypts executables from archive files stored in the  assets  directory of the installation binary.

Name: EventBot
Description: EventBot  dynamically loads its malicious functionality at runtime from an RC4-encrypted TTF file.  EventBot  also utilizes ProGuard to obfuscate the generated APK file.

Name: FakeSpy
Description: FakeSpy  stores its malicious code in encrypted asset files that are decrypted at runtime. Newer versions of  FakeSpy  encrypt the C2 address.

Name: FlexiSpy
Description: FlexiSpy  encrypts its configuration file using AES.

Name: FluBot
Description: FluBot  can obfuscated class, string, and method names in newer malware versions.

Name: Ginp
Description: Ginp  obfuscates its payload, code, and strings.

Name: GolfSpy
Description: GolfSpy  encodes its configurations using a customized algorithm.

Name: GPlayed
Description: GPlayed  has base64-encoded the exfiltrated data, replacing some of the base64 characters to further obfuscate the data.

Name: Gustuff
Description: Gustuff  obfuscated command information using a custom base85-based encoding.

Name: HenBox
Description: HenBox  has obfuscated components using XOR, ZIP with a single-byte key or ZIP/Zlib compression wrapped with RC4 encryption.

Name: INSOMNIA
Description: INSOMNIA  obfuscates various pieces of information within the application.

Name: Mandrake
Description: Mandrake  obfuscates its hardcoded C2 URLs.

Name: Monokle
Description: Monokle  uses XOR to obfuscate its second stage binary.

Name: OBAD
Description: OBAD  contains encrypted code along with an obfuscated decryption routine to make it difficult to analyze.

Name: Pallas
Description: Pallas  stores domain information and URL paths as hardcoded AES-encrypted, base64-encoded strings.

Name: Red Alert 2.0
Description: Red Alert 2.0  has stored data embedded in the strings.xml resource file.

Name: Rotexy
Description: Starting in 2017, the  Rotexy  DEX file was packed with garbage strings and/or operations.

Name: SharkBot
Description: SharkBot  can use a Domain Generation Algorithm to decode the C2 server location.

Name: SilkBean
Description: SilkBean  has hidden malicious functionality in a second stage file and has encrypted C2 server information.

Name: TERRACOTTA
Description: TERRACOTTA  has stored encoded strings.

Name: TianySpy
Description: TianySpy  has encrypted C2 details, email addresses, and passwords.

Name: TrickMo
Description: TrickMo  contains obfuscated function, class, and variable names, and encrypts its shared preferences using Java’s  PBEWithMD5AndDES  algorithm.

Name: Windshift
Description: Windshift  has encrypted application strings using AES in ECB mode and Blowfish, and stored strings encoded in hex during Operation BULL. Further, in Operation BULL, encryption keys were stored within the application’s launcher icon file.

Name: WireLurker
Description: WireLurker  obfuscates its payload through complex code structure, multiple component versions, file hiding, code obfuscation and customized encryption to thwart anti-reversing.

Name: WolfRAT
Description: WolfRAT ’s code is obfuscated.

Name: XLoader for Android
Description: XLoader for Android  loads an encrypted DEX code payload.

Name: Zen
Description: Zen  base64 encodes one of the strings it searches for.

Name: Antivirus/Antimalware
Description: Some mobile security products offer a loopback VPN used for inspecting traffic. This could proactively block traffic to websites that are known for phishing or appear to be conducting a phishing attack.

Name: User Guidance
Description: Users can be trained to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails.

Name: Agent Smith

Name: Anubis
Description: Anubis  can collect a list of running processes.

Name: GolfSpy
Description: GolfSpy  can obtain a list of running processes.

Name: HenBox
Description: HenBox  can obtain a list of running processes.

Name: Rotexy

Name: SharkBot

Name: WolfRAT

Name: YiSpecter
Description: YiSpecter  has collected information about running processes.

Name: Attestation
Description: Attestation can typically detect rooted devices. For MDM-enrolled devices, action can be taken if a device fails an attestation check.

Name: Use Recent OS Version
Description: Android 7 and later iOS versions introduced changes that prevent applications from performing Process Discovery without elevated privileges.

Name: Exobot

Name: FluBot
Description: FluBot  can use a SOCKS proxy to evade C2 IP detection.

Name: Use Recent OS Version
Description: OS feature updates often enhance security and privacy around permissions.

Name: User Guidance
Description: Users should be taught the danger behind granting unnecessary permissions to an application and should be advised to use extra scrutiny when an application requests them.

Name: GPlayed
Description: GPlayed  has used timers to enable Wi-Fi, ping the C2 server, register the device with the C2, and register wake locks on the system.

Name: TERRACOTTA
Description: TERRACOTTA  has used timer events in React Native to initiate the foreground service.

Name: Tiktok Pro
Description: Tiktok Pro  has contained an alarm that triggers every three minutes and timers for communicating with the C2.

Name: Escobar

Name: Enterprise Policy
Description: When devices are enrolled in an EMM/MDM using device owner (iOS) or fully managed (Android) mode, the EMM/MDM can collect a list of installed applications on the device. An administrator can then act on, for example blocking, specific remote access applications from being installed on managed devices.

Name: User Guidance
Description: Users should be encouraged to be very careful with granting dangerous permissions, such as device administrator or access to device accessibility.

Name: DualToy
Description: DualToy  side loads malicious or risky apps to both Android and iOS devices via a USB connection.

Name: WireLurker
Description: WireLurker  monitors for iOS devices connected via USB to an infected OSX computer and installs downloaded third-party applications or automatically generated malicious applications onto the device.

Name: Enterprise Policy
Description: Enterprise policies should prevent enabling USB debugging on Android devices unless specifically needed (e.g., if the device is used for application development).

Name: Lock Bootloader
Description: Users should ensure bootloaders are locked to prevent arbitrary operating system code from being flashed onto the device.

Name: Security Updates
Description: Security updates often contain patches for vulnerabilities.

Name: Use Recent OS Version
Description: iOS 11.4.1 and higher introduce USB Restricted Mode, which disables data access through the device's charging port under certain conditions (making the port only usable for power), likely preventing this technique from working.

Name: User Guidance
Description: Users should be advised not to use public charging stations or computers to charge their devices. Instead, users should be issued a charger acquired from a trustworthy source. Users should be advised not to click on device prompts to trust attached computers unless absolutely necessary.
