Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Use multi-factor authentication for user and privileged accounts. Consider enforcing multi-factor authentication for the  CreateKeyPair  and  ImportKeyPair  API calls through IAM policies.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Configure access controls and firewalls to limit access to critical systems and domain controllers. Most cloud environments support separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances that enable further segmentation of cloud systems.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Do not allow domain administrator or root accounts to be used for day-to-day operations that may expose them to potential adversaries on unprivileged systems.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Ensure that low-privileged user accounts do not have permission to add access keys to accounts. In AWS environments, prohibit users from calling the  sts:GetFederationToken  API unless explicitly required.

Name: ROADTools

Name: Audit
Description: Routinely check user permissions to ensure only the expected users have the ability to list IAM identities or otherwise discover cloud accounts.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit permissions to discover cloud accounts in accordance with least privilege. Organizations should limit the number of users within the organization with an IAM role that has administrative privileges, strive to reduce all permanent privileged role assignments, and conduct periodic entitlement reviews on IAM users, roles and policies.

Description: FIN6  has used Metasploit’s  PsExec  NTDSGRAB module to obtain a copy of the victim's Active Directory database.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has used the Softerra LDAP browser to browse documentation on service accounts.

Name: IceApple
Description: The  IceApple  Active Directory Querier module  can perform authenticated requests against an Active Directory server.

Name: IcedID
Description: IcedID  can query LDAP to identify additional users on the network to infect.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  performs account discovery using commands such as  net localgroup administrators  and  net group "REDACTED" /domain  on specific permissions groups.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has used the AD Explorer tool to enumerate users on a victim's network.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has used the Microsoft administration tool csvde.exe to export Active Directory data.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has used  cmd.exe net user /domain  to enumerate domain users.

Name: Net
Description: Net  commands used with the  /domain  flag can be used to gather information about and manipulate user accounts on the current domain.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has run  net user ,  net user /domain ,  net group "domain admins" /domain , and  net group "Exchange Trusted Subsystem" /domain  to get account listings on a victim.

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , the threat actors used the  dsquery  and  dsget  commands to get domain environment information and to query users in administrative groups.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  queried compromised victim's active directory servers to obtain the list of employees including administrator accounts.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used the  net  command to retrieve information about domain accounts.

Name: OSInfo
Description: OSInfo  enumerates local and domain users

Name: Poseidon Group
Description: Poseidon Group  searches for administrator accounts on both the local victim machine and the network.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  can enumerate local and domain user account information.

Name: POWRUNER
Description: POWRUNER  may collect user account information by running  net user /domain  or a series of other commands on a victim.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has used a tool to query Active Directory using LDAP, discovering information about usernames listed in AD.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can use  System.Security.AccessControl  namespaces to retrieve domain user information.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used PowerShell to discover domain accounts by exectuing  Get-ADUser  and  Get-ADGroupMember .

Name: SoreFang
Description: SoreFang  can enumerate domain accounts via  net.exe user /domain .

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  enumerates user accounts of the domain.

Name: Sykipot
Description: Sykipot  may use  net group "domain admins" /domain  to display accounts in the "domain admins" permissions group and  net localgroup "administrators"  to list local system administrator group membership.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has used  net user /domain  to enumerate domain accounts.

Name: Valak
Description: Valak  has the ability to enumerate domain admin accounts.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has run  net group /dom  and  net group "Domain Admins" /dom  in compromised environments for account discovery.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has identified domain admins through the use of  net group "Domain admins" /DOMAIN .  Wizard Spider  has also leveraged the PowerShell cmdlet  Get-ADComputer  to collect account names from Active Directory data.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Prevent administrator accounts from being enumerated when an application is elevating through UAC since it can lead to the disclosure of account names. The Registry key is located at  HKLM\ SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\CredUI\EnumerateAdministrators . It can be disabled through GPO: Computer Configuration >  > Administrative Templates > Windows Components > Credential User Interface: Enumerate administrator accounts on elevation.

Name: C0027
Description: During  C0027 ,  Scattered Spider  used IAM manipulation to gain persistence and to assume or elevate privileges.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has added the global admin role to accounts they have created in the targeted organization's cloud instances.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  granted  company administrator  privileges to a newly created service principle.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Use multi-factor authentication for user and privileged accounts.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Ensure that all accounts use the least privileges they require. In Azure AD environments, consider using Privileged Identity Management (PIM) to define roles that require two or more approvals before assignment to users.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Ensure that low-privileged user accounts do not have permissions to add permissions to accounts or update IAM policies.

Name: AADInternals
Description: AADInternals  can register a device to Azure AD.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has enrolled a device in MFA to an Azure AD environment following a successful password guessing attack against a dormant account.

Name: C0027
Description: During  C0027 ,  Scattered Spider  registered devices for MFA to maintain persistence through victims' VPN.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  registered devices in order to enable mailbox syncing via the  Set-CASMailbox  command.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Require multi-factor authentication to register devices in Azure AD.   Configure multi-factor authentication systems to disallow enrolling new devices for inactive accounts.   When first enrolling MFA, use conditional access policies to restrict device enrollment to trusted locations or devices, and consider using temporary access passes as an initial MFA solution to enroll a device.

Name: Bundlore
Description: Bundlore  creates a new key pair with  ssh-keygen  and drops the newly created user key in  authorized_keys  to enable remote login.

Name: Earth Lusca
Description: Earth Lusca  has dropped an SSH-authorized key in the  /root/.ssh  folder in order to access a compromised server with SSH.

Name: Skidmap
Description: Skidmap  has the ability to add the public key of its handlers to the  authorized_keys  file to maintain persistence on an infected host.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has added RSA keys in  authorized_keys .

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  will create an ssh key if necessary with the  ssh-keygen -t rsa -f $HOME/.ssh/id_rsa -P  command.  XCSSET  will upload a private key file to the server to remotely access the host without a password.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable SSH if it is not necessary on a host or restrict SSH access for specific users/groups using  /etc/ssh/sshd_config .

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Restrict access to the  authorized_keys  file.

Name: User Account Management
Description: In cloud environments, ensure that only users who explicitly require the permissions to update instance metadata or configurations can do so.

Name: APT1

Name: APT28

Name: APT32

Name: BITTER

Name: C0021

Name: CostaRicto

Name: Ferocious Kitten

Name: FIN7

Name: FunnyDream

Name: IndigoZebra

Name: Kimsuky

Name: Sandworm Team

Name: Silent Librarian

Name: SolarWinds Compromise

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: Organizations may intentionally register similar domains to their own to deter adversaries from creating typosquatting domains. Other facets of this technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls. Efforts should focus on minimizing the amount and sensitivity of data available to external parties.

Description: TA2541  has hosted malicious files on various platforms including Google Drive, OneDrive, Discord, PasteText, ShareText, and GitHub.

Name: Turla

Name: ZIRCONIUM

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Name: Volatile Cedar
Description: Volatile Cedar  has used DirBuster and GoBuster to brute force web directories and DNS subdomains.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Remove or disable access to any systems, resources, and infrastructure that are not explicitly required to be available externally.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls. Efforts should focus on minimizing the amount and sensitivity of data available to external parties.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can use Inveigh to conduct name service poisoning for credential theft and associated relay attacks.

Name: Impacket
Description: Impacket  modules like ntlmrelayx and smbrelayx can be used in conjunction with  Network Sniffing  and  LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay  to gather NetNTLM credentials for  Brute Force  or relay attacks that can gain code execution.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  executed  Responder  using the command   -i  -rPv  on a compromised host to harvest credentials and move laterally.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  can use Inveigh to conduct name service poisoning for credential theft and associated relay attacks.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  can sniff plaintext network credentials and use NBNS Spoofing to poison name services.

Name: Responder
Description: Responder  is used to poison name services to gather hashes and credentials from systems within a local network.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used the Invoke-Inveigh PowerShell cmdlets, likely for name service poisoning.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable LLMNR and NetBIOS in local computer security settings or by group policy if they are not needed within an environment.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Use host-based security software to block LLMNR/NetBIOS traffic. Enabling SMB Signing can stop NTLMv2 relay attacks.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that can identify traffic patterns indicative of AiTM activity can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Network segmentation can be used to isolate infrastructure components that do not require broad network access. This may mitigate, or at least alleviate, the scope of AiTM activity.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has used DYEPACK to manipulate SWIFT messages en route to a printer.

Name: LightNeuron
Description: LightNeuron  is capable of modifying email content, headers, and attachments during transit.

Name: Melcoz
Description: Melcoz  can monitor the clipboard for cryptocurrency addresses and change the intended address to one controlled by the adversary.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has a function that can watch the contents of the system clipboard for valid bitcoin addresses, which it then overwrites with the attacker's address.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: Encrypt all important data flows to reduce the impact of tailored modifications on data in transit.

Name: Cleaver
Description: Cleaver  has used custom tools to facilitate ARP cache poisoning.

Name: LuminousMoth
Description: LuminousMoth  has used ARP spoofing to redirect a compromised machine to an actor-controlled website.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Consider disabling updating the ARP cache on gratuitous ARP replies.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: Ensure that all wired and/or wireless traffic is encrypted appropriately. Use best practices for authentication protocols, such as Kerberos, and ensure web traffic that may contain credentials is protected by SSL/TLS.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Consider enabling DHCP Snooping and Dynamic ARP Inspection on switches to create mappings between IP addresses requested via DHCP and ARP tables and tie the values to a port on the switch that may block bogus traffic.

Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Description: Create static ARP entries for networked devices. Implementing static ARP entries may be infeasible for large networks.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that can identify traffic patterns indicative of AiTM activity can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: User Training
Description: Train users to be suspicious about certificate errors. Adversaries may use their own certificates in an attempt to intercept HTTPS traffic. Certificate errors may arise when the application’s certificate does not match the one expected by the host.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Consider filtering DNS requests to unknown, untrusted, or known bad domains and resources. Resolving DNS requests with on-premise/proxy servers may also disrupt adversary attempts to conceal data within DNS packets.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Consider filtering DHCP traffic on ports 67 and 68 to/from unknown or untrusted DHCP servers. Additionally, port security may also be enabled on layer switches. Furthermore, consider enabling DHCP snooping on layer 2 switches as it will prevent DHCP spoofing attacks and starvation attacks. Consider tracking available IP addresses through a script or a tool.  Additionally, block DHCPv6 traffic and incoming router advertisements, especially if IPv6 is not commonly used in the network.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that can identify traffic patterns indicative of AiTM activity can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: ZxxZ

Name: ADVSTORESHELL
Description: ADVSTORESHELL  compresses output data generated by command execution with a custom implementation of the Lempel–Ziv–Welch (LZW) algorithm.

Name: Agent.btz
Description: Agent.btz  saves system information into an XML file that is then XOR-encoded.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  encrypts collected data with a custom implementation of Blowfish and RSA ciphers.

Name: BLUELIGHT
Description: BLUELIGHT  has encoded data into a binary blob using XOR.

Name: C0017
Description: During  C0017 ,  APT41  hex-encoded PII data prior to exfiltration.

Name: CopyKittens
Description: CopyKittens  encrypts data with a substitute cipher prior to exfiltration.

Name: Duqu
Description: Modules can be pushed to and executed by  Duqu  that copy data to a staging area, compress it, and XOR encrypt it.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has encoded data gathered from the victim with a simple substitution cipher and single-byte XOR using the 0xAA key, and Base64 with character permutation.

Name: FLASHFLOOD
Description: FLASHFLOOD  employs the same encoding scheme as  SPACESHIP  for data it stages. Data is compressed with zlib, and bytes are rotated four times before being XOR'ed with 0x23.

Name: FoggyWeb
Description: FoggyWeb  can use a dynamic XOR key and a custom XOR methodology to encode data before exfiltration. Also,  FoggyWeb  can encode C2 command output within a legitimate WebP file.

Name: FrameworkPOS
Description: FrameworkPOS  can XOR credit card information before exfiltration.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: FunnyDream  has compressed collected files with zLib and encrypted them using an XOR operation with the string key from the command line or  qwerasdf  if the command line argument doesn’t contain the key. File names are obfuscated using XOR with the same key as the compressed file content.

Name: HAWKBALL
Description: HAWKBALL  has encrypted data with XOR before sending it over the C2 channel.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  uses a variation of the XOR cipher to encrypt files before exfiltration.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used RC4 encryption before exfil.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: A  Lazarus Group  malware sample encrypts data using a simple byte based XOR operation prior to exfiltration.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete 's collected data is encrypted with AES before exfiltration.

Name: MESSAGETAP
Description: MESSAGETAP  has XOR-encrypted and stored contents of SMS messages that matched its target list.

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  has used XOR-based encryption for collected files before exfiltration.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has encrypted documents with RC4 prior to exfiltration.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  has used a custom encryption algorithm to encrypt collected data.

Name: Okrum
Description: Okrum  has used a custom implementation of AES encryption to encrypt collected data.

Name: OopsIE
Description: OopsIE  compresses collected files with a simple character replacement scheme before sending them to its C2 server.

Name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D  has used AES in CBC mode to encrypt collected data when saving that data to disk.

Name: OwaAuth
Description: OwaAuth  DES-encrypts captured credentials using the key 12345678 before writing the credentials to a log file.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can store collected documents in a custom container after encrypting and compressing them using RC4 and WinRAR.

Name: RawPOS
Description: RawPOS  encodes credit card data it collected from the victim with XOR.

Name: Reaver
Description: Reaver  encrypts collected data with an incremental XOR key prior to exfiltration.

Name: RGDoor
Description: RGDoor  encrypts files with XOR before sending them back to the C2 server.

Name: Rising Sun
Description: Rising Sun  can archive data using RC4 encryption and Base64 encoding prior to exfiltration.

Name: SombRAT
Description: SombRAT  has encrypted collected data with AES-256 using a hardcoded key.

Name: SPACESHIP
Description: Data  SPACESHIP  copies to the staging area is compressed with zlib. Bytes are rotated by four positions and XOR'ed with 0x23.

Name: Squirrelwaffle
Description: Squirrelwaffle  has encrypted collected data using a XOR-based algorithm.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  can compress and encrypt archived files into multiple .sft files with a repeated xor encryption scheme.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  encrypts exfiltrated data via C2 with static 31-byte long XOR keys.

Name: SUGARDUMP
Description: SUGARDUMP  has encrypted collected data using AES CBC mode and encoded it using Base64.

Name: T9000
Description: T9000  encrypts collected data using a single byte XOR key.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Consider using Group Policy to configure and block additions/modifications to W32Time DLLs.

Name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Description: Consider using Group Policy to configure and block modifications to W32Time parameters in the Registry.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  can zip and encrypt data collected on a target system.

Name: APT1
Description: APT1  has used RAR to compress files before moving them outside of the victim network.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has used a variety of utilities, including WinRAR, to archive collected data with password protection.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  has used tools to compress data before exfilling it.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has used WinRAR to compress data prior to exfil.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used WinRAR and 7-Zip to compress an archive stolen data.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  created a RAR archive of targeted files for exfiltration.

Name: Aquatic Panda
Description: Aquatic Panda  has used WinRAR to compress memory dumps prior to exfiltration.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  has compressed data into password-protected RAR archives prior to exfiltration.

Name: C0026
Description: During  C0026 , the threat actors used WinRAR to collect documents on targeted systems. The threat actors appeared to only exfiltrate files created after January 1, 2021.

Name: Calisto
Description: Calisto  uses the  zip -r  command to compress the data collected on the local system.

Name: ccf32
Description: ccf32  has used  xcopy \\<target_host>\c$\users\public\path.7z c:\users\public\bin\<target_host>.7z /H /Y  to archive collected files.

Name: certutil
Description: certutil  may be used to Base64 encode collected data.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has used gzip for Linux OS and a modified RAR software to archive data on Windows hosts.

Name: CopyKittens
Description: CopyKittens  uses ZPP, a .NET console program, to compress files with ZIP.

Name: CORALDECK
Description: CORALDECK  has created password-protected RAR, WinImage, and zip archives to be exfiltrated.

Name: Crutch
Description: Crutch  has used the WinRAR utility to compress and encrypt stolen files.

Name: Daserf
Description: Daserf  hides collected data in password-protected .rar archives.

Name: DustySky
Description: DustySky  can compress files via RAR while staging data to be exfiltrated.

Name: Earth Lusca
Description: Earth Lusca  has used WinRAR to compress stolen files into an archive prior to exfiltration.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has compressed the dump output of compromised credentials with a 7zip binary.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has used RAR to compress collected data before exfiltration.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has used 7-Zip to archive data.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: During  FunnyDream , the threat actors used 7zr.exe to add collected files to an archive.

Name: GALLIUM
Description: GALLIUM  used WinRAR to compress and encrypt stolen data prior to exfiltration.

Name: Gallmaker
Description: Gallmaker  has used WinZip, likely to archive data prior to exfiltration.

Name: HAFNIUM
Description: HAFNIUM  has used 7-Zip and WinRAR to compress stolen files for exfiltration.

Name: IceApple
Description: IceApple  can encrypt and compress files using Gzip prior to exfiltration.

Name: iKitten
Description: iKitten  will zip up the /Library/Keychains directory before exfiltrating it.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  uses WinRAR to compress data that is intended to be exfiltrated.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  is known to use 7Zip and RAR with passwords to encrypt data prior to exfiltration.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used QuickZip to archive stolen files before exfiltration.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has used gzip to archive dumped LSASS process memory and RAR to stage and compress local folders.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has compressed files before exfiltration using TAR and RAR.

Name: Micropsia
Description: Micropsia  creates a RAR archive based on collected files on the victim's machine.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has used the native Windows cabinet creation tool, makecab.exe, likely to compress stolen data to be uploaded.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has used RAR to create password-protected archives of collected documents prior to exfiltration.

Name: Octopus
Description: Octopus  has compressed data before exfiltrating it using a tool called Abbrevia.

Name: Okrum
Description: Okrum  was seen using a RAR archiver tool to compress/decompress data.

Name: OopsIE
Description: OopsIE  compresses collected files with GZipStream before sending them to its C2 server.

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , the threat actors used the Makecab utility to compress and a version of WinRAR to create password-protected archives of stolen data prior to exfiltration.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  archived victim's data into a RAR file.

Name: Operation Honeybee
Description: During  Operation Honeybee , the threat actors uses zip to pack collected files before exfiltration.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors archived collected files with WinRAR, prior to exfiltration.

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  has the ability to compress files with zip.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  contains a module for compressing data using ZIP.

Name: PowerShower
Description: PowerShower  has used 7Zip to compress .txt, .pdf, .xls or .doc files prior to exfiltration.

Name: PUNCHBUGGY
Description: PUNCHBUGGY  has Gzipped information and saved it to a random temp file before exfil.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  can compress data with Zip before sending it over C2.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can compress and archive collected files using WinRAR.

Name: Rclone
Description: Rclone  can compress files using  gzip  prior to exfiltration.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used 7-Zip to compress stolen emails into password-protected archives prior to exfltration;  APT29  also compressed text files into zipped archives.

Name: Sowbug
Description: Sowbug  extracted documents and bundled them into a RAR archive.

Name: Turian
Description: Turian  can use WinRAR to create a password-protected archive for files of interest.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has encrypted files stolen from connected USB drives into a RAR file before exfiltration.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has archived the ntds.dit database as a multi-volume password-protected archive with 7-Zip.

Name: WindTail
Description: WindTail  has the ability to use the macOS built-in zip utility to archive files.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has archived data into ZIP files on compromised machines.

Name: Audit
Description: System scans can be performed to identify unauthorized archival utilities.

Name: ADVSTORESHELL
Description: ADVSTORESHELL  achieves persistence by adding itself to the  HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  Registry key.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  can add itself to the Registry as a startup program to establish persistence.

Name: Amadey
Description: Amadey  has changed the Startup folder to the one containing its executable by overwriting the registry keys.

Name: ANDROMEDA

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  has the ability to create the Registry key name  EstsoftAutoUpdate  at  HKCU\Software\Microsoft/Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce  to establish persistence.

Name: APT18
Description: APT18  establishes persistence via the  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  key.

Name: APT19
Description: An  APT19  HTTP malware variant establishes persistence by setting the Registry key  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\Windows Debug Tools-%LOCALAPPDATA%\ .

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has deployed malware that has copied itself to the startup directory for persistence.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  added Registry Run keys to establish persistence.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  places scripts in the startup folder for persistence.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  established persistence using Registry Run keys, both to execute PowerShell and VBS scripts as well as to execute their backdoor directly.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has deployed a tool known as  DarkComet  to the Startup folder of a victim, and used Registry run keys to gain persistence.

Name: APT37
Description: APT37 's has added persistence via the Registry key  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion\Run\ .

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has maintained persistence using the startup folder.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  created and modified startup files for persistence.     APT41  added a registry key in  HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Svchost  to establish persistence for Cobalt Strike.

Name: Aria-body
Description: Aria-body  has established persistence via the Startup folder or Run Registry key.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  creates a startup item for persistence.

Name: AuTo Stealer

Name: Avaddon
Description: Avaddon  uses registry run keys for persistence.

Name: AvosLocker
Description: AvosLocker  has been executed via the  RunOnce  Registry key to run itself on safe mode.

Name: BabyShark
Description: BabyShark  has added a Registry key to ensure all future macros are enabled for Microsoft Word and Excel as well as for additional persistence.

Name: Backdoor.Oldrea
Description: Backdoor.Oldrea  adds Registry Run keys to achieve persistence.

Name: BACKSPACE
Description: BACKSPACE  achieves persistence by creating a shortcut to itself in the CSIDL_STARTUP directory.

Name: BADNEWS
Description: BADNEWS  installs a registry Run key to establish persistence.

Name: BadPatch
Description: BadPatch  establishes a foothold by adding a link to the malware executable in the startup folder.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can create or add files to Registry Run Keys to establish persistence.

Name: BBSRAT
Description: BBSRAT  has been loaded through DLL side-loading of a legitimate Citrix executable that is set to persist through the Registry Run key location  HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ssonsvr.exe .

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal  has added itself to the Registry key  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion\Run\  for persistence.

Name: BitPaymer
Description: BitPaymer  has set the run key  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  for persistence.

Name: BlackEnergy
Description: The  BlackEnergy  3 variant drops its main DLL component and then creates a .lnk shortcut to that file in the startup folder.

Name: BoomBox
Description: BoomBox  can establish persistence by writing the Registry value  MicroNativeCacheSvc  to  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run .

Name: Briba
Description: Briba  creates run key Registry entries pointing to malicious DLLs dropped to disk.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  has used a batch script that adds a Registry Run key to establish malware persistence.

Name: build_downer
Description: build_downer  has the ability to add itself to the Registry Run key for persistence.

Name: Carbanak
Description: Carbanak  stores a configuration files in the startup directory to automatically execute commands in order to persist across reboots.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp  has maintained persistence by placing itself inside the current user's startup folder.

Name: Cardinal RAT
Description: Cardinal RAT  establishes Persistence by setting the   HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\Load  Registry key to point to its executable.

Name: Chaes
Description: Chaes  has added persistence via the Registry key  software\microsoft\windows\currentversion\run\microsoft windows html help .

Name: ChChes
Description: ChChes  establishes persistence by adding a Registry Run key.

Name: Chinoxy
Description: Chinoxy  has established persistence via the  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  registry key and by loading a dropper to  (%COMMON_ STARTUP%\\eoffice.exe) .

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  can establish persistence by adding a Registry run key.

Name: Cobalt Group
Description: Cobalt Group  has used Registry Run keys for persistence. The group has also set a Startup path to launch the PowerShell shell command and download Cobalt Strike.

Name: Cobian RAT
Description: Cobian RAT  creates an autostart Registry key to ensure persistence.

Name: Comnie
Description: Comnie  achieves persistence by adding a shortcut of itself to the startup path in the Registry.

Name: Conficker
Description: Conficker  adds Registry Run keys to establish persistence.

Name: CORESHELL

Name: CozyCar
Description: One persistence mechanism used by  CozyCar  is to set itself to be executed at system startup by adding a Registry value under one of the following Registry keys:  HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\   HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\   HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run   HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run

Description: Crimson  can add Registry run keys for persistence.

Name: DarkComet

Name: Darkhotel

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla  has established persistence via the  Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Run  registry key and by creating a .lnk shortcut file in the Windows startup folder.

Name: DnsSystem

Name: DownPaper

Name: Dragonfly

Name: DustySky

Other variants have set the following Registry keys for persistence:  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\imejp :   and  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\IAStorD .

Description: Mosquito  establishes persistence under the Registry key  HKCU\Software\Run auto_update .

Description: MuddyWater  has added Registry Run key  KCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\SystemTextEncoding  to establish persistence.

Name: Naikon

Name: NanHaiShu

Name: NanoCore

Name: NavRAT
Description: NavRAT  creates a Registry key to ensure a file gets executed upon reboot in order to establish persistence.

Name: Nebulae
Description: Nebulae  can achieve persistence through a Registry Run key.

Name: NETEAGLE
Description: The "SCOUT" variant of  NETEAGLE  achieves persistence by adding itself to the  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  Registry key.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  creates a Registry start-up entry to establish persistence.

Name: njRAT

Name: NOKKI

Name: ObliqueRAT

Name: Octopus

Name: Okrum

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  placed LNK files into the victims' startup folder for persistence.

Name: Operation Sharpshooter
Description: During  Operation Sharpshooter , a first-stage downloader installed  Rising Sun  to  %Startup%\mssync.exe  on a compromised host.

Name: Patchwork
Description: Patchwork  has added the path of its second-stage malware to the startup folder to achieve persistence. One of its file stealers has also persisted by adding a Registry Run key.

Name: Pisloader
Description: Pisloader  establishes persistence via a Registry Run key.

Name: PLAINTEE
Description: PLAINTEE  gains persistence by adding the Registry key  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce .

Name: PlugX

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  has added a registry key in the   hive for persistence.

Name: PoisonIvy
Description: PoisonIvy  creates run key Registry entries pointing to a malicious executable dropped to disk.

Name: PowerDuke
Description: PowerDuke  achieves persistence by using various Registry Run keys.

Name: PowerShower
Description: PowerShower  sets up persistence with a Registry run key.

Name: POWERSOURCE

Name: PowerSploit

Name: POWERTON
Description: POWERTON  can install a Registry Run key for persistence.

Name: Prikormka
Description: Prikormka  adds itself to a Registry Run key with the name guidVGA or guidVSA.

Name: PROMETHIUM
Description: PROMETHIUM  has used Registry run keys to establish persistence.

Name: Pteranodon
Description: Pteranodon  copies itself to the Startup folder to establish persistence.

Name: PUNCHBUGGY
Description: PUNCHBUGGY  has been observed using a Registry Run key.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  adds itself to the startup folder or adds itself to the Registry key  SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  for persistence.

Name: Putter Panda
Description: A dropper used by  Putter Panda  installs itself into the ASEP Registry key  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  with a value named McUpdate.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can maintain persistence by creating an auto-run Registry key.

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: If the  QuasarRAT  client process does not have administrator privileges it will add a registry key to  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  for persistence.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  has created Registry Run keys to establish persistence.

Name: RCSession
Description: RCSession  has the ability to modify a Registry Run key to establish persistence.

Name: Reaver
Description: Reaver  creates a shortcut file and saves it in a Startup folder to establish persistence.

Name: RedLeaves

Name: Remcos
Description: Remcos  can add itself to the Registry key  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  for persistence.

Name: Remexi
Description: Remexi  utilizes Run Registry keys in the HKLM hive as a persistence mechanism.

Name: Rifdoor
Description: Rifdoor  has created a new registry entry at  HKEY_CURRENT_USERS\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\Graphics  with a value of  C:\ProgramData\Initech\Initech.exe /run .

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke 's miner has created UPX-packed files in the Windows Start Menu Folder.

Name: RogueRobin
Description: RogueRobin  created a shortcut in the Windows startup folder to launch a PowerShell script each time the user logs in to establish persistence.

Name: Rover
Description: Rover  persists by creating a Registry entry in  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ .

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  tries to add a Registry Run key under the name "Windows Update" to establish persistence.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  has used Registry run keys to establish persistence for the  RTM  Trojan and other tools, such as a modified version of TeamViewer remote desktop software.

Name: RunningRAT
Description: RunningRAT  adds itself to the Registry key  Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  to establish persistence upon reboot.

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  has used the Windows command line to create a Registry entry under  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  to establish persistence.

Name: S-Type
Description: S-Type  may create a .lnk file to itself that is saved in the Start menu folder. It may also create the Registry key  HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\ IMJPMIJ8.1{3 characters of Unique Identifier} .

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  has established persistence by being copied to the Startup directory or through the  \Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  registry key.

Name: Sakula
Description: Most  Sakula  samples maintain persistence by setting the Registry Run key  SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\  in the HKLM or HKCU hive, with the Registry value and file name varying by sample.

Name: SDBbot
Description: SDBbot  has the ability to add a value to the Registry Run key to establish persistence if it detects it is running with regular user privilege.

Name: SeaDuke
Description: SeaDuke  is capable of persisting via the Registry Run key or a .lnk file stored in the Startup directory.

Name: Seasalt

Name: ServHelper

Name: SharpStage

Name: ShimRat

Name: SHIPSHAPE
Description: SHIPSHAPE  achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the Startup folder.

Name: Sidewinder
Description: Sidewinder  has added paths to executables in the Registry to establish persistence.

Name: Silence
Description: Silence  has used  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run ,  HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run , and the Startup folder to establish persistence.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can establish a LNK file in the startup folder for persistence.

Name: Small Sieve
Description: Small Sieve  has the ability to add itself to  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\OutlookMicrosift  for persistence.

Name: Smoke Loader

Name: SMOKEDHAM

Name: Snip3
Description: Snip3  can create a VBS file in startup to persist after system restarts.

Name: SNUGRIDE
Description: SNUGRIDE  establishes persistence through a Registry Run key.

Name: SPACESHIP
Description: SPACESHIP  achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the current user's Startup folder.

Name: SslMM
Description: To establish persistence,  SslMM  identifies the Start Menu Startup directory and drops a link to its own executable disguised as an "Office Start," "Yahoo Talk," "MSN Gaming Z0ne," or "MSN Talk" shortcut.

Name: STARWHALE
Description: STARWHALE  can establish persistence by installing itself in the startup folder, whereas the GO variant has created a  HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\OutlookM  registry key.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  can use the  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  Registry key for persistence.

Name: Sykipot
Description: Sykipot  has been known to establish persistence by adding programs to the Run Registry key.

Name: SysUpdate
Description: SysUpdate  can use a Registry Run key to establish persistence.

Name: TA2541
Description: TA2541  has placed VBS files in the Startup folder and used Registry run keys to establish persistence for malicious payloads.

Name: Taidoor
Description: Taidoor  has modified the  HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  key for persistence.

Name: TAINTEDSCRIBE

Name: TeamTNT

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390 's malware can add a Registry key to  Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  for persistence.

Name: ThreatNeedle

Name: TINYTYPHON
Description: TINYTYPHON  installs itself under Registry Run key to establish persistence.

Name: TinyZBot
Description: TinyZBot  can create a shortcut in the Windows startup folder for persistence.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  establishes persistence in the Startup folder.

Name: Trojan.Karagany

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has created shortcuts in the Startup folder to establish persistence.

Name: Truvasys
Description: Truvasys  adds a Registry Run key to establish persistence.

Name: Turian
Description: Turian  can establish persistence by adding Registry Run keys.

Name: Turla
Description: A  Turla  Javascript backdoor added a local_update_check value under the Registry key  HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  to establish persistence. Additionally, a  Turla  custom executable containing Metasploit shellcode is saved to the Startup folder to gain persistence.

Name: TURNEDUP
Description: TURNEDUP  is capable of writing to a Registry Run key to establish.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has used Registry Run keys to establish automatic execution at system startup.

Name: USBStealer
Description: USBStealer  registers itself under a Registry Run key with the name "USB Disk Security."

Name: Vasport
Description: Vasport  copies itself to disk and creates an associated run key Registry entry to establish.

Name: VBShower
Description: VBShower  used  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\{8}  to maintain persistence.

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  can add itself to the  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  and  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\UIF2IS20VK  Registry keys.

Name: Windshift
Description: Windshift  has created LNK files in the Startup folder to establish persistence.

Name: Winnti for Windows
Description: Winnti for Windows  can add a service named  wind0ws  to the Registry to achieve persistence after reboot.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has established persistence via the Registry key  HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  and a shortcut within the startup folder.

Name: Xbash
Description: Xbash  can create a Startup item for persistence if it determines it is on a Windows system.

Name: Zebrocy
Description: Zebrocy  creates an entry in a Registry Run key for the malware to execute on startup.

Name: Zeus Panda
Description: Zeus Panda  adds persistence by creating Registry Run keys.

Name: ZIRCONIUM
Description: ZIRCONIUM  has created a Registry Run key named  Dropbox Update Setup  to establish persistence for a malicious Python binary.

Name: Flame
Description: Flame  can use Windows Authentication Packages for persistence.

Name: Privileged Process Integrity
Description: Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2012 R2, and later versions, may make LSA run as a Protected Process Light (PPL) by setting the Registry key  HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\RunAsPPL , which requires all DLLs loaded by LSA to be signed by Microsoft.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can use Winlogon Helper DLL to establish persistence.

Name: Cannon
Description: Cannon  adds the Registry key  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon  to establish persistence.

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla  has established persistence via the  Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon  registry key.

Name: Dipsind
Description: A  Dipsind  variant registers as a Winlogon Event Notify DLL to establish persistence.

Name: Gazer
Description: Gazer  can establish persistence by setting the value "Shell" with "explorer.exe, %malware_pathfile%" under the Registry key  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon .

Name: KeyBoy
Description: KeyBoy  issues the command  reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon"  to achieve persistence.

Name: Remexi
Description: Remexi  achieves persistence using Userinit by adding the Registry key  HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\Userinit .

Name: Revenge RAT
Description: Revenge RAT  creates a Registry key at  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\Shell  to survive a system reboot.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has created the Registry key  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\Shell  and sets the value to establish persistence.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  established persistence by adding a Shell value under the Registry key  HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon .

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has established persistence using Userinit by adding the Registry key HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Identify and block potentially malicious software that may be executed through the Winlogon helper process by using application control    tools like AppLocker       that are capable of auditing and/or blocking unknown DLLs.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit the privileges of user accounts so that only authorized administrators can perform Winlogon helper changes.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can enumerate Security Support Providers (SSPs) as well as utilize  PowerSploit 's  Install-SSP  and  Invoke-Mimikatz  to install malicious SSPs and log authentication events.

Name: Mimikatz
Description: The  Mimikatz  credential dumper contains an implementation of an SSP.

Name: PowerSploit
Description: PowerSploit 's  Install-SSP  Persistence module can be used to establish by installing a SSP DLL.

Name: Privileged Process Integrity
Description: Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2012 R2, and later versions may make LSA run as a Protected Process Light (PPL) by setting the Registry key  HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\RunAsPPL , which requires all SSP DLLs to be signed by Microsoft.

Name: PoisonIvy
Description: PoisonIvy  creates a Registry key in the Active Setup pointing to a malicious executable.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: This feature can be disabled entirely with the following terminal command:  defaults write -g ApplePersistence -bool no .

Name: User Training
Description: Holding the Shift key while logging in prevents apps from opening automatically.

Name: Earth Lusca
Description: Earth Lusca  has added the Registry key  HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Control\Print\Environments\Windows x64\Print Processors\UDPrint" /v Driver /d "spool.dll /f  to load malware as a Print Processor.

Name: Gelsemium
Description: Gelsemium  can drop itself in  C:\Windows\System32\spool\prtprocs\x64\winprint.dll  to be loaded automatically by the spoolsv Windows service.

Name: PipeMon
Description: The  PipeMon  installer has modified the Registry key  HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Print\Environments\Windows x64\Print Processors  to install  PipeMon  as a Print Processor.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit user accounts that can load or unload device drivers by disabling  SeLoadDriverPrivilege .

Name: CrossRAT
Description: CrossRAT  can use an XDG Autostart to establish persistence.

Name: Fysbis
Description: If executing without root privileges,  Fysbis  adds a  .desktop  configuration file to the user's  ~/.config/autostart  directory.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can use XDG Autostart Entries to establish persistence on Linux systems.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  can use an XDG Autostart to establish persistence.

Name: RotaJakiro
Description: When executing with user-level permissions,  RotaJakiro  can install persistence using a .desktop file under the  $HOME/.config/autostart/  folder.

Name: Limit Software Installation
Description: Restrict software installation to trusted repositories only and be cautious of orphaned software packages.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Restrict write access to XDG autostart entries to only select privileged users.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit privileges of user accounts so only authorized privileged users can create and modify XDG autostart entries.

Name: Drovorub
Description: Drovorub  can use kernel modules to establish persistence.

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , attackers used a signed kernel rootkit to establish additional persistence.

Name: Skidmap
Description: Skidmap  has the ability to install several loadable kernel modules (LKMs) on infected machines.

Name: Antivirus/Antimalware
Description: Common tools for detecting Linux rootkits include: rkhunter   , chrootkit   , although rootkits may be designed to evade certain detection tools.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Application control and software restriction tools, such as SELinux, KSPP, grsecurity MODHARDEN, and Linux kernel tuning can aid in restricting kernel module loading.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Limit access to the root account and prevent users from loading kernel modules and extensions through proper privilege separation and limiting Privilege Escalation opportunities.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Use MDM to disable user's ability to install or approve kernel extensions, and ensure all approved kernel extensions are in alignment with policies specified in  com.apple.syspolicy.kernel-extension-policy .

Name: Pasam
Description: Pasam  establishes by infecting the Security Accounts Manager (SAM) DLL to load a malicious DLL dropped to disk.

Name: Wingbird
Description: Wingbird  drops a malicious file (sspisrv.dll) alongside a copy of lsass.exe, which is used to register a service that loads sspisrv.dll as a driver. The payload of the malicious driver (located in its entry-point function) is executed when loaded by lsass.exe before the spoofed service becomes unstable and crashes.

Name: Credential Access Protection
Description: On Windows 10 and Server 2016, enable Windows Defender Credential Guard    to run lsass.exe in an isolated virtualized environment without any device drivers.

Name: Privileged Process Integrity
Description: On Windows 8.1 and Server 2012 R2, enable LSA Protection by setting the Registry key  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\RunAsPPL  to  dword:00000001 .    LSA Protection ensures that LSA plug-ins and drivers are only loaded if they are digitally signed with a Microsoft signature and adhere to the Microsoft Security Development Lifecycle (SDL) process guidance.

Name: Restrict Library Loading
Description: Ensure safe DLL search mode is enabled  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\SafeDllSearchMode  to mitigate risk that lsass.exe loads a malicious code library.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has modified LNK shortcuts.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth 's initial payload is a malicious .LNK file.

Name: BACKSPACE
Description: BACKSPACE  achieves persistence by creating a shortcut to itself in the CSIDL_STARTUP directory.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can establish persistence by writing shortcuts to the Windows Startup folder.

Name: BlackEnergy
Description: The  BlackEnergy  3 variant drops its main DLL component and then creates a .lnk shortcut to that file in the startup folder.

Name: Comnie
Description: Comnie  establishes persistence via a .lnk file in the victim’s startup path.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can persist by modifying a .LNK file to include a backdoor.

Name: FELIXROOT
Description: FELIXROOT  creates a .LNK file for persistence.

Name: Gazer
Description: Gazer  can establish persistence by creating a .lnk file in the Start menu or by modifying existing .lnk files to execute the malware through cmd.exe.

Name: Gorgon Group

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  can write or modify browser shortcuts to enable launching of malicious browser extensions.

Name: Helminth
Description: Helminth  establishes persistence by creating a shortcut.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can use a .lnk shortcut for the Control Panel to establish persistence.

Name: Kazuar
Description: Kazuar  adds a .lnk file to the Windows startup folder.

Name: KONNI
Description: A version of  KONNI  drops a Windows shortcut on the victim’s machine to establish persistence.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  malware has maintained persistence on a system by creating a LNK shortcut in the user’s Startup folder.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has used JavaScript to create a shortcut file in the Startup folder that points to its main backdoor.

Name: MarkiRAT
Description: MarkiRAT  can modify the shortcut that launches Telegram by replacing its path with the malicious payload to launch with the legitimate executable.

Name: Micropsia
Description: Micropsia  creates a shortcut to maintain persistence.

Name: Okrum
Description: Okrum  can establish persistence by creating a .lnk shortcut to itself in the Startup folder.

Name: Reaver
Description: Reaver  creates a shortcut file and saves it in a Startup folder to establish persistence.

Name: RedLeaves
Description: RedLeaves  attempts to add a shortcut file in the Startup folder to achieve persistence.

Name: RogueRobin
Description: RogueRobin  establishes persistence by creating a shortcut (.LNK file) in the Windows startup folder to run a script each time the user logs in.

Name: S-Type
Description: S-Type  may create the file  %HOMEPATH%\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\Realtek {Unique Identifier}.lnk , which points to the malicious  msdtc.exe  file already created in the  %CommonFiles%  directory.

Name: SeaDuke
Description: SeaDuke  is capable of persisting via a .lnk file stored in the Startup directory.

Name: SHIPSHAPE
Description: SHIPSHAPE  achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the Startup folder.

Name: SPACESHIP
Description: SPACESHIP  achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the current user's Startup folder.

Name: SslMM
Description: To establish persistence,  SslMM  identifies the Start Menu Startup directory and drops a link to its own executable disguised as an "Office Start," "Yahoo Talk," "MSN Gaming Z0ne," or "MSN Talk" shortcut.

Name: TinyZBot
Description: TinyZBot  can create a shortcut in the Windows startup folder for persistence.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit permissions for who can create symbolic links in Windows to appropriate groups such as Administrators and necessary groups for virtualization. This can be done through GPO: Computer Configuration >  > Windows Settings > Security Settings > Local Policies > User Rights Assignment: Create symbolic links.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has installed a run command on a compromised system to enable malware execution on system startup.

Name: Cyclops Blink
Description: Cyclops Blink  has the ability to execute on device startup, using a modified RC script named S51armled.

Name: Green Lambert
Description: Green Lambert  can add  init.d  and  rc.d  files in the  /etc  folder to establish persistence.

Name: HiddenWasp
Description: HiddenWasp  installs reboot persistence by adding itself to  /etc/rc.local .

Name: iKitten
Description: iKitten  adds an entry to the rc.common file for persistence.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Limit privileges of user accounts so only authorized users can edit the rc.common file.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Restrict write access to logon scripts to specific administrators.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Restrict write access to logon scripts to specific administrators.

Name: APT28
Description: An  APT28  loader Trojan adds the Registry key  HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript  to establish persistence.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor 's dispatcher can establish persistence via adding a Registry key with a logon script  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Environment "UserInitMprLogonScript"  .

Name: Cobalt Group
Description: Cobalt Group  has added persistence by registering the file name for the next stage malware under  HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript .

Name: JHUHUGIT
Description: JHUHUGIT  has registered a Windows shell script under the Registry key  HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript  to establish persistence.

Name: KGH_SPY
Description: KGH_SPY  has the ability to set the  HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript  Registry key to execute logon scripts.

Name: Zebrocy
Description: Zebrocy  performs persistence with a logon script via adding to the Registry key  HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript .

Name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Description: Ensure proper permissions are set for Registry hives to prevent users from modifying keys for logon scripts that may lead to persistence.

Name: Bundlore
Description: Bundlore  can use AppleScript to inject malicious JavaScript into a browser.

Name: Dok
Description: Dok  uses AppleScript to create a login item for persistence.

Name: macOS.OSAMiner
Description: macOS.OSAMiner  has used  osascript  to call itself via the  do shell script  command in the  Launch Agent   .plist  file.

Name: ThiefQuest
Description: ThiefQuest  uses  AppleScript 's  osascript -e  command to launch  ThiefQuest 's persistence via  Launch Agent  and  Launch Daemon .

Name: Code Signing
Description: Require that all AppleScript be signed by a trusted developer ID before being executed - this will prevent random AppleScript code from executing.   This subjects AppleScript code to the same scrutiny as other .app files passing through Gatekeeper.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use application control where appropriate.

Name: Dok
Description: Dok  uses AppleScript to install a login Item by sending Apple events to the  System Events  process.

Name: Green Lambert
Description: Green Lambert  can add  Login Items  to establish persistence.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can persist via startup options for Login items.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has used a brute-force/password-spray tooling that operated in two modes: in brute-force mode it typically sent over 300 authentication attempts per hour per targeted account over the course of several hours or days.    APT28  has also used a Kubernetes cluster to conduct distributed, large-scale password guessing attacks.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has successfully conducted password guessing attacks against a list of mailboxes.

Name: China Chopper
Description: China Chopper 's server component can perform brute force password guessing against authentication portals.

Name: CrackMapExec

Name: Emotet

Name: HermeticWizard
Description: HermeticWizard  can use a list of hardcoded credentials in attempt to authenticate to SMB shares.

Name: Lucifer
Description: Lucifer  has attempted to brute force TCP ports 135 (RPC) and 1433 (MSSQL) with the default username or list of usernames and    passwords.

Name: P.A.S. Webshell

Name: Account Use Policies
Description: Set account lockout policies after a certain number of failed login attempts to prevent passwords from being guessed. Too strict a policy may create a denial of service condition and render environments un-usable, with all accounts used in the brute force being locked-out. Use conditional access policies to block logins from non-compliant devices or from outside defined organization IP ranges.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Use multi-factor authentication. Where possible, also enable multi-factor authentication on externally facing services.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Refer to NIST guidelines when creating password policies.

Name: Update Software
Description: Upgrade management services to the latest supported and compatible version.  Specifically, any version providing increased password complexity or policy enforcement preventing default or weak passwords.

Name: jRAT
Description: jRAT  can list and manage startup entries.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Since StartupItems are deprecated, preventing all users from writing to the  /Library/StartupItems  directory would prevent any startup items from getting registered.

Description: Chimera  has used credential stuffing against victim's remote services to obtain valid accounts.

Name: TrickBot

Name: Update Software

Name: User Account Control
Description: Enable pass the hash mitigations to apply UAC restrictions to local accounts on network logon. The associated Registry key is located  HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System\LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy . Through GPO: Computer Configuration >  > Administrative Templates > SCM: Pass the Hash Mitigations: Apply UAC restrictions to local accounts on network logons.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Do not allow a domain user to be in the local administrator group on multiple systems.

Upon user login,  MacMa  is executed from  /var/root/.local/softwareupdate  with root privileges. Some variations also include the  LimitLoadToSessionType  key with the value  Aqua , ensuring the  MacMa  only runs when there is a logged in GUI user.
