Description: GreyEnergy  encrypts communications using RSA-2048.

Name: GrimAgent
Description: GrimAgent  can use a hardcoded server public RSA key to encrypt the first request to C2.

Name: Hi-Zor
Description: Hi-Zor  encrypts C2 traffic with TLS.

Name: IcedID
Description: IcedID  has used SSL and TLS in communications with C2.

Name: KEYPLUG
Description: KEYPLUG  can use TLS-encrypted WebSocket Protocol (WSS) for C2.

Name: Koadic
Description: Koadic  can use SSL and TLS for communications.

Name: Kobalos
Description: Kobalos 's authentication and key exchange is performed using RSA-512.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  has used TLS-encrypted FTP to exfiltrate data.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo 's C2 communication has been encrypted using OpenSSL.

Name: Mythic
Description: Mythic  supports SSL encrypted C2.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  used the Plink utility and other tools to create tunnels to C2 servers.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors' proxy implementation "Agent" upgraded the socket in use to a TLS socket.

Name: Pay2Key
Description: Pay2Key  has used RSA encrypted communications with C2.

Name: Penquin
Description: Penquin  can encrypt communications using the BlowFish algorithm and a symmetric key exchanged with Diffie Hellman.

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  used TLS to encrypt command and control (C2) communications.

Name: POSHSPY
Description: POSHSPY  encrypts C2 traffic with AES and RSA.

Name: POWERSTATS
Description: POWERSTATS  has encrypted C2 traffic with RSA.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy 's default encryption for its C2 communication channel is SSL, but it also has transport options for RSA and AES.

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  has encrypted C2 communications with the ECIES algorithm.

Name: Rising Sun
Description: Rising Sun  variants can use SSL for encrypting C2 communications.

Name: Sardonic
Description: Sardonic  has the ability to send a random 64-byte RC4 key to communicate with actor-controlled C2 servers by using an RSA public key.

Name: ServHelper
Description: ServHelper  may set up a reverse SSH tunnel to give the attacker access to services running on the victim, such as RDP.

Name: Sliver
Description: Sliver  can use mutual TLS and RSA  cryptography to exchange a session key.

Name: Small Sieve
Description: Small Sieve  can use SSL/TLS for its HTTPS Telegram Bot API-based C2 channel.

Name: SodaMaster
Description: SodaMaster  can use a hardcoded RSA key to encrypt some of its C2 traffic.

Name: SombRAT
Description: SombRAT  can SSL encrypt C2 traffic.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  has encrypted C2 traffic using SSL/TLS.

Name: Sykipot
Description: Sykipot  uses SSL for encrypting C2 communications.

Name: TA2541
Description: TA2541  has used TLS encrypted C2 communications including for campaigns using AsyncRAT.

Name: TinyTurla
Description: TinyTurla  has the ability to encrypt C2 traffic with SSL/TLS.

Name: Tor
Description: Tor  encapsulates traffic in multiple layers of encryption, using TLS by default.

Name: Trojan.Karagany
Description: Trojan.Karagany  can secure C2 communications with SSL and TLS.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has used SSL to connect to C2 servers.

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  has used a combination of a Diffie-Hellman key exchange mixed with a pre-shared key (PSK) to encrypt its top layer of C2 communications.

Name: Volgmer
Description: Some  Volgmer  variants use SSL to encrypt C2 communications.

Name: WannaCry
Description: WannaCry  uses  Tor  for command and control traffic and routes a custom cryptographic protocol over the  Tor  circuit.

Name: WellMail
Description: WellMail  can use hard coded client and certificate authority certificates to communicate with C2 over mutual TLS.

Name: WellMess
Description: WellMess  can communicate to C2 with mutual TLS where client and server mutually check certificates.

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  can use RSA-4096 to encrypt data sent to its C2 server.

Name: XTunnel
Description: XTunnel  uses SSL/TLS and RC4 to encrypt traffic.

Name: Zebrocy
Description: Zebrocy  uses SSL and AES ECB for encrypting C2 communications.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: SSL/TLS Inspection
Description: SSL/TLS inspection can be used to see the contents of encrypted sessions to look for network-based indicators of malware communication protocols.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Leverage services provided by Content Delivery Networks (CDN) or providers specializing in DoS mitigations to filter traffic upstream from services.   Filter boundary traffic by blocking source addresses sourcing the attack, blocking ports that are being targeted, or blocking protocols being used for transport.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Leverage services provided by Content Delivery Networks (CDN) or providers specializing in DoS mitigations to filter traffic upstream from services.   Filter boundary traffic by blocking source addresses sourcing the attack, blocking ports that are being targeted, or blocking protocols being used for transport.

Name: 3PARA RAT
Description: 3PARA RAT  command and control commands are encrypted within the HTTP C2 channel using the DES algorithm in CBC mode with a key derived from the MD5 hash of the string HYF54&%9&jkMCXuiS.  3PARA RAT  will use an 8-byte XOR key derived from the string HYF54&%9&jkMCXuiS if the DES decoding fails

Name: 4H RAT
Description: 4H RAT  obfuscates C2 communication using a 1-byte XOR with the key 0xBE.

Name: ADVSTORESHELL
Description: A variant of  ADVSTORESHELL  encrypts some C2 with 3DES.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  installed a Delphi backdoor that used a custom algorithm for C2 communications.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has used AES for encryption of command and control traffic.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  has encrypted data symmetrically using a randomly generated Blowfish (OFB) key which is encrypted with a public RSA key.

Name: Azorult
Description: Azorult  can encrypt C2 traffic using XOR.

Name: BADCALL
Description: BADCALL  encrypts C2 traffic using an XOR/ADD cipher.

Name: BADNEWS
Description: BADNEWS  encrypts C2 data with a ROR by 3 and an XOR by 0x23.

Name: Bandook
Description: Bandook  has used AES encryption for C2 communication.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can send C2 communications with XOR encryption.

Name: BBSRAT
Description: BBSRAT  uses a custom encryption algorithm on data sent back to the C2 server over HTTP.

Name: BendyBear
Description: BendyBear  communicates to a C2 server over port 443 using modified RC4 and XOR-encrypted chunks.

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal  variants reported on in 2014 and 2015 used a simple XOR cipher for C2. Some  Bisonal  samples encrypt C2 communications with RC4.

Name: BLINDINGCAN
Description: BLINDINGCAN  has encrypted its C2 traffic with RC4.

Name: Bonadan
Description: Bonadan  can XOR-encrypt C2 communications.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  has used RC4 encryption (for Datper malware) and AES (for xxmm malware) to obfuscate HTTP traffic.  BRONZE BUTLER  has also used a tool called RarStar that encodes data with a custom XOR algorithm when posting it to a C2 server.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  can encrypt C2 requests and responses with RC4

Name: CallMe
Description: CallMe  uses AES to encrypt C2 traffic.

Name: Carbanak
Description: Carbanak  encrypts the message body of HTTP traffic with RC2 (in CBC mode).  Carbanak  also uses XOR with random keys for its communications.

Name: Cardinal RAT
Description: Cardinal RAT  uses a secret key with a series of XOR and addition operations to encrypt C2 traffic.

Name: Chaos
Description: Chaos  provides a reverse shell connection on 8338/TCP, encrypted via AES.

Name: CharmPower
Description: CharmPower  can send additional modules over C2 encrypted with a simple substitution cipher.

Name: ChChes
Description: ChChes  can encrypt C2 traffic with AES or RC4.

Name: CHOPSTICK
Description: CHOPSTICK  encrypts C2 communications with RC4.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  has the ability to use AES-256 symmetric encryption in CBC mode with HMAC-SHA-256 to encrypt task commands and XOR to encrypt shell code and configuration data.

Name: Comnie
Description: Comnie  encrypts command and control communications with RC4.

Name: CORESHELL
Description: CORESHELL  C2 messages are encrypted with custom stream ciphers using six-byte or eight-byte keys.

Name: CosmicDuke
Description: CosmicDuke  contains a custom version of the RC4 algorithm that includes a programming error.

Name: Darkhotel
Description: Darkhotel  has used AES-256 and 3DES for C2 communications.

Name: Daserf
Description: Daserf  uses RC4 encryption to obfuscate HTTP traffic.

Name: Derusbi
Description: Derusbi  obfuscates C2 traffic with variable 4-byte XOR keys.

Name: Dipsind
Description: Dipsind  encrypts C2 data with AES256 in ECB mode.

Name: down_new
Description: down_new  has the ability to AES encrypt C2 communications.

Name: Downdelph
Description: Downdelph  uses RC4 to encrypt C2 responses.

Name: Dridex
Description: Dridex  has encrypted traffic with RC4.

Name: Duqu
Description: The  Duqu  command and control protocol's data stream can be encrypted with AES-CBC.

Name: Ebury
Description: Ebury  has encrypted C2 traffic using the client IP address, then encoded it as a hexadecimal string.

Name: Elise
Description: Elise  encrypts exfiltrated data with RC4.

Name: Emissary
Description: The C2 server response to a beacon sent by a variant of  Emissary  contains a 36-character GUID value that is used as an encryption key for subsequent network communications. Some variants of  Emissary  use various XOR operations to encrypt C2 data.

Name: Epic
Description: Epic  encrypts commands from the C2 server using a hardcoded key.

Name: Explosive
Description: Explosive  has encrypted communications with the RC4 method.

Name: FakeM
Description: The original variant of  FakeM  encrypts C2 traffic using a custom encryption cipher that uses an XOR key of "YHCRA" and bit rotation between each XOR operation. Some variants of  FakeM  use RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.

Name: FALLCHILL
Description: FALLCHILL  encrypts C2 data with RC4 encryption.

Name: FatDuke
Description: FatDuke  can AES encrypt C2 communications.

Name: Felismus
Description: Some  Felismus  samples use a custom encryption method for C2 traffic that utilizes AES and multiple keys.

Name: FlawedAmmyy
Description: FlawedAmmyy  has used SEAL encryption during the initial C2 handshake.

Name: FoggyWeb
Description: FoggyWeb  has used a dynamic XOR key and custom XOR methodology for C2 communications.

Name: Frankenstein
Description: During  Frankenstein , the threat actors communicated with C2 via an encrypted RC4 byte stream and AES-CBC.

Name: Gazer
Description: Gazer  uses custom encryption for C2 that uses 3DES.

Name: gh0st RAT
Description: gh0st RAT  uses RC4 and XOR to encrypt C2 traffic.

Name: GreyEnergy
Description: GreyEnergy  encrypts communications using AES256.

Name: GrimAgent
Description: GrimAgent  can use an AES key to encrypt C2 communications.

Name: H1N1
Description: H1N1  encrypts C2 traffic using an RC4 key.

Name: HAMMERTOSS
Description: Before being appended to image files,  HAMMERTOSS  commands are encrypted with a key composed of both a hard-coded value and a string contained on that day's tweet. To decrypt the commands, an investigator would need access to the intended malware sample, the day's tweet, and the image file containing the command.

Name: Helminth
Description: Helminth  encrypts data sent to its C2 server over HTTP with RC4.

Name: Hi-Zor
Description: Hi-Zor  encrypts C2 traffic with a double XOR using two distinct single-byte keys.

Name: HiddenWasp
Description: HiddenWasp  uses an RC4-like algorithm with an already computed PRGA generated key-stream for network communication.

Name: Higaisa
Description: Higaisa  used AES-128 to encrypt C2 traffic.

Name: Hikit
Description: Hikit  performs XOR encryption.

Name: HotCroissant
Description: HotCroissant  has compressed network communications and encrypted them with a custom stream cipher.

Name: httpclient
Description: httpclient  encrypts C2 content with XOR using a single byte, 0x12.

Name: Hydraq
Description: Hydraq  C2 traffic is encrypted using bitwise NOT and XOR operations.

Name: HyperStack
Description: HyperStack  has used RSA encryption for C2 communications.

Name: IceApple
Description: The  IceApple  Result Retriever module can AES encrypt C2 responses.

Name: Inception
Description: Inception  has encrypted network communications with AES.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  uses variations of a simple XOR encryption routine for C&C communications.

Name: KEYMARBLE
Description: KEYMARBLE  uses a customized XOR algorithm to encrypt C2 communications.

Name: Kobalos
Description: Kobalos 's post-authentication communication channel uses a 32-byte-long password with RC4 for inbound and outbound traffic.

Name: Komplex
Description: The  Komplex  C2 channel uses an 11-byte XOR algorithm to hide data.

Name: KONNI
Description: KONNI  has used AES to encrypt C2 traffic.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Several  Lazarus Group  malware families encrypt C2 traffic using custom code that uses XOR with an ADD operation and XOR with a SUB operation. Another  Lazarus Group  malware sample XORs C2 traffic. Other  Lazarus Group  malware uses Caracachs encryption to encrypt C2 payloads.  Lazarus Group  has also used AES to encrypt C2 traffic.

Name: LightNeuron
Description: LightNeuron  uses AES to encrypt C2 traffic.

Name: LookBack
Description: LookBack  uses a modified version of RC4 for data transfer.

Name: Lucifer
Description: Lucifer  can perform a decremental-xor encryption on the initial C2 request before sending it over the wire.

Name: Lurid
Description: Lurid  performs XOR encryption.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  has used AES to exfiltrate documents.

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can encrypt its C2 traffic with RC4.

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  can encrypt the data that it sends and receives from the C2 server using an RC4 encryption algorithm.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has encrypted C2 commands with AES-256.

Name: Mongall
Description: Mongall  has the ability to RC4 encrypt C2 communications.

Name: MoonWind
Description: MoonWind  encrypts C2 traffic using RC4 with a static key.

Name: More_eggs
Description: More_eggs  has used an RC4-based encryption method for its C2 communications.

Name: Mosquito
Description: Mosquito  uses a custom encryption algorithm, which consists of XOR and a stream that is similar to the Blum Blum Shub algorithm.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has used AES to encrypt C2 responses.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has encrypted C2 communications with RC4.

Name: NanoCore
Description: NanoCore  uses DES to encrypt the C2 traffic.

Name: NDiskMonitor
Description: NDiskMonitor  uses AES to encrypt certain information sent over its C2 channel.

Name: Nebulae
Description: Nebulae  can use RC4 and XOR to encrypt C2 communications.

Name: NETEAGLE
Description: NETEAGLE  will decrypt resources it downloads with HTTP requests by using RC4 with the key "ScoutEagle."

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can use AES encryption for C2 data transferred.

Name: Okrum
Description: Okrum  uses AES to encrypt network traffic. The key can be hardcoded or negotiated with the C2 server in the registration phase.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  used an AES key to communicate with their C2 server.

Name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D  encrypts data sent back to the C2 using AES in CBC mode with a null initialization vector (IV) and a key sent from the server that is padded to 32 bytes.

Name: Pandora
Description: Pandora  has the ability to encrypt communications with D3DES.

Name: PingPull
Description: PingPull  can use AES, in cipher block chaining (CBC) mode padded with PKCS5, to encrypt C2 server communications.

Name: PipeMon
Description: PipeMon  communications are RC4 encrypted.

Name: PLAINTEE
Description: PLAINTEE  encodes C2 beacons using XOR.

Name: PLEAD
Description: PLEAD  has used RC4 encryption to download modules.

Name: PlugX
Description: PlugX  can use RC4 encryption in C2 communications.

Name: PoisonIvy
Description: PoisonIvy  uses the Camellia cipher to encrypt communications.

Name: POWERTON
Description: POWERTON  has used AES for encrypting C2 traffic.

Name: Prikormka
Description: Prikormka  encrypts some C2 traffic with the Blowfish cipher.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can RC4 encrypt strings in C2 communication.

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: QuasarRAT  uses AES with a hardcoded pre-shared key to encrypt network communication.

Name: QUIETCANARY
Description: QUIETCANARY  can RC4 encrypt C2 communications.

Name: RainyDay
Description: RainyDay  can use RC4 to encrypt C2 communications.

Name: RDAT
Description: RDAT  has used AES ciphertext to encode C2 communications.

Name: RedLeaves
Description: RedLeaves  has encrypted C2 traffic with RC4, previously using keys of 88888888 and babybear.

Name: Rifdoor
Description: Rifdoor  has encrypted command and control (C2) communications with a stream cipher.

Name: RIPTIDE
Description: APT12  has used the  RIPTIDE  RAT, which communicates over HTTP with a payload encrypted with RC4.

Name: RotaJakiro
Description: RotaJakiro  encrypts C2 communication using a combination of AES, XOR, ROTATE encryption, and ZLIB compression.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  encrypts C2 traffic with a custom RC4 variant.

Name: Sakula
Description: Sakula  encodes C2 traffic with single-byte XOR keys.

Name: Sardonic
Description: Sardonic  has the ability to use an RC4 key to encrypt communications to and from actor-controlled C2 servers.

Name: SeaDuke
Description: SeaDuke  C2 traffic has been encrypted with RC4 and AES.

Name: SideTwist
Description: SideTwist  can encrypt C2 communications with a randomly generated key.

Name: Sliver
Description: Sliver  can use AES-GCM-256 to encrypt a session key for C2 message exchange.

Name: SMOKEDHAM
Description: SMOKEDHAM  has encrypted its C2 traffic with RC4.

Name: SNUGRIDE
Description: SNUGRIDE  encrypts C2 traffic using AES with a static key.

Name: SodaMaster
Description: SodaMaster  can use RC4 to encrypt C2 communications.

Name: SombRAT
Description: SombRAT  has encrypted its C2 communications with AES.

Name: Stealth Falcon
Description: Stealth Falcon  malware encrypts C2 traffic using RC4 with a hard-coded key.

Name: StrifeWater
Description: StrifeWater  can encrypt C2 traffic using XOR with a hard coded key.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  encodes the payload of system information sent to the command and control servers using a one byte 0xFF XOR key.  Stuxnet  also uses a 31-byte long static byte string to XOR data sent to command and control servers. The servers use a different static key to encrypt replies to the implant.

Name: SUNBURST
Description: SUNBURST  encrypted C2 traffic using a single-byte-XOR cipher.

Name: Sys10
Description: Sys10  uses an XOR 0x1 loop to encrypt its C2 domain.

Name: SysUpdate
Description: SysUpdate  has used DES to encrypt all C2 communications.

Name: Taidoor
Description: Taidoor  uses RC4 to encrypt the message body of HTTP content.

Name: TAINTEDSCRIBE
Description: TAINTEDSCRIBE  uses a Linear Feedback Shift Register (LFSR) algorithm for network encryption.

Name: Torisma
Description: Torisma  has encrypted its C2 communications using XOR and VEST-32.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  uses a custom crypter leveraging Microsoft’s CryptoAPI to encrypt C2 traffic.  Newer versions of  TrickBot  have been known to use  bcrypt  to encrypt and digitally sign responses to their C2 server.

Name: TSCookie
Description: TSCookie  has encrypted network communications with RC4.

Name: UPPERCUT
Description: Some versions of  UPPERCUT  have used the hard-coded string "this is the encrypt key" for Blowfish encryption when communicating with a C2. Later versions have hard-coded keys uniquely for each C2 address.

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  can encrypt the data beneath its http2 or tcp encryption at the session layer with CAST-128, using a different key for incoming and outgoing data.

Name: Volgmer
Description: Volgmer  uses a simple XOR cipher to encrypt traffic and files.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has used a version of the Awen web shell that employed AES encryption and decryption for C2 communications.

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  can encrypt its C2 with RC4 with the password  warzone160\x00 .

Name: WellMess
Description: WellMess  can encrypt HTTP POST data using RC6 and a dynamically generated AES key encrypted with a hard coded RSA public key.

Name: Winnti for Linux
Description: Winnti for Linux  has used a custom TCP protocol with four-byte XOR for command and control (C2).

Name: Winnti for Windows
Description: Winnti for Windows  can XOR encrypt C2 traffic.

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  can use AES-CBC to encrypt data sent to its C2 server.

Name: xCaon
Description: xCaon  has encrypted data sent to the C2 server using a XOR key.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  uses RC4 encryption over TCP to communicate with its C2 server.

Name: ZeroT
Description: ZeroT  has used RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.

Name: ZIRCONIUM
Description: ZIRCONIUM  has used AES encrypted communications in C2.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: Industroyer
Description: Industroyer  uses a custom DoS tool that leverages CVE-2015-5374 and targets hardcoded IP addresses of Siemens SIPROTEC devices.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Leverage services provided by Content Delivery Networks (CDN) or providers specializing in DoS mitigations to filter traffic upstream from services.   Filter boundary traffic by blocking source addresses sourcing the attack, blocking ports that are being targeted, or blocking protocols being used for transport.

Name: APT1
Description: APT1  has created email accounts for later use in social engineering, phishing, and when registering domains.

Name: EXOTIC LILY
Description: EXOTIC LILY  has created e-mail accounts to spoof targeted organizations.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: For  FunnyDream , the threat actors likely established an identified email account to register a variety of domains that were used during the campaign.

Name: HEXANE
Description: HEXANE  has established email accounts for use in domain registration including for ProtonMail addresses.

Name: Indrik Spider
Description: Indrik Spider  has created email accounts to communicate with their ransomware victims, to include providing payment and decryption details.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has created email accounts for phishing operations.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has created new email accounts for spearphishing operations.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has created new email accounts for targeting efforts.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has established email accounts using fake personas for spearphishing operations.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has leveraged the legitimate email marketing service SMTP2Go for phishing campaigns.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  created fake email accounts to correspond with fake LinkedIn personas;  Lazarus Group  also established email accounts to match those of the victim as part of their BEC attempt.

Name: Operation Dust Storm
Description: For  Operation Dust Storm , the threat actors established email addresses to register domains for their operations.

Name: Operation Honeybee
Description: During  Operation Honeybee , attackers created email addresses to register for a free account for a control server used for the implants.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: For  Operation Wocao , the threat actors registered email accounts to use during the campaign.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has created email accounts that mimic legitimate organizations for its spearphishing operations.

Name: Silent Librarian
Description: Silent Librarian  has established e-mail accounts to receive e-mails forwarded from compromised accounts.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has leveraged ProtonMail email addresses in ransom notes when delivering  Ryuk  ransomware.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has a HWP document stealer module which changes the default program association in the registry to open HWP documents.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can conduct an image hijack of an  .msc  file extension as part of its UAC bypass process.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Name: Gazer
Description: Gazer  can establish persistence through the system screensaver by configuring it to execute the malware.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Use Group Policy to disable screensavers if they are unnecessary.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Block .scr files from being executed from non-standard locations.

Name: adbupd
Description: adbupd  can use a WMI script to achieve persistence.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has used WMI event subscriptions for persistence.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has attempted to use WMI event subscriptions to establish persistence on compromised hosts.

Name: BADHATCH
Description: BADHATCH  can use WMI event subscriptions for persistence.

Name: Blue Mockingbird
Description: Blue Mockingbird  has used mofcomp.exe to establish WMI Event Subscription persistence mechanisms configured from a *.mof file.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has used WMI event subscriptions for persistence.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has used WMI for persistence.

Name: Metador
Description: Metador  has established persistence through the use of a WMI event subscription combined with unusual living-off-the-land binaries such as  cdb.exe .

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  registered a WMI event subscription consumer called "hard_disk_stat" to establish persistence.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda 's custom ORat tool uses a WMI event consumer to maintain persistence.

Name: Operation Ghost
Description: During  Operation Ghost ,  APT29  used WMI event subscriptions to establish persistence for malware.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  has the ability to persist on a system using WMI events.

Name: POSHSPY
Description: POSHSPY  uses a WMI event subscription to establish persistence.

Name: POWERTON
Description: POWERTON  can use WMI for persistence.

Name: RegDuke
Description: RegDuke  can persist using a WMI consumer that is launched every time a process named WINWORD.EXE is started.

Name: Sardonic
Description: Sardonic  can use a WMI event filter to invoke a command-line event consumer to gain persistence.

Name: SeaDuke
Description: SeaDuke  uses an event filter in WMI code to execute a previously dropped executable shortly after system startup.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can create a WMI Event to execute a payload for persistence.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used a WMI event filter to invoke a command-line event consumer at system boot time to launch a backdoor with  rundll32.exe .

Name: TrailBlazer
Description: TrailBlazer  has the ability to use WMI for persistence.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has used WMI event filters and consumers to establish persistence.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: On Windows 10, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to prevent malware from abusing WMI to attain persistence.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Prevent credential overlap across systems of administrator and privileged accounts.

Name: User Account Management
Description: By default, only administrators are allowed to connect remotely using WMI; restrict other users that are allowed to connect, or disallow all users from connecting remotely to WMI.

Name: Green Lambert
Description: Green Lambert  can establish persistence on a compromised host through modifying the  profile ,  login , and run command (rc) files associated with the  bash ,  csh , and  tcsh  shells.

Name: Linux Rabbit
Description: Linux Rabbit  maintains persistence on an infected machine through rc.local and .bashrc files.

Name: RotaJakiro
Description: When executing with non-root level permissions,  RotaJakiro  can install persistence by adding a command to the .bashrc file that executes a binary in the   ${HOME}/.gvfsd/.profile/  folder.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Making these files immutable and only changeable by certain administrators will limit the ability for adversaries to easily create user level persistence.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  used sticky-keys to obtain unauthenticated, privileged console access.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  replaces the Sticky Keys binary  C:\Windows\System32\sethc.exe  for persistence.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  leveraged sticky keys to establish persistence.

Name: Axiom
Description: Axiom  actors have been known to use the Sticky Keys replacement within RDP sessions to obtain persistence.

Name: Deep Panda
Description: Deep Panda  has used the sticky-keys technique to bypass the RDP login screen on remote systems during intrusions.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can leverage WMI debugging to remotely replace binaries like sethc.exe, Utilman.exe, and Magnify.exe with cmd.exe.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has used sticky keys to launch a command prompt.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Adversaries can replace accessibility features binaries with alternate binaries to execute this technique. Identify and block potentially malicious software executed through accessibility features functionality by using application control    tools, like Windows Defender Application Control  , AppLocker,       or Software Restriction Policies    where appropriate.

Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Description: If possible, use a Remote Desktop Gateway to manage connections and security configuration of RDP within a network.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: To use this technique remotely, an adversary must use it in conjunction with RDP. Ensure that Network Level Authentication is enabled to force the remote desktop session to authenticate before the session is created and the login screen displayed. It is enabled by default on Windows Vista and later.

Name: Audit
Description: Binaries can also be baselined for what dynamic libraries they require, and if an app requires a new dynamic library that wasn\u2019t included as part of an update, it should be investigated.

Name: Code Signing
Description: Enforce that all binaries be signed by the correct Apple Developer IDs.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Allow applications via known hashes.

Name: netsh
Description: netsh  can be used as a persistence proxy technique to execute a helper DLL when netsh.exe is executed.

Name: PUNCHBUGGY
Description: PUNCHBUGGY  can establish using a AppCertDLLs Registry key.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Adversaries install new AppCertDLL binaries to execute this technique. Identify and block potentially malicious software executed through AppCertDLLs functionality by using application control    tools, like Windows Defender Application Control  , AppLocker,       or Software Restriction Policies    where appropriate.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used malware to set  LoadAppInit_DLLs  in the Registry key  SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows  in order to establish persistence.

Name: Cherry Picker
Description: Some variants of  Cherry Picker  use AppInit_DLLs to achieve persistence by creating the following Registry key:  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows "AppInit_DLLs"="pserver32.dll"

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can insert itself into the address space of other applications using the AppInit DLL Registry key.

Name: T9000
Description: If a victim meets certain criteria,  T9000  uses the AppInit_DLL functionality to achieve persistence by ensuring that every user mode process that is spawned will load its malicious DLL, ResN32.dll. It does this by creating the following Registry keys:  HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\AppInit_DLLs – %APPDATA%\Intel\ResN32.dll  and  HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\LoadAppInit_DLLs – 0x1 .

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Adversaries can install new AppInit DLLs binaries to execute this technique. Identify and block potentially malicious software executed through AppInit DLLs functionality by using application control    tools, like Windows Defender Application Control  , AppLocker,       or Software Restriction Policies    where appropriate.

Name: Update Software
Description: Upgrade to Windows 8 or later and enable secure boot.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  has used application shim databases for persistence.

Name: Pillowmint
Description: Pillowmint  has used a malicious shim database to maintain persistence.

Name: SDBbot
Description: SDBbot  has the ability to use application shimming for persistence if it detects it is running as admin on Windows XP or 7, by creating a shim database to patch services.exe.

Name: ShimRat
Description: ShimRat  has installed shim databases in the  AppPatch  folder.

Name: Update Software
Description: Microsoft released an optional patch update - KB3045645 - that will remove the "auto-elevate" flag within the sdbinst.exe. This will prevent use of application shimming to bypass UAC.

Name: User Account Control
Description: Changing UAC settings to "Always Notify" will give the user more visibility when UAC elevation is requested, however, this option will not be popular among users due to the constant UAC interruptions.

Name: SDBbot
Description: SDBbot  has the ability to use image file execution options for persistence if it detects it is running with admin privileges on a Windows version newer than Windows 7.

Name: SUNBURST
Description: SUNBURST  created an Image File Execution Options (IFEO) Debugger registry value for the process  dllhost.exe  to trigger the installation of  Cobalt Strike .

Name: TEMP.Veles
Description: TEMP.Veles  has modified and added entries within  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Options  to maintain persistence.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has used PowerShell profiles to maintain persistence on an infected machine.

Name: Code Signing
Description: Enforce execution of only signed PowerShell scripts. Sign profiles to avoid them from being modified.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Making PowerShell profiles immutable and only changeable by certain administrators will limit the ability for adversaries to easily create user level persistence.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: Avoid PowerShell profiles if not needed. Use the -No Profile flag with when executing PowerShell scripts remotely to prevent local profiles and scripts from being executed.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Consider disabling emond by removing the  Launch Daemon  plist file.

Name: ADVSTORESHELL
Description: Some variants of  ADVSTORESHELL  achieve persistence by registering the payload as a Shell Icon Overlay handler COM object.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has used COM hijacking for persistence by replacing the legitimate  MMDeviceEnumerator  object with a payload.

Name: BBSRAT
Description: BBSRAT  has been seen persisting via COM hijacking through replacement of the COM object for MruPidlList  {42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1}  or Microsoft WBEM New Event Subsystem  {F3130CDB-AA52-4C3A-AB32-85FFC23AF9C1}  depending on the system's CPU architecture.

Name: ComRAT
Description: ComRAT  samples have been seen which hijack COM objects for persistence by replacing the path to shell32.dll in registry location  HKCU\Software\Classes\CLSID{42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1}\InprocServer32 .

Name: Ferocious
Description: Ferocious  can use COM hijacking to establish persistence.

Name: JHUHUGIT
Description: JHUHUGIT  has used COM hijacking to establish persistence by hijacking a class named MMDeviceEnumerator and also by registering the payload as a Shell Icon Overlay handler COM object ({3543619C-D563-43f7-95EA-4DA7E1CC396A}).

Name: KONNI
Description: KONNI  has modified ComSysApp service to load the malicious DLL payload.

Name: Mosquito
Description: Mosquito  uses COM hijacking as a method of persistence.

Name: PcShare
Description: PcShare  has created the  HKCU\\Software\\Classes\\CLSID\\{42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1}\\InprocServer32  Registry key for persistence.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can add a CLSID key for payload execution through  Registry.CurrentUser.CreateSubKey("Software\\Classes\\CLSID\\{" + clsid + "}\\InProcServer32") .

Name: SVCReady
Description: SVCReady  has created the  HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\CLSID\{E6D34FFC-AD32-4d6a-934C-D387FA873A19}  Registry key for persistence.

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT   can perform COM hijacking by setting the path to itself to the  HKCU\Software\Classes\Folder\shell\open\command  key with a  DelegateExecute  parameter.

Name: AppleJeus
Description: During  AppleJeus 's installation process, it uses  postinstall  scripts to extract a hidden plist from the application's  /Resources  folder and execute the  plist  file as a  Launch Daemon  with elevated permissions.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  has encrypted payloads using the Data Protection API (DPAPI), which relies on keys tied to specific user accounts on specific machines.  APT41  has also environmentally keyed second stage malware with an RC5 key derived in part from the infected system's volume serial number.

Name: Equation
Description: Equation  has been observed utilizing environmental keying in payload delivery.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can use Data Protection API to encrypt its components on the victim’s computer, to evade detection, and to make sure the payload can only be decrypted and loaded on one specific compromised computer.

Name: PowerPunch
Description: PowerPunch  can use the volume serial number from a target host to generate a unique XOR key for the next stage payload.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  relies on a specific victim hostname to execute and decrypt important strings.

Name: Winnti for Windows
Description: The  Winnti for Windows  dropper component can verify the existence of a single command line parameter and either terminate if it is not found or later use it as a decryption key.

Name: Do Not Mitigate
Description: Environmental Keying  likely should not be mitigated with preventative controls because it may protect unintended targets from being compromised. If targeted, efforts should be focused on preventing adversary tools from running earlier in the chain of activity and on identifying subsequent malicious behavior if compromised.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has exfiltrated archives of collected data previously staged on a target's OWA server via HTTPS.

Name: Rclone
Description: Rclone  can exfiltrate data over SFTP or HTTPS via WebDAV.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  exfiltrated collected data over a simple HTTPS request to a password-protected archive staged on a victim's OWA servers.

Name: Data Loss Prevention
Description: Data loss prevention can detect and block sensitive data being uploaded via web browsers.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Enforce proxies and use dedicated servers for services such as DNS and only allow those systems to communicate over respective ports/protocols, instead of all systems within a network.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary command and control infrastructure and malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Follow best practices for network firewall configurations to allow only necessary ports and traffic to enter and exit the network.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Enforce proxies and use dedicated servers for services such as DNS and only allow those systems to communicate over respective ports/protocols, instead of all systems within a network.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary command and control infrastructure and malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Follow best practices for network firewall configurations to allow only necessary ports and traffic to enter and exit the network.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can use GitHub for data exfiltration.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: Web proxies can be used to enforce an external network communication policy that prevents use of unauthorized external services.

Name: Flame
Description: Flame  has a module named BeetleJuice that contains Bluetooth functionality that may be used in different ways, including transmitting encoded information from the infected system over the Bluetooth protocol, acting as a Bluetooth beacon, and identifying other Bluetooth devices in the vicinity.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable Bluetooth in local computer security settings or by group policy if it is not needed within an environment.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Prevent the creation of new network adapters where possible.

Name: Agent.btz
Description: Agent.btz  creates a file named thumb.dd on all USB flash drives connected to the victim. This file contains information about the infected system and activity logs.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  has a feature to copy files from every drive onto a removable drive in a hidden folder.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has used a customized  PlugX  variant which could exfiltrate documents from air-gapped networks.

Name: Remsec
Description: Remsec  contains a module to move data from airgapped networks to Internet-connected systems by using a removable USB device.

Name: SPACESHIP
Description: SPACESHIP  copies staged data to removable drives when they are inserted into the system.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has exfiltrated data using USB storage devices.

Name: USBStealer
Description: USBStealer  exfiltrates collected files via removable media from air-gapped victims.

Name: Data Loss Prevention
Description: Data loss prevention can detect and block sensitive data being copied to USB devices.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable Autorun if it is unnecessary.    Disallow or restrict removable media at an organizational policy level if they are not required for business operations.

Name: Limit Hardware Installation
Description: Limit the use of USB devices and removable media within a network.

Name: Data Loss Prevention
Description: Data loss prevention can be detect and block sensitive data being uploaded to web services via web browsers.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  has routines for exfiltration over SMTP, FTP, and HTTP.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32 's backdoor can exfiltrate data by encoding it in the subdomain field of DNS packets.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has used FTP to exfiltrate files (separately from the C2 channel).

Name: BITSAdmin
Description: BITSAdmin  can be used to create  BITS Jobs  to upload files from a compromised host.

Name: Brave Prince
Description: Some  Brave Prince  variants have used South  Korea's Daum email service to exfiltrate information, and later variants have posted the data to a web server via an HTTP post command.

Name: C0017
Description: During  C0017 ,  APT41  exfiltrated victim data via DNS lookups by encoding and prepending it as subdomains to the attacker-controlled domain.

Name: Carbon
Description: Carbon  uses HTTP to send data to the C2 server.

Name: ccf32
Description: ccf32  can upload collected data and files to an FTP server.

Name: CharmPower
Description: CharmPower  can send victim data via FTP with credentials hardcoded in the script.

Name: Cherry Picker
Description: Cherry Picker  exfiltrates files over FTP.

Name: CookieMiner
Description: CookieMiner  has used the  curl --upload-file  command to exfiltrate data over HTTP.

Name: CORALDECK
Description: CORALDECK  has exfiltrated data in HTTP POST headers.

Name: CosmicDuke
Description: CosmicDuke  exfiltrates collected files over FTP or WebDAV. Exfiltration servers can be separately configured from C2 servers.

Name: Dok
Description: Dok  exfiltrates logs of its execution stored in the  /tmp  folder over FTP using the  curl  command.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has sent stolen payment card data to remote servers via HTTP POSTs.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has used FTP to exfiltrate collected data.

Name: ftp
Description: ftp  may be used to exfiltrate data separate from the main command and control protocol.

Name: Kessel
Description: Kessel  can exfiltrate credentials and other information via HTTP POST request, TCP, and DNS.

Name: KONNI
Description: KONNI  has used FTP to exfiltrate reconnaissance data out.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  malware SierraBravo-Two generates an email message via SMTP containing information about newly infected victims.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has exfiltrated data over FTP separately from its primary C2 channel over DNS.

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  has used  ftp  for exfiltration.

Name: Rclone
Description: Rclone  can exfiltrate data over FTP or HTTP, including HTTP via WebDAV.

Name: Remsec
Description: Remsec  can exfiltrate data via a DNS tunnel or email, separately from its C2 channel.

Name: Thrip
Description: Thrip  has used WinSCP to exfiltrate data from a targeted organization over FTP.

Name: WindTail
Description: WindTail  has the ability to automatically exfiltrate files using the macOS built-in utility /usr/bin/curl.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has exfiltrated victim information using FTP.

Name: Data Loss Prevention
Description: Data loss prevention can detect and block sensitive data being sent over unencrypted protocols.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Enforce proxies and use dedicated servers for services such as DNS and only allow those systems to communicate over respective ports/protocols, instead of all systems within a network.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary command and control infrastructure and malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Follow best practices for network firewall configurations to allow only necessary ports and traffic to enter and exit the network.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  can use WinRM for pivoting.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has used WinRM for lateral movement.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can use  WinRM  to execute a payload on a remote host.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has leveraged  WMI  to move laterally within a compromised network via application servers and SQL servers.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  tracks  TrustedHosts  and can move laterally to these targets via WinRM.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used WinRM via PowerShell to execute commands and payloads on remote hosts.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  has used WinRM to enable remote execution.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used Window Remote Management to move laterally through a victim network.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable the WinRM service.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: If the service is necessary, lock down critical enclaves with separate WinRM infrastructure and follow WinRM best practices on use of host firewalls to restrict WinRM access to allow communication only to/from specific devices.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: If the service is necessary, lock down critical enclaves with separate WinRM accounts and permissions.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: Web proxies can be used to enforce an external network communication policy that prevents use of unauthorized external services.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32 's macOS backdoor changes the permission of the file it wants to execute to 755.

Name: Black Basta
Description: The  Black Basta  binary can use  chmod  to gain full permissions to targeted files.

Name: Bundlore
Description: Bundlore  changes the permissions of a payload using the command  chmod -R 755 .

Name: Dok
Description: Dok  gives all users execute permissions for the application using the command  chmod +x /Users/Shared/AppStore.app .

Name: Kinsing
Description: Kinsing  has used chmod to modify permissions on key files for use.

Name: OSX/Shlayer
Description: OSX/Shlayer  can use the  chmod  utility to set a file as executable, such as  chmod 777  or  chmod +x .

Name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D  has changed permissions of a second-stage payload to an executable via  chmod .

Name: P.A.S. Webshell
Description: P.A.S. Webshell  has the ability to modify file permissions.

Name: Penquin
Description: Penquin  can add the executable flag to a downloaded file.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  has changed file permissions of files so they could not be modified.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has modified the permissions on binaries with  chattr .

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  uses the  chmod +x  command to grant executable permissions to the malicious file.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Ensure critical system files as well as those known to be abused by adversaries have restrictive permissions and are owned by an appropriately privileged account, especially if access is not required by users nor will inhibit system functionality.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Applying more restrictive permissions to files and directories could prevent adversaries from modifying the access control lists.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp  can start a remote VNC session by downloading a new plugin.

Name: DanBot
Description: DanBot  can use VNC for remote access to targeted systems.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  has used TightVNC to control compromised hosts.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has installed TightVNC server and client on compromised servers and endpoints for lateral movement.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  has used VNC tools, including UltraVNC, to remotely interact with compromised hosts.

Name: GCMAN
Description: GCMAN  uses VNC for lateral movement.

Name: Proton
Description: Proton  uses VNC to connect into systems.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  has used a VNC module to monitor the victim and collect information to pivot to valuable systems on the network

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  has the ability of performing remote desktop access via a VNC console.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  supports functionality for VNC sessions.

Name: Audit
Description: Inventory workstations for unauthorized VNC server software.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Uninstall any VNC server software where not required.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: VNC defaults to TCP ports 5900 for the server, 5800 for browser access, and 5500 for a viewer in listening mode. Filtering or blocking these ports will inhibit VNC traffic utilizing default ports.

Name: Limit Software Installation
Description: Restrict software installation to user groups that require it. A VNC server must be manually installed by the user or adversary.

Name: BitPaymer
Description: BitPaymer  can use  icacls /reset  and  takeown /F  to reset a targeted executable's permissions and then take ownership.

Name: BlackCat
Description: BlackCat  can use Windows commands such as  fsutil behavior set SymLinkEvaluation R2L:1  to redirect file system access to a different location after gaining access into compromised networks.

Name: CaddyWiper
Description: CaddyWiper  can modify ACL entries to take ownership of files.

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  can modify the binary ACL to prevent security tools from running.

Name: JPIN
Description: JPIN  can use the command-line utility cacls.exe to change file permissions.

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  can launch  icacls   /grant Everyone:F /T /C /Q  to delete every access-based restrictions on files and directories.

Name: WannaCry
Description: WannaCry  uses  attrib +h  and  icacls . /grant Everyone:F /T /C /Q  to make some of its files hidden and grant all users full access controls.

Name: WastedLocker
Description: WastedLocker  has a command to take ownership of a file and reset the ACL permissions using the  takeown.exe /F filepath  command.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used the icacls command to modify access control to backup servers, providing them with full control of all the system folders.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Ensure critical system files as well as those known to be abused by adversaries have restrictive permissions and are owned by an appropriately privileged account, especially if access is not required by users nor will inhibit system functionality.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Applying more restrictive permissions to files and directories could prevent adversaries from modifying the access control lists.

Name: AADInternals
Description: AADInternals  can be used to create SAML tokens using the AD Federated Services token signing certificate.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  created tokens using compromised SAML signing certificates.

Name: Active Directory Configuration
Description: For containing the impact of a previously forged SAML token, rotate the token-signing AD FS certificate in rapid succession twice, which will invalidate any tokens generated using the previous certificate.

Name: Audit
Description: Enable advanced auditing on AD FS. Check the success and failure audit options in the AD FS Management snap-in. Enable Audit Application Generated events on the AD FS farm via Group Policy Object.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Restrict permissions and access to the AD FS server to only originate from privileged access workstations.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Ensure that user accounts with administrative rights follow best practices, including use of privileged access workstations, Just in Time/Just Enough Administration (JIT/JEA), and strong authentication. Reduce the number of users that are members of highly privileged Directory Roles.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls. Efforts should focus on minimizing the amount and sensitivity of data available to external parties.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  bypassed MFA set on OWA accounts by generating a cookie value from a previously stolen secret key.

Name: Audit
Description: Administrators should perform an audit of all access lists and the permissions they have been granted to access web applications and services. This should be done extensively on all resources in order to establish a baseline, followed up on with periodic audits of new or updated resources. Suspicious accounts/credentials should be investigated and removed.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: Configure browsers/applications to regularly delete persistent web cookies.

Name: Andariel
Description: Andariel  has inserted a malicious script within compromised websites to collect potential victim information such as browser type, system language, Flash Player version, and other data.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has captured the user-agent strings from visitors to their phishing sites.

Name: LAPSUS$

Description: In preparation for its attack against the 2018 Winter Olympics,  Sandworm Team  conducted online research of partner organizations listed on an official PyeongChang Olympics partnership site.
