Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  has created hidden folders.

Name: AppleJeus
Description: AppleJeus  has added a leading  .  to plist filenames, unlisting them from the Finder app and default Terminal directory listings.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has saved files with hidden file attributes.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32 's macOS backdoor hides the clientID file via a chflags function.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  can set attributes of log files and directories to HIDDEN, SYSTEM, ARCHIVE, or a combination of those.

Name: BackConfig
Description: BackConfig  has the ability to set folders or files to be hidden from the Windows Explorer default view.

Name: Calisto
Description: Calisto  uses a hidden directory named .calisto to store data from the victim’s machine before exfiltration.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp  has created a hidden file in the Startup folder of the current user.

Name: ccf32
Description: ccf32  has created a hidden directory on targeted systems, naming it after the current local time (year, month, and day).

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  has the ability to set its file attributes to hidden.

Name: CoinTicker
Description: CoinTicker  downloads the following hidden files to evade detection and maintain persistence: /private/tmp/.info.enc, /private/tmp/.info.py, /private/tmp/.server.sh, ~/Library/LaunchAgents/.espl.plist, ~/Library/Containers/./.

Name: Dacls
Description: Dacls  has had its payload named with a dot prefix to make it hidden from view in the Finder application.

Name: EnvyScout
Description: EnvyScout  can use hidden directories and files to hide malicious executables.

Name: Explosive
Description: Explosive  has commonly set file and path attributes to hidden.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has created hidden files and folders within a compromised Linux system  /tmp  directory.  FIN13  also has used  attrib.exe  to hide gathered local host information.

Name: FruitFly
Description: FruitFly  saves itself with a leading "." to make it a hidden file.

Name: HAFNIUM
Description: HAFNIUM  has hidden files on a compromised host.

Name: iKitten
Description: iKitten  saves itself with a leading "." so that it's hidden from users by default.

Name: Imminent Monitor
Description: Imminent Monitor  has a dynamic debugging feature to set the file attribute to hidden.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can create hidden system directories.

Name: Ixeshe
Description: Ixeshe  sets its own executable file's attributes to hidden.

Name: Komplex
Description: The  Komplex  payload is stored in a hidden directory at  /Users/Shared/.local/kextd .

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has used a VBA Macro to set its file attributes to System and Hidden and has named files with a dot prefix to hide them from the Finder application.

Name: Lokibot
Description: Lokibot  has the ability to copy itself to a hidden file and directory.

Name: LoudMiner
Description: LoudMiner  has set the attributes of the VirtualBox directory and VBoxVmService parent directory to "hidden".

Name: LuminousMoth
Description: LuminousMoth  has used malware to store malicious binaries in hidden directories on victim's USB drives.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  has the capability to exfiltrate stolen data to a hidden folder on a removable drive.

Name: MacSpy
Description: MacSpy  stores itself in  ~/Library/.DS_Stores/

Name: Micropsia
Description: Micropsia  creates a new hidden directory to store all components' outputs in a dedicated sub-folder for each.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda 's  PlugX  variant has created a hidden folder on USB drives named  RECYCLE.BIN  to store malicious executables and collected data.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can copy itself to and launch itself from hidden folders.

Name: Okrum
Description: Before exfiltration,  Okrum 's backdoor has used hidden files to store logs and outputs from backdoor commands.

Name: OSX/Shlayer
Description: OSX/Shlayer  has executed a .command script from a hidden directory in a mounted DMG.

Name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D  sets the main loader file’s attributes to hidden.

Name: PlugX
Description: PlugX  can modify the characteristics of folders to hide them from the compromised user.

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  has the ability to hide and unhide files.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  has placed its payload in hidden subdirectories.

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: QuasarRAT  has the ability to set file attributes to "hidden" to hide files from the compromised user's view in Windows File Explorer.

Name: Rising Sun
Description: Rising Sun  can modify file attributes to hide files.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  downloaded a file "libprocesshider", which could hide files on the target system.

Name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
Description: SLOTHFULMEDIA  has been created with a hidden attribute to insure it's not visible to the victim.

Name: SysUpdate
Description: SysUpdate  has the ability to set file attributes to hidden.

Name: ThiefQuest
Description: ThiefQuest  hides a copy of itself in the user's  ~/Library  directory by using a  .  at the beginning of the file name followed by 9 random characters.

Name: Transparent Tribe
Description: Transparent Tribe  can hide legitimate directories and replace them with malicious copies of the same name.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has created a hidden directory under  C:\ProgramData\Apple\Updates\  and  C:\Users\Public\Documents\Flash\ .

Name: WannaCry
Description: WannaCry  uses  attrib +h  to make some of its files hidden.

Name: WastedLocker
Description: WastedLocker  has copied a random file from the Windows System32 folder to the  %APPDATA%  location under a different hidden filename.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  uses a hidden folder named  .xcassets  and  .git  to embed itself in Xcode.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has modified the Registry to hide created user accounts.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has run  reg add ‘HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\SpecialAccounts\UserList’ /v  to hide a newly created user.

Name: SMOKEDHAM
Description: SMOKEDHAM  has modified the Registry to hide created user accounts from the Windows logon screen.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: If the computer is domain joined, then group policy can help restrict the ability to create or hide users. Similarly, preventing the modification of the  /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow   Hide500Users  value will force all users to be visible.

Name: Anchor
Description: Anchor  has used NTFS to hide files.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  used NTFS alternate data streams to hide their payloads.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  can abuse alternate data streams (ADS) to store content for malicious payloads.

Name: BitPaymer
Description: BitPaymer  has copied itself to the  :bin  alternate data stream of a newly created file.

Name: DEADEYE
Description: The DEADEYE.EMBED variant of  DEADEYE  can embed its payload in an alternate data stream of a local file.

Name: esentutl
Description: esentutl  can be used to read and write alternate data streams.

Name: Expand
Description: Expand  can be used to download or copy a file into an alternate data stream.

Name: Gazer
Description: Gazer  stores configuration items in alternate data streams (ADSs) if the Registry is not accessible.

Name: LoJax
Description: LoJax  has loaded an embedded NTFS DXE driver to be able to access and write to NTFS partitions.

Name: PowerDuke
Description: PowerDuke  hides many of its backdoor payloads in an alternate data stream (ADS).

Name: POWERSOURCE
Description: If the victim is using PowerShell 3.0 or later,  POWERSOURCE  writes its decoded payload to an alternate data stream (ADS) named kernel32.dll that is saved in  %PROGRAMDATA%\Windows\ .

Name: Regin
Description: The  Regin  malware platform uses Extended Attributes to store encrypted executables.

Name: Valak
Description: Valak  has the ability save and execute files as alternate data streams (ADS).

Name: WastedLocker
Description: WastedLocker  has the ability to save and execute files as an alternate data stream (ADS).

Name: Zeroaccess
Description: Some variants of the  Zeroaccess  Trojan have been known to store data in Extended Attributes.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Consider adjusting read and write permissions for NTFS EA, though this should be tested to ensure routine OS operations are not impeded.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Turn off or restrict access to unneeded VB components.

Name: LoudMiner
Description: LoudMiner  has used QEMU and VirtualBox to run a Tiny Core Linux virtual machine, which runs XMRig and makes connections to the C2 server for updates.

Name: Maze
Description: Maze  operators have used VirtualBox and a Windows 7 virtual machine to run the ransomware; the virtual machine's configuration file mapped the shared network drives of the target company, presumably so  Maze  can encrypt files on the shared drives as well as the local machine.

Name: Ragnar Locker
Description: Ragnar Locker  has used VirtualBox and a stripped Windows XP virtual machine to run itself. The use of a shared folder specified in the configuration enables  Ragnar Locker  to encrypt files on the host operating system, including files on any mapped drives.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable Hyper-V if not necessary within a given environment.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use application control to mitigate installation and use of unapproved virtualization software.

Name: BOOTRASH
Description: BOOTRASH  has used unallocated disk space between partitions for a hidden file system that stores components of the Nemesis bootkit.

Name: ComRAT
Description: ComRAT  has used a portable FAT16 partition image placed in %TEMP% as a hidden file system.

Name: Equation
Description: Equation  has used an encrypted virtual file system stored in the Windows Registry.

Name: Regin
Description: Regin  has used a hidden file system to store some of its components.

Name: Strider
Description: Strider  has used a hidden file system that is stored as a file on disk.

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  can use concealed storage mechanisms including an NTFS or FAT-16 filesystem encrypted with CAST-128 in CBC mode.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  has used  ProcessWindowStyle.Hidden  to hide windows.

Name: APT19
Description: APT19  used  -W Hidden  to conceal  PowerShell  windows by setting the WindowStyle parameter to hidden.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has used the WindowStyle parameter to conceal  PowerShell  windows.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  has been known to use  -WindowStyle Hidden  to conceal  PowerShell  windows.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has used the WindowStyle parameter to conceal  PowerShell  windows.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  loads its module with the XSL script parameter  vShow  set to zero, which opens the application with a hidden window.

Name: AsyncRAT
Description: AsyncRAT  can hide the execution of scheduled tasks using  ProcessWindowStyle.Hidden .

Name: AvosLocker
Description: AvosLocker  has hidden its console window by using the  ShowWindow  API function.

Name: BONDUPDATER
Description: BONDUPDATER  uses  -windowstyle hidden  to conceal a  PowerShell  window that downloads a payload.

Name: CopyKittens
Description: CopyKittens  has used  -w hidden  and  -windowstyle hidden  to conceal  PowerShell  windows.

Name: Cuba
Description: Cuba  has executed hidden PowerShell windows.

Name: DarkHydrus
Description: DarkHydrus  has used  -WindowStyle Hidden  to conceal  PowerShell  windows.

Name: Deep Panda
Description: Deep Panda  has used  -w hidden  to conceal  PowerShell  windows by setting the WindowStyle parameter to hidden.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  has used  hidcon  to run batch files in a hidden console window.

Name: Gorgon Group
Description: Gorgon Group  has used  -W Hidden  to conceal  PowerShell  windows by setting the WindowStyle parameter to hidden.

Name: HAMMERTOSS
Description: HAMMERTOSS  has used  -WindowStyle hidden  to conceal  PowerShell  windows.

Name: Higaisa
Description: Higaisa  used a payload that creates a hidden window.

Name: HotCroissant
Description: HotCroissant  has the ability to hide the window for operations performed on a given file.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  has executed legitimate tools in hidden windows.

Name: Kevin
Description: Kevin  can hide the current window from the targeted user via the  ShowWindow  API function.

Name: KeyBoy
Description: KeyBoy  uses  -w Hidden  to conceal a  PowerShell  window that downloads a payload.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used an information gathering module that will hide an AV software window from the victim.

Name: Kivars
Description: Kivars  has the ability to conceal its activity through hiding active windows.

Name: Koadic
Description: Koadic  has used the command  Powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -WindowStyle Hidden  to hide its window.

Name: KOCTOPUS
Description: KOCTOPUS  has used  -WindowsStyle Hidden  to hide the command window.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  malware has a function to determine whether the C2 server wishes to execute the newly dropped file in a hidden window.

Name: MCMD
Description: MCMD  can modify processes to prevent them from being visible on the desktop.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has hidden its GUI using the ShowWindow() WINAPI call.

Name: Meteor
Description: Meteor  can hide its console window upon execution to decrease its visibility to a victim.

Name: Nomadic Octopus
Description: Nomadic Octopus  executed PowerShell in a hidden window.

Name: PowerShower
Description: PowerShower  has added a registry key so future powershell.exe instances are spawned with coordinates for a window position off-screen by default.

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: QuasarRAT  can hide process windows and make web requests invisible to the compromised user. Requests marked as invisible have been sent with user-agent string  Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_9_3) AppleWebKit/537.75.14 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/7.0.3 Safari/7046A194A  though  QuasarRAT  can only be run on Windows systems.

Name: QUIETCANARY
Description: QUIETCANARY  can execute processes in a hidden window.

Name: QuietSieve
Description: QuietSieve  has the ability to execute payloads in a hidden window.

Name: SharpDisco
Description: SharpDisco  can hide windows using  ProcessWindowStyle.Hidden .

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  has the ability to set its window state to hidden.

Name: Snip3
Description: Snip3  can execute PowerShell scripts in a hidden window.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  has the ability to hide the console window for its document search module from the user.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  droppers have used COM properties to execute malware in hidden windows.

Name: WindTail
Description: WindTail  can instruct the OS to execute an application without a dock icon or menu.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Limit or restrict program execution using anti-virus software. On MacOS, allowlist programs that are allowed to have the plist tag. All other programs should be considered suspicious.

Name: Keydnap
Description: Keydnap  uses a resource fork to present a macOS JPEG or text file icon rather than the executable's icon assigned by the operating system.

Name: OSX/Shlayer
Description: OSX/Shlayer  has used a resource fork to hide a compressed binary file of itself from the terminal, Finder, and potentially evade traditional scanners.

Name: Application Developer Guidance
Description: Configure applications to use the application bundle structure which leverages the  /Resources  folder location.

Name: FIN4
Description: FIN4  has created rules in victims' Microsoft Outlook accounts to automatically delete emails containing words such as "hacked," "phish," and "malware" in a likely attempt to prevent organizations from communicating about their activities.

Name: Audit
Description: Enterprise email solutions may have monitoring mechanisms that may include the ability to audit inbox rules on a regular basis.  In an Exchange environment, Administrators can use  Get-InboxRule  /  Remove-InboxRule  and  Get-TransportRule  /  Remove-TransportRule  to discover and remove potentially malicious inbox and transport rules.

Name: APT19
Description: APT19  launched an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant using a legitimate executable that loaded the malicious DLL.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  has been known to side load DLLs with a valid version of Chrome with one of their tools.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  ran legitimately-signed executables from Symantec and McAfee which load a malicious DLL. The group also side-loads its backdoor by dropping a library and a legitimate, signed executable (AcroTranscoder).

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  used legitimate executables to perform DLL side-loading of their malware.

Name: BADNEWS
Description: BADNEWS  typically loads its DLL file into a legitimate signed Java or VMware executable.

Name: BBSRAT
Description: DLL side-loading has been used to execute  BBSRAT  through a legitimate Citrix executable, ssonsvr.exe. The Citrix executable was dropped along with  BBSRAT  by the dropper.

Name: BlackTech
Description: BlackTech  has used DLL side loading by giving DLLs hardcoded names and placing them in searched directories.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  has used legitimate applications to side-load malicious DLLs.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  has loaded a malicious DLL by spoofing the name of the legitimate Version.DLL  and placing it in the same folder as the digitally-signed Microsoft binary OneDriveUpdater.exe.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has used side loading to place malicious DLLs in memory.

Name: Chinoxy
Description: Chinoxy  can use a digitally signed binary ("Logitech Bluetooth Wizard Host Process") to load its dll into memory.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  can store a file named  mpsvc.dll , which opens a malicious  mpsvc.mui  file, in the same folder as the legitimate Microsoft executable  MsMpEng.exe  to gain execution.

Name: Denis
Description: Denis  exploits a security vulnerability to load a fake DLL and execute its code.

Name: Dridex
Description: Dridex  can abuse legitimate Windows executables to side-load malicious DLL files.

Name: Earth Lusca
Description: Earth Lusca  has placed a malicious payload in  %WINDIR%\SYSTEM32\oci.dll  so it would be sideloaded by the MSDTC service.

Name: Ecipekac
Description: Ecipekac  can abuse the legitimate application policytool.exe to load a malicious DLL.

Name: Egregor
Description: Egregor  has used DLL side-loading to execute its payload.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has used IISCrack.dll as a side-loading technique to load a malicious version of httpodbc.dll on old IIS Servers (CVE-2001-0507).

Name: FinFisher
Description: FinFisher  uses DLL side-loading to load malicious programs.

Name: GALLIUM
Description: GALLIUM  used DLL side-loading to covertly load  PoisonIvy  into memory on the victim machine.

Name: gh0st RAT
Description: A  gh0st RAT  variant has used DLL side-loading.

Name: Goopy
Description: Goopy  has the ability to side-load malicious DLLs with legitimate applications from Kaspersky, Microsoft, and Google.

Name: Higaisa
Description: Higaisa ’s JavaScript file used a legitimate Microsoft Office 2007 package to side-load the  OINFO12.OCX  dynamic link library.

Name: HTTPBrowser
Description: HTTPBrowser  has used DLL side-loading.

Name: HyperBro
Description: HyperBro  has used a legitimate application to sideload a DLL to decrypt, decompress, and run a payload.

Name: Javali
Description: Javali  can use DLL side-loading to load malicious DLLs into legitimate executables.

Name: Kerrdown
Description: Kerrdown  can use DLL side-loading to load malicious DLLs.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has replaced  win_fw.dll , an internal component that is executed during IDA Pro installation, with a malicious DLL to download and execute a payload.

Name: LookBack
Description: LookBack  side loads its communications module as a DLL into the  libcurl.dll  loader.

Name: LuminousMoth
Description: LuminousMoth  has used legitimate executables such as  winword.exe  and  igfxem.exe  to side-load their malware.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has used DLL side-loading to launch versions of Mimikatz and PwDump6 as well as  UPPERCUT .

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  can support an HKCMD sideloading start method.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has side-loaded its malicious DLL file.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  maintains persistence on victim networks through side-loading dlls to trick legitimate programs into running malware.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has used a legitimately signed executable to execute a malicious payload within a DLL file.

Name: Naikon
Description: Naikon  has used DLL side-loading to load malicious DLL's into legitimate executables.

Name: Nebulae
Description: Nebulae  can use DLL side-loading to gain execution.

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , the threat actors used the legitimate Windows services  IKEEXT  and  PrintNotify  to side-load malicious DLLs.

Name: Pandora
Description: Pandora  can use DLL side-loading to execute malicious payloads.

Name: Patchwork
Description: A  Patchwork  .dll that contains  BADNEWS  is loaded and executed using DLL side-loading.

Name: PlugX
Description: PlugX  has used DLL side-loading to evade anti-virus.

Name: PowGoop
Description: PowGoop  can side-load  Goopdate.dll  into  GoogleUpdate.exe .

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  has the ability to use DLL side-loading for execution.

Name: RainyDay
Description: RainyDay  can use side-loading to run malicious executables.

Name: RCSession
Description: RCSession  can be installed via DLL side-loading.

Name: Sakula
Description: Sakula  uses DLL side-loading, typically using a digitally signed sample of Kaspersky Anti-Virus (AV) 6.0 for Windows Workstations or McAfee's Outlook Scan About Box to load malicious DLL files.

Name: SideCopy
Description: SideCopy  has used a malicious loader DLL file to execute the  credwiz.exe  process and side-load the malicious payload  Duser.dll .

Name: Sidewinder
Description: Sidewinder  has used DLL side-loading to drop and execute malicious payloads including the hijacking of the legitimate Windows application file rekeywiz.exe.

Name: SysUpdate
Description: SysUpdate  can load DLLs through vulnerable legitimate executables.

Name: T9000
Description: During the  T9000  installation process, it drops a copy of the legitimate Microsoft binary igfxtray.exe. The executable contains a side-loading weakness which is used to load a portion of the malware.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  has used DLL side-loading, including by using legitimate Kaspersky antivirus variants as well as  rc.exe , a legitimate Microsoft Resource Compiler.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has been known to side-load DLLs using a valid version of a Windows Address Book and Windows Defender executable with one of their tools.

Name: Waterbear
Description: Waterbear  has used DLL side loading to import and load a malicious DLL loader.

Name: Wingbird
Description: Wingbird  side loads a malicious file, sspisrv.dll, in part of a spoofed lssas.exe service.

Name: ZeroT
Description: ZeroT  has used DLL side-loading to load malicious payloads.

Name: Application Developer Guidance
Description: When possible, include hash values in manifest files to help prevent side-loading of malicious libraries.

Name: Update Software
Description: Update software regularly to include patches that fix DLL side-loading vulnerabilities.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  has used search order hijacking to execute malicious payloads, such as Winnti RAT.

Name: Aquatic Panda
Description: Aquatic Panda  has used DLL search-order hijacking to load  exe ,  dll , and  dat  files into memory.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  can launch itself via DLL Search Order Hijacking.

Name: BackdoorDiplomacy
Description: BackdoorDiplomacy  has executed DLL search order hijacking.

Name: BOOSTWRITE
Description: BOOSTWRITE  has exploited the loading of the legitimate Dwrite.dll file by actually loading the gdi library, which then loads the gdiplus library and ultimately loads the local Dwrite dll.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  has used search order hijacking to load a malicious payload DLL as a dependency to a benign application packaged in the same ISO.

Name: Chaes
Description: Chaes  has used search order hijacking to load a malicious DLL.

Name: Crutch
Description: Crutch  can persist via DLL search order hijacking on Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, or Microsoft OneDrive.

Name: Downdelph
Description: Downdelph  uses search order hijacking of the Windows executable sysprep.exe to escalate privileges.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  contains modules that can discover and exploit various DLL hijacking opportunities.

Name: Evilnum
Description: Evilnum  has used the malware variant, TerraTV, to load a malicious DLL placed in the TeamViewer directory, instead of the original Windows DLL located in a system folder.

Name: FinFisher
Description: A  FinFisher  variant uses DLL search order hijacking.

Name: FoggyWeb
Description: FoggyWeb 's loader has used DLL Search Order Hijacking to load malicious code instead of the legitimate  version.dll  during the  Microsoft.IdentityServer.ServiceHost.exe  execution process.

Name: Hikit
Description: Hikit  has used  DLL Search Order Hijacking  to load  oci.dll  as a persistence mechanism.

Name: HTTPBrowser
Description: HTTPBrowser  abuses the Windows DLL load order by using a legitimate Symantec anti-virus binary, VPDN_LU.exe, to load a malicious DLL that mimics a legitimate Symantec DLL, navlu.dll.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can be launched by using DLL search order hijacking in which the wrapper DLL is placed in the same folder as explorer.exe and loaded during startup into the Windows Explorer process instead of the legitimate library.

Name: Melcoz
Description: Melcoz  can use DLL hijacking to bypass security controls.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has used DLL search order hijacking.

Name: MirageFox
Description: MirageFox  is likely loaded via DLL hijacking into a legitimate McAfee binary.

Name: PlugX
Description: PlugX  has the ability to use DLL search order hijacking for installation on targeted systems.

Name: PowerSploit
Description: PowerSploit  contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can discover and exploit DLL hijacking opportunities in services and processes.

Name: Prikormka
Description: Prikormka  uses DLL search order hijacking for persistence by saving itself as ntshrui.dll to the Windows directory so it will load before the legitimate ntshrui.dll saved in the System32 subdirectory.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can hijack outdated Windows application dependencies with malicious versions of its own DLL payload.

Name: RedLeaves
Description: RedLeaves  is launched through use of DLL search order hijacking to load a malicious dll.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  has used search order hijacking to force TeamViewer to load a malicious DLL.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  has performed DLL search order hijacking to execute their payload.

Name: Tonto Team
Description: Tonto Team  abuses a legitimate and signed Microsoft executable to launch a malicious DLL.

Name: WastedLocker
Description: WastedLocker  has performed DLL hijacking before execution.

Name: WEBC2
Description: Variants of  WEBC2  achieve persistence by using DLL search order hijacking, usually by copying the DLL file to  %SYSTEMROOT%  ( C:\WINDOWS\ntshrui.dll ).

Name: Whitefly
Description: Whitefly  has used search order hijacking to run the loader Vcrodat.

Name: Audit
Description: Use auditing tools capable of detecting DLL search order hijacking opportunities on systems within an enterprise and correct them. Toolkits like the PowerSploit framework contain PowerUp modules that can be used to explore systems for DLL hijacking weaknesses.  Use the program sxstrace.exe that is included with Windows along with manual inspection to check manifest files for side-by-side problems in software.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Adversaries may use new DLLs to execute this technique. Identify and block potentially malicious software executed through search order hijacking by using application control solutions capable of blocking DLLs loaded by legitimate software.

Name: Restrict Library Loading
Description: Disallow loading of remote DLLs. This is included by default in Windows Server 2012+ and is available by patch for XP+ and Server 2003+. Enable Safe DLL Search Mode to force search for system DLLs in directories with greater restrictions (e.g.  %SYSTEMROOT% )to be used before local directory DLLs (e.g. a user's home directory) The Safe DLL Search Mode can be enabled via Group Policy at Computer Configuration >  > Administrative Templates > MSS (Legacy): MSS: (SafeDllSearchMode) Enable Safe DLL search mode. The associated Windows Registry key for this is located at  HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\SafeDLLSearchMode

Name: GoldMax
Description: The  GoldMax  Linux variant has been executed with the  nohup  command to ignore hangup signals and continue to run if the terminal session was terminated.

Name: OSX/Shlayer
Description: OSX/Shlayer  has used the  nohup  command to instruct executed payloads to ignore hangup signals.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can use spoof arguments in spawned processes that execute beacon commands.

Name: SombRAT
Description: SombRAT  has the ability to modify its process memory to hide process command-line arguments.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  has a dylib hijacker module that generates a malicious dylib given the path to a legitimate dylib of a vulnerable application.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Set directory access controls to prevent file writes to the search paths for applications, both in the folders where applications are run from and the standard dylib folders.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  contains modules that can discover and exploit path interception opportunities in the PATH environment variable.

Name: PowerSploit
Description: PowerSploit  contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can discover and exploit path interception opportunities in the PATH environment variable.

Name: Audit
Description: Find and eliminate path interception weaknesses in program configuration files, scripts, the PATH environment variable, services, and in shortcuts by surrounding PATH variables with quotation marks when functions allow for them. Be aware of the search order Windows uses for executing or loading binaries and use fully qualified paths wherever appropriate. Clean up old Windows Registry keys when software is uninstalled to avoid keys with no associated legitimate binaries. Periodically search for and correct or report path interception weaknesses on systems that may have been introduced using custom or available tools that report software using insecure path configurations.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Adversaries will likely need to place new binaries in locations to be executed through this weakness. Identify and block potentially malicious software executed path interception by using application control tools, like Windows Defender Application Control, AppLocker, or Software Restriction Policies where appropriate.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Ensure that proper permissions and directory access control are set to deny users the ability to write files to the top-level directory  C:  and system directories, such as  C:\Windows\ , to reduce places where malicious files could be placed for execution. Require that all executables be placed in write-protected directories.

Name: Audit
Description: Use auditing tools capable of detecting file system permissions abuse opportunities on systems within an enterprise and correct them. Toolkits like the PowerSploit framework contain PowerUp modules that can be used to explore systems for service file system permissions weaknesses.

Name: User Account Control
Description: Turn off UAC's privilege elevation for standard users    to automatically deny elevation requests, add:  "ConsentPromptBehaviorUser"=dword:00000000 . Consider enabling installer detection for all users by adding:  "EnableInstallerDetection"=dword:00000001 . This will prompt for a password for installation and also log the attempt. To disable installer detection, instead add:  "EnableInstallerDetection"=dword:00000000 . This may prevent potential elevation of privileges through exploitation during the process of UAC detecting the installer, but will allow the installation process to continue without being logged.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit privileges of user accounts and groups so that only authorized administrators can interact with service changes and service binary target path locations. Deny execution from user directories such as file download directories and temp directories where able.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  has configured payloads to load via LD_PRELOAD.

Name: Ebury
Description: Ebury  has injected its dynamic library into descendent processes of sshd via LD_PRELOAD.

Name: HiddenWasp
Description: HiddenWasp  adds itself as a shared object to the LD_PRELOAD environment variable.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has modified /etc/ld.so.preload to intercept shared library import functions.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  has modified /etc/ld.so.preload to hook libc functions in order to hide the installed dropper and mining software in process lists.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  adds malicious file paths to the  DYLD_FRAMEWORK_PATH  and  DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH  environment variables to execute malicious code.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Adversaries may use new payloads to execute this technique. Identify and block potentially malicious software executed through hijacking by using application control solutions also capable of blocking libraries loaded by legitimate software.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: When System Integrity Protection (SIP) is enabled in macOS, the aforementioned environment variables are ignored when executing protected binaries. Third-party applications can also leverage Apple’s Hardened Runtime, ensuring these environment variables are subject to imposed restrictions.   Admins can add restrictions to applications by setting the setuid and/or setgid bits, use entitlements, or have a __RESTRICT segment in the Mach-O binary.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  contains modules that can discover and exploit search order hijacking vulnerabilities.

Name: PowerSploit
Description: PowerSploit  contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can discover and exploit search order hijacking vulnerabilities.

Name: Audit
Description: Find and eliminate path interception weaknesses in program configuration files, scripts, the PATH environment variable, services, and in shortcuts by surrounding PATH variables with quotation marks when functions allow for them. Be aware of the search order Windows uses for executing or loading binaries and use fully qualified paths wherever appropriate. Clean up old Windows Registry keys when software is uninstalled to avoid keys with no associated legitimate binaries. Periodically search for and correct or report path interception weaknesses on systems that may have been introduced using custom or available tools that report software using insecure path configurations.

Identify and block potentially malicious software executed path interception by using application control tools, like Windows Defender Application Control, AppLocker, or Software Restriction Policies where appropriate.

Require that all executables be placed in write-protected directories.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  contains modules that can discover and exploit unquoted path vulnerabilities.

Name: PowerSploit
Description: PowerSploit  contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can discover and exploit unquoted path vulnerabilities.

Name: Audit
Description: Find and eliminate path interception weaknesses in program configuration files, scripts, the PATH environment variable, services, and in shortcuts by surrounding PATH variables with quotation marks when functions allow for them. Be aware of the search order Windows uses for executing or loading binaries and use fully qualified paths wherever appropriate. Periodically search for and correct or report path interception weaknesses on systems that may have been introduced using custom or available tools that report software using insecure path configurations.

Identify and block potentially malicious software executed path interception by using application control tools, like Windows Defender Application Control, AppLocker, or Software Restriction Policies where appropriate.

Require that all executables be placed in write-protected directories.

Name: Blue Mockingbird
Description: Blue Mockingbird  has used wmic.exe and Windows Registry modifications to set the COR_PROFILER environment variable to execute a malicious DLL whenever a process loads the .NET CLR.

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla  can detect profilers by verifying the  COR_ENABLE_PROFILING  environment variable is present and active.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Identify and block potentially malicious unmanaged COR_PROFILER profiling DLLs  by using application control solutions like AppLocker that are capable of auditing and/or blocking unapproved DLLs.

Name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Description: Ensure proper permissions are set for Registry hives to prevent users from modifying keys associated with COR_PROFILER.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit the privileges of user accounts so that only authorized administrators can edit system environment variables.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  has the ability to hide memory artifacts and to patch Event Tracing for Windows (ETW) and the Anti Malware Scan Interface (AMSI).

Name: Ebury
Description: Ebury  can hook logging functions so that nothing from the backdoor gets sent to the logging facility.

Name: HermeticWiper
Description: HermeticWiper  has the ability to set the  HKLM:\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Control\\CrashControl\CrashDumpEnabled  Registry key to  0  in order to disable crash dumps.

Name: Waterbear
Description: Waterbear  can hook the  ZwOpenProcess  and  GetExtendedTcpTable  APIs called by the process of a security product to hide PIDs and TCP records from detection.

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  has suppressed all error reporting by calling  SetErrorMode  with 0x8007 as a parameter.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Ensure event tracers/forwarders   , firewall policies, and other associated mechanisms are secured with appropriate permissions and access controls.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: Consider automatically relaunching forwarding mechanisms at recurring intervals (ex: temporal, on-logon, etc.) as well as applying appropriate change management to firewall rules and other related system configurations.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Ensure event tracers/forwarders   , firewall policies, and other associated mechanisms are secured with appropriate permissions and access controls and cannot be manipulated by user accounts.

Name: Operation Honeybee
Description: During  Operation Honeybee , the threat actors used a batch file that modified the COMSysApp service to load a malicious ipnet.dll payload and to load a DLL into the  svchost.exe  process.

Name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Description: Ensure proper permissions are set for Registry hives to prevent users from modifying keys for system components that may lead to privilege escalation.

Name: BlackEnergy
Description: One variant of  BlackEnergy  locates existing driver services that have been disabled and drops its driver component into one of those service's paths, replacing the legitimate executable. The malware then sets the hijacked service to start automatically to establish persistence.

Name: Audit
Description: Use auditing tools capable of detecting file system permissions abuse opportunities on systems within an enterprise and correct them. Toolkits like the PowerSploit framework contain PowerUp modules that can be used to explore systems for service file system permissions weaknesses.

Name: User Account Control
Description: Turn off UAC's privilege elevation for standard users   to automatically deny elevation requests, add:  "ConsentPromptBehaviorUser"=dword:00000000 . Consider enabling installer detection for all users by adding:  "EnableInstallerDetection"=dword:00000001 . This will prompt for a password for installation and also log the attempt. To disable installer detection, instead add:  "EnableInstallerDetection"=dword:00000000 . This may prevent potential elevation of privileges through exploitation during the process of UAC detecting the installer, but will allow the installation process to continue without being logged.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit privileges of user accounts and groups so that only authorized administrators can interact with service changes and service binary target path locations. Deny execution from user directories such as file download directories and temp directories where able.

Name: 2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  modified in-registry internet settings to lower internet security.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  has the capability to kill any running analysis processes and AV software.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has disabled Purview Audit on targeted accounts prior to stealing emails from  Microsoft 365 tenants.

Name: Aquatic Panda
Description: Aquatic Panda  has attempted to stop endpoint detection and response (EDR) tools on compromised systems.

Name: Avaddon
Description: Avaddon  looks for and attempts to stop anti-malware solutions.

Name: Babuk
Description: Babuk  can stop anti-virus services on a compromised host.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  has manually loaded ntdll from disk in order to identity and remove API hooks set by security products.

Name: Brave Prince
Description: Brave Prince  terminates antimalware processes.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  has incorporated code into several tools that attempts to terminate anti-virus processes.

Name: Bundlore
Description: Bundlore  can change browser security settings to enable extensions to be installed.  Bundlore  uses the  pkill cfprefsd  command to prevent users from inspecting processes.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp  has attempted to disable security software by creating a suspended process for the security software and injecting code to delete antivirus core files when the process is resumed.

Name: ChChes
Description: ChChes  can alter the victim's proxy configuration.

Name: Clop
Description: Clop  can uninstall or disable security products.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  has the ability to use Smart Applet attacks to disable the Java SecurityManager sandbox.

Name: Conficker
Description: Conficker  terminates various services related to system security and Windows.

Name: DarkComet
Description: DarkComet  can disable Security Center functions like anti-virus.

Name: Diavol
Description: Diavol  can attempt to stop security software.

Name: Donut
Description: Donut  can patch Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI), Windows Lockdown Policy (WLDP), as well as exit-related  Native API  functions to avoid process termination.

Name: Ebury
Description: Ebury  can disable SELinux Role-Based Access Control and deactivate PAM modules.

Name: Egregor
Description: Egregor  has disabled Windows Defender to evade protections.

Name: EKANS
Description: EKANS  stops processes related to security and management software.

Name: Ember Bear
Description: Ember Bear  has executed a batch script designed to disable Windows Defender on a compromised host.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has deployed a utility script named  kill.bat  to disable anti-virus.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  has delivered macros which can tamper with Microsoft Office security settings.

Name: Gold Dragon
Description: Gold Dragon  terminates anti-malware processes if they’re found running on the system.

Name: Goopy
Description: Goopy  has the ability to disable Microsoft Outlook's security policies to disable macro warnings.

Name: Gorgon Group
Description: Gorgon Group  malware can attempt to disable security features in Microsoft Office and Windows Defender using the  taskkill  command.

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  can hook APIs, kill processes, break file system paths, and change ACLs to prevent security tools from running.

Name: H1N1
Description: H1N1  kills and disables services for Windows Security Center, and Windows Defender.

Name: HDoor
Description: HDoor  kills anti-virus found on the victim.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has modified DNS resolvers to evade DNS monitoring tools.

Name: Imminent Monitor
Description: Imminent Monitor  has a feature to disable Windows Task Manager.

Name: Indrik Spider
Description: Indrik Spider  used  PsExec  to leverage Windows Defender to disable scanning of all downloaded files and to restrict real-time monitoring.

Name: JPIN
Description: JPIN  can lower security settings by changing Registry keys.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has been observed turning off Windows Security Center and can hide the AV software window from the view of the infected user.

Name: KOCTOPUS
Description: KOCTOPUS  will attempt to delete or disable all Registry keys and scheduled tasks related to Microsoft Security Defender and Security Essentials.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  malware TangoDelta attempts to terminate various processes associated with McAfee. Additionally,  Lazarus Group  malware SHARPKNOT disables the Microsoft Windows System Event Notification and Alerter services.     .

Name: LockerGoga
Description: LockerGoga  installation has been immediately preceded by a "task kill" command in order to disable anti-virus.

Name: macOS.OSAMiner
Description: macOS.OSAMiner  has searched for the Activity Monitor process in the System Events process list and kills the process if running.  macOS.OSAMiner  also searches the operating system's  install.log  for apps matching its hardcoded list, killing all matching process names.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has disabled antivirus services on targeted systems in order to upload malicious payloads.

Name: Maze
Description: Maze  has disabled dynamic analysis and other security tools including IDA debugger, x32dbg, and OllyDbg.   It has also disabled Windows Defender's Real-Time Monitoring feature and attempted to disable endpoint protection services.

Name: MegaCortex
Description: MegaCortex  was used to kill endpoint security processes.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has a function to kill processes associated with defenses and can prevent certain processes from launching.

Name: Meteor
Description: Meteor  can attempt to uninstall Kaspersky Antivirus or remove the Kaspersky license; it can also add all files and folders related to the attack to the Windows Defender exclusion list.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  can disable the system's local proxy settings.

Name: NanHaiShu
Description: NanHaiShu  can change Internet Explorer settings to reduce warnings about malware activity.

Name: NanoCore
Description: NanoCore  can modify the victim's anti-virus.

Name: Netwalker
Description: Netwalker  can detect and terminate active security software-related processes on infected systems.

Name: Night Dragon
Description: During  Night Dragon , threat actors disabled anti-virus and anti-spyware tools in some instances on the victim’s machines. The actors also disabled proxy settings to allow direct communication from victims to the Internet.

Name: POWERSTATS
Description: POWERSTATS  can disable Microsoft Office Protected View by changing Registry keys.

Name: Proton
Description: Proton  kills security tools like Wireshark that are running.

Name: Putter Panda
Description: Malware used by  Putter Panda  attempts to terminate processes corresponding to two components of Sophos Anti-Virus (SAVAdminService.exe and SavService.exe).

Name: Pysa
Description: Pysa  has the capability to stop antivirus services and disable Windows Defender.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  has the ability to modify the Registry to add its binaries to the Windows Defender exclusion list.

Name: Ragnar Locker
Description: Ragnar Locker  has attempted to terminate/stop processes and services associated with endpoint security products.

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  can connect to and disable the Symantec server on the victim's network.

Name: RobbinHood
Description: RobbinHood  will search for Windows services that are associated with antivirus software on the system and kill the process.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  used scripts which detected and uninstalled antivirus software.

Name: RunningRAT
Description: RunningRAT  kills antimalware running process.

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  has stopped services related to anti-virus.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY 's  amsiPatch.py  module can disable Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI) functions.

Name: Skidmap
Description: Skidmap  has the ability to set SELinux to permissive mode.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used the service control manager on a remote system to disable services associated with security monitoring products.

Name: SslMM
Description: SslMM  identifies and kills anti-malware processes.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  can add directories used by the malware to the Windows Defender exclusions list to prevent detection.

Name: SUNBURST
Description: SUNBURST  attempted to disable software security services following checks against a FNV-1a + XOR hashed hardcoded blocklist.

Name: TA2541
Description: TA2541   has attempted to disable built-in security protections such as Windows AMSI.

Name: TA505
Description: TA505  has used malware to disable Windows Defender.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has disabled and uninstalled security tools such as Alibaba, Tencent, and BMC cloud monitoring agents on cloud-based infrastructure.

Name: ThiefQuest
Description: ThiefQuest  uses the function  kill_unwanted  to obtain a list of running processes and kills each process matching a list of security related processes.

Name: TinyZBot
Description: TinyZBot  can disable Avira anti-virus.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  can disable Windows Defender.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has used a AMSI bypass, which patches the in-memory amsi.dll, in PowerShell scripts to bypass Windows antimalware products.

Name: Unknown Logger
Description: Unknown Logger  has functionality to disable security tools, including Kaspersky, BitDefender, and MalwareBytes.

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  can disarm Windows Defender during the UAC process to evade detection.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  can download and execute AdvancedRun.exe to disable the Windows Defender Theat Protection service and set an exclusion path for the C:\ drive.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has shut down or uninstalled security applications on victim systems that might prevent ransomware from executing.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  can kill AV products' processes.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use application control where appropriate, especially regarding the execution of tools outside of the organization's security policies (such as rootkit removal tools) that have been abused to impair system defenses. Ensure that only approved security applications are used and running on enterprise systems.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Ensure proper process and file permissions are in place to prevent adversaries from disabling or interfering with security services.

Name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Description: Ensure proper Registry permissions are in place to prevent adversaries from disabling or interfering with security services.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Ensure proper user permissions are in place to prevent adversaries from disabling or interfering with security services.

Name: Pacu
Description: Pacu  can allowlist IP addresses in AWS GuardDuty.

Name: Audit
Description: Routinely check account role permissions to ensure only expected users and roles have permission to modify cloud firewalls.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Ensure least privilege principles are applied to Identity and Access Management (IAM) security policies.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  have created firewall exemptions on specific ports, including ports 443, 6443, 8443, and 9443.

Name: BACKSPACE
Description: The "ZR" variant of  BACKSPACE  will check to see if known host-based firewalls are installed on the infected systems.  BACKSPACE  will attempt to establish a C2 channel, then will examine open windows to identify a pop-up from the firewall software and will simulate a mouse-click to allow the connection to proceed.

Name: BADCALL
Description: BADCALL  disables the Windows firewall before binding to a port.

Name: Carbanak
Description: Carbanak  may use  netsh  to add local firewall rule exceptions.

Name: CookieMiner
Description: CookieMiner  has checked for the presence of "Little Snitch", macOS network monitoring and application firewall software, stopping and exiting if it is found.

Name: Cyclops Blink
Description: Cyclops Blink  can modify the Linux iptables firewall to enable C2 communication via a stored list of port numbers.

Name: DarkComet
Description: DarkComet  can disable Security Center functions like the Windows Firewall.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has disabled host-based firewalls. The group has also globally opened port 3389.

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  can block the Deibold Warsaw GAS Tecnologia security tool at the firewall level.

Name: H1N1
Description: H1N1  kills and disables services for Windows Firewall.

Name: HARDRAIN
Description: HARDRAIN  opens the Windows Firewall to modify incoming connections.

Name: HOPLIGHT
Description: HOPLIGHT  has modified the firewall using  netsh .

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  has a command to disable routing and the Firewall on the victim’s machine.

Name: Kasidet
Description: Kasidet  has the ability to change firewall settings to allow a plug-in to be downloaded.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has been observed disabling the system firewall.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Various  Lazarus Group  malware modifies the Windows firewall to allow incoming connections or disable it entirely using  netsh .

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has added the following rule to a victim's Windows firewall to allow RDP traffic -  "netsh" advfirewall firewall add rule name="Terminal Server" dir=in action=allow protocol=TCP localport=3389 .

Name: Moses Staff
Description: Moses Staff  has used batch scripts that can disable the Windows firewall on specific remote machines.

Name: NanoCore
Description: NanoCore  can modify the victim's firewall.

Name: netsh
Description: netsh  can be used to disable local firewall settings.

Name: njRAT
Description: njRAT  has modified the Windows firewall to allow itself to communicate through the firewall.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used PowerShell to add and delete rules in the Windows firewall.

Name: PyDCrypt
Description: PyDCrypt  has modified firewall rules to allow incoming SMB, NetBIOS, and RPC connections using  netsh.exe  on remote machines.

Name: Remsec
Description: Remsec  can add or remove applications or ports on the Windows firewall or disable it entirely.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  used scripts which killed processes and added firewall rules to block traffic related to other cryptominers.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used  netsh  to configure firewall rules that limited certain UDP outbound packets.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has disabled  iptables .

Name: TYPEFRAME
Description: TYPEFRAME  can open the Windows Firewall on the victim’s machine to allow incoming connections.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  can disable the firewall by modifying the registry key  HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\SharedAccess\Parameters\FirewallPolicy\StandardProfile .

Name: Audit
Description: Routinely check account role permissions to ensure only expected users and roles have permission to modify system firewalls.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Ensure proper process and file permissions are in place to prevent adversaries from disabling or modifying firewall settings.

Name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Description: Ensure proper Registry permissions are in place to prevent adversaries from disabling or modifying firewall settings.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Ensure proper user permissions are in place to prevent adversaries from disabling or modifying firewall settings.

Name: Pacu
Description: Pacu  can disable or otherwise restrict various AWS logging services, such as AWS CloudTrail and VPC flow logs.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Configure default account policy to enable logging. Manage policies to ensure only necessary users have permissions to make changes to logging policies.

Name: 2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  disabled event logging on compromised systems.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has executed scripts to disable the event log service.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29 , used  AUDITPOL  to prevent the collection of audit logs.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  has used appcmd.exe to disable logging on a victim server.

Name: Wevtutil
Description: Wevtutil  can be used to disable specific event logs on the system.

Name: Audit
Description: Consider periodic review of  auditpol  settings for Administrator accounts and perform dynamic baselining on SIEM(s) to investigate potential malicious activity. Also ensure that the EventLog service and its threads are properly running.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Ensure proper process and file permissions are in place to prevent adversaries from disabling or interfering with logging or deleting or modifying .evtx logging files. Ensure .evtx files, which are located at  C:\Windows\system32\Winevt\Logs  , have the proper file permissions for limited, legitimate access and audit policies for detection.

Name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Description: Ensure proper Registry permissions are in place to prevent adversaries from disabling or interfering logging. The addition of the MiniNT registry key disables Event Viewer.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Ensure proper user permissions are in place to prevent adversaries from disabling or interfering with logging.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has prepended a space to all of their terminal commands to operate without leaving traces in the HISTCONTROL environment.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  can bypass ScriptBlock logging to execute unmanaged PowerShell code from memory.

Name: Environment Variable Permissions
Description: Prevent users from changing the  HISTCONTROL ,  HISTFILE , and  HISTFILESIZE  environment variables.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Make sure that the  HISTCONTROL  environment variable is set to "ignoredups" instead of "ignoreboth" or "ignorespace".

Name: AvosLocker
Description: AvosLocker  can restart a compromised machine in safe mode.

Name: Black Basta
Description: Black Basta  can reboot victim machines in safe mode with networking via  bcdedit /set safeboot network .

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  can force a reboot in safe mode with networking.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Restrict administrator accounts to as few individuals as possible, following least privilege principles, that may be abused to remotely boot a machine in safe mode.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: Ensure that endpoint defenses run in safe mode.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use application controls to mitigate installation and use of payloads that may be utilized to spoof security alerting.

Name: Audit
Description: Routinely check account role permissions to ensure only expected users and roles have permission to modify logging settings. To ensure Audit rules can not be modified at runtime, add the  auditctl -e 2  as the last command in the audit.rules files. Once started, any attempt to change the configuration in this mode will be audited and denied. The configuration can only be changed by rebooting the machine.

Name: User Account Management
Description: An adversary must already have root level access on the local system to make full use of this technique; be sure to restrict users and accounts to the least privileges they require.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Consider removing previous versions of tools that are unnecessary to the environment when possible.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: Consider implementing policies on internal web servers, such HTTP Strict Transport Security, that enforce the use of HTTPS/network traffic encryption to prevent insecure connections.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has cleared event logs, including by using the commands  wevtutil cl System  and  wevtutil cl Security .

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has cleared select event log entries.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  clears Window Event logs and Sysmon logs from the system.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  attempted to remove evidence of some of its activity by clearing Windows security and system events.

Name: BlackCat
Description: BlackCat  can clear Windows event logs using  wevtutil.exe .

Name: BlackEnergy
Description: The  BlackEnergy  component KillDisk is capable of deleting Windows Event Logs.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has cleared event logs on compromised hosts.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has cleared Windows event logs and other logs produced by tools they used, including system, security, terminal services, remote services, and audit logs. The actors also deleted specific Registry keys.

Name: FIN5
Description: FIN5  has cleared event logs from victims.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has cleared logs during post compromise cleanup activities.

Name: FinFisher
Description: FinFisher  clears the system event logs using   OpenEventLog/ClearEventLog APIs  .

Name: gh0st RAT
Description: gh0st RAT  is able to wipe event logs.

Name: HermeticWiper
Description: HermeticWiper  can overwrite the  C:\Windows\System32\winevt\Logs  file on a targeted system.

Name: HermeticWizard
Description: HermeticWizard  has the ability to use  wevtutil cl system  to clear event logs.

Name: Hydraq
Description: Hydraq  creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can clear all system event logs.

Name: Indrik Spider
Description: Indrik Spider  has used  Cobalt Strike  to empty log files.

Name: KillDisk
Description: KillDisk  deletes Application, Security, Setup, and System Windows Event Logs.

Name: Lucifer
Description: Lucifer  can clear and remove event logs.

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can delete Windows Event logs by invoking the  OpenEventLogW  and  ClearEventLogW  functions.

Name: Meteor
Description: Meteor  can use  Wevtutil  to remove Security, System and Application Event Viewer logs.

Name: NotPetya
Description: NotPetya  uses  wevtutil  to clear the Windows event logs.

Name: Olympic Destroyer
Description: Olympic Destroyer  will attempt to clear the System and Security event logs using  wevtutil .

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , the threat actors deleted all Windows system and security event logs using  /Q /c wevtutil cl system  and  /Q /c wevtutil cl security .

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  has a module to clear event logs with PowerShell.

Name: RunningRAT
Description: RunningRAT  contains code to clear event logs.

Name: SynAck
Description: SynAck  clears event logs.

Name: Wevtutil
Description: Wevtutil  can be used to clear system and security event logs from the system.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  has a command to clear system event logs.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: Obfuscate/encrypt event files locally and in transit to avoid giving feedback to an adversary.

Name: Remote Data Storage
Description: Automatically forward events to a log server or data repository to prevent conditions in which the adversary can locate and manipulate data on the local system. When possible, minimize time delay on event reporting to avoid prolonged storage on the local system.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Protect generated event files that are stored locally with proper permissions and authentication and limit opportunities for adversaries to increase privileges by preventing Privilege Escalation opportunities.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can disconnect previously connected remote drives.

Name: Net
Description: The  net use \system\share /delete  command can be used in  Net  to remove an established connection to a network share.

Name: RobbinHood
Description: RobbinHood  disconnects all network shares from the computer with the command  net use * /DELETE /Y .

Name: APT32

Name: BITTER

Name: C0010

Name: SideCopy

Name: TA2541

Name: TA505

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has uploaded backdoored Docker images to Docker Hub.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  has hosted malicious payloads on Dropbox.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Name: APT41

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has used history -c to clear script shell logs.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has cleared command history with  history -c .

Name: Environment Variable Permissions
Description: Making the environment variables associated with command history read only may ensure that the history is preserved.

Name: Remote Data Storage
Description: Forward logging of historical data to remote data store and centralized logging solution to preserve historical command line log data.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Preventing users from deleting or writing to certain files can stop adversaries from maliciously altering their  ~/.bash_history  or  ConsoleHost_history.txt  files.

Name: Goopy
Description: Goopy  has the ability to delete emails used for C2 once the content has been copied.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  removed evidence of email export requests using  Remove-MailboxExportRequest .

Name: Audit
Description: In an Exchange environment, Administrators can use  Get-TransportRule  /  Remove-TransportRule  to discover and remove potentially malicious transport rules.

Name: Remote Data Storage
Description: Automatically forward mail data and events to a log server or data repository to prevent conditions in which the adversary can locate and manipulate data on the local system. When possible, minimize time delay on event reporting to avoid prolonged storage on the local system.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Protect generated event files that are stored locally with proper permissions and authentication and limit opportunities for adversaries to increase privileges by preventing Privilege Escalation opportunities.

Name: MacMa
Description: MacMa  can clear possible malware traces such as application logs.

Name: Proton
Description: Proton  removes logs from  /var/logs  and  /Library/logs .

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  has cleared log files within the /var/log/ folder.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has removed system logs from  /var/log/syslog .

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: Obfuscate/encrypt event files locally and in transit to avoid giving feedback to an adversary.

Name: Remote Data Storage
Description: Automatically forward events to a log server or data repository to prevent conditions in which the adversary can locate and manipulate data on the local system. When possible, minimize time delay on event reporting to avoid prolonged storage on the local system.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Protect generated event files that are stored locally with proper permissions and authentication and limit opportunities for adversaries to increase privileges by preventing Privilege Escalation opportunities.

Name: 2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  utilized  net use  to connect to network shares.

Name: Anchor
Description: Anchor  can support windows execution via SMB shares.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has mapped network drives using  Net  and administrator credentials.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  will copy files over to Windows Admin Shares (like ADMIN$) as part of lateral movement.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  used  Net  to use Windows' hidden network shares to copy their tools to remote machines for execution.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used SMB for lateral movement.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  has transferred implant files using Windows Admin Shares.

Name: BlackEnergy

Name: Blue Mockingbird
Description: Blue Mockingbird  has used Windows Explorer to manually copy malicious files to remote hosts over SMB.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  has the ability to use SMB to pivot in compromised networks.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has used Windows admin shares to move laterally.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can use Window admin shares (C$ and ADMIN$) for lateral movement.

Name: Conficker

Name: Conti

Name: Diavol

Name: Duqu

The remote host is then infected by using the compromised credentials to schedule a task on remote machines that executes the malware.

Name: Emotet
Description: Emotet  has leveraged the Admin$, C$, and IPC$ shares for lateral movement.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has leveraged SMB to move laterally within a compromised network via application servers and SQL servers.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has attempted to map to C$ on enumerated hosts to test the scope of their current credentials/context.  FIN8  has also used smbexec from the  Impacket  suite for lateral movement.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has used valid accounts to access SMB shares.

Name: HermeticWizard
Description: HermeticWizard  can use a list of hardcoded credentials to to authenticate via NTLMSSP to the SMB shares on remote systems.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  actors have been known to copy files to the network shares of other computers to move laterally.

Name: Kwampirs
Description: Kwampirs  copies itself over network shares to move laterally on a victim network.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  malware SierraAlfa accesses the  ADMIN$  share via SMB to conduct lateral movement.

Name: Lucifer
Description: Lucifer  can infect victims by brute forcing SMB.

Name: Moses Staff
Description: Moses Staff  has used batch scripts that can enable SMB on a compromised host.

Name: Net
Description: Lateral movement can be done with  Net  through  net use  commands to connect to the on remote systems.

Name: Net Crawler
Description: Net Crawler  uses Windows admin shares to establish authenticated sessions to remote systems over SMB as part of lateral movement.

Name: NotPetya
Description: NotPetya  can use  PsExec , which interacts with the  ADMIN$  network share to execute commands on remote systems.

Name: Olympic Destroyer
Description: Olympic Destroyer  uses  PsExec  to interact with the  ADMIN$  network share to execute commands on remote systems.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used  Impacket 's smbexec.py as well as accessing the C$ and IPC$ shares to move laterally.

Name: Orangeworm
Description: Orangeworm  has copied its backdoor across open network shares, including ADMIN$, C$WINDOWS, D$WINDOWS, and E$WINDOWS.

Name: PsExec
Description: PsExec , a tool that has been used by adversaries, writes programs to the  ADMIN$  network share to execute commands on remote systems.

Name: Regin
Description: The  Regin  malware platform can use Windows admin shares to move laterally.

Name: Royal
Description: Royal  can use SMB to connect to move laterally.

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  has used the C$ network share for lateral movement.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has copied payloads to the  ADMIN$  share of remote systems and run  net use  to connect to network shares.

Name: Shamoon
Description: Shamoon  accesses network share(s), enables share access to the target device, copies an executable payload to the target system, and uses a  Scheduled Task/Job  to execute the malware.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used administrative accounts to connect over SMB to targeted users.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  propagates to available network shares.

Name: Threat Group-1314
Description: Threat Group-1314  actors mapped network drives using  net use .

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  used  net use  commands to connect to lateral systems within a network.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used SMB to drop Cobalt Strike Beacon on a domain controller for lateral movement.

Name: Zox
Description: Zox  has the ability to use SMB for communication.

Name: zwShell

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Consider using the host firewall to restrict file sharing communications such as SMB.

Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Description: Consider disabling Windows administrative shares.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Do not reuse local administrator account passwords across systems. Ensure password complexity and uniqueness such that the passwords cannot be cracked or guessed.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Deny remote use of local admin credentials to log into systems. Do not allow domain user accounts to be in the local Administrators group multiple systems.

Name: HyperBro

Name: InnaputRAT

Name: jRAT

Name: Kazuar

Name: Kimsuky

Name: Kivars

Name: Komplex

Name: KONNI
Description: KONNI  can delete files.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  malware has deleted files in various ways, including "suicide scripts" to delete malware binaries from the victim.  Lazarus Group  also uses secure file deletion to delete files from the victim.

Name: LightNeuron
Description: LightNeuron  has a function to delete files.

Name: Linfo

Name: LiteDuke

Name: MESSAGETAP

Name: Metador

Name: metaMain

Name: Metamorfo

Name: Meteor

Name: Milan
Description: Milan  can delete files via  C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c ping 1.1.1.1 -n 1 -w 3000 > Nul & rmdir /s /q .

Name: Misdat
Description: Misdat  is capable of deleting the backdoor file.

Name: MoonWind

Name: More_eggs
Description: More_eggs  can remove itself from a system.

Name: Mori

Name: Mosquito

Name: MURKYTOP
Description: MURKYTOP  has the capability to delete local files.

Name: Mustang Panda

Name: NanHaiShu

Name: Nebulae
Description: Nebulae  has the ability to delete files and directories.

Name: njRAT
Description: njRAT  is capable of deleting files.

Name: NOKKI
Description: NOKKI  can delete files to cover tracks.

Name: OceanSalt
Description: OceanSalt  can delete files from the system.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has deleted files associated with their payload after execution.

Name: Okrum
Description: Okrum 's backdoor deletes files after they have been successfully uploaded to C2 servers.

Name: OopsIE
Description: OopsIE  has the capability to delete files and scripts from the victim's machine.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  removed all previously delivered files from a compromised computer.

Name: Operation Honeybee
Description: During  Operation Honeybee , the threat actors used batch files that reduced their fingerprint on a compromised system by deleting malware-related files.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , the threat actors consistently removed traces of their activity by first overwriting a file using  /c cd /d c:\windows\temp\ & copy \\<IP ADDRESS>\c$\windows\system32\devmgr.dll \\<IP ADDRESS>\c$\windows\temp\LMAKSW.ps1 /y  and then deleting the overwritten file using  /c cd /d c:\windows\temp\ & del \\<IP ADDRESS>\c$\windows\temp\LMAKSW.ps1 .

Name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D  has a command to delete a file from the system.  OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D  deletes the app bundle and dropper after execution.

Name: OutSteel
Description: OutSteel  can delete itself following the successful execution of a follow-on payload.

Name: P.A.S. Webshell

Name: Pasam
Description: Pasam  creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can delete files.

Name: Patchwork
Description: Patchwork  removed certain files and replaced them so they could not be retrieved.

Name: Pay2Key

Name: PcShare

Name: Penquin

Name: Pillowmint

Name: POWERSTATS

Name: Prikormka

Name: ProLock

Name: Proton

Name: Proxysvc

Name: Pteranodon

Name: PUNCHBUGGY
Description: PUNCHBUGGY  can delete files written to disk.

Name: PyDCrypt
Description: PyDCrypt  will remove all created artifacts such as dropped executables.

Name: Pysa
Description: Pysa  has deleted batch files after execution.

Name: QakBot

Name: QUADAGENT
Description: QUADAGENT  has a command to delete its Registry key and scheduled task.

Name: RainyDay
Description: RainyDay  has the ability to uninstall itself by deleting its service and files.

Name: RCSession
Description: RCSession  can remove files from a targeted system.

Name: RDAT

Name: RDFSNIFFER
Description: RDFSNIFFER  has the capability of deleting local files.

Name: Reaver
Description: Reaver  deletes the original dropped file from the victim.

Name: RedLeaves
Description: RedLeaves  can delete specified files.

Name: Remsec

Name: REvil

Name: Rising Sun

Name: Rocke

Name: ROKRAT
