Name: Pysa
Description: Pysa  can perform OS credential dumping using  Mimikatz .

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has used its plainpwd tool, a modified version of  Mimikatz , and comsvcs.dll to dump Windows credentials from system memory.

Name: Silence
Description: Silence  has used the Farse6.1 utility (based on  Mimikatz ) to extract credentials from lsass.exe.

Name: SILENTTRINITY

Name: TEMP.Veles
Description: TEMP.Veles  has used  Mimikatz  and a custom tool, SecHack, to harvest credentials.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  actors have used a modified version of  Mimikatz  called Wrapikatz to dump credentials. They have also dumped credentials from domain controllers.

Name: Volt Typhoon

Name: Whitefly

Description: On Windows 10, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to secure LSASS and prevent credential stealing.

Name: Credential Access Protection

Name: Active Directory Configuration
Description: Consider adding users to the "Protected Users" Active Directory security group. This can help limit the caching of users' plaintext credentials.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Consider limiting the number of cached credentials (HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\Current Version\Winlogon\cachedlogonscountvalue)

Name: Password Policies
Description: Ensure that local administrator accounts have complex, unique passwords across all systems on the network.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Do not put user or admin domain accounts in the local administrator groups across systems unless they are tightly controlled, as this is often equivalent to having a local administrator account with the same password on all systems. Follow best practices for design and administration of an enterprise network to limit privileged account use across administrative tiers.

Name: User Training
Description: Limit credential overlap across accounts and systems by training users and administrators not to use the same password for multiple accounts.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: Use anti-spoofing and email authentication mechanisms to filter messages based on validity checks of the sender domain (using SPF) and integrity of messages (using DKIM). Name: Software Configuration
Description: Use anti-spoofing and email authentication mechanisms to filter messages based on validity checks of the sender domain (using SPF) and integrity of messages (using DKIM). Enabling these mechanisms within an organization (through policies such as DMARC) may enable recipients (intra-org and cross domain) to perform similar message filtering and validation.   Furthermore, policies may enforce / install browser extensions that protect against IDN and homograph attacks. Browser password managers may also be configured to only populate credential fields when the URL matches that of the original, legitimate site.

Name: User Training
Description: Users can be trained to identify social engineering techniques and spearphishing attempts. Additionally, users may perform visual checks of the domains they visit; however, homographs in ASCII and in IDN domains and URL schema obfuscation may render manual checks difficult. Phishing training and other cybersecurity training may raise awareness to check URLs before visiting the sites.

Name: C0011

Name: C0021

Name: Earth Lusca

Name: Elderwood

Name: Ember Bear

Name: EXOTIC LILY

Name: FIN4

Name: FIN8

Name: Grandoreiro

Name: GuLoader

Name: Hancitor

Name: Kimsuky

Name: KOCTOPUS

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has sent malicious links to victims via email.

Name: LazyScripter
Description: LazyScripter  has used spam emails that contain a link that redirects the victim to download a malicious document.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has sent spearphishing emails with links, often using a fraudulent lookalike domain and stolen branding.

Name: LuminousMoth

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  has sent phishing emails that contain a link to an external server with ZIP and RAR archives.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has sent malicious URL links through email to victims. In some cases the URLs were shortened or linked to Word documents with malicious macros that executed PowerShells scripts to download  Pupy .

Name: Melcoz
Description: Melcoz  has been spread through malicious links embedded in e-mails.

Name: Mofang
Description: Mofang  delivered spearphishing emails with malicious links included.

Name: Molerats
Description: Molerats  has sent phishing emails with malicious links included.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has sent targeted spearphishing e-mails with malicious links.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has delivered malicious links to their intended targets.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  has been spread via e-mail campaigns utilizing malicious links.

Name: Night Dragon
Description: During  Night Dragon , threat actors sent spearphishing emails containing links to compromised websites where malware was downloaded.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has sent spearphising emails with malicious links to potential victims.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  sent malicious OneDrive links with fictitious job offer advertisements via email.

Name: Operation Dust Storm
Description: During  Operation Dust Storm , the threat actors sent spearphishing emails containing a malicious link.

Name: Operation Spalax
Description: During  Operation Spalax , the threat actors sent phishing emails to victims that contained a malicious link.

Name: OutSteel
Description: OutSteel  has been distributed through malicious links contained within spearphishing emails.

Name: Patchwork
Description: Patchwork  has used spearphishing with links to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.

Name: Pony

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  has spread through emails with malicious links.

Name: Saint Bot

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has crafted phishing emails containing malicious hyperlinks.

Name: Sidewinder
Description: Sidewinder  has sent e-mails with malicious links often crafted for specific targets.

Name: Snip3

Name: SpicyOmelette
Description: SpicyOmelette  has been distributed via emails containing a malicious link that appears to be a PDF document.

Name: Squirrelwaffle
Description: Squirrelwaffle  has been distributed through phishing emails containing a malicious URL.

Name: TA2541
Description: TA2541  has used spearphishing e-mails with malicious links to deliver malware.

Name: TA505
Description: TA505  has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious links.

Name: Transparent Tribe
Description: Transparent Tribe  has embedded links to malicious downloads in e-mails.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  has been delivered via malicious links in phishing e-mails.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  attempted to trick targets into clicking on a link featuring a seemingly legitimate domain from Adobe.com to download their malware and gain initial access.

Name: Valak
Description: Valak  has been delivered via malicious links in e-mail.

Name: Windshift
Description: Windshift  has sent spearphishing emails with links to harvest credentials and deliver malware.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has sent phishing emails containing a link to an actor-controlled Google Drive document or other free online file hosting services.

Name: ZIRCONIUM
Description: ZIRCONIUM  has used malicious links in e-mails to deliver malware.

Name: Audit
Description: Audit applications and their permissions to ensure access to data and resources are limited based upon necessity and principle of least privilege.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: Determine if certain websites that can be used for spearphishing are necessary for business operations and consider blocking access if activity cannot be monitored well or if it poses a significant risk.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: Use anti-spoofing and email authentication mechanisms to filter messages based on validity checks of the sender domain (using SPF) and integrity of messages (using DKIM). Enabling these mechanisms within an organization (through policies such as DMARC) may enable recipients (intra-org and cross domain) to perform similar message filtering and validation.   . Furthermore, policies may enforce / install browser extensions that protect against IDN and homograph attacks.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Azure AD Administrators apply limitations upon the ability for users to grant consent to unfamiliar or unverified third-party applications.

Name: User Training
Description: Users can be trained to identify social engineering techniques and spearphishing emails with malicious links which includes phishing for consent with OAuth 2.0. Additionally, users may perform visual checks of the domains they visit; however, homographs in ASCII and in IDN domains and URL schema obfuscation may render manual checks difficult. Phishing training and other cybersecurity training may raise awareness to check URLs before visiting the sites.

Name: C0027
Description: During  C0027 ,  Scattered Spider  sent Telegram messages impersonating IT personnel to harvest credentials.

Name: User Training
Description: Users can be trained to identify social engineering techniques and spearphishing attempts.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has used spearphishing with Microsoft Office attachments to enable harvesting of user credentials.

Name: SideCopy
Description: SideCopy  has crafted generic lures for spam campaigns to collect emails and credentials for targeting efforts.

Name: Sidewinder
Description: Sidewinder  has sent e-mails with malicious attachments that lead victims to credential harvesting websites.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: Use anti-spoofing and email authentication mechanisms to filter messages based on validity checks of the sender domain (using SPF) and integrity of messages (using DKIM). Enabling these mechanisms within an organization (through policies such as DMARC) may enable recipients (intra-org and cross domain) to perform similar message filtering and validation.

Name: User Training
Description: Users can be trained to identify social engineering techniques and spearphishing attempts.

Name: Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit
Description: Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit  is a UEFI BIOS rootkit developed by the company Hacking Team to persist remote access software on some targeted systems.

Name: LoJax
Description: LoJax  is a UEFI BIOS rootkit deployed to persist remote access software on some targeted systems.

Name: Trojan.Mebromi
Description: Trojan.Mebromi  performs BIOS modification and can download and execute a file as well as protect itself from removal.

Name: Boot Integrity
Description: Check the integrity of the existing BIOS or EFI to determine if it is vulnerable to modification. Use Trusted Platform Module technology.    Move system's root of trust to hardware to prevent tampering with the SPI flash memory.   Technologies such as Intel Boot Guard can assist with this.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Prevent adversary access to privileged accounts or access necessary to perform this technique.

Name: Update Software
Description: Patch the BIOS and EFI as necessary.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has deployed a bootkit along with  Downdelph  to ensure its persistence on the victim. The bootkit shares code with some variants of  BlackEnergy .

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  deployed Master Boot Record bootkits on Windows systems to hide their malware and maintain persistence on victim systems.

Name: BOOTRASH
Description: BOOTRASH  is a Volume Boot Record (VBR) bootkit that uses the VBR to maintain persistence.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp  has installed a bootkit on the system to maintain persistence.

Name: FinFisher
Description: Some  FinFisher  variants incorporate an MBR rootkit.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  malware WhiskeyAlfa-Three modifies sector 0 of the Master Boot Record (MBR) to ensure that the malware will persist even if a victim machine shuts down.

Name: ROCKBOOT
Description: ROCKBOOT  is a Master Boot Record (MBR) bootkit that uses the MBR to establish persistence.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  can implant malicious code into a compromised device's firmware.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  overwrites the MBR with a bootloader component that performs destructive wiping operations on hard drives and displays a fake ransom note when the host boots.

Name: Boot Integrity
Description: Use Trusted Platform Module technology and a secure or trusted boot process to prevent system integrity from being compromised.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Ensure proper permissions are in place to help prevent adversary access to privileged accounts necessary to install a bootkit.

Name: Cyclops Blink
Description: Cyclops Blink  has maintained persistence by patching legitimate device firmware when it is downloaded, including that of WatchGuard devices.

Name: Equation
Description: Equation  is known to have the capability to overwrite the firmware on hard drives from some manufacturers.

Name: Update Software
Description: Perform regular firmware updates to mitigate risks of exploitation and/or abuse.

Name: Audit
Description: Periodically check the integrity of system image to ensure it has not been modified.

Name: Boot Integrity
Description: Enable secure boot features to validate the digital signature of the boot environment and system image using a special purpose hardware device. If the validation check fails, the device will fail to boot preventing loading of unauthorized software.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific protocols, such as TFTP, can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific technique used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various network configurations.

Name: Audit
Description: Periodically check the integrity of the running configuration and system image to ensure they have not been modified.

Name: Boot Integrity
Description: Enable secure boot features to validate the digital signature of the boot environment and system image using a special purpose hardware device. If the validation check fails, the device will fail to boot preventing loading of unauthorized software.

Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Description: Restrict use of protocols without encryption or authentication mechanisms. Limit access to administrative and management interfaces from untrusted network sources.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific protocols, such as TFTP, can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific technique used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various network configurations.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Follow vendor device hardening best practices to disable unnecessary and unused features and services, avoid using default configurations and passwords, and introduce logging and auditing for detection.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Use of Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting (AAA) systems will limit actions administrators can perform and provide a history of user actions to detect unauthorized use and abuse. TACACS+ can keep control over which commands administrators are permitted to use through the configuration of authentication and command authorization.

Name: Aria-body
Description: Aria-body  has the ability to inject itself into another process such as rundll32.exe and dllhost.exe.

Name: BackdoorDiplomacy
Description: BackdoorDiplomacy  has dropped legitimate software onto a compromised host and used it to execute malicious DLLs.

Name: BADHATCH
Description: BADHATCH  has the ability to execute a malicious DLL by injecting into  explorer.exe  on a compromised machine.

Name: BlackEnergy
Description: BlackEnergy  injects its DLL component into svchost.exe.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: The  Bumblebee  loader can support the  Dij  command which gives it the ability to inject DLLs into the memory of other processes.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors used a DLL named  D8B3.dll  that was injected into the Winlogon process.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp 's bootkit can inject a malicious DLL into the address space of running processes.

Name: Carbon
Description: Carbon  has a command to inject code into a process.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  has the ability to load DLLs via reflective injection.

Name: ComRAT
Description: ComRAT  has injected its orchestrator DLL into explorer.exe.  ComRAT  has also injected its communications module into the victim's default browser to make C2 connections appear less suspicious as all network connections will be initiated by the browser process.

Name: Conti
Description: Conti  has loaded an encrypted DLL into memory and then executes it.

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla  can use a .NET-based DLL named  RunPe6  for process injection.

Name: Derusbi
Description: Derusbi  injects itself into the secure shell (SSH) process.

Name: Duqu
Description: Duqu  will inject itself into different processes to evade detection. The selection of the target process is influenced by the security software that is installed on the system (Duqu will inject into different processes depending on which security suite is installed on the infected host).

Name: Dyre
Description: Dyre  injects into other processes to load modules.

Name: Elise
Description: Elise  injects DLL files into iexplore.exe.

Name: Emissary
Description: Emissary  injects its DLL file into a newly spawned Internet Explorer process.

Name: Emotet
Description: Emotet  has been observed injecting in to Explorer.exe and other processes.

Name: FinFisher
Description: FinFisher  injects itself into various processes depending on whether it is low integrity or high integrity.

Name: FunnyDream
Description: The  FunnyDream  FilepakMonitor component can inject into the Bka.exe process using the  VirtualAllocEx ,  WriteProcessMemory  and  CreateRemoteThread  APIs to load the DLL component.

Name: Gelsemium
Description: Gelsemium  has the ability to inject DLLs into specific processes.

Name: Get2
Description: Get2  has the ability to inject DLLs into processes.

Name: Heyoka Backdoor
Description: Heyoka Backdoor  can inject a DLL into rundll32.exe for execution.

Name: HIDEDRV
Description: HIDEDRV  injects a DLL for  Downdelph  into the explorer.exe process.

Name: IronNetInjector
Description: IronNetInjector  has the ability to inject a DLL into running processes, including the  IronNetInjector  DLL into explorer.exe.

Name: Kazuar
Description: If running in a Windows environment,  Kazuar  saves a DLL to disk that is injected into the explorer.exe process to execute the payload.  Kazuar  can also be configured to inject and execute within specific processes.

Name: Koadic
Description: Koadic  can perform process injection by using a reflective DLL.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: A  Lazarus Group  malware sample performs reflective DLL injection.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has utilized techniques like reflective DLL loading to write a DLL into memory and load a shell that provides backdoor access to the victim.

Name: Lizar
Description: Lizar  has used the PowerKatz plugin that can be loaded into the address space of a PowerShell process through reflective DLL loading.

Name: Matryoshka
Description: Matryoshka  uses reflective DLL injection to inject the malicious library and execute the RAT.

Name: Maze
Description: Maze  has injected the malware DLL into a target process.

Name: MegaCortex
Description: MegaCortex  loads  injecthelper.dll  into a newly created  rundll32.exe  process.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has injected a malicious DLL into the Windows Media Player process (wmplayer.exe).

Name: Mongall
Description: Mongall  can inject a DLL into  rundll32.exe  for execution.

Name: Netwalker
Description: The  Netwalker  DLL has been injected reflectively into the memory of a legitimate running process.

Name: PipeMon
Description: PipeMon  can inject its modules into various processes using reflective DLL loading.

Name: PoisonIvy
Description: PoisonIvy  can inject a malicious DLL into a process.

Name: PowerSploit
Description: PowerSploit  contains a collection of CodeExecution modules that inject code (DLL, shellcode) into a process.

Name: PS1
Description: PS1  can inject its payload DLL Into memory.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  can migrate into another process using reflective DLL injection.

Name: Putter Panda
Description: An executable dropped onto victims by  Putter Panda  aims to inject the specified DLL into a process that would normally be accessing the network, including Outlook Express (msinm.exe), Outlook (outlook.exe), Internet Explorer (iexplore.exe), and Firefox (firefox.exe).

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can use  ImprovedReflectiveDLLInjection  to deploy components.

Name: RARSTONE
Description: After decrypting itself in memory,  RARSTONE  downloads a DLL file from its C2 server and loads it in the memory space of a hidden Internet Explorer process. This "downloaded" file is actually not dropped onto the system.

Name: RATANKBA
Description: RATANKBA  performs a reflective DLL injection using a given pid.

Name: Remsec
Description: Remsec  can perform DLL injection.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  has injected its DLL component into  EhStorAurhn.exe .

Name: SDBbot
Description: SDBbot  has the ability to inject a downloaded DLL into a newly created rundll32.exe process.

Name: ShadowPad
Description: ShadowPad  has injected a DLL into svchost.exe.

Name: Socksbot
Description: Socksbot  creates a suspended svchost process and injects its DLL into it.

Name: SombRAT
Description: SombRAT  can execute  loadfromfile ,  loadfromstorage , and  loadfrommem  to inject a DLL  from disk, storage, or memory respectively.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  injects an entire DLL into an existing, newly created, or preselected trusted process.

Name: Sykipot
Description: Sykipot  injects itself into running instances of outlook.exe, iexplore.exe, or firefox.exe.

Name: TA505
Description: TA505  has been seen injecting a DLL into winword.exe.

Name: Taidoor
Description: Taidoor  can perform DLL loading.

Name: TajMahal
Description: TajMahal  has the ability to inject DLLs for malicious plugins into running processes.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has injected a DLL backdoor into dllhost.exe and svchost.exe.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has used Metasploit to perform reflective DLL injection in order to escalate privileges.

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  can use DLL injection to load embedded files and modules.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has injected malicious DLLs into memory with read, write, and execute permissions.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  is injected into a shared SVCHOST process.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process.

Name: Carbanak
Description: Carbanak  downloads an executable and injects it directly into a new process.

Name: Gorgon Group
Description: Gorgon Group  malware can download a remote access tool,  ShiftyBug , and inject into another process.

Name: GreyEnergy
Description: GreyEnergy  has a module to inject a PE binary into a remote process.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can inject its backdoor as a portable executable into a target process.

Name: Lizar
Description: Lizar  can execute PE files in the address space of the specified process.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke 's miner, "TermsHost.exe", evaded defenses by injecting itself into Windows processes, including Notepad.exe.

Name: Zeus Panda
Description: Zeus Panda  checks processes on the system and if they meet the necessary requirements, it injects into that process.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  performs the injection by attaching its code into the APC queue using NtQueueApcThread API.

Name: BADHATCH
Description: BADHATCH  can inject itself into a new  svchost.exe -k netsvcs  process using the asynchronous procedure call (APC) queue.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  can use asynchronous procedure call (APC) injection to execute commands received from C2.

Name: Carberp
Description: Carberp  has queued an APC routine to explorer.exe by calling ZwQueueApcThread.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has injected malicious code into a new svchost.exe process.

Name: IcedID
Description: IcedID  has used  ZwQueueApcThread  to inject itself into remote processes.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can inject its code into a trusted process via the APC queue.

Name: Pillowmint
Description: Pillowmint  has used the NtQueueApcThread syscall to inject code into svchost.exe.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  has written its payload into a newly-created  EhStorAuthn.exe  process using  ZwWriteVirtualMemory  and executed it using  NtQueueApcThread  and  ZwAlertResumeThread .

Name: Sardonic
Description: Sardonic  can use the  QueueUserAPC  API to execute shellcode on a compromised machine.

Name: TURNEDUP
Description: TURNEDUP  is capable of injecting code into the APC queue of a created  Rundll32  process as part of an "Early Bird injection."

Description: Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process.

Name: Gazer
Description: Gazer  performs thread execution hijacking to inject its orchestrator into a running thread from a remote process.

Name: Trojan.Karagany
Description: Trojan.Karagany  can inject a suspended thread of its own process into a new process and initiate via the  ResumeThread  API.

Name: Waterbear
Description: Waterbear  can use thread injection to inject shellcode into the process of security software.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has injected code into target processes via thread local storage callbacks.

Description: Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Utilize Yama (ex: /proc/sys/kernel/yama/ptrace_scope) to mitigate ptrace based process injection by restricting the use of ptrace to privileged users only. Other mitigation controls involve the deployment of security kernel modules that provide advanced access control and process restrictions such as SELinux, grsecurity, and AppArmor.

Name: Epic
Description: Epic  has overwritten the function pointer in the extra window memory of Explorer's Shell_TrayWnd in order to execute malicious code in the context of the explorer.exe process.

Name: Power Loader
Description: Power Loader  overwrites Explorer’s Shell_TrayWnd extra window memory to redirect execution to a NTDLL function that is abused to assemble and execute a return-oriented programming (ROP) chain and create a malicious thread within Explorer.exe.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can inject into a target process using process doppelgänging.

Name: Leafminer
Description: Leafminer  has used  Process Doppelgänging  to evade security software while deploying tools on compromised systems.

Name: SynAck
Description: SynAck  abuses NTFS transactions to launch and conceal malicious processes.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  has used process hollowing to create and manipulate processes through sections of unmapped memory by reallocating that space with its malicious code.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  can create a new process in a suspended state from a targeted legitimate process in order to unmap its memory and replace it with malicious code.

Name: Azorult
Description: Azorult  can decrypt the payload into memory, create a new suspended process of itself, then inject a decrypted payload to the new process and resume new process execution.

Name: BADNEWS
Description: BADNEWS  has a command to download an .exe and use process hollowing to inject it into a new process.

Name: Bandook
Description: Bandook  has been launched by starting iexplore.exe and replacing it with  Bandook 's payload.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can inject into a target process including Svchost, Explorer, and cmd using process hollowing.

Name: BBSRAT
Description: BBSRAT  has been seen loaded into msiexec.exe through process hollowing to hide its execution.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  can execute binaries through process hollowing.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can use process hollowing for execution.

Name: Denis
Description: Denis  performed process hollowing through the API calls CreateRemoteThread, ResumeThread, and Wow64SetThreadContext.

Name: Dtrack
Description: Dtrack  has used process hollowing shellcode to target a predefined list of processes from  %SYSTEM32% .

Name: Duqu
Description: Duqu  is capable of loading executable code via process hollowing.

Name: Gorgon Group
Description: Gorgon Group  malware can use process hollowing to inject one of its trojans into another process.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used a file injector DLL to spawn a benign process on the victim's system and inject the malicious payload into it via process hollowing.

Name: Lokibot
Description: Lokibot  has used process hollowing to inject itself into legitimate Windows process.

Name: menuPass

Name: NETWIRE
Description: The  NETWIRE  payload has been injected into benign Microsoft executables via process hollowing.

Name: Orz
Description: Some  Orz  versions have an embedded DLL known as MockDll that uses process hollowing and  Regsvr32  to execute another payload.

Name: Patchwork
Description: A  Patchwork  payload uses process hollowing to hide the UAC bypass vulnerability exploitation inside svchost.exe.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can use process hollowing to execute its main payload.

Name: RCSession
Description: RCSession  can launch itself from a hollowed svchost.exe process.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: The  Saint Bot  loader has used API calls to spawn  MSBuild.exe  in a suspended state before injecting the decrypted  Saint Bot  binary into it.

Name: Smoke Loader
Description: Smoke Loader  spawns a new copy of c:\windows\syswow64\explorer.exe and then replaces the executable code in memory with malware.

Name: Snip3
Description: Snip3  can use RunPE to execute malicious payloads within a hollowed Windows process.

Name: TA2541
Description: TA2541  has used process hollowing to execute CyberGate malware.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: A  Threat Group-3390  tool can spawn  svchost.exe  and inject the payload into that process.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  injects into the svchost.exe process.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has used process hollowing to inject into child processes.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  has the ability to inject its fourth stage into a suspended process created by the legitimate Windows utility  InstallUtil.exe .

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  can create a suspended notepad process and write shellcode to delete a file into the suspended process using  NtWriteVirtualMemory .

Description: Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process.

Name: InvisiMole

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has routed traffic over  Tor  and VPN servers to obfuscate their activities.

Name: APT29
Description: A backdoor used by  APT29  created a  Tor  hidden service to forward traffic from the  Tor  client to local ports 3389 (RDP), 139 (Netbios), and 445 (SMB) enabling full remote access from outside the network and has also used TOR.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  has used Tor for C2 communication.

Name: CostaRicto
Description: During  CostaRicto , the threat actors used a layer of proxies to manage C2 communications.

Name: Cyclops Blink
Description: Cyclops Blink  has used  Tor  nodes for C2 traffic.

Name: Dok
Description: Dok  downloads and installs  Tor  via homebrew.

Name: Dridex
Description: Dridex  can use multiple layers of proxy servers to hide terminal nodes in its infrastructure.

Name: FIN4
Description: FIN4  has used Tor to log in to victims' email accounts.

Name: GreyEnergy
Description: GreyEnergy  has used Tor relays for Command and Control servers.

Name: Inception
Description: Inception  used chains of compromised routers to proxy C2 communications between them and cloud service providers.

Name: Industroyer
Description: Industroyer  used  Tor  nodes for C2.

Name: Keydnap
Description: Keydnap  uses a copy of tor2web proxy for HTTPS communications.

Name: Kobalos
Description: Kobalos  can chain together multiple compromised machines as proxies to reach their final targets.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has used multi-hop proxies to disguise the source of their malicious traffic.

Name: MacSpy
Description: MacSpy  uses Tor for command and control.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors executed commands through the installed web shell via  Tor  exit nodes.

Name: Siloscape
Description: Siloscape  uses Tor to communicate with C2.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  can use multiple layers of proxy servers to hide terminal nodes in its infrastructure.

Name: Tor
Description: Traffic traversing the  Tor  network will be forwarded to multiple nodes before exiting the  Tor  network and continuing on to its intended destination.

Name: Uroburos
Description: Uroburos  can use implants on multiple compromised machines to proxy communications through its worldwide P2P network.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has used  Tor  for C2.

Name: WannaCry
Description: WannaCry  uses  Tor  for command and control traffic.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Traffic to known anonymity networks and C2 infrastructure can be blocked through the use of network allow and block lists. It should be noted that this kind of blocking may be circumvented by other techniques like  Domain Fronting .

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  used other victims as proxies to relay command traffic, for instance using a compromised Georgian military email server as a hop point to NATO victims. The group has also used a tool that acts as a proxy to allow C2 even if the victim is behind a router.  APT28  has also used a machine to relay and obscure communications between  CHOPSTICK  and their server.

Name: APT3
Description: An  APT3  downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections for its initial C2.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used various tools to proxy C2 communications.

Name: FIN5
Description: FIN5  maintains access to victim environments by using  FLIPSIDE  to create a proxy for a backup RDP tunnel.

Name: GALLIUM
Description: GALLIUM  used a modified version of  HTRAN  to redirect connections between networks.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  InvisiMole can identify proxy servers used by the victim and use them for C2 communication.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has used multiple proxies to obfuscate network traffic from victims.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has used a global service provider's IP as a proxy for C2 traffic from a victim.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has controlled  POWERSTATS  from behind a proxy network to obfuscate the C2 location.    MuddyWater  has used a series of compromised websites that victims connected to randomly to relay information to command and control (C2).

Name: Mythic
Description: Mythic  can leverage a modified SOCKS5 proxy to tunnel egress C2 traffic.

Name: Okrum
Description: Okrum  can identify proxy servers configured and used by the victim, and use it to make HTTP requests to C2 its server.

Name: POWERSTATS
Description: POWERSTATS  has connected to C2 servers through proxies.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  has a module that can proxy C2 communications.

Name: QUIETEXIT
Description: QUIETEXIT  can proxy traffic via SOCKS.

Name: Regin
Description: Regin  leveraged several compromised universities as proxies to obscure its origin.

Name: ShimRat
Description: ShimRat  can use pre-configured HTTP proxies.

Name: Silence
Description: Silence  has used ProxyBot, which allows the attacker to redirect traffic from the current node to the backconnect server via Sock4\Socks5.

Name: Tonto Team
Description: Tonto Team  has routed their traffic through an external server in order to obfuscate their location.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  has been known to reach a command and control server via one of nine proxy IP addresses.

Name: Winnti for Windows
Description: The  Winnti for Windows  HTTP/S C2 mode can make use of an external proxy.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific C2 protocol used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool C2 signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way as to avoid detection by common defensive tools.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  used custom tools to create SOCK5 and custom protocol proxies between infected hosts.

Name: BACKSPACE
Description: The "ZJ" variant of  BACKSPACE  allows "ZJ link" infections with Internet access to relay traffic from "ZJ listen" to a command server.

Name: CHOPSTICK
Description: CHOPSTICK  used a proxy server between victims and the C2 server.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can be configured to have commands relayed over a peer-to-peer network of infected hosts. This can be used to limit the number of egress points, or provide access to a host without direct internet access.

Name: Drovorub
Description: Drovorub  can use a port forwarding rule on its agent module to relay network traffic through the client module to a remote host on the same network.

Name: Duqu
Description: Duqu  can be configured to have commands relayed over a peer-to-peer network of infected hosts if some of the hosts do not have Internet access.

Name: FatDuke
Description: FatDuke  can used pipes to connect machines with restricted internet access to remote machines via other infected hosts.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has utilized a proxy tool to communicate between compromised assets.

Name: Higaisa
Description: Higaisa  discovered system proxy settings and used them if available.

Name: Hikit
Description: Hikit  supports peer connections.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can function as a proxy to create a server that relays communication between the client and C&C server, or between two clients.

Name: Kazuar
Description: Kazuar  has used internal nodes on the compromised network for C2 communications.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has used a compromised router to serve as a proxy between a victim network's corporate and restricted segments.

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can create a named pipe to listen for and send data to a named pipe-based C2 server.

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  can create a named pipe to listen for and send data to a named pipe-based C2 server.

Name: MiniDuke
Description: MiniDuke  can can use a named pipe to forward communications from one compromised machine with internet access to other compromised machines.

Name: Mythic
Description: Mythic  can leverage a peer-to-peer C2 profile between agents.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors proxied traffic through multiple infected systems.

Name: Pay2Key
Description: Pay2Key  has designated machines in the compromised network to serve as reverse proxy pivot points to channel communications with C2.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used SSH port forwarding capabilities on public-facing systems, and configured at least one instance of  Cobalt Strike  to use a network pipe over SMB.

Name: Strider
Description: Strider  has used local servers with both local network and Internet access to act as internal proxy nodes to exfiltrate data from other parts of the network without direct Internet access.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  installs an RPC server for P2P communications.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has compromised internal network systems to act as a proxy to forward traffic to C2.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has used the built-in  netsh   port proxy  command to create proxies on compromised systems to facilitate access.

Name: Winnti for Windows
Description: The  Winnti for Windows  HTTP/S C2 mode can make use of a local proxy.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific C2 protocol used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool C2 signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way as to avoid detection by common defensive tools.

Name: APT1
Description: The  APT1  group is known to have used RDP during operations.

Description: APT3  enables the Remote Desktop Protocol for persistence.    APT3  has also interacted with compromised systems to browse and copy files through RDP sessions.

Description: APT39  has been seen using RDP for lateral movement and persistence, in some cases employing the rdpwinst tool for mangement of multiple sessions.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  used RDP for lateral movement.

Name: Axiom
Description: Axiom  has used RDP during operations.

Name: Blue Mockingbird

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors used RDP to access specific network hosts of interest.

Name: C0018
Description: During  C0018 , the threat actors opened a variety of ports to establish RDP connections, including ports 28035, 32467, 41578, and 46892.

Name: Carbanak
Description: Carbanak  enables concurrent Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) sessions.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has used RDP to access targeted systems.

Name: Cobalt Group
Description: Cobalt Group  has used Remote Desktop Protocol to conduct lateral movement.

Name: Cobalt Strike

Description: FIN7  has used RDP to move laterally in victim environments.

Description: FIN8  has used RDP for lateral movement.

Name: jRAT

Name: Patchwork

Name: Pupy

Name: Pysa

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: QuasarRAT  has a module for performing remote desktop access.

Name: Revenge RAT

Name: SDBbot

Name: Silence
Description: Silence  has used RDP for lateral movement.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used RDP sessions from public-facing systems to internal servers.

Name: TEMP.Veles

Name: WarzoneRAT

Name: Wizard Spider

Name: zwShell
Description: zwShell  has used RDP for lateral movement.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  has remote desktop functionality.

Name: Audit
Description: Audit the Remote Desktop Users group membership regularly. Remove unnecessary accounts and groups from Remote Desktop Users groups.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable the RDP service if it is unnecessary.

Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Description: Use remote desktop gateways.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Use multi-factor authentication for remote logins.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Do not leave RDP accessible from the internet. Enable firewall rules to block RDP traffic between network security zones within a network.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Change GPOs to define shorter timeouts sessions and maximum amount of time any single session can be active. Change GPOs to specify the maximum amount of time that a disconnected session stays active on the RD session host server.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Consider removing the local Administrators group from the list of groups allowed to log in through RDP.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit remote user permissions if remote access is necessary.

Name: Axiom
Description: Axiom  has targeted victims with remote administration tools including RDP.

Name: WannaCry
Description: WannaCry  enumerates current remote desktop sessions and tries to execute the malware on each session.

Name: Audit
Description: Audit the Remote Desktop Users group membership regularly. Remove unnecessary accounts and groups from Remote Desktop Users groups.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable the RDP service if it is unnecessary.

Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Description: Use remote desktop gateways.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Enable firewall rules to block RDP traffic between network security zones within a network.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Change GPOs to define shorter timeouts sessions and maximum amount of time any single session can be active. Change GPOs to specify the maximum amount of time that a disconnected session stays active on the RD session host server.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Consider removing the local Administrators group from the list of groups allowed to log in through RDP.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit remote user permissions if remote access is necessary.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Ensure that agent forwarding is disabled on systems that do not explicitly require this feature to prevent misuse.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Ensure SSH key pairs have strong passwords and refrain from using key-store technologies such as ssh-agent unless they are properly protected.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Do not allow remote access via SSH as root or other privileged accounts.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Ensure proper file permissions are set and harden system to prevent root privilege escalation opportunities.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has used the meek domain fronting plugin for  Tor  to hide the destination of C2 traffic.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  has the ability to accept a value for HTTP Host Header to enable domain fronting.

Name: meek
Description: meek  uses Domain Fronting to disguise the destination of network traffic as another server that is hosted in the same Content Delivery Network (CDN) as the intended destination.

Name: Mythic
Description: Mythic  supports domain fronting via custom request headers.

Name: SMOKEDHAM
Description: SMOKEDHAM  has used a fronted domain to obfuscate its hard-coded C2 server domain.

Name: SSL/TLS Inspection
Description: If it is possible to inspect HTTPS traffic, the captures can be analyzed for connections that appear to be domain fronting.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has leveraged compromised high-privileged on-premises accounts synced to Office 365 to move laterally into a cloud environment, including through the use of Azure AD PowerShell.

Name: C0027
Description: During  C0027 ,  Scattered Spider  used compromised Azure credentials for credential theft activity and lateral movement to on-premises systems.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Use multi-factor authentication on cloud services whenever possible.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Limit the number of high-privileged domain and cloud accounts, and ensure that these are not used for day-to-day operations. Ensure that on-premises accounts do not have privileged cloud permissions and that isolated, cloud-only accounts are used for managing cloud environments.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: If direct virtual machine connections are not required for administrative use, disable these connection types where feasible.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit which users are allowed to access compute infrastructure via cloud native methods.

Name: APT18
Description: APT18  actors used the native  at  Windows task scheduler tool to use scheduled tasks for execution on a victim network.

Name: at
Description: at  can be used to schedule a task on a system to be executed at a specific date or time.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  has used  at  to register a scheduled task to execute malware during lateral movement.

Name: CrackMapExec
Description: CrackMapExec  can set a scheduled task on the target system to execute commands remotely using  at .

Name: MURKYTOP
Description: MURKYTOP  has the capability to schedule remote AT jobs.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  actors use  at  to schedule tasks to run self-extracting RAR archives, which install  HTTPBrowser  or  PlugX  on other victims on a network.

Name: Audit
Description: Toolkits like the PowerSploit framework contain PowerUp modules that can be used to explore systems for permission weaknesses in scheduled tasks that could be used to escalate privileges.    Windows operating system also creates a registry key specifically associated with the creation of a scheduled task on the destination host at: Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Schedule\TaskCache\Tree\At1.    In Linux and macOS environments, scheduled tasks using  at  can be audited locally, or through centrally collected logging, using syslog, or auditd events from the host.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Configure settings for scheduled tasks to force tasks to run under the context of the authenticated account instead of allowing them to run as SYSTEM. The associated Registry key is located at  HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\SubmitControl . The setting can be configured through GPO: Computer Configuration >  > Windows Settings > Security Settings > Local Policies > Security Options: Domain Controller: Allow server operators to schedule tasks, set to disabled.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Configure the Increase Scheduling Priority option to only allow the Administrators group the rights to schedule a priority process. This can be configured through GPO: Computer Configuration >  > Windows Settings > Security Settings > Local Policies > User Rights Assignment: Increase scheduling priority.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit privileges of user accounts and remediate Privilege Escalation vectors so only authorized administrators can create scheduled tasks on remote systems. In Linux environments, users account-level access to  at  can be managed using  at.allow  and  at.deny  files. Users listed in the at.allow are enabled to schedule actions using at, whereas users listed in at.deny file disabled from the utility.

Name: Agent Tesla

Name: Anchor

Name: AppleJeus

Description: Koadic  has used scheduled tasks to add persistence.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has used  schtasks  for persistence including through the periodic execution of a remote XSL script or a dropped VBS payload.

Name: LitePower
Description: LitePower  can create a scheduled task to enable persistence mechanisms.

Name: Lokibot
Description: Lokibot  embedded the commands  schtasks /Run /TN \Microsoft\Windows\DiskCleanup\SilentCleanup /I  inside a batch script.

Name: Lucifer
Description: Lucifer  has established persistence by creating the following scheduled task  schtasks /create /sc minute /mo 1 /tn QQMusic ^ /tr C:Users\%USERPROFILE%\Downloads\spread.exe /F .

Name: LuminousMoth
Description: LuminousMoth  has created scheduled tasks to establish persistence for their tools.

Name: Machete
Description: The different components of  Machete  are executed by Windows Task Scheduler.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  has created scheduled tasks to maintain  Machete 's persistence.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has used scheduled tasks to establish persistence and execution.

Name: Matryoshka
Description: Matryoshka  can establish persistence by adding a Scheduled Task named "Microsoft Boost Kernel Optimization".

Name: Maze
Description: Maze  has created scheduled tasks using name variants such as "Windows Update Security", "Windows Update Security Patches", and "Google Chrome Security Update", to launch  Maze  at a specific time.

Name: MCMD
Description: MCMD  can use scheduled tasks for persistence.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has used a script (atexec.py) to execute a command on a target machine via Task Scheduler.

Name: Meteor
Description: Meteor  execution begins from a scheduled task named  Microsoft\Windows\Power Efficiency Diagnostics\AnalyzeAll  and it creates a separate scheduled task called  mstask  to run the wiper only once at 23:55:00.

Name: Milan
Description: Milan  can establish persistence on a targeted host with scheduled tasks.

Name: Molerats
Description: Molerats  has created scheduled tasks to persistently run VBScripts.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has used scheduled tasks to establish persistence.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has created a scheduled task to execute additional malicious software, as well as maintain persistence.

Name: Naikon
Description: Naikon  has used schtasks.exe for lateral movement in compromised networks.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can create a scheduled task to establish persistence.

Name: NotPetya
Description: NotPetya  creates a task to reboot the system one hour after infection.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has created scheduled tasks that run a VBScript to execute a payload on victim machines.

Name: Okrum
Description: Okrum 's installer can attempt to achieve persistence by creating a scheduled task.

Name: OopsIE
Description: OopsIE  creates a scheduled task to run itself every three minutes.

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , the threat actors used scheduled tasks to execute batch scripts for lateral movement with the following command:  SCHTASKS /Create /S <IP Address> /U <Username> /p <Password> /SC ONCE /TN test /TR <Path to a Batch File> /ST <Time> /RU SYSTEM.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  created scheduled tasks to set a periodic execution of a remote XSL script.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used scheduled tasks to execute malicious PowerShell code on remote systems.

Name: Patchwork
Description: A  Patchwork  file stealer can run a TaskScheduler DLL to add persistence.

Name: PowerSploit
Description: PowerSploit 's  New-UserPersistenceOption  Persistence argument can be used to establish via a  Scheduled Task/Job .

Name: POWERSTATS
Description: POWERSTATS  has established persistence through a scheduled task using the command  "C:\Windows\system32\schtasks.exe" /Create /F /SC DAILY /ST 12:00 /TN MicrosoftEdge /TR "c:\Windows\system32\wscript.exe C:\Windows\temp\Windows.vbe" .

Name: POWRUNER
Description: POWRUNER  persists through a scheduled task that executes it every minute.

Name: Prestige
Description: Prestige  has been executed on a target system through a scheduled task created by  Sandworm Team  using  Impacket .

Name: Pteranodon
Description: Pteranodon  schedules tasks to invoke its components in order to establish persistence.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  has the ability to create scheduled tasks for persistence.

Name: QUADAGENT
Description: QUADAGENT  creates a scheduled task to maintain persistence on the victim’s machine.

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: QuasarRAT  contains a .NET wrapper DLL for creating and managing scheduled tasks for maintaining persistence upon reboot.

Name: RainyDay
Description: RainyDay  can use scheduled tasks to achieve persistence.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  can schedule tasks via the Windows COM API to maintain persistence.

Name: Rancor
Description: Rancor  launched a scheduled task to gain persistence using the  schtasks /create /sc  command.

Name: Remexi
Description: Remexi  utilizes scheduled tasks as a persistence mechanism.

Name: RemoteCMD
Description: RemoteCMD  can execute commands remotely by creating a new schedule task on the remote system

Name: Revenge RAT
Description: Revenge RAT  schedules tasks to run malicious scripts at different intervals.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  tries to add a scheduled task to establish persistence.

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  can remotely create a scheduled task to execute itself on a system.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  has created a scheduled task named "Maintenance" to establish persistence.

Name: schtasks
Description: schtasks  is used to schedule tasks on a Windows system to run at a specific date and time.

Name: ServHelper
Description: ServHelper  contains modules that will use  schtasks  to carry out malicious operations.

Name: Shamoon
Description: Shamoon  copies an executable payload to the target system by using  SMB/Windows Admin Shares  and then scheduling an unnamed task to execute the malware.

Name: SharpDisco
Description: SharpDisco  can create scheduled tasks to execute reverse shells that read and write data to and from specified SMB shares.

Name: SharpStage
Description: SharpStage  has a persistence component to write a scheduled task for the payload.

Name: Sibot
Description: Sibot  has been executed via a scheduled task.

Name: Silence
Description: Silence  has used scheduled tasks to stage its operation.

Name: Smoke Loader
Description: Smoke Loader  launches a scheduled task.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used  scheduler  and  schtasks  to create new tasks on remote host as part of their lateral movement. They manipulated scheduled tasks by updating an existing legitimate task to execute their tools and then returned the scheduled task to its original configuration.  APT29  also created a scheduled task to maintain  SUNSPOT  persistence when the host booted.

Name: SoreFang
Description: SoreFang  can gain persistence through use of scheduled tasks.

Name: SQLRat
Description: SQLRat  has created scheduled tasks in  %appdata%\Roaming\Microsoft\Templates\ .

Name: Stealth Falcon
Description: Stealth Falcon  malware creates a scheduled task entitled "IE Web Cache" to execute a malicious file hourly.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  schedules a network job to execute two minutes after host infection.

Name: SUGARDUMP
Description: SUGARDUMP  has created scheduled tasks called  MicrosoftInternetExplorerCrashRepoeterTaskMachineUA  and  MicrosoftEdgeCrashRepoeterTaskMachineUA , which were configured to execute  CrashReporter.exe  during user logon.

Name: SVCReady
Description: SVCReady  can create a scheduled task named  RecoveryExTask  to gain persistence.

Name: TA2541
Description: TA2541  has used scheduled tasks to establish persistence for installed tools.

Name: Tarrask
Description: Tarrask  is able to create "hidden" scheduled tasks for persistence.

Name: TEMP.Veles
Description: TEMP.Veles  has used scheduled task XML triggers.

Name: Tomiris
Description: Tomiris  has used  SCHTASKS /CREATE /SC DAILY /TN StartDVL /TR "" /ST 10:00  to establish persistence.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  creates a scheduled task on the system that provides persistence.

Name: Valak
Description: Valak  has used scheduled tasks to execute additional payloads and to gain persistence on a compromised host.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used scheduled tasks to establish persistence for  TrickBot  and other malware.

Name: yty
Description: yty  establishes persistence by creating a scheduled task with the command  SchTasks /Create /SC DAILY /TN BigData /TR " + path_file + "/ST 09:30" .

Name: Zebrocy
Description: Zebrocy  has a command to create a scheduled task for persistence.

Name: zwShell
Description: zwShell  has used SchTasks for execution.

Name: ZxxZ
Description: ZxxZ  has used scheduled tasks for persistence and execution.

Name: Audit
Description: Toolkits like the PowerSploit framework contain PowerUp modules that can be used to explore systems for permission weaknesses in scheduled tasks that could be used to escalate privileges.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Configure settings for scheduled tasks to force tasks to run under the context of the authenticated account instead of allowing them to run as SYSTEM. The associated Registry key is located at HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\SubmitControl. The setting can be configured through GPO: Computer Configuration >  > Windows Settings > Security Settings > Local Policies > Security Options: Domain Controller: Allow server operators to schedule tasks, set to disabled.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Configure the Increase Scheduling Priority option to only allow the Administrators group the rights to schedule a priority process. This can be configured through GPO: Computer Configuration >  > Windows Settings > Security Settings > Local Policies > User Rights Assignment: Increase scheduling priority.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit privileges of user accounts and remediate Privilege Escalation vectors so only authorized administrators can create scheduled tasks on remote systems.

Name: Anchor
Description: Anchor  can install itself as a cron job.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has used cron to create pre-scheduled and periodic background jobs on a Linux system.

Name: Exaramel for Linux
Description: Exaramel for Linux  uses crontab for persistence if it does not have root privileges.

Name: GoldMax
Description: The  GoldMax  Linux variant has used a crontab entry with a  @reboot  line to gain persistence.

Name: Janicab
Description: Janicab  used a cron job for persistence on Mac devices.

Name: Kinsing
Description: Kinsing  has used crontab to download and run shell scripts every minute to ensure persistence.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  can use crontabs to establish persistence.

Name: Penquin
Description: Penquin  can use Cron to create periodic and pre-scheduled background jobs.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  installed a cron job that downloaded and executed files from the C2.

Name: Skidmap
Description: Skidmap  has installed itself via crontab.

Name: SpeakUp
Description: SpeakUp  uses cron tasks to ensure persistence.

Name: Xbash
Description: Xbash  can create a cronjob for persistence if it determines it is on a Linux system.

Name: Audit
Description: Review changes to the  cron  schedule.  cron  execution can be reviewed within the  /var/log  directory. To validate the location of the  cron  log file, check the syslog config at  /etc/rsyslog.conf  or  /etc/syslog.conf

Name: User Account Management
Description: cron  permissions are controlled by  /etc/cron.allow and /etc/cron.deny . If there is a  cron.allow  file, then the user or users that need to use  cron  will need to be listed in the file.  cron.deny  is used to explicitly disallow users from using cron. If neither files exist, then only the super user is allowed to run cron.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Limit access to the root account and prevent users from creating and/or modifying systemd timer unit files.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Restrict read/write access to systemd  .timer  unit files to only select privileged users who have a legitimate need to manage system services.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit user access to system utilities such as 'systemctl' or 'systemd-run' to users who have a legitimate need.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Ensure containers are not running as root by default. In Kubernetes environments, consider defining Pod Security Standards that prevent pods from running privileged containers.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Limit privileges of user accounts and remediate privilege escalation vectors so only authorized administrators can create container orchestration jobs.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has purchased credentials and session tokens from criminal underground forums.

Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls. Efforts should focus on minimizing the amount and sensitivity of data available to external parties.

Name: Application Developer Guidance
Description: Application developers uploading to public code repositories should be careful to avoid publishing sensitive information such as credentials and API keys.

Name: Audit
Description: Scan public code repositories for exposed credentials or other sensitive information before making commits. Ensure that any leaked credentials are removed from the commit history, not just the current latest version of the code.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has searched for vulnerabilities, tools, and geopolitical trends on Google to target victims.

Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls. Efforts should focus on minimizing the amount and sensitivity of data available to external parties.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: For  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  used LinkedIn to identify and target employees within a chosen organization.

Name: LightNeuron

Name: Audit
Description: Regularly check component software on critical services that adversaries may target for persistence to verify the integrity of the systems and identify if unexpected changes have been made.

Name: Code Signing
Description: Ensure all application component binaries are signed by the correct application developers.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Do not allow administrator accounts that have permissions to add component software on these services to be used for day-to-day operations that may expose them to potential adversaries on unprivileged systems.

Name: 2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  used various MS-SQL stored procedures.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  used xp_cmdshell to store and execute SQL code.

Name: Audit
Description: Regularly check component software on critical services that adversaries may target for persistence to verify the integrity of the systems and identify if unexpected changes have been made.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Do not allow administrator accounts that have permissions to add component software on these services to be used for day-to-day operations that may expose them to potential adversaries on unprivileged systems.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has used a modified and obfuscated version of the reGeorg web shell to maintain persistence on a target's Outlook Web Access (OWA) server.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has installed web shells on exploited Microsoft Exchange servers.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has used Web shells to maintain access to victim websites.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has used web shells for persistence or to ensure redundant access.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has installed ANTAK and ASPXSPY web shells.

Name: ASPXSpy
Description: ASPXSpy  is a Web shell. The ASPXTool version used by  Threat Group-3390  has been deployed to accessible servers running Internet Information Services (IIS).

Name: BackdoorDiplomacy
Description: BackdoorDiplomacy  has used web shells to establish an initial foothold and for lateral movement within a victim's system.

Name: C0017
Description: During  C0017 ,  APT41  deployed JScript web shells through the creation of malicious ViewState objects.

Name: China Chopper
Description: China Chopper 's server component is a Web Shell payload.

Name: Deep Panda
Description: Deep Panda  uses Web shells on publicly accessible Web servers to access victim networks.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has commonly created Web shells on victims' publicly accessible email and web servers, which they used to maintain access to a victim network and download additional malicious files.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has utilized obfuscated and open-source web shells such as JspSpy, reGeorg, MiniWebCmdShell, and Vonloesch Jsp File Browser 1.2 to enable remote code execution and to execute commands on compromised web server.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has installed web shells on compromised hosts to maintain access.

Name: GALLIUM
Description: GALLIUM  used Web shells to persist in victim environments and assist in execution and exfiltration.

Name: HAFNIUM
Description: HAFNIUM  has deployed multiple web shells on compromised servers including SIMPLESEESHARP, SPORTSBALL,  China Chopper , and  ASPXSpy .

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used modified versions of open source PHP web shells to maintain access, often adding "Dinosaur" references within the code.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  relies on web shells for an initial foothold as well as persistence into the victim's systems.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has used multiple web shells to gain execution.

Name: Moses Staff
Description: Moses Staff  has dropped a web shell onto a compromised system.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used web shells, often to maintain access to a victim network.

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , the threat actors generated a web shell within a vulnerable Enterprise Resource Planning Web Application Server as a persistence mechanism.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used their own web shells, as well as those previously placed on target systems by other threat actors, for reconnaissance and lateral movement.

Name: OwaAuth
Description: OwaAuth  is a Web shell that appears to be exclusively used by  Threat Group-3390 . It is installed as an ISAPI filter on Exchange servers and shares characteristics with the  China Chopper  Web shell.

Name: P.A.S. Webshell
Description: P.A.S. Webshell  can gain remote access and execution on target web servers.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has used webshells including  P.A.S. Webshell  to maintain access to victim networks.

Name: SEASHARPEE
Description: SEASHARPEE  is a Web shell.

Name: SUPERNOVA
Description: SUPERNOVA  is a Web shell.

Name: TEMP.Veles
Description: TEMP.Veles  has planted Web shells on Outlook Exchange servers.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  has used a variety of Web shells.

Name: Tonto Team
Description: Tonto Team  has used a first stage web shell after compromising a vulnerable Exchange server.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has started a web service in the target host and wait for the adversary to connect, acting as a web shell.

Name: Volatile Cedar
Description: Volatile Cedar  can inject web shell code into a server.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has used webshells, including ones named AuditReport.jspx and iisstart.aspx, in compromised environments.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Consider disabling functions from web technologies such as PHP’s  evaI()  that may be abused for web shells.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Enforce the principle of least privilege by limiting privileges of user accounts so only authorized accounts can modify the web directory.

Name: IceApple
Description: IceApple  is an IIS post-exploitation framework, consisting of 18 modules that provide several functionalities.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  targeted Windows servers running Internet Information Systems (IIS) to install C2 components.

Name: OwaAuth
Description: OwaAuth  has been loaded onto Exchange servers and disguised as an ISAPI filter (owaauth.dll). The IIS w3wp.exe process then loads the malicious DLL.

Name: RGDoor
Description: RGDoor  establishes persistence on webservers as an IIS module.

Name: Audit
Description: Regularly check installed IIS components to verify the integrity of the web server and identify if unexpected changes have been made.

Name: Code Signing
Description: Ensure IIS DLLs and binaries are signed by the correct application developers.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Restrict unallowed ISAPI extensions and filters from running by specifying a list of ISAPI extensions and filters that can run on IIS.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Do not allow administrator accounts that have permissions to add IIS components to be used for day-to-day operations that may expose these permissions to potential adversaries and/or other unprivileged systems.

Name: AppleJeus
Description: AppleJeus 's spearphishing links required user interaction to navigate to the malicious website.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has tricked unwitting recipients into clicking on malicious hyperlinks within emails crafted to resemble trustworthy senders.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has used various forms of spearphishing attempting to get a user to click on a malicous link.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  has lured victims into clicking malicious links delivered through spearphishing.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has lured targets to download a Cobalt Strike beacon by including a malicious link within spearphishing emails.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has lured users to click links to malicious HTML applications delivered via spearphishing emails.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has sent spearphishing emails in an attempt to lure users to click on a malicious link.

Name: BackConfig
Description: BackConfig  has compromised victims via links to URLs hosting malicious content.

Name: Bazar

Name: BlackTech

Name: Bumblebee
