Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has lured victims into clicking a malicious link delivered through spearphishing.

Name: ZIRCONIUM
Description: ZIRCONIUM  has used malicious links in e-mails to lure victims into downloading malware.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: If a link is being visited by a user, network intrusion prevention systems and systems designed to scan and remove malicious downloads can be used to block activity.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: If a link is being visited by a user, block unknown or unused files in transit by default that should not be downloaded or by policy from suspicious sites as a best practice to prevent some vectors, such as .scr, .exe, .pif, .cpl, etc. Some download scanning devices can open and analyze compressed and encrypted formats, such as zip and rar that may be used to conceal malicious files.

Name: User Training
Description: Use user training as a way to bring awareness to common phishing and spearphishing techniques and how to raise suspicion for potentially malicious events.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Name: Audit
Description: Regularly check component software on critical services that adversaries may target for persistence to verify the integrity of the systems and identify if unexpected changes have been made.

Name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Description: Consider using Group Policy to configure and block modifications to Terminal Services parameters in the Registry.

Name: LuminousMoth
Description: LuminousMoth  has created a link to a Dropbox file that has been used in their spear-phishing operations.

Name: Silent Librarian
Description: Silent Librarian  has cloned victim organization login pages and staged them for later use in credential harvesting campaigns.  Silent Librarian  has also made use of a variety of URL shorteners for these staged websites.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can leverage its implementation of  Mimikatz  to obtain and use golden tickets.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  has used  Mimikatz  to generate Kerberos golden tickets.

Name: Mimikatz
Description: Mimikatz 's kerberos module can create golden tickets.

Name: Rubeus
Description: Rubeus  can forge a ticket-granting ticket.

Name: Active Directory Configuration
Description: For containing the impact of a previously generated golden ticket, reset the built-in KRBTGT account password twice, which will invalidate any existing golden tickets that have been created with the KRBTGT hash and other Kerberos tickets derived from it. For each domain, change the KRBTGT account password once, force replication, and then change the password a second time. Consider rotating the KRBTGT account password every 180 days.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Limit domain admin account permissions to domain controllers and limited servers. Delegate other admin functions to separate accounts.

Name: Rubeus
Description: Rubeus  can reveal the credentials of accounts that have Kerberos pre-authentication disabled through AS-REP roasting.

Name: Audit
Description: Kerberos preauthentication is enabled by default. Older protocols might not support preauthentication therefore it is possible to have this setting disabled. Make sure that all accounts have preauthentication whenever possible and audit changes to setting. Windows tools such as PowerShell may be used to easily find which accounts have preauthentication disabled.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: Enable AES Kerberos encryption (or another stronger encryption algorithm), rather than RC4, where possible.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Ensure strong password length (ideally 25+ characters) and complexity for service accounts and that these passwords periodically expire. Also consider using Group Managed Service Accounts or another third party product such as password vaulting.

Name: Pre-compromise
Description: This technique cannot be easily mitigated with preventive controls since it is based on behaviors performed outside of the scope of enterprise defenses and controls.

Name: AADInternals
Description: AADInternals  can be used to forge Kerberos tickets using the password hash of the AZUREADSSOACC account.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can leverage its implementation of  Mimikatz  to obtain and use silver tickets.

Name: Mimikatz
Description: Mimikatz 's kerberos module can create silver tickets.

Name: Rubeus
Description: Rubeus  can create silver tickets.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: Enable AES Kerberos encryption (or another stronger encryption algorithm), rather than RC4, where possible.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Ensure strong password length (ideally 25+ characters) and complexity for service accounts and that these passwords periodically expire.   Also consider using Group Managed Service Accounts or another third party product such as password vaulting.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Limit service accounts to minimal required privileges, including membership in privileged groups such as Domain Administrators.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Enable application control solutions such as AppLocker and/or Device Guard to block the loading of malicious SIP DLLs.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Restrict storage and execution of SIP DLLs to protected directories, such as C:\Windows, rather than user directories.

Name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Description: Ensure proper permissions are set for Registry hives to prevent users from modifying keys related to SIP and trust provider components. Components may still be able to be hijacked to suitable functions already present on disk if malicious modifications to Registry keys are not prevented.

Name: CoinTicker
Description: CoinTicker  downloads the EggShell mach-o binary using curl, which does not set the quarantine flag.

Name: MacMa
Description: MacMa  has removed the  com.apple.quarantineattribute  from the dropped file,  $TMPDIR/airportpaird .

Name: OSX/Shlayer
Description: If running with elevated privileges,  OSX/Shlayer  has used the  spctl  command to disable Gatekeeper protection for a downloaded file.  OSX/Shlayer  can also leverage system links pointing to bash scripts in the downloaded DMG file to bypass Gatekeeper, a flaw patched in macOS 11.3 and later versions.  OSX/Shlayer  has been Notarized by Apple, resulting in successful passing of additional Gatekeeper checks.

Name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D  uses the command  xattr -d com.apple.quarantine  to remove the quarantine file attribute used by Gatekeeper.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  has dropped a malicious applet into an app's  .../Contents/MacOS/  folder of a previously launched app to bypass Gatekeeper's security checks on first launch apps (prior to macOS 13).

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: System settings can prevent applications from running that haven't been downloaded through the Apple Store which can help mitigate some of these issues.

Name: certutil
Description: certutil  can be used to install browser root certificates as a precursor to performing  Adversary-in-the-Middle  between connections to banking websites. Example command:  certutil -addstore -f -user ROOT ProgramData\cert512121.der .

Name: Dok
Description: Dok  installs a root certificate to aid in  Adversary-in-the-Middle  actions using the command  add-trusted-cert -d -r trustRoot -k /Library/Keychains/System.keychain /tmp/filename .

Name: Hikit
Description: Hikit  uses  certmgr.exe -add GlobalSign.cer -c -s -r localMachine Root  and  certmgr.exe -add GlobalSign.cer -c -s -r localMachineTrustedPublisher  to install a self-generated certificate to the local trust store as a root CA and Trusted Publisher.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  can add a certificate to the Windows store.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: Windows Group Policy can be used to manage root certificates and the  Flags  value of  HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\SystemCertificates\Root\ProtectedRoots  can be set to 1 to prevent non-administrator users from making further root installations into their own HKCU certificate store.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: HTTP Public Key Pinning (HPKP) is one method to mitigate potential  Adversary-in-the-Middle  situations where and adversary uses a mis-issued or fraudulent certificate to intercept encrypted communications by enforcing use of an expected certificate.

Name: Anchor
Description: Anchor  has been signed with valid certificates to evade detection by security tools.

Name: AppleJeus
Description: AppleJeus  has used a valid digital signature from Sectigo to appear legitimate.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  leveraged code-signing certificates to sign malware when targeting both gaming and non-gaming organizations.

Name: BackConfig
Description: BackConfig  has been signed with self signed digital certificates mimicking a legitimate software company.

Name: Bandook
Description: Bandook  was signed with valid Certum certificates.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  has been signed with fake certificates including those appearing to be from VB CORPORATE PTY. LTD.

Name: Black Basta
Description: The  Black Basta  dropper has been digitally signed with a certificate issued by Akeo Consulting for legitimate executables used for creating bootable USB drives.

Name: BLINDINGCAN
Description: BLINDINGCAN  has been signed with code-signing certificates such as CodeRipper.

Name: BOOSTWRITE
Description: BOOSTWRITE  has been signed by a valid CA.

Name: C0015
Description: For  C0015 , the threat actors used DLL files that had invalid certificates.

Name: ChChes
Description: ChChes  samples were digitally signed with a certificate originally used by Hacking Team that was later leaked and subsequently revoked.

Name: Clop
Description: Clop  can use code signing to evade detection.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can use self signed Java applets to execute signed applet attacks.

Name: CopyKittens
Description: CopyKittens  digitally signed an executable with a stolen certificate from legitimate company AI Squared.

Name: CSPY Downloader
Description: CSPY Downloader  has come signed with revoked certificates.

Name: Darkhotel
Description: Darkhotel  has used code-signing certificates on its malware that are either forged due to weak keys or stolen.  Darkhotel  has also stolen certificates and signed backdoors and downloaders with them.

Name: Daserf
Description: Some  Daserf  samples were signed with a stolen digital certificate.

Name: Ebury
Description: Ebury  has installed a self-signed RPM package mimicking the original system package on RPM based systems.

Name: Ecipekac
Description: Ecipekac  has used a valid, legitimate digital signature to evade detection.

Name: Ember Bear
Description: Ember Bear  has used stolen certificates from Electrum Technologies GmbH to sign payloads.

Name: Epic
Description: Turla  has used valid digital certificates from Sysprint AG to sign its  Epic  dropper.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has used Comodo code-signing certificates.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  has signed  Carbanak  payloads with legally purchased code signing certificates.  FIN7  has also digitally signed their phishing documents, backdoors and other staging tools to bypass security controls.

Name: GALLIUM
Description: GALLIUM  has used stolen certificates to sign its tools including those from Whizzimo LLC.

Name: Gazer
Description: Gazer  versions are signed with various valid certificates; one was likely faked and issued by Comodo for "Solid Loop Ltd," and another was issued for "Ultimate Computer Support Ltd."

Name: GreyEnergy
Description: GreyEnergy  digitally signs the malware with a code-signing certificate.

Name: Helminth
Description: Helminth  samples have been signed with legitimate, compromised code signing certificates owned by software company AI Squared.

Name: HermeticWiper
Description: The  HermeticWiper  executable has been signed with a legitimate certificate issued to Hermetica Digital Ltd.

Name: HermeticWizard
Description: HermeticWizard  has been signed by valid certificates assigned to Hermetica Digital.

Name: Janicab
Description: Janicab  used a valid AppleDeveloperID to sign the code to get past security restrictions.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has signed files with the name EGIS CO,. Ltd..

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has digitally signed malware and utilities to evade detection.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has used stolen code signing certificates to sign malware.

Name: LockerGoga
Description: LockerGoga  has been signed with stolen certificates in order to make it look more legitimate.

Name: LuminousMoth
Description: LuminousMoth  has signed their malware with a valid digital signature.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has resized and added data to the certificate table to enable the signing of modified files with legitimate signatures.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has digitally signed executables using AVAST Software certificates.

Name: Molerats
Description: Molerats  has used forged Microsoft code-signing certificates on malware.

Name: More_eggs
Description: More_eggs  has used a signed binary shellcode loader and a signed Dynamic Link Library (DLL) to create a reverse shell.

Name: Moses Staff
Description: Moses Staff  has used signed drivers from an open source tool called DiskCryptor to evade detection.

Name: Nerex
Description: Nerex  drops a signed Microsoft DLL to disk.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  digitally signed their own malware to evade detection.

Name: Operation Honeybee
Description: During  Operation Honeybee , the threat actors deployed the MaoCheng dropper with a stolen Adobe Systems digital signature.

Name: Patchwork
Description: Patchwork  has signed malware with self-signed certificates from fictitious and spoofed legitimate software companies.

Name: PipeMon
Description: PipeMon , its installer, and tools are signed with stolen code-signing certificates.

Name: PROMETHIUM
Description: PROMETHIUM  has signed code with self-signed certificates.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can use signed loaders to evade detection.

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: A  QuasarRAT  .dll file is digitally signed by a certificate from AirVPN.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  samples have been signed with a code-signing certificates.

Name: Scattered Spider
Description: Scattered Spider  has used self-signed and stolen certificates originally issued to NVIDIA and Global Software LLC.

Name: Silence
Description: Silence  has used a valid certificate to sign their primary loader Silence.Downloader (aka TrueBot).

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  was able to get  SUNBURST  signed by SolarWinds code signing certificates by injecting the malware into the SolarWinds Orion software lifecycle.

Name: SpicyOmelette
Description: SpicyOmelette  has been signed with valid digital certificates.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  has been signed with self-signed certificates.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  used a digitally signed driver with a compromised Realtek certificate.

Name: Suckfly
Description: Suckfly  has used stolen certificates to sign its malware.

Name: SUNBURST
Description: SUNBURST  was digitally signed by SolarWinds from March - May 2020.

Name: SysUpdate
Description: SysUpdate  has been signed with stolen digital certificates.

Name: TA505
Description: TA505  has signed payloads with code signing certificates from Thawte and Sectigo.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  has come with a signed downloader component.

Name: Winnti Group
Description: Winnti Group  used stolen certificates to sign its malware.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used Digicert code-signing certificates for some of its malware.

Name: Amadey
Description: Amadey  has modified the  :Zone.Identifier  in the ADS area to zero.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has embedded ISO images and VHDX files in HTML to evade Mark-of-the-Web.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  has been packaged in ISO files in order to bypass Mark of the Web (MOTW) security measures.

Name: TA505
Description: TA505  has used .iso files to deploy malicious .lnk files.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Consider disabling auto-mounting of disk image files (i.e., .iso, .img, .vhd, and .vhdx). This can be achieved by modifying the Registry values related to the Windows Explorer file associations in order to disable the automatic Explorer "Mount and Burn" dialog for these file extensions. Note: this will not deactivate the mount functionality itself.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Consider blocking container file types at web and/or email gateways. Consider unregistering container file extensions in Windows File Explorer.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  adds malicious code to a host's Xcode projects by enumerating CocoaPods  target_integrator.rb  files under the  /Library/Ruby/Gems  folder or enumerates all  .xcodeproj  folders under a given directory.  XCSSET  then downloads a script and Mach-O file into the Xcode project folder.

Name: Update Software
Description: A patch management process should be implemented to check unused dependencies, unmaintained and/or previously vulnerable dependencies, unnecessary features, components, files, and documentation.

Name: Vulnerability Scanning
Description: Continuous monitoring of vulnerability sources and the use of automatic and manual code review tools should also be implemented as well.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used malware to turn off the  RequireSigned  feature which ensures only signed DLLs can be run on Windows.

Name: BlackEnergy
Description: BlackEnergy  has enabled the  TESTSIGNING  boot configuration option to facilitate loading of a driver component.

Name: Hikit
Description: Hikit  has attempted to disable driver signing verification by tampering with several Registry keys prior to the loading of a rootkit driver component.

Name: Pandora
Description: Pandora  can use CVE-2017-15303 to disable Windows Driver Signature Enforcement (DSE) protection and load its driver.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has modified variables in kernel memory to turn off Driver Signature Enforcement after exploiting vulnerabilities that obtained kernel mode privileges.

Name: Boot Integrity
Description: Use of Secure Boot may prevent some implementations of modification to code signing policies.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Limit the usage of local administrator and domain administrator accounts to be used for day-to-day operations that may expose them to potential adversaries.

Name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Description: Ensure proper permissions are set for the Registry to prevent users from modifying keys related to code signing policies.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  gained access to production environments where they could inject malicious code into legitimate, signed files and widely distribute them to end users.

Name: CCBkdr
Description: CCBkdr  was added to a legitimate, signed version 5.33 of the CCleaner software and distributed on CCleaner's distribution site.

Name: Cobalt Group
Description: Cobalt Group  has compromised legitimate web browser updates to deliver a backdoor.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has placed trojanized installers for control system software on legitimate vendor app stores.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  has gained initial access by compromising a victim's software supply chain.

Name: GOLD SOUTHFIELD
Description: GOLD SOUTHFIELD  has distributed ransomware by backdooring software installers via a strategic web compromise of the site hosting Italian WinRAR.

Name: GoldenSpy
Description: GoldenSpy  has been packaged with a legitimate tax preparation software.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has distributed  NotPetya  by compromising the legitimate Ukrainian accounting software M.E.Doc and replacing a legitimate software update with a malicious one.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  gained initial network access to some victims via a trojanized update of SolarWinds Orion software.

Name: SUNSPOT
Description: SUNSPOT  malware was designed and used to insert  SUNBURST  into software builds of the SolarWinds Orion IT management product.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  has compromised the Able Desktop installer to gain access to victim's environments.

Name: Update Software
Description: A patch management process should be implemented to check unused applications, unmaintained and/or previously vulnerable software, unnecessary features, components, files, and documentation.

Name: Vulnerability Scanning
Description: Continuous monitoring of vulnerability sources and the use of automatic and manual code review tools should also be implemented as well.

Name: Boot Integrity
Description: Use Trusted Platform Module technology and a secure or trusted boot process to prevent system integrity from being compromised. Check the integrity of the existing BIOS or EFI to determine if it is vulnerable to modification.

Name: Ember Bear
Description: Ember Bear  has used control panel files (CPL), delivered via e-mail, for execution.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can register itself for execution and persistence via the Control Panel.

Name: Reaver
Description: Reaver  drops and executes a malicious CPL file as its payload.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Identify and block potentially malicious and unknown .cpl files by using application control    tools, like Windows Defender Application Control  , AppLocker,       or Software Restriction Policies    where appropriate.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Restrict storage and execution of Control Panel items to protected directories, such as  C:\Windows , rather than user directories.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has used CHM files to move concealed payloads.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  used compiled HTML (.chm) files for targeting.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  uses ActiveX objects for file execution and manipulation.

Name: Dark Caracal
Description: Dark Caracal  leveraged a compiled HTML file that contained a command to download and run an executable.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used a CHM payload to load and execute another malicious file once delivered to a victim.

Name: Silence
Description: Silence  has weaponized CHM files in their phishing campaigns.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Consider using application control to prevent execution of hh.exe if it is not required for a given system or network to prevent potential misuse by adversaries.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: Consider blocking download/transfer and execution of potentially uncommon file types known to be used in adversary campaigns, such as CHM files

Name: Cobalt Group
Description: Cobalt Group  has used the command  cmstp.exe /s /ns C:\Users\ADMINI~W\AppData\Local\Temp\XKNqbpzl.txt  to bypass AppLocker and launch a malicious script.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has used CMSTP.exe and a malicious INF to execute its  POWERSTATS  payload.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: CMSTP.exe may not be necessary within a given environment (unless using it for VPN connection installation).

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Consider using application control configured to block execution of CMSTP.exe if it is not required for a given system or network to prevent potential misuse by adversaries.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  has dropped RegAsm.exe onto systems for performing malicious activity.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Regsvcs and Regasm may not be necessary within a given environment.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Block execution of Regsvcs.exe and Regasm.exe if they are not required for a given system or network to prevent potential misuse by adversaries.

Name: Chaes
Description: Chaes  has used Installutill to download content.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has used  InstallUtil.exe  to execute malicious software.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has used  InstallUtil.exe  to execute a malicious Beacon stager.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  had used  InstallUtil.exe  to download and deploy executables.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  has used  InstallUtil.exe  as part of its process to disable Windows Defender.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: InstallUtil may not be necessary within a given environment.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use application control configured to block execution of InstallUtil.exe if it is not required for a given system or network to prevent potential misuse by adversaries.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  can use  odbcconf.exe  to run DLLs on targeted hosts.

Name: Cobalt Group
Description: Cobalt Group  has used  odbcconf  to proxy the execution of malicious DLL files.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Odbcconf.exe may not be necessary within a given environment.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use application control configured to block execution of Odbcconf.exe if it is not required for a given system or network to prevent potential misuse by adversaries.

Name: AppleJeus
Description: AppleJeus  has been installed via MSI installer.

Name: Chaes
Description: Chaes  has used .MSI files as an initial way to start the infection chain.

Name: Clop
Description: Clop  can use msiexec.exe to disable security tools on the system.

Name: DEADEYE
Description: DEADEYE  can use  msiexec.exe  for execution of malicious DLL.

Name: Duqu
Description: Duqu  has used  msiexec  to execute malicious Windows Installer packages. Additionally, a PROPERTY=VALUE pair containing a 56-bit encryption key has been used to decrypt the main payload from the installer packages.

Name: FlawedAmmyy
Description: FlawedAmmyy  has been installed via  msiexec.exe .

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  can use MSI files to execute DLLs.

Name: IcedID
Description: IcedID  can inject itself into a suspended msiexec.exe process to send beacons to C2 while appearing as a normal msi application.

Name: Javali
Description: Javali  has used the MSI installer to download and execute malicious payloads.

Name: LoudMiner
Description: LoudMiner  used an MSI installer to install the virtualization software.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  has used msiexec to install the  Machete  malware.

Name: Maze
Description: Maze  has delivered components for its ransomware attacks using MSI files, some of which have been executed from the command-line using  msiexec .

Name: Melcoz
Description: Melcoz  can use MSI files with embedded VBScript for execution.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has used MsiExec.exe to automatically execute files.

Name: Molerats
Description: Molerats  has used msiexec.exe to execute an MSI payload.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can use MSIExec to spawn multiple cmd.exe processes.

Name: Ragnar Locker
Description: Ragnar Locker  has been delivered as an unsigned MSI package that was executed with  msiexec.exe .

Name: Rancor
Description: Rancor  has used  msiexec  to download and execute malicious installer files over HTTP.

Name: RCSession
Description: RCSession  has the ability to execute inside the msiexec.exe process.

Name: RemoteUtilities
Description: RemoteUtilities  can use Msiexec to install a service.

Name: TA505
Description: TA505  has used  msiexec  to download and execute malicious Windows Installer files.

Name: ZIRCONIUM
Description: ZIRCONIUM  has used the msiexec.exe command-line utility to download and execute malicious MSI files.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Consider disabling the  AlwaysInstallElevated  policy to prevent elevated execution of Windows Installer packages.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Restrict execution of Msiexec.exe to privileged accounts or groups that need to use it to lessen the opportunities for malicious usage.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has use  mshta  to execute malicious scripts on a compromised host.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has used mshta.exe for code execution.

Name: BabyShark
Description: BabyShark  has used mshta.exe to download and execute applications from a remote server.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors used  mshta  to execute DLLs.

Name: Confucius
Description: Confucius  has used mshta.exe to execute malicious VBScript.

Name: Earth Lusca
Description: Earth Lusca  has used  mshta.exe  to load an HTA script within a malicious .LNK file.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  has used mshta.exe to execute VBScript to execute malicious code on victim systems.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  has used  mshta.exe  to execute malicious HTA files.

Name: Inception
Description: Inception  has used malicious HTA files to drop and execute malware.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used mshta.exe to run malicious scripts on the system.

Name: Koadic
Description: Koadic  can use mshta to serve additional payloads and to help schedule tasks for persistence.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has used  mshta.exe  to execute HTML pages downloaded by initial access documents.

Name: LazyScripter
Description: LazyScripter  has used  mshta.exe  to execute  Koadic  stagers.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has used mshta.exe to execute a HTA payload.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has used mshta.exe to execute its  POWERSTATS  payload and to pass a PowerShell one-liner for execution.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has used mshta.exe to launch collection scripts.

Name: NanHaiShu
Description: NanHaiShu  uses mshta.exe to load its program and files.

Name: Operation Dust Storm
Description: During  Operation Dust Storm , the threat actors executed JavaScript code via  mshta.exe .

Name: POWERSTATS
Description: POWERSTATS  can use Mshta.exe to execute additional payloads on compromised hosts.

Name: Pteranodon
Description: Pteranodon  can use mshta.exe to execute an HTA file hosted on a remote server.

Name: Revenge RAT
Description: Revenge RAT  uses mshta.exe to run malicious scripts on the system.

Name: Sibot
Description: Sibot  has been executed via MSHTA application.

Name: SideCopy
Description: SideCopy  has utilized  mshta.exe  to execute a malicious hta file.

Name: Sidewinder
Description: Sidewinder  has used  mshta.exe  to execute malicious payloads.

Name: TA2541
Description: TA2541  has used  mshta  to execute scripts including VBS.

Name: TA551
Description: TA551  has used mshta.exe to execute malicious payloads.

Name: Xbash
Description: Xbash  can use mshta for executing scripts.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Mshta.exe may not be necessary within a given environment since its functionality is tied to older versions of Internet Explorer that have reached end of life.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use application control configured to block execution of  mshta.exe  if it is not required for a given system or network to prevent potential misuse by adversaries. For example, in Windows 10 and Windows Server 2016 and above, Windows Defender Application Control (WDAC) policy rules may be applied to block the  mshta.exe  application and to prevent abuse.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  can call regsvr32.exe for execution.

Name: APT19
Description: APT19  used Regsvr32 to bypass application control techniques.

Name: APT32

Name: Dridex
Description: Dridex  can use  regsvr32.exe  to initiate malicious code.

Name: Egregor

Name: EVILNUM

Name: Koadic

Name: Orz

Name: QakBot

Name: Ragnar Locker

Name: RogueRobin

Name: Saint Bot

Name: Squirrelwaffle

Name: Exploit Protection
Description: Microsoft's Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET) Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) feature can be used to block regsvr32.exe from being used to bypass application control.    Identify and block potentially malicious software executed through regsvr32 functionality by using application control    tools, like Windows Defender Application Control  , AppLocker,       or Software Restriction Policies    where appropriate.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Consider removing mavinject.exe if Microsoft App-V is not used within a given environment.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use application control configured to block execution of mavinject.exe if it is not required for a given system or network to prevent potential misuse by adversaries.

Name: Hancitor
Description: Hancitor  has used verclsid.exe to download and execute a malicious script.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Consider removing verclsid.exe if it is not necessary within a given environment.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use application control configured to block execution of verclsid.exe if it is not required for a given system or network to prevent potential misuse by adversaries.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Consider modifying host firewall rules to prevent egress traffic from verclsid.exe.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has ensured web servers in a victim environment are Internet accessible before copying tools or malware to it.

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla  can check for internet connectivity by issuing HTTP GET requests.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has used  Ping  and  tracert  for network reconnaissance efforts.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has used the  Ping  command to check connectivity to actor-controlled C2 servers.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  has tested connectivity between a compromised machine and a C2 server using   Ping  with commands such as  CSIDL_SYSTEM\cmd.exe /c ping -n 1 .

Name: GoldFinder
Description: GoldFinder  performed HTTP GET requests to check internet connectivity and identify HTTP proxy servers and other redirectors that an HTTP request traveled through.

Name: HAFNIUM
Description: HAFNIUM  has checked for network connectivity from a compromised host using  ping , including attempts to contact  googlecom .

Name: HEXANE
Description: HEXANE  has used tools including  BITSAdmin  to test internet connectivity from compromised hosts.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has conducted a network call out to a specific website as part of their initial discovery activity.

Name: More_eggs
Description: More_eggs  has used HTTP GET requests to check internet connectivity.

Name: Neoichor
Description: Neoichor  can check for Internet connectivity by contacting bingcom with the request format  bingcom?id=<GetTickCount> .

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used a Visual Basic script that checked for internet connectivity.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can measure the download speed on a targeted host.

Name: QuietSieve
Description: QuietSieve  can check C2 connectivity with a  ping  to 8.8.8.8 (Google public DNS).

Name: Rising Sun
Description: Rising Sun  can test a connection to a specified network IP address over a specified port number.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used  GoldFinder  to perform HTTP GET requests to check internet connectivity and identify HTTP proxy servers and other redirectors that an HTTP request travels through.

Name: SUGARUSH
Description: SUGARUSH  has checked for internet connectivity from an infected host before attempting to establish a new TCP connection.

Name: SysUpdate
Description: SysUpdate  can contact the DNS server operated by Google as part of its C2 establishment process.

Name: TA2541
Description: TA2541  has run scripts to check internet connectivity from compromised hosts.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has used  tracert  to check internet connectivity.

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  can make  Ping  GET HTTP requests to its C2 server at regular intervals for network connectivity checks.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: MMC may not be necessary within a given environment since it is primarily used by system administrators, not regular users or clients.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use application control configured to block execution of MMC if it is not required for a given system or network to prevent potential misuse by adversaries.

Name: 2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  used a backdoor which could execute a supplied DLL using  rundll32.exe .

Name: ADVSTORESHELL
Description: ADVSTORESHELL  has used rundll32.exe in a Registry value to establish persistence.

Name: APT19

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  has a tool that can run DLLs.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  malware has used rundll32.exe to execute an initial infection process.

Name: APT38

Name: Bad Rabbit

Name: BLINDINGCAN

Description: Blue Mockingbird  has executed custom-compiled XMRIG miner DLLs using rundll32.exe.

Description: NOKKI  has used rundll32 for execution.

Description: During  Operation Spalax , the threat actors used  rundll32.exe  to execute malicious installers.

Description: PowerDuke  uses rundll32.exe to load.

Description: Prikormka  uses rundll32.exe to load its DLL.

Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used  Rundll32.exe  to execute payloads.

Description: SVCReady  has used  rundll32.exe  for execution.

Description: TA505  has leveraged  rundll32.exe  to execute malicious DLLs.

Description: TA551  has used rundll32.exe to load malicious DLLs.

Description: USBferry  can execute rundll32.exe in memory to avoid detection.

Description: The  Winnti for Windows  installer loads a DLL using rundll32.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has utilized  rundll32.exe  to deploy ransomware commands with the use of WebDAV.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  has used rundll32.exe to execute other DLLs and named pipes.

Name: Exploit Protection
Description: Microsoft's Enhanced Mitigation Experience Toolkit (EMET) Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) feature can be used to block methods of using rundll32.exe to bypass application control.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  can collect names and passwords of all Wi-Fi networks to which a device has previously connected.

Name: Emotet
Description: Emotet  can extract names of all locally reachable Wi-Fi networks and then perform a brute-force attack to spread to new networks.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has collected names and passwords of all Wi-Fi networks to which a device has previously connected.

Name: Avaddon
Description: Avaddon  checks for specific keyboard layouts and OS languages to avoid targeting Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) entities.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can perform a check to ensure that the operating system's keyboard and language settings are not set to Russian.

Name: Clop
Description: Clop  has checked the keyboard language using the GetKeyboardLayout() function to avoid installation on Russian-language or other Commonwealth of Independent States-language machines; it will also check the  GetTextCharset  function.

Name: Cuba
Description: Cuba  can check if Russian language is installed on the infected machine by using the function  GetKeyboardLayoutList .

Name: DEATHRANSOM
Description: Some versions of  DEATHRANSOM  have performed language ID and keyboard layout checks; if either of these matched Russian, Kazakh, Belarusian, Ukrainian or Tatar  DEATHRANSOM  would exit.

Name: DropBook
Description: DropBook  has checked for the presence of Arabic language in the infected machine's settings.

Name: Flagpro
Description: Flagpro  can check whether the target system is using Japanese, Taiwanese, or English through detection of specific Windows Security and Internet Explorer dialog.

Name: GrimAgent
Description: GrimAgent  has used  Accept-Language  to identify hosts in the United Kingdom, United States, France, and Spain.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  has used implants to collect the system language ID of a compromised machine.

Name: MarkiRAT
Description: MarkiRAT  can use the  GetKeyboardLayout  API to check if a compromised host's keyboard is set to Persian.

Name: Maze
Description: Maze  has checked the language of the machine with function  GetUserDefaultUILanguage  and terminated execution if the language matches with an entry in the predefined list.

Name: Misdat
Description: Misdat  has attempted to detect if a compromised host had a Japanese keyboard via the Windows API call  GetKeyboardType .

Name: Neoichor
Description: Neoichor  can identify the system language on a compromised host.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  deployed malware designed not to run on computers set to Korean, Japanese, or Chinese in Windows language preferences.

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  can check the system language using  GetUserDefaultUILanguage  and  GetSystemDefaultUILanguage . If the language is found in the list, the process terminates.

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  has been observed to query the registry key  HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Nls\Language  and the value  InstallLanguage . If the machine has the value 0x419 (Russian), 0x422 (Ukrainian), or 0x423 (Belarusian), it stops execution.

Name: S-Type
Description: S-Type  has attempted to determine if a compromised system was using a Japanese keyboard via the  GetKeyboardType  API call.

Name: SharpStage
Description: SharpStage   has been used to target Arabic-speaking users and used code that checks if the compromised machine has the Arabic language installed.

Name: Spark
Description: Spark  has checked the results of the  GetKeyboardLayoutList  and the language name returned by  GetLocaleInfoA  to make sure they contain the word "Arabic" before executing.

Name: SynAck
Description: SynAck  lists all the keyboard layouts installed on the victim’s system using  GetKeyboardLayoutList  API and checks against a hardcoded language code list. If a match if found, SynAck sleeps for 300 seconds and then exits without encrypting files.

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  uses AppleScript to check the host's language and location with the command  user locale of (get system info) .

Name: Zeus Panda
Description: Zeus Panda  queries the system's keyboard mapping to determine the language used on the system. It will terminate execution if it detects LANG_RUSSIAN, LANG_BELARUSIAN, LANG_KAZAK, or LANG_UKRAINIAN.

Name: Anchor
Description: Anchor  can create and execute services to load its payload.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32 's backdoor has used Windows services as a way to execute its malicious payload.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38  has created new services or modified existing ones to run executables, commands, or scripts.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has used post-exploitation tools including RemCom and the Non-sucking Service Manager (NSSM) to execute processes.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  used  svchost.exe and  Net  to execute a system service installed to launch a  Cobalt Strike  BEACON loader.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor 's dispatcher can be executed as a service.

Name: Bad Rabbit
Description: Bad Rabbit  drops a file named  infpub.dat into the Windows directory and is executed through SCManager and  rundll.exe .

Name: BBSRAT
Description: BBSRAT  can start, stop, or delete services.

Name: Blue Mockingbird
Description: Blue Mockingbird  has executed custom-compiled XMRIG miner DLLs by configuring them to execute via the "wercplsupport" service.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  can create Windows system services for execution.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has used  PsExec  to deploy beacons on compromised systems.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  can create and start services on a compromised host.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can use  PsExec  to execute a payload on a remote host. It can also use Service Control Manager to start new services.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can use  PsExec  to execute a payload on a remote host.

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has created Windows services to execute encoded PowerShell commands.

Name: gh0st RAT
Description: gh0st RAT  can execute its service if the Service key exists. If the key does not exist,  gh0st RAT  will create and run the service.

Name: HermeticWiper
Description: HermeticWiper  can create system services to aid in executing the payload.

Name: HermeticWizard
Description: HermeticWizard  can use  OpenRemoteServiceManager  to create a service.

Name: HOPLIGHT
Description: HOPLIGHT  has used svchost.exe to execute a malicious DLL .

Name: Hydraq
Description: Hydraq  uses svchost.exe to execute a malicious DLL included in a new service group.

Name: HyperBro
Description: HyperBro  has the ability to start and stop a specified service.

Name: Impacket
Description: Impacket  contains various modules emulating other service execution tools such as  PsExec .

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  has used Windows services as a way to execute its malicious payload.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  has used a tool known as RemoteExec (similar to  PsExec ) to remotely execute batch scripts and binaries.

Name: Koadic
Description: Koadic  can run a command on another machine using  PsExec .

Name: LoudMiner
Description: LoudMiner  started the cryptomining virtual machine as a service on the infected machine.

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can create a remote service, let it run once, and then delete it.

Name: Net
Description: The  net start  and  net stop  commands can be used in  Net  to execute or stop Windows services.

Name: Net Crawler
Description: Net Crawler  uses  PsExec  to perform remote service manipulation to execute a copy of itself as part of lateral movement.

Name: Netwalker
Description: Operators deploying  Netwalker  have used psexec and certutil to retrieve the  Netwalker  payload.

Name: NotPetya
Description: NotPetya  can use  PsExec  to help propagate itself across a network.

Name: Okrum
Description: Okrum 's loader can create a new service named NtmsSvc to execute the payload.

Name: Olympic Destroyer
Description: Olympic Destroyer  utilizes  PsExec  to help propagate itself across a network.

Name: Operation Honeybee
Description: During  Operation Honeybee , threat actors ran  sc start  to start the COMSysApp as part of the service hijacking and  sc stop  to stop and reconfigure the COMSysApp.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors created services on remote systems for execution purposes.

Name: Pandora
Description: Pandora  has the ability to install itself as a Windows service.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  contains an implementation of  PsExec  for remote execution.

Name: Proxysvc
Description: Proxysvc  registers itself as a service on the victim’s machine to run as a standalone process.

Name: PsExec
Description: Microsoft Sysinternals  PsExec  is a popular administration tool that can be used to execute binaries on remote systems using a temporary Windows service.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  uses  PsExec  to execute a payload or commands on a remote host.

Name: Pysa
Description: Pysa  has used  PsExec  to copy and execute the ransomware.

Name: Ragnar Locker
Description: Ragnar Locker  has used sc.exe to execute a service that it creates.

Name: RemoteCMD
Description: RemoteCMD  can execute commands remotely by creating a new service on the remote system.

Name: Shamoon
Description: Shamoon  creates a new service named "ntssrv" to execute the payload.  Shamoon  can also spread via  PsExec .

Name: Silence
Description: Silence  has used  Winexe  to install a service on the remote system.

Name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
Description: SLOTHFULMEDIA  has the capability to start services.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  can install a service to execute itself as a service.

Name: SysUpdate
Description: SysUpdate  can manage services and processes.

Name: TinyTurla
Description: TinyTurla  can install itself as a service on compromised machines.

Name: WastedLocker
Description: WastedLocker  can execute itself as a service.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  can download and execute AdvancedRun.exe via  sc.exe .

Name: Winexe
Description: Winexe  installs a service on the remote system, executes the command, then uninstalls the service.

Name: Wingbird
Description: Wingbird  uses services.exe to register a new autostart service named "Audit Service" using a copy of the local lsass.exe file.

Name: Winnti for Windows
Description: Winnti for Windows  can run as a service using svchost.exe.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used  services.exe  to execute scripts and executables during lateral movement within a victim's network.  Wizard Spider  has also used batch scripts that leverage  PsExec  to execute a previously transferred ransomware payload on a victim's network.

Name: xCmd
Description: xCmd  can be used to execute binaries on remote systems by creating and starting a service.

Name: ZxShell
Description: ZxShell  can create a new service for execution.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: On Windows 10, enable Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules to block processes created by  PsExec  from running.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Ensure that permissions disallow services that run at a higher permissions level from being created or interacted with by a user with a lower permission level.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Ensure that high permission level service binaries cannot be replaced or modified by users with a lower permission level.

Name: AppleJeus
Description: AppleJeus  has loaded a plist file using the  launchctl  command.

Name: Calisto
Description: Calisto  uses launchctl to enable screen sharing on the victim’s machine.

Name: LoudMiner
Description: LoudMiner  launched the QEMU services in the  /Library/LaunchDaemons/  folder using  launchctl . It also uses  launchctl  to unload all  Launch Daemon s when updating to a newer version of  LoudMiner .

Name: macOS.OSAMiner
Description: macOS.OSAMiner  has used  launchctl  to restart the  Launch Agent .

Name: XCSSET
Description: XCSSET  loads a system level launchdaemon using the  launchctl load -w  command from  /System/Librarby/LaunchDaemons/ssh.plist .

Name: User Account Management
Description: Prevent users from installing their own launch agents or launch daemons.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has used PubPrn.vbs within execution scripts to execute malware, possibly bypassing defenses.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: On Windows 10, update Windows Defender Application Control policies to include rules that block the older, vulnerable versions of PubPrn.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Certain signed scripts that can be used to execute other programs may not be necessary within a given environment. Use application control configured to block execution of these scripts if they are not required for a given system or network to prevent potential misuse by adversaries.

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can use port-knocking to authenticate itself to another implant called Cryshell to establish an indirect connection to the C2 server.

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  has authenticated itself to a different implant, Cryshell, through a port knocking and handshake procedure.

Name: PROMETHIUM
Description: PROMETHIUM  has used a script that configures the knockd service and firewall to only accept C2 connections from systems that use a specified sequence of knock ports.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Mitigation of some variants of this technique could be achieved through the use of stateful firewalls, depending upon how it is implemented.

Name: Penquin
Description: Penquin  installs a  TCP  and  UDP  filter on the  eth0  interface.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Mitigation of some variants of this technique could be achieved through the use of stateful firewalls, depending upon how it is implemented.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can use built-in modules to abuse trusted utilities like MSBuild.exe.

Name: Frankenstein
Description: During  Frankenstein , the threat actors used MSbuild to execute an actor-created file.

Name: PlugX
Description: A version of  PlugX  loads as shellcode within a .NET Framework project using msbuild.exe, presumably to bypass application control techniques.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: MSBuild.exe may not be necessary within an environment and should be removed if not being used.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Use application control configured to block execution of  msbuild.exe  if it is not required for a given system or network to prevent potential misuse by adversaries. For example, in Windows 10 and Windows Server 2016 and above, Windows Defender Application Control (WDAC) policy rules may be applied to block the  msbuild.exe  application and to prevent abuse.

Name: AADInternals
Description: AADInternals  can gather encryption keys from Azure AD services such as ADSync and Active Directory Federated Services servers.

Name: Ebury
Description: Ebury  has intercepted unencrypted private keys as well as private key pass-phrases.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can use modules like  Invoke-SessionGopher  to extract private key and session information.

Name: FoggyWeb
Description: FoggyWeb  can retrieve token signing certificates and token decryption certificates from a compromised AD FS server.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has searched for private keys in .ssh.

Name: jRAT
Description: jRAT  can steal keys for VPNs and cryptocurrency wallets.

Name: Kinsing
Description: Kinsing  has searched for private keys.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  has scanned and looked for cryptographic keys and certificate file extensions.

Name: Mafalda
Description: Mafalda  can collect a Chrome encryption key used to protect browser cookies.

Name: Mimikatz
Description: Mimikatz 's  CRYPTO::Extract  module can extract keys by interacting with Windows cryptographic application programming interface (API) functions.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used  Mimikatz  to dump certificates and private keys from the Windows certificate store.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  has used SSH private keys on the infected machine to spread its coinminer throughout a network.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  obtained PKI keys, certificate files, and the private encryption key from an Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) container to decrypt corresponding SAML signing certificates.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has searched for unsecured SSH keys.

Name: Audit
Description: Ensure only authorized keys are allowed access to critical resources and audit access lists regularly.

Name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Description: When possible, store keys on separate cryptographic hardware instead of on the local system. For example, on Windows systems use a TPM to secure keys and other sensitive credential material.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Use strong passphrases for private keys to make cracking difficult.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Ensure permissions are properly set on folders containing sensitive private keys to prevent unintended access. Additionally, on Cisco devices, set the  nonexportable  flag during RSA key pair generation.

Name: Kinsing
Description: Kinsing  has searched  bash_history  for credentials.

Name: Operating System Configuration
Description: There are multiple methods of preventing a user's command history from being flushed to their .bash_history file, including use of the following commands: set +o history  and  set -o history  to start logging again; unset HISTFILE  being added to a user's .bash_rc file; and ln -s /dev/null ~/.bash_history  to write commands to  /dev/null instead.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  has the ability to extract credentials from the Registry.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  used Outlook Credential Dumper to harvest credentials stored in Windows registry.

Name: IceApple
Description: IceApple  can harvest credentials from local and remote host registries.

Name: PowerSploit
Description: PowerSploit  has several modules that search the Windows Registry for stored credentials:  Get-UnattendedInstallFile ,  Get-Webconfig ,  Get-ApplicationHost ,  Get-SiteListPassword ,  Get-CachedGPPPassword , and  Get-RegistryAutoLogon .

Name: Reg
Description: Reg  may be used to find credentials in the Windows Registry.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  has retrieved PuTTY credentials by querying the  Software\SimonTatham\Putty\Sessions  registry key

Name: Valak
Description: Valak  can use the clientgrabber module to steal e-mail credentials from the Registry.

Name: Audit
Description: Proactively search for credentials within the Registry and attempt to remediate the risk.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Do not store credentials within the Registry.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: If it is necessary that software must store credentials in the Registry, then ensure the associated accounts have limited permissions so they cannot be abused if obtained by an adversary.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has targeted various collaboration tools like Slack, Teams, JIRA, Confluence, and others to hunt for exposed credentials to support privilege escalation and lateral movement.

Name: Audit
Description: Preemptively search through communication services to find shared unsecured credentials. Searching for common patterns like " password is  ", " password= " and take actions to reduce exposure when found.

Name: User Training
Description: Ensure that developers and system administrators are aware of the risk associated with sharing unsecured passwords across communication services.

Name: AADInternals
Description: AADInternals  can gather unsecured credentials for Azure AD services, such as Azure AD Connect, from a local machine.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  has the ability to extract credentials from configuration or support files.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  has a tool that can locate credentials in files on the file system such as those from Firefox or Chrome.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has used a variety of publicly available tools like  LaZagne  to gather credentials.

Name: Azorult
Description: Azorult  can steal credentials in files belonging to common software such as Skype, Telegram, and Steam.

Name: BlackEnergy
Description: BlackEnergy  has used a plug-in to gather credentials stored in files on the host by various software programs, including The Bat! email client, Outlook, and Windows Credential Store.

Name: Emotet
Description: Emotet  has been observed leveraging a module that retrieves passwords stored on a system for the current logged-on user.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can use various modules to search for files containing passwords.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has obtained administrative credentials by browsing through local files on a compromised machine.

Name: Fox Kitten
Description: Fox Kitten  has accessed files to gain valid credentials.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has searched for SSH keys, Docker credentials, and Kubernetes service tokens.

Name: jRAT
Description: jRAT  can capture passwords from common chat applications such as MSN Messenger, AOL, Instant Messenger, and and Google Talk.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used tools that are capable of obtaining credentials from saved mail.

Name: LaZagne
Description: LaZagne  can obtain credentials from chats, databases, mail, and WiFi.

Name: Leafminer
Description: Leafminer  used several tools for retrieving login and password information, including LaZagne.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has run a tool that steals passwords saved in victim email.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used credential dumping tools such as  LaZagne  to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.

Name: pngdowner
Description: If an initial connectivity check fails,  pngdowner  attempts to extract proxy details and credentials from Windows Protected Storage and from the IE Credentials Store. This allows the adversary to use the proxy credentials for subsequent requests if they enable outbound HTTP access.

Name: PoshC2
Description: PoshC2  contains modules for searching for passwords in local and remote files.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  can use Lazagne for harvesting credentials.

Name: Pysa
Description: Pysa  has extracted credentials from the password database before encrypting the files.

Name: QuasarRAT
Description: QuasarRAT  can obtain passwords from FTP clients.

Name: Smoke Loader
Description: Smoke Loader  searches for files named logins.json to parse for credentials.

Name: TA505
Description: TA505  has used malware to gather credentials from FTP clients and Outlook.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has searched for unsecured AWS credentials and Docker API credentials.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  can obtain passwords stored in files from several applications such as Outlook, Filezilla, OpenSSH, OpenVPN and WinSCP.    Additionally, it searches for the ".vnc.lnk" affix to steal VNC credentials.

Name: XTunnel
Description: XTunnel  is capable of accessing locally stored passwords on victims.

Name: Audit
Description: Preemptively search for files containing passwords and take actions to reduce the exposure risk when found.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Establish an organizational policy that prohibits password storage in files.

Name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Description: Restrict file shares to specific directories with access only to necessary users.

Name: User Training
Description: Ensure that developers and system administrators are aware of the risk associated with having plaintext passwords in software configuration files that may be left on endpoint systems or servers.

Name: Hildegard
Description: Hildegard  has queried the Cloud Instance Metadata API for cloud credentials.

Name: Peirates
Description: Peirates  can query the query AWS and GCP metadata APIs for secrets.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has queried the AWS instance metadata service for credentials.

Name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Description: Disable unnecessary metadata services and restrict or disable insecure versions of metadata services that are in use to prevent adversary access.

Name: Filter Network Traffic
Description: Limit access to the Instance Metadata API. A properly configured Web Application Firewall (WAF) may help prevent external adversaries from exploiting Server-side Request Forgery (SSRF) attacks that allow access to the Cloud Instance Metadata API.

Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Description: Limit access to the Instance Metadata API using a host-based firewall such as iptables.

Name: Peirates
Description: Peirates  can query the Kubernetes API for secrets.

Name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Description: Limit communications with the container service to managed and secured channels, such as local Unix sockets or remote access via SSH. Require secure port access to communicate with the APIs over TLS by disabling unauthenticated access to the Docker API and Kubernetes API Server.    In Kubernetes clusters deployed in cloud environments, use native cloud platform features to restrict the IP ranges that are permitted to access to API server.   Where possible, consider enabling just-in-time (JIT) access to the Kubernetes API to place additional restrictions on access.

Name: Network Segmentation
Description: Deny direct remote access to internal systems through the use of network proxies, gateways, and firewalls.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Use the principle of least privilege for privileged accounts such as the service account in Kubernetes. For example, if a pod is not required to access the Kubernetes API, consider disabling the service account altogether.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Enforce authentication and role-based access control on the container API to restrict users to the least privileges required.   When using Kubernetes, avoid giving users wildcard permissions or adding users to the  system:masters  group, and use  RoleBindings  rather than  ClusterRoleBindings  to limit user privileges to specific namespaces.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has used a variety of publicly available tools like Gpppassword to gather credentials.

Name: PowerSploit
Description: PowerSploit  contains a collection of Exfiltration modules that can harvest credentials from Group Policy Preferences.

Name: SILENTTRINITY
Description: SILENTTRINITY  has a module that can extract cached GPP passwords.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used PowerShell cmdlets  Get-GPPPassword  and  Find-GPOPassword  to find unsecured credentials in a compromised network group policy.

Name: Active Directory Configuration
Description: Remove vulnerable Group Policy Preferences.

Name: Audit
Description: Search SYSVOL for any existing GGPs that may contain credentials and remove them.

Name: Update Software
Description: Apply patch KB2962486 which prevents credentials from being stored in GPPs.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used stolen cookies to access cloud resources and a forged  duo-sid  cookie to bypass MFA set on an email account.

Name: Software Configuration
Description: Configure browsers or tasks to regularly delete persistent cookies.

Name: TeamTNT
Description: TeamTNT  has relied on users to download and execute malicious Docker images.

Name: Audit
Description: Audit images deployed within the environment to ensure they do not contain any malicious components.

Name: Code Signing
Description: Utilize a trust model such as Docker Content Trust with digital signatures to ensure runtime verification of the integrity and publisher of specific image tags.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network prevention intrusion systems and systems designed to scan and remove malicious downloads can be used to block activity.

Name: User Training
Description: Train users to be aware of the existence of malicious images and how to avoid deploying instances and containers from them.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has used legitimate local admin account credentials.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can use known credentials to run commands and spawn processes as a local user account.

Name: Emotet
Description: Emotet  can brute force a local admin password, then use it to facilitate lateral movement.

Name: FIN10
Description: FIN10  has moved laterally using the Local Administrator account.

Name: HAFNIUM
Description: HAFNIUM  has used the NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM account to create files on Exchange servers.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used a tool called GREASE to add a Windows admin account in order to allow them continued access via RDP.

Name: NotPetya
Description: NotPetya  can use valid credentials with  PsExec  or  wmic  to spread itself to remote systems.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used local account credentials found during the intrusion for lateral movement and privilege escalation.

Name: PROMETHIUM
Description: PROMETHIUM  has created admin accounts on a compromised host.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used compromised local accounts to access victims' networks.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has used known administrator account credentials to execute the backdoor directly.

Name: Turla
Description: Turla  has abused local accounts that have the same password across the victim’s network.

Name: Umbreon
Description: Umbreon  creates valid local users to provide access to the system.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Ensure that local administrator accounts have complex, unique passwords across all systems on the network.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Audit local accounts permission levels routinely to look for situations that could allow an adversary to gain wide access by obtaining credentials of a privileged account.       Limit the usage of local administrator accounts to be used for day-to-day operations that may expose them to potential adversaries.  For example, audit the use of service accounts in Kubernetes, and avoid automatically granting them access to the Kubernetes API if this is not required.   Implementing LAPS may also help prevent reuse of local administrator credentials across a domain.

Name: FIN13
Description: FIN13  has leveraged default credentials for authenticating myWebMethods (WMS) and QLogic web management interface to gain initial access.

Name: HyperStack
Description: HyperStack  can use default credentials to connect to IPC$ shares on remote machines.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  enabled and used the default system managed account, DefaultAccount, via  "powershell.exe" /c net user DefaultAccount /active:yes  to connect to a targeted Exchange server over RDP.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  infected WinCC machines via a hardcoded database server password.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Applications and appliances that utilize default username and password should be changed immediately after the installation, and before deployment to a production environment.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has used compromised Office 365 service accounts with Global Administrator privileges to collect email from user inboxes.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has gained access to a global administrator account in Azure AD and has used  Service Principal  credentials in Exchange.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has used compromised Office 365 accounts in tandem with  Ruler  in an attempt to gain control of endpoints.

Name: C0027
Description: During  C0027 ,  Scattered Spider  leveraged compromised credentials from victim users  to authenticate to Azure tenants.

Name: Ke3chang
Description: Ke3chang  has used compromised credentials to sign into victims’ Microsoft 365 accounts.

Name: LAPSUS$
Description: LAPSUS$  has used compromised credentials to access cloud assets within a target organization.

Name: Pacu
Description: Pacu  leverages valid cloud accounts to perform most of its operations.

Name: Peirates
Description: Peirates  can use stolen service account tokens to perform its operations.

Name: ROADTools
Description: ROADTools  leverages valid cloud credentials to perform enumeration operations using the internal Azure AD Graph API.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used a compromised O365 administrator account to create a new Service Principal.

Name: Account Use Policies
Description: Use conditional access policies to block logins from non-compliant devices or from outside defined organization IP ranges.

Name: Active Directory Configuration
Description: Disable legacy authentication, which does not support MFA, and require the use of modern authentication protocols instead.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Use multi-factor authentication for cloud accounts, especially privileged accounts. This can be implemented in a variety of forms (e.g. hardware, virtual, SMS), and can also be audited using administrative reporting features.

Name: Password Policies
Description: Ensure that cloud accounts, particularly privileged accounts, have complex, unique passwords across all systems on the network. Passwords and access keys should be rotated regularly. This limits the amount of time credentials can be used to access resources if a credential is compromised without your knowledge. Cloud service providers may track access key age to help audit and identify keys that may need to be rotated.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Review privileged cloud account permission levels routinely to look for those that could allow an adversary to gain wide access, such as Global Administrator and Privileged Role Administrator in Azure AD.     These reviews should also check if new privileged cloud accounts have been created that were not authorized. For example, in Azure AD environments configure alerts to notify when accounts have gone many days without using privileged roles, as these roles may be able to be removed.   Consider using temporary, just-in-time (JIT) privileged access to Azure AD resources rather than permanently assigning privileged roles.

Name: User Account Management
Description: Periodically review user accounts and remove those that are inactive or unnecessary. Limit the ability for user accounts to create additional accounts.

Name: User Training
Description: Applications may send push notifications to verify a login as a form of multi-factor authentication (MFA). Train users to only accept valid push notifications and to report suspicious push notifications.

Name: APT3
Description: APT3  leverages valid accounts after gaining credentials for use within the victim domain.

Name: Chimera
Description: Chimera  has used compromised domain accounts to gain access to the target environment.

Name: Cobalt Strike
Description: Cobalt Strike  can use known credentials to run commands and spawn processes as a domain user account.

Name: CreepySnail
Description: CreepySnail  can use stolen credentials to authenticate on target networks.

Name: Indrik Spider
Description: Indrik Spider  has collected credentials from infected systems, including domain accounts.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has used domain administrator accounts after dumping LSASS process memory.

Name: Naikon
Description: Naikon  has used administrator credentials for lateral movement in compromised networks.

Name: Night Dragon
Description: During  Night Dragon , threat actors used domain accounts to gain further access to victim systems.

Name: Operation CuckooBees
Description: During  Operation CuckooBees , the threat actors used compromised domain administrator credentials as part of their lateral movement.

Name: Operation Ghost
Description: For  Operation Ghost ,  APT29  used stolen administrator credentials for lateral movement on compromised networks.

Name: Operation Wocao
Description: During  Operation Wocao , threat actors used domain credentials, including domain admin, for lateral movement and privilege escalation.

Name: Ryuk
Description: Ryuk  can use stolen domain admin accounts to move laterally within a victim domain.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has used stolen credentials to access administrative accounts within the domain.

Name: Shamoon
Description: If  Shamoon  cannot access shares using current privileges, it attempts access using hard coded, domain-specific credentials gathered earlier in the intrusion.

Name: SolarWinds Compromise
Description: During the  SolarWinds Compromise ,  APT29  used domain administrators' accounts to help facilitate lateral movement on compromised networks.

Name: Stuxnet
Description: Stuxnet  attempts to access network resources with a domain account’s credentials.

Name: TA505
Description: TA505  has used stolen domain admin accounts to compromise additional hosts.

Name: Threat Group-1314
Description: Threat Group-1314  actors used compromised domain credentials for the victim's endpoint management platform, Altiris, to move laterally.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has used compromised domain accounts to authenticate to devices on compromised networks.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has used administrative accounts, including Domain Admin, to move laterally within a victim network.

Name: Multi-factor Authentication
Description: Integrating multi-factor authentication (MFA) as part of organizational policy can greatly reduce the risk of an adversary gaining control of valid credentials that may be used for additional tactics such as initial access, lateral movement, and collecting information. MFA can also be used to restrict access to cloud resources and APIs.

Name: Privileged Account Management
Description: Audit domain account permission levels routinely to look for situations that could allow an adversary to gain wide access by obtaining credentials of a privileged account. Do not put user or admin domain accounts in the local administrator groups across systems unless they are tightly controlled and use of accounts is segmented, as this is often equivalent to having a local administrator account with the same password on all systems. Follow best practices for design and administration of an enterprise network to limit privileged account use across administrative tiers. Limit credential overlap across systems to prevent access if account credentials are obtained.

Name: User Training
Description: Applications may send push notifications to verify a login as a form of multi-factor authentication (MFA). Train users to only accept valid push notifications and to report suspicious push notifications.

Name: Darkhotel
Description: Darkhotel  has used malware that repeatedly checks the mouse cursor position to determine if a real user is on the system.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  used images embedded into document lures that only activate the payload when a user double clicks to avoid sandboxes.

Name: Okrum
Description: Okrum  loader only executes the payload after the left mouse button has been pressed at least three times, in order to avoid being executed within virtualized or emulated environments.

Name: Spark
Description: Spark  has used a splash screen to check whether an user actively clicks on the screen before running malicious code.

Name: 2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack
Description: During the  2015 Ukraine Electric Power Attack ,  Sandworm Team  leveraged Microsoft Office attachments which contained malicious macros that were automatically executed once the user permitted them.

Name: admin@338
Description: admin@338  has attempted to get victims to launch malicious Microsoft Word attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.

Name: Agent Tesla
Description: Agent Tesla  has been executed through malicious e-mail attachments

Name: Ajax Security Team
Description: Ajax Security Team  has lured victims into executing malicious files.

Name: Andariel
