Description: Andariel  has attempted to lure victims into enabling malicious macros within email attachments.

Name: Aoqin Dragon
Description: Aoqin Dragon  has lured victims into opening weaponized documents, fake external drives, and fake antivirus to execute malicious payloads.

Name: AppleJeus
Description: AppleJeus  has required user execution of a malicious MSI installer.

Name: AppleSeed
Description: AppleSeed  can achieve execution through users running malicious file attachments distributed via email.

Name: APT-C-36
Description: APT-C-36  has prompted victims to accept macros in order to execute the subsequent payload.

Name: APT12
Description: APT12  has attempted to get victims to open malicious Microsoft Word and PDF attachment sent via spearphishing.

Name: APT19
Description: APT19  attempted to get users to launch malicious attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  attempted to get users to click on Microsoft Office attachments containing malicious macro scripts.

Name: APT29
Description: APT29  has used various forms of spearphishing attempting to get a user to open attachments, including, but not limited to, malicious Microsoft Word documents, .pdf, and .lnk files.

Name: APT30
Description: APT30  has relied on users to execute malicious file attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.

Name: APT32
Description: APT32  has attempted to lure users to execute a malicious dropper delivered via a spearphishing attachment.

Name: APT33
Description: APT33  has used malicious e-mail attachments to lure victims into executing malware.

Name: APT37
Description: APT37  has sent spearphishing attachments attempting to get a user to open them.

Name: APT38
Description: APT38   has attempted to lure victims into enabling malicious macros within email attachments.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has sent spearphishing emails in an attempt to lure users to click on a malicious attachment.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  has used malicious files including VBS, LNK, and HTML for execution.

Name: Bad Rabbit
Description: Bad Rabbit  has been executed through user installation of an executable disguised as a flash installer.

Name: BADFLICK
Description: BADFLICK  has relied upon users clicking on a malicious attachment delivered through spearphishing.

Name: Bandook
Description: Bandook  has used lure documents to convince the user to enable macros.

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal  has relied on users to execute malicious file attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.

Name: BITTER
Description: BITTER  has attempted to lure victims into opening malicious attachments delivered via spearphishing.

Name: Black Basta
Description: Black Basta  has been downloaded and executed from malicious Excel files.

Name: BlackTech
Description: BlackTech  has used e-mails with malicious documents to lure victims into installing malware.

Name: BLINDINGCAN
Description: BLINDINGCAN  has lured victims into executing malicious macros embedded within Microsoft Office documents.

Name: BoomBox
Description: BoomBox  has gained execution through user interaction with a malicious file.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER  has attempted to get users to launch malicious Microsoft Word attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  has gained execution through users opening malicious documents.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  has relied upon a user opening an ISO file to enable execution of malicious shortcut files and DLLs.

Name: Bundlore
Description: Bundlore  has attempted to get users to execute a malicious .app file that looks like a Flash Player update.

Name: C0011
Description: During  C0011 ,  Transparent Tribe  relied on a student target to open a malicious document delivered via email.

Name: C0015
Description: During  C0015 , the threat actors relied on users to enable macros within a malicious Microsoft Word document.

Name: Cardinal RAT
Description: Cardinal RAT  lures victims into executing malicious macros embedded within Microsoft Excel documents.

Name: CARROTBALL
Description: CARROTBALL  has been executed through users being lured into opening malicious e-mail attachments.

Name: Chaes
Description: Chaes  requires the user to click on the malicious Word document to execute the next part of the attack.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  has gained execution through luring victims into opening malicious files.

Name: Cobalt Group
Description: Cobalt Group  has sent emails containing malicious attachments that require users to execute a file or macro to infect the victim machine.

Name: Confucius
Description: Confucius  has lured victims to execute malicious attachments included in crafted spearphishing emails related to current topics.

Name: CSPY Downloader
Description: CSPY Downloader  has been delivered via malicious documents with embedded macros.

Name: CURIUM
Description: CURIUM  has lured users into opening malicious files delivered via social media.

Name: DanBot
Description: DanBot  has relied on victims' opening a malicious file for initial execution.

Name: Dark Caracal
Description: Dark Caracal  makes their malware look like Flash Player, Office, or PDF documents in order to entice a user to click on it.

Name: Darkhotel
Description: Darkhotel  has sent spearphishing emails in an attempt to lure users into clicking on a malicious attachments.

Name: DarkHydrus
Description: DarkHydrus  has sent malware that required users to hit the enable button in Microsoft Excel to allow an .iqy file to be downloaded.

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla  has relied on a user to open a malicious document or archived file delivered via email for initial execution.

Name: Disco
Description: Disco  has been executed through inducing user interaction with malicious .zip and .msi files.

Name: DnsSystem
Description: DnsSystem  has lured victims into opening macro-enabled Word documents for execution.

Name: Dragonfly
Description: Dragonfly  has used various forms of spearphishing in attempts to get users to open malicious attachments.

Name: Dridex
Description: Dridex  has relied upon users clicking on a malicious attachment delivered through spearphishing.

Name: Earth Lusca
Description: Earth Lusca  required users to click on a malicious file for the loader to activate.

Name: Elderwood
Description: Elderwood  has leveraged multiple types of spearphishing in order to attempt to get a user to open attachments.

Name: Ember Bear
Description: Ember Bear  has attempted to lure victims into executing malicious files.

Name: Emotet
Description: Emotet  has relied upon users clicking on a malicious attachment delivered through spearphishing.

Name: EnvyScout
Description: EnvyScout  has been executed through malicious files attached to e-mails.

Name: EXOTIC LILY
Description: EXOTIC LILY  has gained execution through victims clicking on malicious LNK files contained within ISO files, which can execute hidden DLLs within the ISO.

Name: Ferocious Kitten
Description: Ferocious Kitten  has attempted to convince victims to enable malicious content within a spearphishing email by including an odd decoy message.

Name: FIN4
Description: FIN4  has lured victims to launch malicious attachments delivered via spearphishing emails (often sent from compromised accounts).

Name: FIN6
Description: FIN6  has used malicious documents to lure victims into allowing execution of PowerShell scripts.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  lured victims to double-click on images in the attachments they sent which would then execute the hidden LNK file.

Name: FIN8
Description: FIN8  has used malicious e-mail attachments to lure victims into executing malware.

Name: Flagpro
Description: Flagpro  has relied on users clicking a malicious attachment delivered through spearphishing.

Name: Frankenstein
Description: During  Frankenstein , the threat actors relied on a victim to enable macros within a malicious Microsoft Word document likely sent via email.

Name: Gallmaker
Description: Gallmaker  sent victims a lure document with a warning that asked victims to "enable content" for execution.

Name: Gamaredon Group
Description: Gamaredon Group  has attempted to get users to click on Office attachments with malicious macros embedded.

Name: Gorgon Group
Description: Gorgon Group  attempted to get users to launch malicious Microsoft Office attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  has infected victims via malicious attachments.

Name: GuLoader
Description: The  GuLoader  executable has been retrieved via embedded macros in malicious Word documents.

Name: Hancitor
Description: Hancitor  has used malicious Microsoft Word documents, sent via email, which prompted the victim to enable macros.

Name: HEXANE
Description: HEXANE  has relied on victim's executing malicious file attachments delivered via email or embedded within actor-controlled websites to deliver malware.

Name: Heyoka Backdoor
Description: Heyoka Backdoor  has been spread through malicious document lures.

Name: Higaisa
Description: Higaisa  used malicious e-mail attachments to lure victims into executing LNK files.

Name: IcedID
Description: IcedID  has been executed through Word documents with malicious embedded macros.

Name: Inception
Description: Inception  lured victims into clicking malicious files for machine reconnaissance and to execute malware.

Name: IndigoZebra
Description: IndigoZebra  sent spearphishing emails containing malicious attachments that urged recipients to review modifications in the file which would trigger the attack.

Name: Indrik Spider
Description: Indrik Spider  has attempted to get users to click on a malicious zipped file.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can deliver trojanized versions of software and documents, relying on user execution.

Name: Javali
Description: Javali  has achieved execution through victims opening malicious attachments, including MSI files with embedded VBScript.

Name: JCry
Description: JCry  has achieved execution by luring users to click on a file that appeared to be an Adobe Flash Player update installer.

Name: JSS Loader
Description: JSS Loader  has been executed through malicious attachments contained in spearphishing emails.

Name: Kerrdown
Description: Kerrdown  has gained execution through victims opening malicious files.

Name: KGH_SPY
Description: KGH_SPY  has been spread through Word documents containing malicious macros.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used attempted to lure victims into opening malicious e-mail attachments.

Name: KOCTOPUS
Description: KOCTOPUS  has relied on victims clicking a malicious document for execution.

Name: KONNI
Description: KONNI  has relied on a victim to enable malicious macros within an attachment delivered via email.

Name: KOPILUWAK
Description: KOPILUWAK  has gained execution through malicious attachments.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has attempted to get users to launch a malicious Microsoft Word attachment delivered via a spearphishing email.

Name: LazyScripter
Description: LazyScripter  has lured users to open malicious email attachments.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has sent spearphishing attachments attempting to get a user to click.

Name: Lokibot
Description: Lokibot  has tricked recipients into enabling malicious macros by getting victims to click "enable content" in email attachments.

Name: Machete
Description: Machete  has relied on users opening malicious attachments delivered through spearphishing to execute malware.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  has attempted to lure victims into opening malicious email attachments.

Name: menuPass
Description: menuPass  has attempted to get victims to open malicious files such as Windows Shortcuts (.lnk) and/or Microsoft Office documents, sent via email as part of spearphishing campaigns.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  requires the user to double-click the executable to run the malicious HTA file or to download a malicious installer.

Name: Mofang
Description: Mofang 's malicious spearphishing attachments required a user to open the file after receiving.

Name: Molerats
Description: Molerats  has sent malicious files via email that tricked users into clicking Enable Content to run an embedded macro and to download malicious archives.

Name: Mongall
Description: Mongall  has relied on a user opening a malicious document for execution.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has attempted to get users to enable macros and launch malicious Microsoft Word documents delivered via spearphishing emails.

Name: Mustang Panda
Description: Mustang Panda  has sent malicious files requiring direct victim interaction to execute.

Name: Naikon
Description: Naikon  has convinced victims to open malicious attachments to execute malware.

Name: NativeZone
Description: NativeZone  can display an RTF document to the user  to enable execution of   Cobalt Strike  stage shellcode.

Name: NETWIRE
Description: NETWIRE  has been executed through luring victims into opening malicious documents.

Name: Nomadic Octopus
Description: Nomadic Octopus  as attempted to lure victims into clicking on malicious attachments within spearphishing emails.

Name: Octopus
Description: Octopus  has relied upon users clicking on a malicious attachment delivered through spearphishing.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has delivered macro-enabled documents that required targets to click the "enable content" button to execute the payload on the system.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  lured victims into executing malicious documents that contained "dream job" descriptions from defense, aerospace, and other sectors.

Name: Operation Dust Storm
Description: During  Operation Dust Storm , the threat actors relied on potential victims to open a malicious Microsoft Word document sent via email.

Name: Operation Honeybee
Description: During  Operation Honeybee , threat actors relied on a victim to enable macros within a malicious Word document.

Name: Operation Sharpshooter
Description: During  Operation Sharpshooter , the threat actors relied on victims executing malicious Microsoft Word or PDF files.

Name: Operation Spalax
Description: During  Operation Spalax , the threat actors relied on a victim to open a PDF document and click on an embedded malicious link to download malware.

Name: OSX/Shlayer
Description: OSX/Shlayer  has relied on users mounting and executing a malicious DMG file.

Name: OutSteel
Description: OutSteel  has relied on a user to execute a malicious attachment delivered via spearphishing.

Name: Patchwork
Description: Patchwork  embedded a malicious macro in a Word document and lured the victim to click on an icon to execute the malware.

Name: PLATINUM
Description: PLATINUM  has attempted to get users to open malicious files by sending spearphishing emails with attachments to victims.

Name: PLEAD
Description: PLEAD  has been executed via malicious e-mail attachments.

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  has used spearphishing attachments to infect victims.

Name: Pony
Description: Pony  has attempted to lure targets into downloading an attached executable (ZIP, RAR, or CAB archives) or document (PDF or other MS Office format).

Name: PROMETHIUM
Description: PROMETHIUM  has attempted to get users to execute compromised installation files for legitimate software including compression applications, security software, browsers, file recovery applications, and other tools and utilities.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  has gained execution through users opening malicious attachments.

Name: Ramsay
Description: Ramsay  has been executed through malicious e-mail attachments.

Name: Rancor
Description: Rancor  attempted to get users to click on an embedded macro within a Microsoft Office Excel document to launch their malware.

Name: REvil
Description: REvil  has been executed via malicious MS Word e-mail attachments.

Name: Rifdoor
Description: Rifdoor  has been executed from malicious Excel or Word documents containing macros.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  has relied upon users clicking on a malicious attachment delivered through spearphishing.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  has relied on users opening malicious email attachments, decompressing the attached archive, and double-clicking the executable within.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  has attempted to lure victims into opening e-mail attachments to execute malicious code.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  has relied upon users to execute a malicious attachment delivered via spearphishing.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has tricked unwitting recipients into clicking on spearphishing attachments and enabling malicious macros embedded within files.

Name: SideCopy
Description: SideCopy  has attempted to lure victims into clicking on malicious embedded archive files sent via spearphishing campaigns.

Name: Sidewinder
Description: Sidewinder  has lured targets to click on malicious files to gain execution in the target environment.

Name: Silence
Description: Silence  attempts to get users to launch malicious attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.

Name: Snip3
Description: Snip3  can gain execution through the download of visual basic files.

Name: SQLRat
Description: SQLRat  relies on users clicking on an embedded image to execute the scripts.

Name: Squirrelwaffle
Description: Squirrelwaffle  has relied on users enabling malicious macros within Microsoft Excel and Word attachments.

Name: STARWHALE
Description: STARWHALE  has relied on victims opening a malicious Excel file for execution.

Name: StrongPity
Description: StrongPity  has been executed via compromised installation files for legitimate software including compression applications, security software, browsers, file recovery applications, and other tools and utilities.

Name: SUGARDUMP
Description: Some  SUGARDUMP  variants required a user to enable a macro within a malicious .xls file for execution.

Name: SVCReady
Description: SVCReady  has relied on users clicking a malicious attachment delivered through spearphishing.

Name: SYSCON
Description: SYSCON  has been executed by luring victims to open malicious e-mail attachments.

Name: TA2541
Description: TA2541  has used macro-enabled MS Word documents to lure victims into executing malicious payloads.

Name: TA459
Description: TA459  has attempted to get victims to open malicious Microsoft Word attachment sent via spearphishing.

Name: TA505
Description: TA505  has used lures to get users to enable content in malicious attachments and execute malicious files contained in archives. For example,  TA505  makes their malware look like legitimate Microsoft Word documents, .pdf and/or .lnk files.

Name: TA551
Description: TA551  has prompted users to enable macros within spearphishing attachments to install malware.

Name: Taidoor
Description: Taidoor  has relied upon a victim to click on a malicious email attachment.

Name: The White Company
Description: The White Company  has used phishing lure documents that trick users into opening them and infecting their computers.

Name: Threat Group-3390
Description: Threat Group-3390  has lured victims into opening malicious files containing malware.

Name: ThreatNeedle
Description: ThreatNeedle  relies on a victim to click on a malicious document for initial execution.

Name: Tonto Team
Description: Tonto Team  has relied on user interaction to open their malicious RTF documents.

Name: Transparent Tribe
Description: Transparent Tribe  has used weaponized documents in e-mail to compromise targeted systems.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  has attempted to get users to launch malicious documents to deliver its payload.

Name: Tropic Trooper
Description: Tropic Trooper  has lured victims into executing malware via malicious e-mail attachments.

Name: TYPEFRAME
Description: A Word document delivering  TYPEFRAME  prompts the user to enable macro execution.

Name: Valak
Description: Valak  has been executed via Microsoft Word documents containing malicious macros.

Name: WarzoneRAT
Description: WarzoneRAT  has relied on a victim to open a malicious attachment within an email for execution.

Name: Whitefly
Description: Whitefly  has used malicious .exe or .dll files disguised as documents or images.

Name: Windshift
Description: Windshift  has used e-mail attachments to lure victims into executing malicious code.

Name: WIRTE
Description: WIRTE  has attempted to lure users into opening malicious MS Word and Excel files to execute malicious payloads.

Name: Wizard Spider
Description: Wizard Spider  has lured victims to execute malware with spearphishing attachments containing macros to download either  Emotet , Bokbot,  TrickBot , or  Bazar .

Name: Woody RAT
Description: Woody RAT  has relied on users opening a malicious email attachment for execution.

Name: ZxxZ
Description: ZxxZ  has relied on victims to open a malicious attachment delivered via email.

Name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Description: On Windows 10, various Attack Surface Reduction (ASR) rules can be enabled to prevent the execution of potentially malicious executable files (such as those that have been downloaded and executed by Office applications/scripting interpreters/email clients or that do not meet specific prevalence, age, or trusted list criteria). Note: cloud-delivered protection must be enabled for certain rules.

Name: Execution Prevention
Description: Application control may be able to prevent the running of executables masquerading as other files.

Name: User Training
Description: Use user training as a way to bring awareness to common phishing and spearphishing techniques and how to raise suspicion for potentially malicious events.

Name: APT41
Description: APT41  used legitimate websites for C2 through dead drop resolvers (DDR), including GitHub, Pastebin, and Microsoft TechNet.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  can store C2 information on cloud hosting services such as AWS and CloudFlare and websites like YouTube and Facebook.

Name: BADNEWS
Description: BADNEWS  collects C2 information via a dead drop resolver.

Name: BLACKCOFFEE
Description: BLACKCOFFEE  uses Microsoft’s TechNet Web portal to obtain a dead drop resolver containing an encoded tag with the IP address of a command and control server.

Name: BRONZE BUTLER
Description: BRONZE BUTLER 's MSGET downloader uses a dead drop resolver to access malicious payloads.

Name: C0017
Description: During  C0017 ,  APT41  used dead drop resolvers on two separate tech community forums for their  KEYPLUG  Windows-version backdoor; notably  APT41  updated the community forum posts frequently with new dead drop resolvers during the campaign.

Name: CharmPower
Description: CharmPower  can retrieve C2 domain information from actor-controlled S3 buckets.

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  can obtain C2 information from Google Docs.

Name: Javali
Description: Javali  can read C2 information from Google Documents and YouTube.

Name: KEYPLUG
Description: The  KEYPLUG  Windows variant has retrieved C2 addresses from encoded data in posts on tech community forums.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has used YouTube to store and hide C&C server domains.

Name: MiniDuke
Description: Some  MiniDuke  components use Twitter to initially obtain the address of a C2 server or as a backup if no hard-coded C2 server responds.

Name: Patchwork
Description: Patchwork  hides base64-encoded and encrypted C2 server locations in comments on legitimate websites.

Name: PlugX
Description: PlugX  uses Pastebin to store C2 addresses.

Name: PolyglotDuke
Description: PolyglotDuke  can use Twitter, Reddit, Imgur and other websites to get a C2 URL.

Name: Rocke
Description: Rocke  has used Pastebin to check the version of beaconing malware and redirect to another Pastebin hosting updated malware.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  has used an RSS feed on Livejournal to update a list of encrypted C2 server names.  RTM  has also hidden  Pony  C2 server IP addresses within transactions on the Bitcoin and Namecoin blockchain.

Name: RTM
Description: RTM  has used an RSS feed on Livejournal to update a list of encrypted C2 server names.

Name: Xbash
Description: Xbash  can obtain a webpage hosted on Pastebin to update its C2 domain list.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: Web proxies can be used to enforce external network communication policy that prevents use of unauthorized external services.

Name: Astaroth
Description: Astaroth  can check for Windows product ID's used by sandboxes and usernames and disk serial numbers associated with analyst environments.

Name: AsyncRAT
Description: AsyncRAT  can identify strings such as Virtual, vmware, or VirtualBox to detect virtualized environments.

Name: Attor
Description: Attor  can detect whether it is executed in some virtualized or emulated environment by searching for specific artifacts, such as communication with I/O ports and using VM-specific instructions.

Name: BadPatch
Description: BadPatch  attempts to detect if it is being run in a Virtual Machine (VM) using a WMI query for disk drive name, BIOS, and motherboard information.

Name: Black Basta
Description: Black Basta  can check system flags and libraries, process timing, and API's to detect code emulation or sandboxing.

Name: BLUELIGHT
Description: BLUELIGHT  can check to see if the infected machine has VM tools running.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  has the ability to search for designated file paths and Registry keys that indicate a virtualized environment from multiple products.

Name: CSPY Downloader
Description: CSPY Downloader  can search loaded modules, PEB structure, file paths, Registry keys, and memory to determine if it is being debugged or running in a virtual environment.

Name: Darkhotel
Description: Darkhotel  malware has used a series of checks to determine if it's being analyzed; checks include the length of executable names, if a filename ends with  .Md5.exe , and if the program is executed from the root of the C:\ drive, as well as checks for sandbox-related libraries.

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla  can search a compromised system's running processes and services to detect Hyper-V, QEMU, Virtual PC, Virtual Box, and VMware, as well as Sandboxie.

Name: Denis
Description: Denis  ran multiple system checks, looking for processor and register characteristics, to evade emulation and analysis.

Name: Dyre
Description: Dyre  can detect sandbox analysis environments by inspecting the process list and Registry.

Name: EvilBunny
Description: EvilBunny 's dropper has checked the number of processes and the length and strings of its own file name to identify if the malware is in a sandbox environment.

Name: Evilnum
Description: Evilnum  has used a component called TerraLoader to check certain hardware and file information to detect sandboxed environments.

Name: Ferocious
Description: Ferocious  can run anti-sandbox checks using the Microsoft Excel 4.0 function  GET.WORKSPACE  to determine the OS version, if there is a mouse present, and if the host is capable of playing sounds.

Name: FinFisher
Description: FinFisher  obtains the hardware device list and checks if the MD5 of the vendor ID is equal to a predefined list in order to check for sandbox/virtualized environments.

Name: Frankenstein
Description: During  Frankenstein , the threat actors used a script that ran WMI queries to check if a VM or sandbox was running, including VMWare and Virtualbox. The script would also call WMI to determine the number of cores allocated to the system; if less than two the script would stop execution.

Name: GoldMax
Description: GoldMax  will check if it is being run in a virtualized environment by comparing the collected MAC address to  c8:27:cc:c2:37:5a .

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  can detect VMWare via its I/O port and Virtual PC via the  vpcext  instruction.

Name: GravityRAT
Description: GravityRAT  uses WMI to check the BIOS and manufacturer information for strings like "VMWare", "Virtual", and "XEN" and another WMI request to get the current temperature of the hardware to determine if it's a virtual machine environment.

Name: GuLoader
Description: GuLoader  has the ability to perform anti-VM and anti-sandbox checks using string hashing, the API call  EnumWindows , and checking for Qemu guest agent.

Name: InvisiMole
Description: InvisiMole  can check for artifacts of VirtualBox, Virtual PC and VMware environment, and terminate itself if they are detected.

Name: Lucifer
Description: Lucifer  can check for specific usernames, computer names, device drivers, DLL's, and virtual devices associated with sandboxed environments and can enter an infinite loop and stop itself if any are detected.

Name: macOS.OSAMiner
Description: macOS.OSAMiner  can parse the output of the native  system_profiler  tool to determine if the machine is running with 4 cores.

Name: MegaCortex
Description: MegaCortex  has checked the number of CPUs in the system to avoid being run in a sandbox or emulator.

Name: NativeZone
Description: NativeZone  has checked if Vmware or VirtualBox VM is running on a compromised host.

Name: ObliqueRAT
Description: ObliqueRAT  can halt execution if it identifies processes belonging to virtual machine software or analysis tools.

Name: OilRig
Description: OilRig  has used macros to verify if a mouse is connected to a compromised machine.

Name: Okrum
Description: Okrum 's loader can check the amount of physical memory and terminates itself if the host has less than 1.5 Gigabytes of physical memory in total.

Name: OopsIE
Description: OopsIE  performs several anti-VM and sandbox checks on the victim's machine. One technique the group has used was to perform a WMI query  SELECT * FROM MSAcpi_ThermalZoneTemperature  to check the temperature to see if it’s running in a virtual environment.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  used tools that conducted a variety of system checks to detect sandboxes or VMware services.

Name: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D
Description: OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D  checks a number of system parameters to see if it is being run on real hardware or in a virtual machine environment, such as  sysctl hw.model  and the kernel boot time.

Name: P8RAT
Description: P8RAT  can check the compromised host for processes associated with VMware or VirtualBox environments.

Name: PlugX
Description: PlugX  checks if VMware tools is running in the background by searching for any process named "vmtoolsd".

Name: PoetRAT
Description: PoetRAT  checked the size of the hard drive to determine if it was being run in a sandbox environment. In the event of sandbox detection, it would delete itself by overwriting the malware scripts with the contents of "License.txt" and exiting.

Name: Pupy
Description: Pupy  has a module that checks a number of indicators on the system to determine if its running on a virtual machine.

Name: QakBot
Description: QakBot  can check the compromised host for the presence of multiple executables associated with analysis tools and halt execution if any are found.

Name: Remcos
Description: Remcos  searches for Sandboxie and VMware on the system.

Name: RogueRobin
Description: RogueRobin  uses WMI to check BIOS version for VBOX, bochs, qemu, virtualbox, and vm to check for evidence that the script might be executing within an analysis environment.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  can check for VMware-related files and DLLs related to sandboxes.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  has run several virtual machine and sandbox checks, including checking if  Sbiedll.dll  is present in a list of loaded modules, comparing the machine name to  HAL9TH  and the user name to  JohnDoe , and checking the BIOS version for known virtual machine identifiers.

Name: Shark
Description: Shark  can stop execution if the screen width of the targeted machine is not over 600 pixels.

Name: Smoke Loader
Description: Smoke Loader  scans processes to perform anti-VM checks.

Name: Snip3
Description: Snip3  has the ability to detect Windows Sandbox, VMWare, or VirtualBox by querying  Win32_ComputerSystem  to extract the  Manufacturer  string.

Name: SodaMaster
Description: SodaMaster  can check for the presence of the Registry key  HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Applications\VMwareHostOpen.exe  before proceeding to its main functionality.

Name: SUNBURST
Description: SUNBURST  checked the domain name of the compromised host to verify it was running in a real environment.

Name: SVCReady
Description: SVCReady  has the ability to determine if its runtime environment is virtualized.

Name: SynAck
Description: SynAck  checks its directory location in an attempt to avoid launching in a sandbox.

Name: Trojan.Karagany
Description: Trojan.Karagany  can detect commonly used and generic virtualization platforms based primarily on drivers and file paths.

Name: UBoatRAT
Description: UBoatRAT  checks for virtualization software such as VMWare, VirtualBox, or QEmu on the compromised machine.

Name: Volt Typhoon
Description: Volt Typhoon  has run system checks to determine if they were operating in a virtualized environment.

Name: WastedLocker
Description: WastedLocker  checked if UCOMIEnumConnections and IActiveScriptParseProcedure32 Registry keys were detected as part of its anti-analysis technique.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  can stop its execution when it recognizes the presence of certain monitoring tools.

Name: yty
Description: yty  has some basic anti-sandbox detection that tries to detect Virtual PC, Sandboxie, and VMware.

Name: APT12
Description: APT12  has used blogs and WordPress for C2 infrastructure.

Name: APT28
Description: APT28  has used Google Drive for C2.

Name: APT37
Description: APT37  leverages social networking sites and cloud platforms (AOL, Twitter, Yandex, Mediafire, pCloud, Dropbox, and Box) for C2.

Name: APT39
Description: APT39  has communicated with C2 through files uploaded to and downloaded from DropBox.

Name: BADNEWS
Description: BADNEWS  can use multiple C2 channels, including RSS feeds, Github, forums, and blogs.

Name: BLACKCOFFEE
Description: BLACKCOFFEE  has also obfuscated its C2 traffic as normal traffic to sites such as Github.

Name: BLUELIGHT
Description: BLUELIGHT  can use different cloud providers for its C2.

Name: BoxCaon
Description: BoxCaon  has used DropBox for C2 communications.

Name: CALENDAR
Description: The  CALENDAR  malware communicates through the use of events in Google Calendar.

Name: Carbanak
Description: Carbanak  has used a VBScript named "ggldr" that uses Google Apps Script, Sheets, and Forms services for C2.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  can use Dropbox to download malicious payloads, send commands, and receive information.

Name: CloudDuke
Description: One variant of  CloudDuke  uses a Microsoft OneDrive account to exchange commands and stolen data with its operators.

Name: Comnie
Description: Comnie  uses blogs and third-party sites (GitHub, tumbler, and BlogSpot) to avoid DNS-based blocking of their communication to the command and control server.

Name: ComRAT
Description: ComRAT  has the ability to use the Gmail web UI to receive commands and exfiltrate information.

Name: CozyCar
Description: CozyCar  uses Twitter as a backup C2 channel to Twitter accounts specified in its configuration file.

Name: CreepyDrive
Description: CreepyDrive  can use OneDrive for C2.

Name: Crutch
Description: Crutch  can use Dropbox to receive commands and upload stolen data.

Name: DOGCALL
Description: DOGCALL  is capable of leveraging cloud storage APIs such as Cloud, Box, Dropbox, and Yandex for C2.

Name: Empire
Description: Empire  can use Dropbox and GitHub for C2.

Name: FIN7
Description: FIN7  used legitimate services like Google Docs, Google Scripts, and Pastebin for C2.

Name: GLOOXMAIL
Description: GLOOXMAIL  communicates to servers operated by Google using the Jabber/XMPP protocol.

Name: Grandoreiro
Description: Grandoreiro  can utilize web services including Google sites to send and receive C2 data.

Name: HEXANE
Description: HEXANE  has used cloud services, including OneDrive, for C2.

Name: KARAE
Description: KARAE  can use public cloud-based storage providers for command and control.

Name: Kazuar
Description: Kazuar  has used compromised WordPress blogs as C2 servers.

Name: Kimsuky
Description: Kimsuky  has used Blogspot pages for C2.

Name: Lazarus Group
Description: Lazarus Group  has used GitHub as C2, pulling hosted image payloads then committing command execution output to files in specific directories.

Name: LOWBALL
Description: LOWBALL  uses the Dropbox cloud storage service for command and control.

Name: Magic Hound
Description: Magic Hound  malware can use a SOAP Web service to communicate with its C2 server.

Name: MuddyWater
Description: MuddyWater  has used web services including OneHub to distribute remote access tools.

Name: Operation Ghost
Description: For  Operation Ghost ,  APT29  used social media platforms to hide communications to C2 servers.

Name: Orz
Description: Orz  has used Technet and Pastebin web pages for command and control.

Name: POLONIUM
Description: POLONIUM  has used OneDrive and DropBox for C2.

Name: POORAIM
Description: POORAIM  has used AOL Instant Messenger for C2.

Name: PowerStallion
Description: PowerStallion  uses Microsoft OneDrive as a C2 server via a network drive mapped with  net use .

Name: RegDuke
Description: RegDuke  can use Dropbox as its C2 server.

Name: Revenge RAT
Description: Revenge RAT  used blogpost.com as its primary command and control server during a campaign.

Name: RogueRobin
Description: RogueRobin  has used Google Drive as a Command and Control channel.

Name: ROKRAT
Description: ROKRAT  has used legitimate social networking sites and cloud platforms (including but not limited to Twitter, Yandex, Dropbox, and Mediafire) for C2 communications.

Name: Sandworm Team
Description: Sandworm Team  has used the Telegram Bot API from Telegram Messenger to send and receive commands to its Python backdoor.  Sandworm Team  also used legitimate M.E.Doc software update check requests for sending and receiving commands and hosted malicious payloads on putdrive.com.

Name: SLOWDRIFT
Description: SLOWDRIFT  uses cloud based services for C2.

Name: Small Sieve
Description: Small Sieve  has the ability to use the Telegram Bot API from Telegram Messenger to send and receive messages.

Name: Turla
Description: A  Turla  JavaScript backdoor has used Google Apps Script as its C2 server.

Name: UBoatRAT
Description: UBoatRAT  has used GitHub and a public blog service in Hong Kong for C2 communications.

Name: yty
Description: yty  communicates to the C2 server by retrieving a Google Doc.

Name: ZIRCONIUM
Description: ZIRCONIUM  has used Dropbox for C2 allowing upload and download of files as well as execution of arbitrary commands.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: Web proxies can be used to enforce external network communication policy that prevents use of unauthorized external services.

Name: EVILNUM
Description: EVILNUM  has used a one-way communication method via GitLab and Digital Point to perform C2.

Name: HAMMERTOSS
Description: The "tDiscoverer" variant of  HAMMERTOSS  establishes a C2 channel by downloading resources from Web services like Twitter and GitHub.  HAMMERTOSS  binaries contain an algorithm that generates a different Twitter handle for the malware to check for instructions every day.

Name: Leviathan
Description: Leviathan  has received C2 instructions from user profiles created on legitimate websites such as Github and TechNet.

Name: Metamorfo
Description: Metamorfo  has downloaded a zip file for execution on the system.

Name: OnionDuke
Description: OnionDuke  uses Twitter as a backup C2.

Name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Description: Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level.

Name: Restrict Web-Based Content
Description: Web proxies can be used to enforce external network communication policy that prevents use of unauthorized external services.

Name: AppleJeus
Description: AppleJeus  has waited a specified time before downloading a second stage payload.

Name: BADFLICK
Description: BADFLICK  has delayed communication to the actor-controlled IP address by 5 minutes.

Name: Bazar
Description: Bazar  can use a timer to delay execution of core functionality.

Name: BendyBear
Description: BendyBear  can check for analysis environments and signs of debugging using the Windows API  kernel32!GetTickCountKernel32  call.

Name: Bisonal
Description: Bisonal  has checked if the malware is running in a virtual environment with the anti-debug function GetTickCount() to compare the timing.

Name: Brute Ratel C4
Description: Brute Ratel C4  can call  NtDelayExecution  to pause execution.

Name: Bumblebee
Description: Bumblebee  has the ability to set a hardcoded and randomized sleep interval.

Name: Clambling
Description: Clambling  can wait 30 minutes before initiating contact with C2.

Name: Clop
Description: Clop  has used the  sleep  command to avoid sandbox detection.

Name: Crimson
Description: Crimson  can determine when it has been installed on a host for at least 15 days before downloading the final payload.

Name: DarkTortilla
Description: DarkTortilla  can implement the  kernel32.dll  Sleep function to delay execution for up to 300 seconds before implementing persistence or processing an addon package.

Name: DRATzarus
Description: DRATzarus  can use the  GetTickCount  and  GetSystemTimeAsFileTime  API calls to measure function timing.    DRATzarus  can also remotely shut down into sleep mode under specific conditions to evade detection.

Name: Egregor
Description: Egregor  can perform a  long sleep (greater than or equal to 3 minutes) to evade detection.

Name: EvilBunny
Description: EvilBunny  has used time measurements from 3 different APIs before and after performing sleep operations to check and abort if the malware is running in a sandbox.

Name: FatDuke
Description: FatDuke  can turn itself on or off at random intervals.

Name: GoldenSpy
Description: GoldenSpy 's installer has delayed installation of  GoldenSpy  for two hours after it reaches a victim system.

Name: GoldMax
Description: GoldMax  has set an execution trigger date and time, stored as an ASCII Unix/Epoch time value.

Name: GrimAgent
Description: GrimAgent  can sleep for 195 - 205 seconds after payload execution and before deleting its task.

Name: GuLoader
Description: GuLoader  has the ability to perform anti-debugging based on time checks, API calls, and CPUID.

Name: HermeticWiper
Description: HermeticWiper  has the ability to receive a command parameter to sleep prior to carrying out destructive actions on a targeted host.

Name: LiteDuke
Description: LiteDuke  can wait 30 seconds before executing additional code if security software is detected.

Name: Lokibot
Description: Lokibot  has performed a time-based anti-debug check before downloading its third stage.

Name: metaMain
Description: metaMain  has delayed execution for five to six minutes during its persistence establishment process.

Name: Okrum
Description: Okrum 's loader can detect presence of an emulator by using two calls to GetTickCount API, and checking whether the time has been accelerated.

Name: Operation Dream Job
Description: During  Operation Dream Job ,  Lazarus Group  used tools that collected  GetTickCount  and  GetSystemTimeAsFileTime  data to detect sandbox or VMware services.

Name: P8RAT
Description: P8RAT  has the ability to "sleep" for a specified time to evade detection.

Name: Pony
Description: Pony  has delayed execution using a built-in function to avoid detection and analysis.

Name: QakBot
Description: The  QakBot  dropper can delay dropping the payload to evade detection.

Name: Raindrop
Description: After initial installation,  Raindrop  runs a computation to delay execution.

Name: Saint Bot
Description: Saint Bot  has used the command  timeout 20  to pause the execution of its initial loader.

Name: Snip3
Description: Snip3  can execute  WScript.Sleep  to delay execution of its second stage.

Name: SodaMaster
Description: SodaMaster  has the ability to put itself to "sleep" for a specified time.

Name: StrifeWater
Description: StrifeWater  can modify its sleep time responses from the default of 20-22 seconds.

Name: SUNBURST
Description: SUNBURST  remained dormant after initial access for a period of up to two weeks.

Name: SVCReady
Description: SVCReady  can enter a sleep stage for 30 minutes to evade detection.

Name: ThiefQuest
Description: ThiefQuest  invokes  time  call to check the system's time, executes a  sleep  command, invokes a second  time  call, and then compares the time difference between the two  time  calls and the amount of time the system slept to identify the sandbox.

Name: Tomiris
Description: Tomiris  has the ability to sleep for at least nine minutes to evade sandbox-based analysis systems.

Name: TrickBot
Description: TrickBot  has used  printf  and file I/O loops to delay process execution as part of API hammering.

Name: Ursnif
Description: Ursnif  has used a 30 minute delay after execution to evade sandbox monitoring tools.

Name: WhisperGate
Description: WhisperGate  can pause for 20 seconds to bypass antivirus solutions.

Name: XCSSET
Description: Using the machine's local time,  XCSSET  waits 43200 seconds (12 hours) from the initial creation timestamp of a specific file,  .report . After the elapsed time,  XCSSET  executes additional modules.

Description: Asacub  can request device administrator permissions.

Description: GPlayed  can request device administrator permissions.

Name: User Guidance

Name: Android/AdDisplay.Ashas

Name: AndroidOS/MalLocker.B
Description: AndroidOS/MalLocker.B  has registered to receive 14 different broadcast intents for automatically triggering malware payloads.

Name: DEFENSOR ID

Name: EventBot

Name: Exobot

Name: FakeSpy

Name: FlexiSpy
Description: FlexiSpy  uses root access to establish reboot hooks to re-install the application from  /data/misc/adn .   At boot,  FlexiSpy  spawns daemons for process monitoring, call monitoring, call managing, and system.

Name: GolfSpy
Description: GolfSpy  registers for the  USER_PRESENT  broadcast intent and uses it as a trigger to take photos with the front-facing camera.

Name: GPlayed
Description: GPlayed  can register for the  BOOT_COMPLETED  broadcast intent.

Name: HenBox

Name: Pegasus for Android

Name: SimBad

Name: SpyDealer

Name: SpyNote RAT

Name: TERRACOTTA
Description: TERRACOTTA  has registered several broadcast receivers.

Name: Tiktok Pro
Description: Tiktok Pro  has registered for device boot, incoming, and outgoing calls broadcast intents.

Name: TrickMo
Description: TrickMo  registers for the  SCREEN_ON  and  SMS_DELIVER  intents to perform actions when the device is unlocked and when the device receives an SMS message.

Name: Use Recent OS Version
Description: Android 8 introduced additional limitations on the implicit intents that an application can register for.

Name: BusyGasper
Description: BusyGasper  can utilize the device’s sensors to determine when the device is in use and subsequently hide malicious activity. When active, it attempts to hide its malicious activity by turning the screen’s brightness as low as possible and muting the device.

Name: FluBot

Name: Hornbill

Name: Deploy Compromised Device Detection Method

Name: Enterprise Policy

Name: Use Recent OS Version

Name: User Guidance

Users should be taught how to boot into safe mode to uninstall malicious applications that may be interfering with the uninstallation process.

Name: Dvmap
Description: Dvmap  replaces  /system/bin/ip  with a malicious version.  Dvmap  can inject code by patching  libdmv.so  or  libandroid_runtime.so , depending on the Android OS version. Both libraries are related to the Dalvik and ART runtime environments. The patched functions can only call  /system/bin/ip , which was replaced with the malicious version.

Name: FlexiSpy

Name: Zen

Name: AndroidOS/MalLocker.B

Name: Rotexy

If attempts to revoke administrator permissions are detected,  Rotexy  periodically switches off the phone screen to inhibit permission removal.

Name: TrickMo

Name: Anubis

Name: Circles

Name: Interconnection Filtering

Name: Cerberus

Name: Attestation

Name: Security Updates

Name: User Guidance

Name: Agent Smith

Name: Android/AdDisplay.Ashas

Name: AndroidOS/MalLocker.B
Description: AndroidOS/MalLocker.B  has masqueraded as popular apps, cracked games, and video players.

Name: Anubis

Name: Asacub
Description: Asacub  has masqueraded as a client of popular free ads services.

Name: BOULDSPY
Description: BOULDSPY  has been installed using the package name  com.android.callservice , pretending to be an Android system service.

Name: Bouncing Golf
Description: Bouncing Golf  distributed malware as repackaged legitimate applications, with the malicious code in the  com.golf  package.

Name: CarbonSteal
Description: CarbonSteal  has impersonated several apps, including official Google apps, chat apps, VPN apps, and popular games.

Name: Cerberus
Description: Cerberus  has pretended to be an Adobe Flash Player installer.

Name: Chameleon
Description: Chameleon  has disguised itself as other applications, such as a cryptocurrency app called ‘CoinSpot’, and IKO bank in Poland. It has also used familiar icons, such as the Chrome and Bitcoin logos.

Name: CHEMISTGAMES
Description: CHEMISTGAMES  has masqueraded as popular South Korean applications.

Name: Dendroid

Name: DoubleAgent

Name: DroidJack

Name: EventBot

Name: Fakecalls
Description: Fakecalls  has masqueraded as popular Korean banking apps.

Name: FakeSpy

Name: FrozenCell

Name: Ginp

Name: GoldenEagle

Name: GPlayed

Name: HenBox

Name: Mandrake

Name: Red Alert 2.0

Name: X-Agent for Android

Name: XLoader for Android

Name: User Guidance

Name: Cerberus

Name: Application Developer Guidance
Description: Developers should use Android App Links   and iOS Universal Links   to provide a secure binding between URIs and applications, preventing malicious applications from intercepting redirections. Additionally, for OAuth use cases, PKCE   should be used to prevent use of stolen authorization codes.

Name: Use Recent OS Version
Description: iOS 11 introduced a first-come-first-served principle for URIs, allowing only the prior installed app to be launched via the URI.   Android 6 introduced App Links.

Name: User Guidance
Description: Users should be instructed to not open links in applications they don’t recognize.

Name: Desert Scorpion
Description: If running on a Huawei device,  Desert Scorpion  adds itself to the protected apps list, which allows it to run with the screen off.

Name: Dvmap
Description: Dvmap  can enable installation of apps from unknown sources.

Name: GoldenEagle
Description: GoldenEagle  has modified or configured proxy information.

Name: Mandrake
Description: Mandrake  can enable app installation from unknown sources.

Name: SilkBean
Description: SilkBean  has attempted to trick users into enabling installation of applications from unknown sources.

Name: TianySpy
Description: TianySpy  can install malicious configurations on iPhones to allow malware to be installed via Ad Hoc distribution.

Name: Windshift
Description: Windshift  has installed malicious MDM profiles on iOS devices as part of Operation ROCK.

Name: XLoader for iOS
Description: XLoader for iOS  has been installed via a malicious configuration profile.

Name: YiSpecter
Description: YiSpecter  has used fake Verisign and Symantec certificates to bypass malware detection systems.  YiSpecter  has also signed malicious apps with iOS enterprise certificates to work on non-jailbroken iOS devices.

Name: Enterprise Policy
Description: On iOS, the  allowEnterpriseAppTrust  and  allowEnterpriseAppTrustModification  configuration profile restrictions can be used to prevent users from installing apps signed using enterprise distribution keys.

Name: Use Recent OS Version
Description: Mobile OSes have implemented measures to make it more difficult to trick users into installing untrusted certificates and configurations. iOS 10.3 and higher add an additional step for users to install new trusted CA certificates and configuration profiles. On Android, apps that target compatibility with Android 7 and higher (API Level 24) default to only trusting CA certificates that are bundled with the operating system, not CA certificates that are added by the user or administrator, hence decreasing their susceptibility to successful adversary-in-the-middle attack.

Name: User Guidance
Description: Typically, insecure or malicious configuration settings are not installed without the user's consent. Users should be advised not to install unexpected configuration settings (CA certificates, iOS Configuration Profiles, Mobile Device Management server provisioning).

Name: Security Updates
Description: Security updates may contain patches to integrity checking mechanisms that can detect unauthorized hardware modifications.

Name: XcodeGhost
Description: XcodeGhost  was injected into apps by a modified version of Xcode (Apple's software development tool).

Name: Application Developer Guidance
Description: Application developers should be cautious when selecting third-party libraries to integrate into their application.

Name: AbstractEmu
Description: AbstractEmu  can check device system properties to potentially avoid running while under analysis.

Name: Android/AdDisplay.Ashas
Description: Android/AdDisplay.Ashas  can check that the device IP is not in the range of known Google IP addresses before triggering the payload and can delay payload deployment to avoid detection during testing and avoid association with unwanted ads.

Name: Anubis
Description: Anubis  has used motion sensor data  to attempt to determine if it is running in an emulator.

Name: Cerberus
Description: Cerberus  avoids being analyzed by only activating the malware after recording a certain number of steps from the accelerometer.

Name: Chameleon
Description: Chameleon  can perform system checks to verify if the device is rooted or has ADB enabled and can avoid execution if found.

Name: Dendroid
Description: Dendroid  can detect if it is being ran on an emulator.

Name: FakeSpy
Description: FakeSpy  can detect if it is running in an emulator and adjust its behavior accordingly.

Name: Ginp
Description: Ginp  can determine if it is running in an emulator.

Name: HenBox
Description: HenBox  can detect if the app is running on an emulator.

Name: Mandrake
Description: Mandrake  can evade automated analysis environments by requiring a CAPTCHA on launch that will prevent the application from running if not passed. It also checks for indications that it is running in an emulator.

Name: Rotexy
Description: Rotexy  checks if it is running in an analysis environment.

Name: TERRACOTTA
Description: TERRACOTTA  checks whether its call stack has been modified, an indication that it is running in an analysis environment, and if so, does not decrypt its obfuscated strings  .

Name: TrickMo
Description: TrickMo  can detect if it is running on a rooted device or an emulator.

Name: Windshift
Description: Windshift  has deployed anti-analysis capabilities during their Operation BULL campaign.

Name: WolfRAT
Description: WolfRAT  can perform primitive emulation checks.

Name: Exobot
Description: Exobot  can obtain a list of installed applications and can detect if an antivirus application is running, and close it if it is.

Name: Gustuff
Description: Gustuff  checks for antivirus software contained in a predefined list.

Name: Use Recent OS Version
Description: Android 11 introduced privacy enhancements to package visibility, filtering results that are returned from the package manager. iOS 12 removed the private API that could previously be used to list installed applications on non-app store applications.

Name: User Guidance
Description: iOS users should be instructed to not download applications from unofficial sources, as applications distributed via the Apple App Store cannot list installed applications on a device.

Name: Adups
Description: Adups  was pre-installed on Android devices from some vendors.

Name: Allwinner
Description: A Linux kernel distributed by  Allwinner  reportedly contained an simple backdoor that could be used to obtain root access. It was believed to have been left in the kernel by mistake by the authors.

Name: CHEMISTGAMES
Description: CHEMISTGAMES  has been distributed as updates to legitimate applications. This was accomplished by compromising legitimate app developers, and subsequently gaining access to their Google Play Store developer account.

Name: Stealth Mango
Description: In at least one case,  Stealth Mango  may have been installed using physical access to the device by a repair shop.

Name: Triada
Description: Triada  was added into the Android system by a third-party vendor identified as Yehuo or Blazefire during the production process.

Name: Security Updates
Description: Security updates may contain patches that inhibit system software compromises.

Name: System Partition Integrity
Description: Ensure Verified Boot is enabled on devices with that capability.

Name: Twitoor
Description: Twitoor  can be controlled via Twitter.

Name: BusyGasper
Description: BusyGasper  can be controlled via IRC using freenode.net servers.

Name: Mandrake
Description: Mandrake  has used Firebase for C2.

Name: TERRACOTTA
Description: TERRACOTTA  has used Firebase for C2 communication.

Name: ANDROIDOS_ANSERVER.A
Description: ANDROIDOS_ANSERVER.A  uses encrypted content within a blog site for part of its command and control. Specifically, the encrypted content contains URLs for other servers to be used for other aspects of command and control.

Name: Anubis
Description: Anubis  can retrieve the C2 address from Twitter and Telegram.

Name: Red Alert 2.0
Description: Red Alert 2.0  can fetch a backup C2 domain from Twitter if the primary C2 is unresponsive.

Name: XLoader for Android
Description: XLoader for Android  has fetched its C2 address from encoded Twitter names, as well as Instagram and Tumblr.
